tgt_text.3024: Those men who apply themselves to the study of the holy scriptures ought not to cavil and quibble at syllables, but ought first to look at the spirit and meaning of the nouns and verbs used, and at the occasions on which and the manners in which each expression is used;
tgt_text.3025: for it often happens that the same expressions are applied to different things at different times;
tgt_text.3026: and, on the contrary, opposite expressions are at dif­ ferent times applied to the same thing with perfect consistency.
tgt_text.3027: Those men act absurdly who judge of the whole from a part, instead of, on the contrary, forming their estimate of a part from their knowledge of the whole;
tgt_text.3028: for this is the more proper way to form one's opinion of anything, whether it be a body or a doctrine;
tgt_text.3029: therefore the divine code of laws is, in a manner, a united creature, which one must regard in all its parts and members at once with all one's eyes, and one must contemplate the meaning and sense of the whole scripture with accuracy and clearness, not disturbing its harmony nor dissevering its unity ;
tgt_text.3030: for the parts will have a very different appearance and character if they are once deprived of their union.
tgt_text.3031: Let there then be a law against all those who profess to look on what is venerable and divine, in any other than a respectful and holy spirit, inflicting punishment on their blindness.
tgt_text.3033: There is nothing either more pleasant or more deserving of respect than to serve God, whose power is su­ perior to that of the mightiest sovereign;
tgt_text.3034: and it appears to me that the greatest king?
tgt_text.3035: have also been chief priests, showing, by their actions, that it is right for those who are the masters of other men nevertheless to serve the servants of God.Ibid.
tgt_text.3036: E. No foolish man is a king even though he be invested with supreme power by sea and land, but he only is a king who is a virtuous and God-loving iran, even though he may be deprived of those supplies and revenues, by means of which kings in general are strengthened in their sovereignty;
tgt_text.3037: for as a rudder, or a collection of drugs, or a flute, or a harp, are all superfluities to a man who has no knowledge of the art of steering, or medicine, or music, because he is not able to employ any one of them to the purpose for which it is made, while they may be said to be excellently adapted to and to be very seasonable for a pilot, or a physician, or a musician;
tgt_text.3038: so also, since kingcraft is an art, and the best of arts, we must look upon him who does not know how to exert it as a private individual;
tgt_text.3039: and as the man who does know how to exert it well as the only king.
tgt_text.3040: P. 776. E. A facility of change must of necessity belong to man, by reason of the unsteadiness of external circum­ stances.
tgt_text.3041: Accordingly we thus oftentimes, after we have chosen friends, and have associated with them for some time, though we have nothing to accuse them of, turn away from them with aversion as enemies.
tgt_text.3042: P. 776. E. These are the words of Philo :
tgt_text.3044: Caius, as he was ignorant of the greatness of the cause, that he should never fall into death, suffered a more simple punishment;
tgt_text.3045: but his imitator, not being able to take refuge in the plea of ignorance, is subjected to a double punish­ ment ;
tgt_text.3046: on which account Lamech shall be avenged seventy and seven fold, for the reason above mentioned, according to which he was the second offender who had not thought fit to take warning from the punishment of him who had offended before, and he clearly receives his punishment, being a more simple one ;
tgt_text.3047: as in numbers the units have a highly multiplied power, resembling that of the decades, such as now Lamech, changing his mind, denounces against himself.
tgt_text.3049: To be aware of what one has done amiss, and to blame one's self, is the part of a righteous man;
tgt_text.3050: but to be insensible to such things causes still more grievous evils to the soul, and the conduct of wicked men.
tgt_text.3052: B. It is said by men who have applied themselves to the study of natural philosophy, that the female is nothing else but an imperfect male.
tgt_text.3054: It is not lawful to divulge the sacred mysteries to the uninitiated until they are purified by a perfect purification;
tgt_text.3055: for the man who is not initiated, or who is of moderate capacity, being unable either to hear or to see that nature which is in­ corporeal and appreciable only by the intellect, being deceived by the visible sight, will blame what ought not to be blamed.
tgt_text.3056: Now, to divulge sacred mysteries to uninitiated people, is tha act of a person who violates the laws of the privileges belong ing to the priesthood.
tgt_text.3058: B. It is absurd that there should be a law in cities that it is not lawful do divulge sacred mysteries to the unini­ tiated, but that one may speak of the true rites and ceremonies which lead to piety and holiness to ears full of folly.
tgt_text.3059: All men must not partake of all things, nor of all discourses, above all, of such as are sacred;
tgt_text.3060: for those that desire to be admitted to a participation in such things, ought to have many qualifications beforehand.
tgt_text.3061: In the first place, what is the greatest and most important, they ought to have deep feelings of piety towards the only true and living God, and correct notions of holiness, avoiding all inextricable errors which perplex so many about images and statues, and in fact about any erections whatever, and about unlawful ceremonies, or illicit mysteries.
tgt_text.3062: In the second place, they must be purified with all holy purifications, both in soul and body, as far as it is allowed by their national laws and customs.
tgt_text.3063: In the third place, they must give credible evidence of their entering into the common joy, so that they may not, after having partaken of the sacred food, like intemperate youths, be changed by satiety and over­ abundance, becoming like drunken men;
tgt_text.3065: P. 782. D. The man who lives in wickedness, bears about destruction within him, since he has living with him that which is both treacherous, designing, and hostile to him.
tgt_text.3066: For the conscience of the wicked man is alone a sufficient punishment to him, inflicting cowardice on his soul from its own inmost feelings, as it feared blows.
tgt_text.3068: The life of the wicked man is subject to pain and sorrow, and full of fear;
tgt_text.3069: and in everything which it does ac­ cording to the outward senses, it is mingled with fear and griefP.
tgt_text.3070: 784. C. The reasoning of some persons is very rapidly satiated, who, though they have been borne upwards on wings for a little while, yet do presently return back again ;
tgt_text.3071: not so much flying upwards, says Philo, as being dragged down again to the lowest depths of hell.
tgt_text.3072: But happy are they who do not draw back.
tgt_text.3074: Before now, some persons who have tasted happiness, being very speedily satiated, after they have given hopes of their being in health, have fallen back into the same disease as before.
tgt_text.3075: P. 784. D. To commit perjury is impious and mischievous.P. 788. I.
tgt_text.3076: We ought to look upon those men as our friends who are inclined to assist us, and to requite our kindnesses with kindness, even if they are destitute of power;
tgt_text.3077: for friend­ ship is a thing which is seen more in moments of necessity, than in a steady conjunction or union of dispositions.
tgt_text.3078: So that in the case of each person who unites with another in an association of friendship, one may apply the expression of Pythagoras to him, and say, " A friend is a second 1."P. 789.
tgt_text.3080: When the fruits of these crops which are raised from seed are in a state of perfection, they receive the begin­ nings of the generation of trees in order that the mercies of God may last for ever, and then that one continually succeeding the other, and connecting ends with beginnings and beginnings with ends, they may be in reality never ending.
tgt_text.3082: The mercies of God give us not only what is neces­ sary, but also all such things as conduce to a more excessive and liberal enjoyment of life.
tgt_text.3083: It is said to you, 0 noble man, who live in obedience to the divine precepts, endeavour with all thy might not only to preserve the gifts which you have received unimpaired and unalloyed, but also think them worthy of all imaginable honour and regard, as being endowed with free will and independent power, so that he who has committed them to your charge may have no reason to find fault with you for having neglected to take proper care of them;
tgt_text.3084: and the Creator of the world has entrusted to your care to employ them according to your own deliberative purpose, a soul, and speech, and the outward senses.
tgt_text.3085: Therefore, those men who receive these gifts in a proper spirit, and who preserve them for him who has bestowed them on them, have kept their intellect carefully in such a way that it shall never think of anything else than of God and his virtues;
tgt_text.3086: and their speech in such a manner that with unwearied mouth it shall honour the Father of the universe with praises and hymns;
tgt_text.3087: and their outward senses in such a way that after they have represented to themselves the whole of the world which is perceptible to those senses, namely, the heaven and the earth, and the natures which are between those two, they may relate what they have seen in a pure and guile­ less manner to the soul.
tgt_text.3088: If you take away their resources of wealth from politicians, you will find nothing left but empty arrogance devoid of sense, for as long as there is an abundant supply of external good things, wisdom and presence of mind appear also to attend them, but when that plenty is taken away all appearance of wisdom is taken away at the same time.
tgt_text.3089: Good men, to speak somewhat metaphorically, are of more value than whole nations, since they support cities and con­ stitutions as buttresses support large houses.
tgt_text.3090: If it depended on wicked men, no city would ever enjoy tranquillity ;
tgt_text.3091: but states continue free from seditious troubles on account of the righteousness of one or two men who live in them, whose virtue is a remedy for the diseases of war, because God, who loves mankind, grants this effect as a reward to those who are virtuous and honourable, so that they should not only benefit themselves, but all who are near them.
tgt_text.3092: There is no place upon earth more sacred than the mind of a wise man, while all the virtues hover around like so many stars.
tgt_text.3093: The comprehension of the future does not belong to the nature of man.
tgt_text.3094: All things are not known to the mortal race.
tgt_text.3095: God alone is acquainted with the ultimate results of things.
tgt_text.3096: Quiet, which is free from danger, is better than words the object of which is only to give pleasure.
tgt_text.3097: The lawgiver says, " You shall not do all the things which we will do here this day,* every one doing that which is pleasant in his own sight," by which words he declares as loudly as possible that there is no evil which may not be produced by selfishness and self-sufficiency, which must be eradicated from the mind as unholy feelings.
tgt_text.3098: Let no one embrace that which is pleasing to himself rather than that which is agreeable to nature, for the one is found to be the cause of mischief and the other the cause of benefit.
tgt_text.3099: Those who do everything for their own sake alone practise selfishness, which is the greatest of evils, which produces unsociability, want of fellowship, unfriendliness, injustice, impiety, for nature has made man not like those beasts which love solitude, but like the gregarious beasts which live together like the most sociable of all creatures, that he may live not to himself alone, but also to his father, and to his mother, and to his brethren, and to his wife, and to his children, and to all his other relations and friends, and to those of the same borough as himself, and to those of the same tribe, and to his native country, and to his fellow countrymen, and to all mankind, and moreover to the different parts of the universe, and to the whole world, and much more to the Father and Creator of the world, for he must be (if at least he is really endowed with reason) sociable, loving the world, and loving God, that he may also be beloved by God.
tgt_text.3100: There are thousands and thousands, I do not say only of important matters, but also of those which appear to be most trivial, which escape the human intellect.
tgt_text.3101: No one may so far yield to unreasonable folly as to boast that he has seen the invisible God.
tgt_text.3102: As pillars support whole houses, so also do the divine powers support the whole world, and that most excellent and God- loving race of mankind.
tgt_text.3103: I think it absolutely impossible that no part of the soul should become tainted, not even the outermost and lowest parts of it, even if the man appears to be perfect among men.
tgt_text.3104: Slow counsel is profitless, and change of purpose in ex­ tremities is mischievous.
tgt_text.3105: A teacher of a good and virtuous disposition, even if he sees his pupils at first stiff-necked by nature, does not despair of producing in them a change for the better;
tgt_text.3106: but, like a good physician, he does not apply a remedy at once at the first moment of the disease attacking the patient, but he gives nature time that it may recede a little, so that he may first make ready the path to safety, and then apply healthful and salutary remedies.
tgt_text.3107: And in the same manner does the vir­ tuous man apply the arguments and doctrines of philosophy.
tgt_text.3108: If, when a pupil is first introduced to you, and first comes to learn of you, you hasten to eradicate all his ignorance at once, and attempt to introduce every kind of knowledge in a lump, you will produce the contrary effect to that which you desire, for it will not be likely that such an eradication, having taken place all in a moment, will continue effectual, nor that the pupil will be able at once to contain such an abundant influx and overflow of instruction ;
tgt_text.3109: but being exceedingly per­ plexed and troubled, he will resist both these operations, that of eradicating one thing and that of introducing another;
tgt_text.3110: but the system of taking away his ignorance with gentleness and moderation, and of, in the same manner, gently instilling wis­ dom into the mind, will be the causes of admitted advantage.
tgt_text.3111: The ordinary production of wickedness enslaves the mind, even if it has not as yet produced any perfect fruit;
tgt_text.3112: for it is, as the proverb says, washing a brick, or taking up water in a net, to trv and eradicate wickedness out of the soul of man.
tgt_text.3113: For " behold," says Moses, " with what designs the minds of all men are impressed."*
tgt_text.3114: And he speaks truly, for he does not say, what designs are attached to and adapted to it, but that which has been considered with care and deliberation is also explained with accuracy, and this too not slowly and with difficulty, but from man's earliest youth, or as one may almost say, from his very cradle, as if it were a part of him, kept in continual exercise.
tgt_text.3115: Those who are unmanly from an innate effeminacy, falling down of their own accord before they meet with any oppo­ sition, are a disgrace and ridicule to themselves.
tgt_text.3116: Wickedness in a foolish man has a twin offspring, for the foolish man is wavering and hesitating, mingling considerations together which ought not to be mingled, and jumbling and confusing what ought to be kept distinct, having as many colours in his soul as a viper has in his body, and polluting even his sound thoughts with those which cause trouble and death.
tgt_text.3117: The thoughts of a bad man are one thing, and his words another, and his actions indeed are many, but they are all inconsistent and at variance one with another, for he does not say what he thinks, and he has decided on the contrary of what he affirms, and he does things which are not consistent with his original designs, so that, to speak truly, one may say that the life of the wicked man is a life of enmity.
tgt_text.3118: That which is not distinct is unsuited to a free man, being the most shameful product of folly and haughtiness;
tgt_text.3119: for as distinctness in everything that is to be done is a mark of acuteness and wisdom, and deserves honour and praise, so also an absence of shame is a sign of folly and infamy, on which account the other definition which you disregard, classifies a man who is afflicted with this disease thus, saying, he is im­ pious who does not know how to respect the face of an honour­ able man, nor to rise up in the presence of an elder,* nor to guide his own steps in the right way.
tgt_text.3120: The servants of virtuous men submit to voluntary obedience to God, for they are not servants to human caprices, but to wise men;
tgt_text.3121: and he who is the servant of wisdom may justly be said to be also the servant of God.
tgt_text.3122: An irreconcileable and endless war is carried on by the atheists against the godly, so that they threaten them even with slavery.
tgt_text.3123: Justice, above all things, conduces to the safety both of man­ kind and of the parts of the world, earth and heaven.
tgt_text.3124: It is good to begin every day with divine and holy employ­ ments, and after that to proceed to the necessary duties of life.
tgt_text.3125: On this account God has commanded us* to take care to obey his commandments, and especially at the first moment of the dawn, as soon as we are risen, to pay our adoration to Him, that their offerings to God may precede every human occu­ pation, having the recollection of God for their prompter and leader.
tgt_text.3126: Every soul which piety fertilises with its own mysteries is necessarily awake for all holy services, and eager for the con­ templation of those things which are worth being seen, for this is the feeling of the soul at the great festival, and this is the true season of joy.
tgt_text.3127: The things of creation are far removed from the uncreated God, even though they are brought into close proximity fol­ lowing the attractive mercies of the Saviour.
tgt_text.3128: It is a sign of courage not to be easily alarmed by tho terrors of death, and to;
tgt_text.3129: be full of cheerful confidence in dan­ gers, and to be of valiant hardiness amid disasters, and to prefer dying with honour to being saved disgracefully, and to wish to be the cause of victory ;
tgt_text.3130: and a happy boldness, and a cheerfulness of soul, and fortitude, are the atttendants on a manly spirit.
tgt_text.3131: As an equality of measurement is the cause of the most perfect blessings, so also a want of measure is the cause of the greatest evils, as it dissolves that most useful bond of equality.
tgt_text.3132: Inequality is a grievous thing and the cause of differences, just as equality is free from all annoyances and contributes to unite men for advantageous ends.
tgt_text.3133: Obedience to the law and equality are the seeds of peace, and the causes of safety and continued durability;
tgt_text.3134: but in­ equality and covetousness are excitements to war, and dissolvers of all existing things.
tgt_text.3135: Those things which chastise the first, are, if men are wise, preventatives of the second.
tgt_text.3137: for through them, as through windows, the comprehension of the objects of the outward senses enters into the mind, and again through them the mind goes out to investigate such objects.
tgt_text.3138: But the sight is a part of these windows, that is to say, of the outward senses, since above all others it is akin to the soul, because it is nearly connected with the most beautiful of all things, namely light, and is a servant of divine things ;
tgt_text.3139: and, indeed, that is the sense which first opened the way to philosophy.
tgt_text.3140: For when the eye had beheld the motions of the sun and moon, and the periodical revolutions of the stars, and the unvarying motions of the whole host of heaven, and the inde­ scribable order and harmony of the whole universe, and the one unerring Creator of the world, it then related what it had seen to reason, as having the supreme authority ;
tgt_text.3141: and reason, having beheld with a still more acutely piercing eye both these things, and things of a still more sublime character in their appearance and species, and the great cause of all things, it then immediately arrived at a due conception of God, and of creation, and of providence;
tgt_text.3142: considering that the whole nature of all things was not brought into existence of its own accord, but that of necessity it had a creator, and a father, and a guide, and a governor, who also created it, and who also preserves everything which he has created.
tgt_text.3143: If you have a great deal of wealth, take care and do not be carried away by its overflow;
tgt_text.3144: but endeavour to take hold of some dry ground, in order to establish your mind with proper firmness ;
tgt_text.3145: and this will be the proper exertion of justice and fairness.
tgt_text.3146: And if you should have abundant supplies of all the things requisite for the indulgence of those passions which lie beneath the belly, be not carried away by such plenty, but op­ pose to them a saving degree of contentedness, taking in this way dry ground to stand upon instead of an absorbing quick­ sand.
tgt_text.3147: One should practise being contented with a little, for this is being near God;
tgt_text.3148: but the contrary habit is being very far from him.
tgt_text.3149: What can be a real sacrifice except the piety of a soul de­ voted to the love of God ?
tgt_text.3150: whose grateful feelings are made immortal by God, having conferred on them an immortal duration like that of the sun and the moon, and the whole world.
tgt_text.3151: The hopes of wicked men are unstable, as they expect a good fate, but suffer a contrary destiny of which they are worthy.
tgt_text.3152: The words of Philo, from his treatise on Men and Things which areWho is there who does wrong who is not convicted by his own conscience as if he were in a court of justice, even though no man correct him ?
tgt_text.3153: Since the mind of those who have not studied philosophy is blind with respect to many of the circumstances of life, one must take those who do see the character of affairs for one's guides.
tgt_text.3154: He who has not shame or fear for his companions, has an unbridled mouth and a licentious tongue.
tgt_text.3155: Perfection and an absence of deficiency are found in God alone.
tgt_text.3156: But deficiency and imperfection exist in every man.
tgt_text.3157: For man is taught, even if he be the wisest of his race, by some other man, and he knows nothing without being taught by his own nature.
tgt_text.3158: And if one man has more knowledge than another, still he has it not naturally, but because of instruc­ tion which he has received.
tgt_text.3159: These things are proved to be most completely natural, that the descent of the soul is its elation by means of self-conceit, and that its ascent and elevation is its return from arrogance.
tgt_text.3160: It is desirable to eradicate self-conceit, which is the friend of endurance, and prudence, and justice,* and also to destroy overbearing pride ;
tgt_text.3161: for it is no small proof and exercise of folly to study virtue in an illegitimate manner.
tgt_text.3162: If you are puffed up by glory and authority so as to desire great things, then remember, like the skilful pilot of a ship, to take in your sails, that you may not be carried away into absurd conduct.
tgt_text.3163: Sleep, according to the prophet, is a trance, not indeed in accordance with insanity, but proceeding from a relaxation of the outward senses and the retreat of reason;
tgt_text.3164: for at that time the outward senses cease from attaching themselves to their proper objects, and the mind is quiet, neither being any longer under the influence nor affording any motion to them, and they, being in consequence cut off from any energy because they are separated from the objects which are perceptible to them, are dissolved in a state of motionless inactivity.
tgt_text.3165: Very naturally some who have been wise enough to arrive at correct notions of the truth, have described sleep as a thing to teach us to meditate upon death, and a shadow and outline of the resurrection which is hereafter to follow, for it bears in itself visible images of both conditions, for it removes the same man from his state of perfection and brings him back to it.
tgt_text.3166: It is better absolutely never to make any promise at all than not to assist another willingly, for no blame attaches to the one, but great dislike on the part of those who are less powerful, and intense hatred and long enduring punishment from those who are more powerful, is the result of the other line of con­ duct.
tgt_text.3167: Some persons say that the last thing which the wise man puts off is the tunic of vain glory, for even if a man gets the mastery over his other passions, still he is inclined by nature to be influenced by glory and the praises of the multitude.
tgt_text.3168: Self-conceit is an impure thing by nature.
tgt_text.3169: To give thanks to God is intrinsically right, but not to do so to him in the first place, and not to begin with the first reasons for gratitude, is blameable, for it is not right to give the chief honour to the creation, and the inferior honour to God, who is the giver of all things in the creation;
tgt_text.3170: and indeed that is a most culpable division, inasmuch as it is laying down a certaiu disorder of order.
tgt_text.3171: Envy naturally attaches itself to whatever is great.
tgt_text.3172: The most perfect and greatest of all good things are usually the result of laborious exercise and energetic vigorous labourIt is absurd for a man who is in the pursuit of honours to flee from labours by which honours are acquired.
tgt_text.3173: What is the meaning of the expression, " You shall not eat the flesh in the blood of the soul ?" *
tgt_text.3174: God appears by this expression to intend to show that the blood is the essence of the soul, that is to say, of the soul endowed with the outward senses, not the soul spoken of in the most excellent sense of the word, that is to say, as far as it is endued with reason and intellect;
tgt_text.3175: for there are three divisions of the soul, one part being nutritious, a second being endued with the outward senses, and the third being endued with reason.
tgt_text.3176: Accordingly the divine Spirit is the essence of the rational portion, accord­ ing to the sacred historian of the creation of the world, for he says that "
tgt_text.3177: God breathed into his face the breath of life."
tgt_text.3179: But of that part which is endued with the outward, senses, and which has the revivifying power, blood is the essence, for he says in another place that " the soul of all flesh is the blood ;
tgt_text.3180: ”‡ but what is connected with the flesh is the outward sense and the passions, and not the mind and the intellect;
tgt_text.3181: not but what that expression, " in the blood of the soul," also indicates that the soul is one thing and the body another.
tgt_text.3182: So that in real truth the breath is the essence of the soul, but it has not any place of itself independently of the blood, but it resembles and is combined with blood.
tgt_text.3183: The extremity of happiness is the assistance of God, for there can be no such thing as want when God gives his aid.
tgt_text.3184: It is impossible that the harmony, and arrangement, and reason, and analogy, and that all the great accord and real happiness which we see existing in the world can have been originated by themselves, for it follows inevitably that these things must have had a creator, and a father, and a regulator and governor, who generated them in the first place, and who now preserves what he has generated.
tgt_text.3185: God wishing to send down from heaven to the earth an image of his divine virtue, out of his compassion for our race, that it might not be destitute of a more excellent portion, and that he might thus wash off the pollutions which defile our miserable existence, so full of all dishonour, established his church among us.
tgt_text.3186: The one most powerful relaxation of the soul leads to the sacred love of the one living God, teaching mankind to take God as its guide in all their plans, and words, and actions.
tgt_text.3187: The extremity of happiness is to rest unchangeably and immovably on God alone.
tgt_text.3188: The stars are turned round and revolve in a regular circle, some proceeding on in the same manner through the whole heaven, and others have special eccentric motions of their own.
tgt_text.3189: Some men think that repentance appears at times to take possession of God on account of the oaths which he has sworn, but they do not form correct notions ;
tgt_text.3190: for apart from the fact that the Deity does not change, neither the expression, " God repented," nor that, " And it grieved him at the heart,"* is indicative of repentance, for the Deity is unchangeable;
tgt_text.3191: but they only show the character of the pure intellect which is now deeply meditating on the cause for which he created man upon the earth.
tgt_text.3192: There is no hesitation and no envy in God;
tgt_text.3193: but he often uses expressions indicative of hesitation or of uncertainty from a reference to man, who is susceptible of such feelings;
tgt_text.3194: for as I have often said, there are altogether two supreme sources;
tgt_text.3195: in the one case God does not speak as man speaks, in the other he instructs man as a man instructs his son, the former being a sign of his power, the second of the way in which he teaches and guides man.
tgt_text.3196: He who does not offer to God first fruits of his own free will does not really offer first fruits at all, even if he brings everything which is great, with a most royal abundance of treasure;
tgt_text.3197: for the real first fruits consist not in the things offered, but in the pious disposition of him who offers them.
tgt_text.3198: The mercies of God do always outstrip justice, for the work which he has chosen for himself is that of doing good, and the task of punishing follows that;
tgt_text.3199: and it is common, when great evils are about to arise, for an abundance of great and nu­ merous blessings to happen first.
tgt_text.3200: The virtues alone know how to regulate the affairs of men.
tgt_text.3201: The contemplation of virtue is exceedingly beautiful, and actions according to it, and the exercise of it, are desirable above all things.
tgt_text.3202: If you wish to have a good reputation in a twofold manner, then honour exceedingly those who are doing well, and reprove those who are doing ill.
tgt_text.3203: When you are entreated to pardon offences, pardon willingly those who have offended against you, because indulgence given in requital for indulgence, and reconciliation with our fellow servants, is a means of averting the divine anger.
tgt_text.3204: The virtuous man is a lover of his race, and he is merciful and inclined to pardon, and never bears ill will towards any man whatever, but thinks it right to surpass in doing good rather than in injuring.

tgt_text.3415: this, calling the birds from the east dextems or right, and those on the west sinis­ tras or left;
tgt_text.3416: * when he says, whether they go to the right to the day and to the sun, or whether they go to the left towards the dusky evening.
tgt_text.3417: But the name Eden, when rightly understood, is an indica­ tion of all kinds of delights, and joys, and pleasures;
tgt_text.3418: since all good things and all blessings derive their beginning from the place of the Lord.
tgt_text.3419: Thirdly, because wisdom itself is splendour and light.
tgt_text.3420: Why did God place man whom be had created in the Para­ dise, but not that man who is after his own image ?
tgt_text.3422: Some persons have said, when they fancied that the Paradise was a garden, that because the man who was created was endowed with senses, therefore he naturally and properly proceeded into a sensible place ;
tgt_text.3423: but the other man, who is made after God's own image, being appreciable only by the intellect, and invisible, had all the incorporeal species for his share;
tgt_text.3424: but I should rather say that the paradise was a symbol of wisdom, for that created man is a kind of mixture, as hav­ ing been compounded of soul and body, having work to do by learning and discipline;
tgt_text.3425: desiring according to the law of philosophy that he may become happy;
tgt_text.3426: but he who is accord­ ing to God's own image is in need of nothing, being by him- self a hearer, and being taught by himself, and being found to be his own master by reason of his natural endowments.
tgt_text.3427: Why does Moses say that every tree in the Paradise was beautiful to look upon and good to eat?
tgt_text.3428: *9. He says this because the virtue of trees is of a twofold nature, consisting in bearing leaves and fruit, one of which qualities is referred to the pleasing of the sight, the other to the gratification of the taste ;
tgt_text.3429: but the word beautiful was not employed inappropriately.
tgt_text.3430: Indeed it is very proper that the plants should be always green and flourishing perpetually, as belonging to a divine Paradise, which as such must be ever­ lasting ;
tgt_text.3431: and it is fit too that they should never degenerate so as to lose their leaves.
tgt_text.3432: But of the fruit he says, not that it was beautiful, but that it was good, speaking in a very philosophical spirit;
tgt_text.3433: since men take food, not only because of the pleasure which it affords, but also because of its use;
tgt_text.3434: and use is the flowing forth and imparting of some good.
tgt_text.3435: What is meant by the tree of life, and why it was placed in the middle of the Paradise ?10.
tgt_text.3436: Some people have believed that, if there were really plants of a corporeal and deadly nature, there are also some which are causes of life and immortality, because, they say, life and death are opposed to one another, and because some plants are ascertained to be unwholesome, therefore of necessity there must be others from which health may be derived.
tgt_text.3437: But what these are which are wholesome they know not;
tgt_text.3438: for generation, as the opinion of the wise has it, is the beginning of corruption.
tgt_text.3439: But perhaps we ought to look on these things as spoken in an allegorical sense;
tgt_text.3440: for some say the tree of life belongs to the earth, inasmuch as it is the earth which produces every­ thing which is of use for life, whether it be the life of mankind or of any other animal;
tgt_text.3441: since God has appointed the situation in the centre for this plant, and the centre of the universe is the earth.
tgt_text.3442: There are others who assert that what is meant by the tree of life is the centre between the seven circles of heaven;
tgt_text.3443: but some affirm that it is the sun which is meant, as that is nearly in the centre, between the different planets, and is likewise the cause of the four seasons, and since it is owing to him that every thing which exists is called into existence.
tgt_text.3444: Others again understand by the tree of life the direction of the soul, for this it is which renders the sense nervous and solid, so as to produce actions corresponding to its nature, and to the community of the parts of the body.
tgt_text.3445: But whatever is in the middle is in a manner the primary cause and beginning of things, like the leader of a chorus.
tgt_text.3446: But still, the best and wisest authorities have considered that by the tree of life is indicated the best of all the virtues of man, piety, by which alone the mind attains to immortality.
tgt_text.3447: What is meant by the tree of the knowledge of good and evil?
tgt_text.3449: This indeed exhibits that meaning which is sought for in the letter of the Scriptures more clearly to the sight, as it bears a manifest allegory on the face of it.
tgt_text.3450: What is meant then under this figure is prudence, which is the comprehension of science, by which all things are known and distinguished from one another, whether they be good and beautiful, or bad and unseemly, or in short every sort of contrariety is discerned;
tgt_text.3451: since some things belong to the better class, and some to the worse.
tgt_text.3452: Therefore the wisdom which exists in this world is not in truth God himself, but the work of God;
tgt_text.3453: that it is which sees and thoroughly investigates every thing.
tgt_text.3454: But the wisdom which exists in man sees in an incorrect and mixed manner with somewhat darkened eyes;
tgt_text.3455: for it is found to be in­ competent to see and comprehend clearly and without alloy each particular thing separately.
tgt_text.3456: Moreover, there is a kind of deception mingled with human wisdom ;
tgt_text.3457: since very often there are some shadows found which hinder the eyes from contem­ plating a brilliant light;
tgt_text.3458: since what the eye is in the body, such also is the mind and wisdom in the soul.
tgt_text.3459: What the river is which proceeded out of Adin by which the Paradise is watered, and from which the four rivers proceed, the Phison, and the Gihon, and the Tigris, and the Euphrates ?
tgt_text.3461: The sources of the Deglath and of the Arazania, that is to say of the Tigris and Euphrates, are said to arise in the mountains of Armenia;
tgt_text.3462: but there is no paradise there at this day, nor do both the sources of both these rivers remain there.
tgt_text.3463: Perhaps, therefore, we ought to consider that the real situation of the Paradise is in a place at a distance from this part of the world which we inhabit, and that it has a river running beneath the earth, which pours forth many veins of the largest size;
tgt_text.3464: so that they, rising up together, pour themselves forth into other veins, which receive them on account of their great size, and then those have been suppressed by the gulfs of the waves;
tgt_text.3465: on which account, through the impulse given to them by the violence which is implanted in them, they burst out on the face of the earth in other places, and also among others in the mountains of Armenia.
tgt_text.3466: Therefore, those things which have been ac­ counted the sources of the rivers, are rather their flowing course;
tgt_text.3467: or again, they may be said to be correctly looked upon as sources, because by all means we must consider the holy scriptures infallible, which point out the fact of four rivers ;
tgt_text.3468: for the river is the beginning, and not the spring.
tgt_text.3469: But perhaps this passage also contains an allegorical meaning;
tgt_text.3470: for the four rivers are the signs of four virtues:
tgt_text.3471: Phison being the sign of prudence, as deriving its name from parsimony;
tgt_text.3472: * and Gihon being the sign of sobriety, as having its employment in the regulation of meat and drink, and as restraining the appetites of the belly, and of those parts which are below the belly, as being earthly;
tgt_text.3473: the Tigris again is the sign of fortitude, for this it is which regulates the raging commotion of anger within us;
tgt_text.3474: and the Euphrates is the sign of justice, since there is nothing in which the thoughts of men exult more than in justice.
tgt_text.3475: Why it is that he not only describes the situation of'tne Euphrates, but also says that the Phison goes round all the land of Evilat, and thai the Gihon goes round all the land of Ethiopia, and that the Tigris goes toward Assyria ?f13.
tgt_text.3476: The Tigris is a very cruel and mischievous river, as the citizens of Babylon bear witness, and so do the magi, who have found it to be of a character quite different from the nature of other rivers;
tgt_text.3477: however they might also have another reason for looking on it with aversion.
tgt_text.3478: But the Euphrates is a gentler, and more salubrious, and more nourishing stream.
tgt_text.3479: On which account, the wise men of the Hebrews and Assyrians speak of it as one which increases and extends itself;
tgt_text.3480: and on this account it is not here characterised by its connection with other things, as the other three rivers are, but by itself.
tgt_text.3481: My own opinion is, that these expressions are all symbol­ ical, for prudence is the virtue of the rational part of man ;
tgt_text.3482: and it is in this that wickedness is sometimes found.
tgt_text.3483: And fortitude is that portion of the human character which is liable to degenerate into anger.
tgt_text.3484: And sobriety, again, may be impaired by the desires, but anger and concupiscence are the characteristics of beasts;
tgt_text.3485: therefore the sacred historian has here described those three rivers by the places which they flow round.
tgt_text.3486: But he has not described the Euphrates in that manner, as being the symbol of justice, for there is no certain and limited portion of it allotted to the soul, but a perfect harmony of the three parts of the soul and of the three virtues is possessed by it.
tgt_text.3487: Why God placed man in the Paradise with a twofold object, namely, that he might both till it and keep it, when the Paradise was in reality in need of no cultivation, because it was perfect in everything, as having been planted by God;
tgt_text.3488: nor, again, did it require a keeper, for who was there to ravage it ? *14.
tgt_text.3489: These are the two objects which a cultivation of the land must attain to and take care of, the cultivation of the land and the safe keeping of the things which are in it, otherwise it will be spoiled by laziness or else by devastation.
tgt_text.3490: But although the Paradise did not stand in need of these exertions, nevertheless it was proper that he who had the regulation and care of it committed to him, namely, the first man, should be as it were a sort of pattern and law to all workmen in future of everything which ought to be done by them.
tgt_text.3491: Moreover it was suitable that, though all the Paradise was full of everything, it should still leave the cultivator some grounds for care, and some means of displaying his industry;
tgt_text.3492: for instance, by digging around it, and tending it, and soften­ ing it, and digging trenches, and irrigating it by water;
tgt_text.3493: and it was needful to attend to its safety, although there was no one to lay it waste, because of the wild beasts, also more especially in respect of the air and water;
tgt_text.3494: as, for instance, when a drought prevailed, to irrigate it with a plenteous supply of water, and in moister weather to check the super­ abundance of moisture by directing the course of the streams in other directions.
tgt_text.3495: Why, when God commanded the man to eat of every tree within the Paradise, he speaks in the singular number, and says, " Thou shalt eat;
tgt_text.3496: " but when he commands that he shall abstain from the tree which would give him the know­ ledge of good and evil, he speaks in the plural number, and says, " Te shall not eat of it, for in the day in which ye eat of it ye shall surely die ?" *15.
tgt_text.3497: In the first place he uses this language because one good was derived from many;
tgt_text.3498: and that also is not unim­ portant in these principles, since he who has done anything which is of utility is one, and he who attains to anything useful is also one;
tgt_text.3499: but when I say one, I am speaking not of that which in point of number comes before duality, but of that one creative virtue by which many beings rightly coalesce, and by their concord imitate singularity, as a flock, a herd, a troop, a chorus, an army, a nation, a tribe, a family, a state;
tgt_text.3500: for all these things being many members form one community, being united by affection as by a kiss;
tgt_text.3501: when things which are not combined, and which have no principle of union by reason of their duality and multitude, fall into different divisions, for duality is the beginning of discord.
tgt_text.3502: But two men living as if they were one, by the same philosophy, practise an unalloyed and brilliant virtue, which is free from all taint of wickedness;
tgt_text.3503: but where good and evil are mingled together the combination contains the principle of death.
tgt_text.3504: What is the meaning of the expression, " Ye shall surely die ?"t16.
tgt_text.3505: The death of the good is the beginning of another life;
tgt_text.3506: for life is a twofold thing, one life being in the body, corruptible;
tgt_text.3507: the other without the body, incorruptible.
tgt_text.3508: Therefore one wicked mail surely dies the death, who while still breathing and among the living is in reality long since buried, so as to retain in himself no single spark of real life, which is perfect virtue.
tgt_text.3509: But a good man, who deserves so high a title, does not surely die, but has his life prolonged, and so attains to an eternal end.
tgt_text.3510: Why God says, " It is not good for man to be alone ;
tgt_text.3511: let us make him a help meet for him ?"*17. By these words God intimates that there is to be a communion, not with all men, but with those who are willing to be assisted and in their turn to assist others, even though they may scarcely have any power to do so;
tgt_text.3512: since love consists not more in utility than in the harmonious concord of trustworthy and steadfast manners;
tgt_text.3513: so that every one who joins in a communion of love may be entitled to utter the expression of Pythagoras, " A friend is another I.
tgt_text.3514: "Why, when God had already said, " Let us make a help for man," he creates beasts and cattle ?f18.
tgt_text.3515: Perhaps some gluttons and insatiably greedy persons may say that God did this because beasts and flying things were, as it were, necessary food for man, and his meetest helper;
tgt_text.3516: for that the eating of meat assists the belly so as to conduce to the health and vigour of the body.
tgt_text.3517: But I should think that by reason of the evil implanted in them by nature animals of all kinds, whether terrestrial or flying in the air, were in this age hostile to and contrary to man;
tgt_text.3518: but that in the case of the first man, as one adorned with every imaginable virtue, they were, as it were, allies, and a rein­ forcement in war, and familiar friends, as being tame and domestic by nature, and this was the sole principle of their familiarity with man, for this it was fit that servants should dwell with their lord.
tgt_text.3519: Why the creation of animals and flying creatures is men­ tioned a second time, when the account of their creation had already been given in the history of the six days ?
tgt_text.3521: Perhaps those things which were created in the six days were incorporeal angels, indicated under these symbol­ ical expressions, being the appearances of terrestrial and flying animals, but now they were produced in reality, being the copies of what had been created before, images per­ ceptible by the outward senses of invisible models.
tgt_text.3522: Why did God bring every animal to man, that he might give them their names ?
tgt_text.3523: #20. He has here explained a great source of perplexity to the students of philosophy, admonishing them that names proceed from having been given, and not from nature;
tgt_text.3524: for a natural nomenclature is with peculiar fitness assigned to each creature when a man of wisdom and pre-eminent knowledge appears;
tgt_text.3525: and, in fact, the office of assigning the names to animals is one which particularly belongs to the mind of the wise man alone, and indeed to the first man born out of the earth, since it was fitting that the first of the human race, and the sovereign of all the animals born out of the earth, should have the dignity assigned to him.
tgt_text.3526: For inasmuch as he was the first person to see the animals, and as he was the first person who deserved to govern them all as their chief, so also it was fitting that he should be their first namer and the inventor of their names, since it would have been inconsistent and mad to leave them with­ out any names, or to allow them to receive names from any one born at a later period, which would have been an insult to and a derogation from the honour and glory due to the first born.
tgt_text.3527: But we may also adopt this idea, that the giving of names to the different animals was so easily arranged that the very moment that Adam gave the name the animal itself also heard it;
tgt_text.3528: being influenced by the name thus given to it as by a familiar indication closely connected with it.
tgt_text.3529: Why Moses says, " He brought the animals to Adam, that he might see what he would call them," when God can never entertain a doubt ?f21.
tgt_text.3530: It is in truth inconsistent with the nature of God to doubt;
tgt_text.3531: therefore it does not appear that he was in doubt on this occasion, but that since be had given intellect to man as being the first man born out of the earth and endowed with a great desire for virtue, by which he was made thoroughly wise as if he had been endowed with wisdom by nature, so as to consider all things like the proper Ruler and Lord of all, God now caused him to be influenced to display the proper performance of his task, and saw what was really the most excellent point of his mind.
tgt_text.3532: Besides this, by this statement he evidently indicates the perfect free-will existing in us, refuting those who affirm that everything exists by a certain necessity.
tgt_text.3533: Or else because it belonged to man to employ the animals, therefore he also gave him authority to give them names.
tgt_text.3534: What is the meaning of the expression, " And whatever he called each living thing, that was the name thereof ?"22. We must consider that Adam gave names not only to all living creatures, but also to plants, and to everything else which is inanimate, beginning with the more excellent class;
tgt_text.3535: for the living creature is superior to that which has not life.
tgt_text.3536: Therefore the scripture considers the mention of the better part sufficient, indicating by this mention to all who are not utterly devoid of sense, that he in fact gave names to everything, since it was easy to fix names to things without life, which were never likely to change their place, and which had no passions of the soul to exercise, but the giving of proper appellations to living creatures was a more difficult task on account of the motions of their bodies and the various impulses of their souls, in accordance with imagination and the variety of the outward senses, and the different agitations of the mind from which the effects of their works proceed.
tgt_text.3537: Therefore the mind could give names to the more difficult classes of living creatures.
tgt_text.3538: And on this account it was a very proper expression to employ, that he gave them names as being easy to name, because they were near.
tgt_text.3539: What is the meaning of the expression:
tgt_text.3540: “But for Adam there was not found a helper like to him ?"*23. Every thing was helping and assisting the prince of the human race:
tgt_text.3541: the earth, the rivers, the sea, the air, the light, the heaven.
tgt_text.3542: Moreover, every species of fruit and plant co-operated with him, and every herd of cattle, and every beast which was not savage.
tgt_text.3543: Nevertheless, of all these things which were assisting him, there was nothing like himself, inasmuch as they were none of them human beings.
tgt_text.3544: Therefore, God gave a certain indication that he might show that man ought to be an assistant to and co­ operator with man, being endowed with perfect similarity to one another in both body and soul.
tgt_text.3545: What is the meaning of the statement, " And God sent a trance upon Adam, and caused him to sleep ?"*24.
tgt_text.3546: How it is that man sleeps is a question which has caused an extraordinary amount of perplexity to philo­ sophers.
tgt_text.3547: But yet our prophet has distinctly explained this question;
tgt_text.3548: for sleep is in itself properly a trance, not of that kind which is more nearly allied to insanity, but of that which is in accordance with the dissolution of the senses and the absence of counsel;
tgt_text.3549: for then the senses withdraw from those things which are their proper object, and the intellect withdraws from the senses, not strengthening their nerves, nor giving any motion to those parts which have received the power of action, inasmuch as they are with­ drawn from the objects perceptible by the outward senses.
tgt_text.3550: What the rib is which God took from the man whom he had formed out of the earth, and which he made into a woman ?
tgt_text.3552: The letter of this statement is plain enough;
tgt_text.3553: for it is expressed according to a symbol of the part, a half of the whole, each party, the man and the woman, being as sections of nature co-equal for the production of that genus which is called man.
tgt_text.3554: But with respect to the mind, man is under­ stood in a symbolical manner, and his.
tgt_text.3555: one rib is virtue, proceeding from the senses;
tgt_text.3556: but woman, who is the sensation of counsel, will be more variable.
tgt_text.3557: But some think that the rib means valour and vigour, on which account men call a boxer who has strong loins eminently strong.
tgt_text.3558: Therefore, the lawgiver relates that the woman was formed out of the rib of the man, indicating by that expres­ sion, that one half of the body of the man is woman.
tgt_text.3559: And this is testified to by the formation of the body, by the way in which it is put together, by its motions and vigour, by the force of the soul, and its strength;
tgt_text.3560: for all things are regarded as in a twofold light;
tgt_text.3561: since, as the formation of the man is more perfect, and, if one may so say, more double than the formation of the woman, so also it required half the time, that is to say forty days ;
tgt_text.3562: when, for the imperfect, and, if I may so call it, half section of the man, that is to say the woman, there was need of a double allowance, that is to say, of eighty days, so that the doubling of the time required for the nature of the man might be changed, in order to the formation of the peculiar properties of the woman;
tgt_text.3563: for that body, and that soul, the nature of which is in a twofold ratio, the body and soul, that is, of the man, require but half of the delineation and formation:
tgt_text.3564: but that body of which the nature and construction is in the ratio of one half, namely, that of the woman, her formation and delineation is in a twofold ratio.
tgt_text.3565: Why Moses calls the form of the woman a building ?*26.
tgt_text.3566: The union and plenitude of concord formed by the man and woman is symbolically called a house;
tgt_text.3567: but every thing is altogether imperfect and destitute of a home, which is deserted by a woman;
tgt_text.3568: for to the man the public affairs of the state are committed, but the particular affairs of the house belong to the woman;
tgt_text.3569: and a want of the woman will be the destruction of the house;
tgt_text.3570: but the actual presence of the woman shows the regulation of the house.
tgt_text.3571: Why, as other animals and as man also was made, the woman was not also made out of the earth, but out of the rib of the man ?
tgt_text.3573: This was so ordained in the first place, in order that the woman might not be of equal dignity with the man.
tgt_text.3574: In the second place, that she might not be of equal age with him, but younger;
tgt_text.3575: since those who marry wives more advanced in years than themselves deserve blame, as having overturned the law of nature.
tgt_text.3576: Thirdly, the design of God was, that the husband should take care of his wife, as of a necessary part of himself;
tgt_text.3577: but that the woman should requite him in turn with service, as a portion of the universe.
tgt_text.3578: In the fourth place, he admonishes mail by this enigmatical intimation, that he should take care of his wife as of his daughter;
tgt_text.3579: and he admonishes the woman that she should honour her husband as her father.
tgt_text.3580: And very rightly, since the woman changes her habitation, passing from her own offspring to her husband.
tgt_text.3581: On which account, it is altogether right and proper that he who has received should take upon himself the liability in respect of what has been given;
tgt_text.3582: and that she who has been removed should worthily give the same honour to her husband which she has pre­ viously given to her parents;
tgt_text.3583: for the husband receives his wife from her parents, as a deposit which is entrusted to him;
tgt_text.3584: and the woman receives her husband from the law.
tgt_text.3585: Why, when the man saw the woman who had been formed in this manner, he proceeded to say:
tgt_text.3586: "She" (or "this," του̃το) " is now bone of my bone and flesh of my flesh:
tgt_text.3587: she shall be called woman, because she has been taken out of man?"*28. He might have been amazed at what he had seen, and have said in a negative manner:
tgt_text.3588: How can this exquisite and desirable beauty have been derived from bones and from flesh which are endowed with neither beauty nor elegance, being of a form so far more beautiful, and endowed with such excessive life and grace ?
tgt_text.3589: The matter is incredible because she is like;
tgt_text.3590: and yet it is credible, because God him­ self has been her creator and painter.
tgt_text.3591: Again, he might have said affirmatively:
tgt_text.3592: Truly she is a living being, my bone and my flesh, for she exists by having been taken from that bone and flesh of mine.
tgt_text.3593: But he makes mention of his bone and flesh in a very natural manner;
tgt_text.3594: for the human or corporeal tabernacle is the com­ bination of bones, and flesh, and entrails, and veins, and nerves, and ligaments, and blood-vessels, and breathing tubes, and blood.
tgt_text.3595: And she is called woman (in Greek γυνη̃) with great correctness, as the power of producing with fertility, either because she becomes pregnant through the reception of the seed, and so brings forth;
tgt_text.3596: or, as the prophet says, because'she was made out of man, not out of the earth, as he was;
tgt_text.3597: nor from seed, as all mankind after them;
tgt_text.3598: but of a certain intermediate nature;
tgt_text.3599: and like a branch, brought out of one vine to produce another vine.
tgt_text.3601: Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and cleave to his wife, and they shall be two in one flesh ?”*29. He here orders man to behave himself towards his wife with such excess of affection in their intercourse, that he is willing to leave his parents, not in order that by that means it may be more suitable, but as they would scarcely be a motive for his fidelity to his wife.
tgt_text.3602: And we must remark, that it is very excellent and prudently done, that he has avoided saying that the woman is to leave her parents and cleave to her husband, since the character of the man is bolder than the nature of the woman;
tgt_text.3603: but he says that the man ought to do this for the sake of the woman;
tgt_text.3604: for he is borne on by a cheerful and willing impulse to the concord of knowledge, to which, becoming wholly devoted, he re­ strains and regulates his desires, and clings to his wife alone like bird-lime.
tgt_text.3605: Especially because he himself, delighting in his master-like authority, is to be respected for his pride:
tgt_text.3606: but the woman, being in the rank of a servant, is praised, for assenting to a life of communion.
tgt_text.3607: And when it is said that the two are one flesh, that indi­ cates that the flesh is very tangible and fully endowed with outward senses, on which it depends to be afflicted with pain and delighted with pleasure, so that both the man and woman may derive pleasure and pain from the same sources, and may feel the same;
tgt_text.3608: aye, and may still more think the same.
tgt_text.3609: Why both of them, the man and the woman, are said to have been naked, and not to have been ashamed ?
tgt_text.3611: They were not ashamed, in the first place, because they were in the neighbourhood of the world, and the different parts of the world are all naked, each of them indicating some peculiar qualities, and having peculiar coverings of their own.
tgt_text.3612: In the second place, on account of the sincerity and simplicity of their manners and of their natural disposition, which had no taint of pride about it.
tgt_text.3613: For ambition had as yet no existence.
tgt_text.3614: Thirdly, because the climate and the mildness of the atmosphere was a sufficient covering for them, so as to prevent either cold or heat from hurting them.
tgt_text.3615: In the fourth place, because they, by reason of the relationship existing between themselves and the world, could not receive injury from any part of it whatever, as being related to them.
tgt_text.3616: Why does Moses say that the serpent was more cunning than all the beasts of the field ?*31. One may probably affirm with truth that the ser.
tgt_text.3617: pent in reality is more cunning than any beast whatever.
tgt_text.3618: But the reason why he appears to me to be spoken of in these terms here is on account of the natural proneness of mankind to vice, of which he is the symbol.
tgt_text.3619: And by vice I mean concupiscence, inasmuch as those who are devoted to pleasure are more cunning, and are the inventors of stra­ tagems and means by which to indulge their passions.
tgt_text.3620: Being, forsooth, very crafty in devising plans, both such as favour pleasure and also such as procure means of enjoying it.
tgt_text.3621: But it appears to me that since that animal, so superior in wisdom, was about to seduce man, it is not the whole race that is here meant to be spoken of as so exceedingly wise, but only that single serpent, for the reason above mentioned.
tgt_text.3622: Did the serpent speak with a human voice ?†32.
tgt_text.3623: In the first place, it may be the fact that at the beginning of the world even the other animals besides man were not entirely destitute of the power of articulate speech, but only that man excelled them in a greater fluency and perspicuity of speech and language.
tgt_text.3624: In the second place, when anything very marvellous requires to be done, God changes the subject natures by which he means to operate.
tgt_text.3625: Thirdly, because our soul is entirely filled with many errors, and rendered deaf to all words except in one or two lan­ guages to which it is accustomed;
tgt_text.3626: but the souls of those who were first created were rendered acute to thoroughly under­ stand every voice of every kind, in order that they might be pure from evil and wholly unpolluted.
tgt_text.3627: Since we indeed are not endowed with senses in such perfection, for those which we have received are in some degree depraved, just as the construction of our bodies too is small;
tgt_text.3628: but the first created men, as they received bodies of vast size reaching to a gigantic Leight, must also of necessity have received more accurate senses, and, what is more excellent still, a power of examining into and hearing things in a philosophical manner.
tgt_text.3629: For some people think, and perhaps with some reason, that they were endowed with such eyes as enabled them to behold even those natures, and essences, and operations, which exist in heaven, as also ears by which they could comprehend every kind of voice and language.
tgt_text.3630: Why did the serpent accost the woman, and not the man ?*33.
tgt_text.3631: The serpent, having formed his estimate of virtue, devised a treacherous stratagem against them, for the sake of bringing mortality on them.
tgt_text.3632: But the woman was more accustomed to be deceived than the man.
tgt_text.3633: For his counsels as well as his body are of a masculine sort, and competent to disentangle the notions of seduction;
tgt_text.3634: but the mind of the woman is more effeminate, so that through her softness she easily yields and is easily caught by the persuasions of falsehood, which imitate the resemblance of truth.
tgt_text.3635: Since therefore, in his old age, the serpentt strips himself of his scales from the top of his head to his tail, he, by his nakedness, reproaches man because he has exchanged death for immortality.
tgt_text.3636: His nature is renewed by the beast, and made to resemble every time.
tgt_text.3637: The woman, when she sees this, is deceived;
tgt_text.3638: when she ought rather to have looked upon him as an example, who, while showing his ingenuity towards her, was full of devices, but she was led to desire to acquire a life which should be free from old age, and from all decay.
tgt_text.3639: Why the serpent tells the woman lies, saying, " God has said, Ye shall not eat of every tree in the Paradise," when, on the contrary, what God really had said was, " Ye shall eat of every tree in the Paradise, except one ? ”*34.
tgt_text.3640: It is the custom for contending arguers to speak falsely in an artful manner, in order to produce ignorance of the real facts, as was done in this case, since the man and woman had been commanded to eat of all the trees but one.
tgt_text.3641: But this insidious prompter of wickedness coming in, says that the order which they had received was that they should not eat of them all.
tgt_text.3642: He brought forward an ambiguous statement as a slippery stumbling-block to cause the soul to trip.
tgt_text.3643: For this expression, “Ye shall not eat of every tree," means in the first place either, not even of one, which is false;
tgt_text.3644: or, secondly, not of every one, as if he intended to say, there are some of which you may not eat, which is true.
tgt_text.3645: Therefore he asserts such a falsehood more explicitly.
tgt_text.3646: Why, when it was commanded them to avoid eating of one plant alone, the woman made also a further addition to this injunction, saying, “He said, Ye shall not eat of it, neither shall ye touch it ? "t35.
tgt_text.3647: In the first place she says this, because taste and every other sense after its kind consists in the touch appro­ priate to it.
tgt_text.3648: In the second place she says it that it may seem to condemn them themselves, who did what they had been forbidden.
tgt_text.3649: For if even the mere act of touching it was prohibited, how could they who, besides touching the tree, presumed to eat of the fruit, and so added a greater transgression to the lesser one, be anything but condemners and punishers of themselves ?
tgt_text.3650: What is the meaning of the expression, " Ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil? ”‡36. Whence was it that the serpent found the plural word " gods," when there is only one true God, and when this is the first time that he names him ?
tgt_text.3651: But perhaps this arises from there having been in him a certain prescient wisdom, by which he now declared the notion of the multi­ tude of gods which was at a future time to prevail amongst men;
tgt_text.3652: and, perhaps, history now relates this correctly at its first being advanced not by any rational being, nor by any creature of the higher class, but as having derived its origin from the most virulent and vile of beasts and serpents, since other similar creatures lie hid under the earth, and their lurking places are in the holes and fissures of the earth.
tgt_text.3653: Moreover, it is the inseparable sign of a being endowed with reason to look upon God as essentially one being, but it is the mark of a beast to imagine that there are many gods, and these too devoid of reason, and who can scarcely be said with propriety to have any existence at all.
tgt_text.3654: Moreover, the devil proceeds with great art, speaking by the mouth of the serpent.
tgt_text.3655: For not only is there in the Divinity the knowledge of good and evil, but there is also an approval of what is good and a repudiation of what is evil;
tgt_text.3656: but he does not speak of either of these feelings because they were useful, but only suggested the mere knowledge of the two contrary things, namely, of good and evil.
tgt_text.3657: In the second place, the expression, " as gods," in the plural number, is in this place not used inconsiderately, but in order to give the idea of there being both a bad and a good God.
tgt_text.3658: And these are of a twofold quality.
tgt_text.3659: Therefore it is suitable to the notion of particular gods to have a know­ ledge of contrary things;
tgt_text.3660: but the Supreme Cause is above all others.
tgt_text.3661: Why the woman first touched the tree and ate of its fruit, and the man afterwards, receiving it from her ?*37.
tgt_text.3662: The words used first of all, by their own intrinsic force, assert that it was suitable that immortality and every good thing should be represented as under the power of the man, and death and every evil under that of the woman.
tgt_text.3663: But with reference to the mind, the woman, when under­ stood symbolically, is sense, and the man is intellect.
tgt_text.3664: More­ over, the outward senses do of necessity touch those things which are perceptible by them ;
tgt_text.3665: but it is through the medium of the outward senses that things are transmitted to the mind.
tgt_text.3666: For the outward senses are influenced by the objects which are presented to them;
tgt_text.3667: and the intellect by the out­ ward senses.
tgt_text.3668: What is the meaning of the expression, " And she gave it to her husband to eat with her ? "*38. What has been just said bears on this point also, since the time is nearly one and the same in which the out­ ward senses are influenced by the object which is presented to them, and the intellect has an impression made on it by the outward senses.
tgt_text.3669: What is the meaning of the expression, " And the eyes of both of them were opened ? "t39.
tgt_text.3670: That they were not created blind is manifest even from this fact that as all other things, both animals and plants, were created in perfection, so also man must have been adorned with the things which are his most excellent parts, namely, eyes.
tgt_text.3671: And we may especially prove this, because a little while before the earth-born Adam was giving names to all the animals on the earth.
tgt_text.3672: Therefore it is per­ fectly plain that he saw them before doing so.
tgt_text.3673: Unless, indeed, Moses used the expression " eyes" in a figurative sense for the vision of the soul, by which alone the percep­ tion of good and evil, of what is elegant or unsightly, and, in fact, of all contrary natures, arise.
tgt_text.3674: But, if the eye is to be taken separately as counsel, which is called the warning of the understanding, then again there is a separate eye, which is a certain something devoid of sound reason, which is called opinion.
tgt_text.3675: What is the meaning of the expression, " Because they knew that they were naked ? "t40.
tgt_text.3676: They first arrived at the knowledge of this fact, that is to say, of their nakedness, after they had eaten of the forbidden fruit.
tgt_text.3677: Therefore, opinion was like the beginning of wickedness, when they perceived that they had not as yet used any covering, inasmuch as all parts of the universe are immortal and incorruptible;
tgt_text.3678: but they themselves imme­ diately found themselves in need of some corruptible cover­ ings made with hands.
tgt_text.3679: But this knowledge was in the nakedness itself, not as having been in itself the cause of any change, but because their mind now conceived a novelty unlike the rest of the universal world.
tgt_text.3680: Why they sewed fig-leaves into girdles ?*41. They did this in the first place, because the fruit of the fig is very pleasant and agreeable to the taste.
tgt_text.3681: There­ fore the sacred historian here, by a symbolical expression, indicates those who sew together and join pleasures to plea­ sures by every means and contrivance imaginable.
tgt_text.3682: Therefore they bind them around the place where the parts of generation are seated, as that is the instrument of important transactions.
tgt_text.3683: And they do this, secondly, because although the fruit of the fig-tree is, as I have already said, sweeter than any other, yet its leaves are harder.
tgt_text.3684: And, therefore, Moses here wishes by this symbol to intimate that the motions of plea­ sure are slippery and smooth in appearance, but that they, nevertheless, are in reality hard, so that it is impossible that he who feels them should be delighted, unless he was pre­ viously sorrowful, and he will again become sorrowful.
tgt_text.3685: For to be always sorrowing is a melancholy thing between a double grief, the one being at its beginning, and the other coming before the first is ended.
tgt_text.3686: What is meant by the statement that the sound was heard of God walking in the Paradise ?
tgt_text.3687: was it the sound of his voice, or of his feet ?
tgt_text.3688: and can God be said to walk ?
tgt_text.3690: Those gods who are in heaven, perceptible to our outward senses, walk in a ring, proceeding onwards by a circuitous track;
tgt_text.3691: but the Supreme Cause is steadfast and immoveable, as the ancients have decided.
tgt_text.3692: But the true God gives some indication also, as if he wished to give a sense of motion.
tgt_text.3693: For in truth even without his uttering any words, the prophets hear him, by a certain virtue of some diviner voice sounding in their ears, or perhaps being even articulately uttered.
tgt_text.3694: As therefore God is heard without uttering any sound, so also he gives an idea of walking when he is not walking, nay, though he is altogether immoveable.
tgt_text.3695: But do you not see that before they had tasted of wickedness, as they were stable and constant, and immoveable and tranquil, and uniform, so also in an equal manner must they have looked upon the Deity as immoveable, as in fact he is.
tgt_text.3696: But they once had become endued with cunning, they, by judging from themselves, began to strip him of his attributes of immo­ bility and unchangeableness, and conjectured that he too was subject to variation and change.
tgt_text.3697: Why while they are hiding themselves from the face o God, the woman is not mentioned first, since she was the first to eat of the forbidden fruit:
tgt_text.3698: but why the man is spoken of in the first place;
tgt_text.3699: for the sacred historian's words are, " And Adam and his wife hid themselves ?"*43. The woman, being imperfect and depraved by nature, made the beginning of sinning and prevaricating;
tgt_text.3700: but the man, as being the more excellent and perfect creature, was the first to set the example of blushing and of being ashamed, and indeed, of every good feeling and action.
tgt_text.3701: Why they did not hide themselves in some other place, but in the middle of the trees of the Paradise ?f44.
tgt_text.3702: Every thing is not done by sinners with wisdom and sagacity, but it often happens that while thieves are watch­ ing for an opportunity of plunder, having no thoughts of the Deity who presides over the world, the booty which is close to them and lying at their feet is by some admirable management wrested from them without delay :
tgt_text.3703: and some­ thing of this kind took place on the present occasion.
tgt_text.3704: For when they ought rather to have fled to a distance from the garden in which their offence had taken place, they still were arrested in the middle of the Paradise itself, in order that they might be convicted of their sin too clearly to find any refuge even in flight itself.
tgt_text.3705: And this statement indicates in a figurative manner that every wicked man takes refuge in wickedness, and that every man who is wholly devoted to his passions flies to those passions as to an asylum.
tgt_text.3706: Why God asks Adam, "Where art thou?" when he knows everything:
tgt_text.3707: and why he does not also put the same question to the woman ?
tgt_text.3709: The expression, "Where art thou ?" does not here seem to be a mere interrogatory, but rather a threat and a conviction :
tgt_text.3712: from how many good things art thou changed ?
tgt_text.3713: having forsaken immortality and a life of the most perfect happiness, you have become changed to death and misery in which you are buried."
tgt_text.3714: But God did not condescend to put any question to the woman at all, looking upon her as the cause of the evil which had occurred, and as the guide to her husband to a life of shame.
tgt_text.3715: But there is an allegorical meaning in this passage, because the principal part is the man, his guide, the mind, having in itself the masculine principle, when it gives ear to any one introduces also the defect of the female part, namely that of the outward sense.
tgt_text.3716: Wby the man says, " The woman gave me of the tree, and I did eat;
tgt_text.3717: "* but the'woman does not say, " The serpent gave to me, but, " The serpent beguiled me and I did eat ?
tgt_text.3719: The literal expression here affords grounds for that probable opinion that woman is accustomed rather to be deceived than to devise anything of importance out of her own head ;
tgt_text.3720: but with the man the case is just the contrary.
tgt_text.3721: But as regards the intellect, everything which is the object of the outward senses beguiles and seduces each.
tgt_text.3722: particular sense of every imperfect being to which it is adapted.
tgt_text.3723: And the sense then, being vitiated by the object, infects the dominant and principal part, the mind, with its own taint.
tgt_text.3724: Therefore the mind receives the impression from the outward sense, giving it that which it has received itself.
tgt_text.3725: For the outward sense is deceived and beguiled by the sensible object submitted to it, but the senses of the wise man are infallible, as are also the cogitations of his mind.
tgt_text.3726: Why God curses the serpent first, then the woman, and the man last of all ?"t47.
tgt_text.3727: The reason is that the order of the curses followed the order in which the offences were committed.
tgt_text.3728: The first offence was the deceit practised by the serpent;
tgt_text.3729: the second was the sin of the woman which was owing to him when bhe abandoned herself to his seduction;
