tgt_text.3730: the third thing was the guilt of the man in yielding rather to the inclination of the woman than to the commandment of God.
tgt_text.3731: But this order is very admirable, containing within itself a perfect allegory;
tgt_text.3732: inasmuch as the serpent is the emblem of desire, as is proved, and the woman of the outward sense;
tgt_text.3733: but the man is the symbol of intellect.
tgt_text.3734: Therefore the infamous author of the sin is desire;
tgt_text.3735: and that first deceives the outward sense, and then the outward sense captivates the mind.
tgt_text.3736: Why the curse is pronounced on the serpent in this manner, that he shall go on his breast and on his belly, and eat dust, and be at enmity with the woman ? *48.
tgt_text.3737: The words in themselves are plain enough, and we have evidence of them in what we have seen.
tgt_text.3738: But the real meaning contains an allegory concealed beneath it;
tgt_text.3739: since the serpent is the emblem of desire, representing under a figure a man devoted to pleasure.
tgt_text.3740: For he creeps upon his breast and upon his belly, being filled with meat and drink like cormorants, being inflamed by an insatiable cupidity, and being incontinent in their voracity and devouring of flesh, so that whatever relates to food is in every article some­ thing earthly, on which account he is said to eat the dust.
tgt_text.3741: But desire has naturally a quarrel with the outward sense, which Moses here symbolically calls the woman ;
tgt_text.3742: but where the passions appear to be as it were guardians and champions in behalf of the senses, nevertheless they are beyond all question still more clearly flatterers forming devices against them like so many enemies;
tgt_text.3743: and it is the custom of those who are contending with one another to perpetrate greater evils by means of those things which they concede.
tgt_text.3744: Forsooth they turn the eyes to the ruin of the sight, the ears to hearing what is unwelcome;
tgt_text.3745: and the rest of the outward senses to insensibility.
tgt_text.3746: Moreover they cause dissolution and paralysis to the entire body, taking away from it all sound­ ness, and foolishly building up instead a great number of most mischievous diseases.
tgt_text.3747: Why the curse pronounced against the woman is the multiplication of her sadness and groans, that she shall bring forth children in sorrow, and that her desire shall be to her husband, and that she shall be ruled over by him ?
tgt_text.3749: Every woman who is the companion for life of a hus­ band suffers all those things, not indeed as a curse but as necessary evils.
tgt_text.3750: But speaking figuratively, the human sense is wholly subjected to severe labour and pain, being stricken and wounded by domestic agitations.
tgt_text.3751: Now the following are the train in the service of the outward senses :
tgt_text.3752: the sight is the servant of the eyes, hearing of the ears, smelling of the nostrils, taste of the mouth, feeling of the touch.
tgt_text.3753: Since the life of the worthless and wicked man is full of pain and want, it arises of necessity from these facts that every thing which is done in accordance with the outward sense must be mingled with pain and fear.
tgt_text.3754: In respect of the mind a conversion of the outward sense takes place towards the man not as to a companion, for it, like the woman, is subject to authority as being depraved, but as to a master, because it has chosen violence rather than justice.
tgt_text.3755: Why God, as he had pronounced a curse on the serpent and on the woman which bore a relation to themselves and to one another, he did not pronounce a similar one upon the man, but connected the earth with him, saying," Cursed is the earth for thy sake;
tgt_text.3756: in sorrow shalt thou eat of it, thorns and thistles shall it bring forth unto thee, and thou shalt eat the grass of the field:
tgt_text.3757: in the sweat of thy brow shalt thou eat thy bread.?"*50. Since allintellect is a divine inspiration, God did not judge it right to curse him in the manner deserved by his offence;
tgt_text.3758: but converted his curse so as to fall upon the earth and his cultivation of it.
tgt_text.3759: But man, as a body of co-equal nature and similar character to that of the earth and under­ standing, is its cultivator.
tgt_text.3760: When the cultivator is endowed with virtue and diligence, then the body produces its proper fruit, namely sanity, an excellent state of the outward senses, strength, and beauty.
tgt_text.3761: But if the cultivator be a savage, then every thing is different.
tgt_text.3762: For the body becomes liable to a curse, since it has for its husbandman an intellect unchastised and unsound.
tgt_text.3763: And its fruit is nothing useful, but only thorns and thistles, sorrow and fear, and other vices which every thought strikes down, and as it were pierces the intellect with its darts.
tgt_text.3764: Bat grass here is symbolically used for food;
tgt_text.3765: since man has changed himself from a rational animal into a brute beast, having neglected all divine food, which is given by philosophy, by means of distinct words and laws to regulate the will.
tgt_text.3766: What is the meaning of the expression, " Until thou re­ turnest to the earth from which thou wast taken;
tgt_text.3767: ” for man was not created out of the earth alone, but also of the divine Spirit ?*51.
tgt_text.3768: In the first place it is clear, that the first man who was formed out of the earth was made up both of earth and heaven;
tgt_text.3769: but because he did not continue uncorrupt, but despised the commandment of God, fleeing from the most excellent part, namely, from heaven, he gave himself up wholly as a slave to the earth, the denser and heavier element.
tgt_text.3770: In the second place, if any one burns with a desire of virtue, which makes the soul immortal, he, beyond all ques­ tion, attains to a heavenly inheritance;
tgt_text.3771: but because he was covetous of pleasure, by which spiritual death is engendered, he again gives himself over a second time to the earth, on which account it is said to him, ‟ Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return;
tgt_text.3772: ” therefore the earth, as it is the beginning of a wicked and depraved man, so also it is his end;
tgt_text.3773: but heaven is the beginning and end of him who is endowed with virtue.
tgt_text.3774: Why Adam called his wife Life, and affirmed to her, " Thou art the mother of all living ?"t52.
tgt_text.3775: In the first place, Adam gave to the first created woman that familiar name of Life, inasmuch as she was des­ tined to be the fountain of all the generations which should ever arise upon the earth after their time.
tgt_text.3776: In the second place, he called her by this name because she did not derive the existence of her substance out of the earth, but out of a living creature, namely, out of one part of the man, that is to say, out of his rib, which was formed into a woman, and on that account she was called " life," because she was first made out of a living creature, and because the first beings who were endowed with reason were to be generated from her.
tgt_text.3777: Nevertheless, it is possible that this may have been a metaphorical expression ;
tgt_text.3778: for is not the outward sense, which is a figurative emblem of the woman, called with peculiar propriety " life ?” because it is by the possession of these senses that the living being is above all other means distinguished from that which is not alive, as it is by that that the imaginations and impulses of the soul are set in motion, for the senses are the causes of each;
tgt_text.3779: and, in real truth the outward sense is the mother of all living creatures, for as there could be no generation without a mother, so also there could be no living creature without sense.
tgt_text.3780: Why God made garments of skins for Adam and his wife, and clothed them ?*53.
tgt_text.3781: Perhaps some one may laugh at the expressions here used, considering the small value of the garments thus made, as if they were not at all worthy of the labour of a Creator of such dignity and greatness;
tgt_text.3782: but a man who has a proper appreciation of wisdom and virtue will rightly and deservedly look upon this work as one very suitable for a God, that, namely, of teaching wisdom to those who were before labouring to no purpose;
tgt_text.3783: and who, having but little anxiety about procuring useful things, being seized with an insane desire for miserable honours, have given themselves up as slaves to convenience, looking upon the study of wis­ dom and virtue with detestation, and being in love with splendour of life and skill in mean and handicraft arts, which is in no way connected with a virtuous man.
tgt_text.3784: And these unhappy men do not know that a frugality, which is in need of nothing, becomes, as it were, a relation and neighbour to man, but that luxurious splendour is banished to a distance as an enemy;
tgt_text.3785: therefore the garment made of skins, if one should come to a correct judgment, deserves to be looked upon as a more noble possession than a purple robe embroidered with various colours.
tgt_text.3786: Therefore this is the literal meaning of the text;
tgt_text.3787: but if we look to the real meaning, then the garment of skins is a figurative expression for the natural skin, that.
tgt_text.3789: for God, when first of all he made the intellect, called it Adam;
tgt_text.3790: after that he created the outward sense, to which he gave the name of Life.
tgt_text.3791: In the third place, he of necessity also made a body, calling that by a figurative expression, a garment of skins;
tgt_text.3792: for it was fitting that the intellect and the outward sense should be clothed in a body as in a gar­ ment of skins;
tgt_text.3793: that the creature itself might first of all appear worthy of divine virtue;
tgt_text.3794: since by what power can the formation of the human body be put together more ex­ cellently, and in a more becoming manner, than by God on which account he did put it together, and at the same time he clothed it;
tgt_text.3795: when some prepare articles of human clothing and others put them on;
tgt_text.3796: but this natural clothing, contemporary with the man himself, namely, the body, be­ longed to the same Being both to make and to clothe the man in after it was made.
tgt_text.3797: Who those beings are to whom God says, " Behold, Adam has become as one of us, to know good and evil ?”*54. The expression, " one of us," indicates a plurality of beings;
tgt_text.3798: unless indeed we are to suppose, that God is con­ versing with his own virtues, which he employed as instru­ ments, as it were, to create the universe and all that is in it;
tgt_text.3799: but that expression " as," resembles an enigma, and a similitude, and a comparison, but is not declaratory of any dissimilarity;
tgt_text.3800: for that which is intelligible and sensibly good, and likewise that which is of a contrary character, is known to God in a different manner from that in which it is known to man;
tgt_text.3801: since, in the same way in which the natures of those who inquire and those who comprehend, and the things themselves too which are inquired into, and per­ ceived, and comprehended, are distinguished, virtue itself is also capable of comprehending them.
tgt_text.3802: But all these things are similitudes, and forms, and images, among men;
tgt_text.3803: but among the gods they are prototypes, models, indications, and more manifest examples of things which are somewhat obscure;
tgt_text.3804: but the unborn and uncreated Father joins himself to no one, except with the intention of extending the honour of his virtues.
tgt_text.3805: What is the meaning of the words, " Lest perchance he put forth his hand and take of the tree of life, and eat and live for ever;
tgt_text.3806: "* for there is no uncertainty and no envy in God ?
tgt_text.3808: It is quite true that God never feels either uncer­ tainty or envy;
tgt_text.3809: nevertheless he often employs ambiguous things and expressions, assenting to them as a man might do;
tgt_text.3810: for, as I have said before, the supreme providence is of a twofold nature, sometimes being God, and not acting in any respect as a man;
tgt_text.3811: but, on some occasions, as a man instructs his son, so likewise should the Lord God give warning to you.
tgt_text.3812: Therefore the first of these circumstances belongs to his sovereign power, and the second to his disciplinary, and to the first introduction to instruction, so as to insinuate into man's heart a voluntary inclination, since that expression, " lest perchance," is not to be taken as a proof of any hesi­ tation on the part of God, but in relation to man, who, by his nature, is prone to hesitation, and is a denunciation of the inclinations which exist in him.
tgt_text.3813: For when any appearance of anything whatever occurs to any man, immediately there arises within him an impulse towards that which appears, being caused by that very thing which appears.
tgt_text.3814: And from this arises the second hesitating kind of uncertainty, distracting the mind in various direc­ tions, as to whether the thing is fit to be accepted, or acquired, or not.
tgt_text.3815: And very likely present circumstances have a respect to that second feeling;
tgt_text.3816: for, in truth, the Divinity is incapable of any cunning, or malevolence, or wickedness:
tgt_text.3817: it is absolutely impossible that God should either envy the immortality or any other good fortune be­ longing to any being.
tgt_text.3818: And we can bring the most unde­ niable proof of this;
tgt_text.3819: for it was not in consequence of any one's entreaties that he created the world;
tgt_text.3820: but, being a merciful benefactor, rendering an essence previously un­ tamed and unregulated, and liable to suffering, gentle and pleasant, he did so by a vast harmony of blessings, and a regulated arrangement of them, like a chorus;
tgt_text.3821: and he being himself the only sure being, planted the tree of life by his own luminous character.
tgt_text.3822: Moreover, he was not influenced by the mediation or exhortation of any other being in communicating incor­ ruptibility to man.
tgt_text.3823: But while man existed as the purest intellect, displaying no appearance either of work or of any evil discourse, he was certain to have a fitting guide, to lead him in the paths of piety, which is undoubted and genuine immortality.
tgt_text.3824: But from the time when he began to be converted to depravity, wishing for the things which belong to mortal life, he wandered from immortality;
tgt_text.3825: for it is not fitting that craft and wickedness should be rendered im­ mortal, and moreover it would be useless to the subject;
tgt_text.3826: since the longer the life is which is granted to the wicked and depraved man, the more miserable is he than others, so that his immortality becomes a grave misfortune to him.
tgt_text.3827: Why now he calls the Paradise "pleasure," when he is sending man forth out of it to till the ground from which ne was taken.*56.
tgt_text.3828: The distinction of agriculture is conspicuous, when man in the state of paradise, practising the cultivation of wisdom as if he were employed in the cultivation of trees, and enjoying the food of imperishable and most useful fruits, was himself endowed with immortality likewise.
tgt_text.3829: After that, being expelled from the place of wisdom, he experienced the opposite effects of ignorance, by which the body is polluted, and at the same time the intellect is blinded, and, being exposed to a want of proper food, he wastes away, and yields to a miserable death.
tgt_text.3830: On which account, now, in contempt of the foolish man, God calls the Paradise "pleasure," in order to put it in opposition to a life of pain, and misery, and savageness.
tgt_text.3831: In truth, the life which is passed in wisdom is a pleasure, full of liberal joy, and is the constant enjoyment of a rational soul;
tgt_text.3832: but that life which is destitute of wisdom is found to be both savage and miserable, although it is excessively deceived by the appetites, which pain both precedes and follows.
tgt_text.3833: Why God places a cherubim in front of the Paradise, and a flaming sword, which turned every way, to keep the way of the tree of life ?f57.
tgt_text.3834: The name cherubim designates the two original vir­ tues which belong to the Deity, namely, his creative and his royal virtues.
tgt_text.3835: The one of which has the title of God, the other, or the royal virtue, that of Lord.
tgt_text.3836: Now the form of the creative power is a peaceable, and gentle, and benefi­ cent virtue;
tgt_text.3837: but the royal power is a legislative, and chastising, and correcting virtue.
tgt_text.3838: Moreover, by the flaming sword he here symbolically intimates the heaven:
tgt_text.3839: for the air is of a flaming colour, and turns itself round, revolving about the universe.
tgt_text.3840: Therefore, all these things assumed to themselves the guardianship of the Paradise, because they are the presi­ dents over wisdom, like a mirror;
tgt_text.3841: since, to illustrate my meaning by an example, the wisdom of the world is a sort of mirror of the divine virtues, in the similitude of which it was perfected, and by which the universe and all the things in it are regulated and arranged.
tgt_text.3842: But the way to wisdom is called philosophy (a word which means the love or the pursuit of philosophy).
tgt_text.3843: And since the creative virtue is endued with philosophy, being both philosophical and royal, so also the world itself is philosophical.
tgt_text.3844: Some persons however have fancied that it is the sun which is indicated by the flaming sword;
tgt_text.3845: because, by its constant revolutions and turnings every way, it marks out the seasons of the year, as being the guardian of human life and of every thing which serves to the life of all men.
tgt_text.3846: Whether it was properly said with respect to Cain:
tgt_text.3847: " I have gotten a man from the Lord ?” *58.
tgt_text.3848: Here there is a distinction made, as to-from some one, and out of some one, and by some thing.
tgt_text.3849: Out of some one, as out of materials;
tgt_text.3850: from some one, as from a cause;
tgt_text.3851: and by some thing, as by an instrument.
tgt_text.3852: But the Father and Creator of all the world is not an instrument, but a cause.
tgt_text.3853: Therefore he wanders from right wisdom who says, " That what has been made has been made, not from God, but by God.
tgt_text.3854: "Why the sacred historian first describes the employment of the younger brother, Abel, saying:
tgt_text.3855: " He was a keeper of sheep ;
tgt_text.3856: but Cain was a cultivator of the earth ? " t59. Since, although the virtuous son was in point of time younger than the wicked son, yet in point of virtue he was older.
tgt_text.3857: On which account, on the present occasion, when their actions are to be compared together, he is placed first.
tgt_text.3858: Therefore one of them exercises a business, and takes care of living creatures, although they are devoid of reason, gladly taking upon himself the employment of a shepherd, which is a princely office, and as it were a sort of rehearsal of royal power;
tgt_text.3859: but the other devotes his attention to earthly and inanimate objects.
tgt_text.3860: Why Cain after some days offers up the first-fruits of his fruits, but when it is said that "Abel offered up first-fruits of the first-born of his flock and of the fat," * "after some days" is not added ?60.
tgt_text.3861: Moses here intimates the difference between a lover of himself, and one who is thoroughly devoted to God;
tgt_text.3862: for the one took to himself the first-fruits of his fruits, and very impiously looked upon God as worthy only of the secondary and inferior offerings;
tgt_text.3863: for the expression, "after some days," implies that he did not do so immediately;
tgt_text.3864: and when it is said that he offered of the fruits, that intimates that he did not offer of the best fruits which he had, and herein displays his iniquity.
tgt_text.3865: But the other, without any delay, offered up the first-born and eldest of all his flocks, in order that in this the Father might not be treated unworthily.
tgt_text.3866: Why, when he had begun with Cain, he still mentions him here in the second place, when he says:
tgt_text.3867: " And God had respect unto Abel and unto his offerings;
tgt_text.3868: but unto Cain and unto his sacrifices he paid no attention ?”†61. In the first place, because the good man, who is by nature first, is not at first perceived by the outward senses of any man except in his own turn, and by people of virtuous conduct.
tgt_text.3869: Secondly, because the good and the wicked man are two distinct characters;
tgt_text.3870: he accepts the good man, seeing that- he is a lover of what is good, and an eager student of virtue ;
tgt_text.3871: but he rejects and regards with aversion the wicked man, presuming that he will be prone to that side by the order of nature.
tgt_text.3872: Therefore he says here with exceeding fitness, that God had regard, not to the offerings, but to those who offered them, rather than to the gifts themselves;
tgt_text.3873: for men have regard to and regulate their approbation by the abundance and richness of offerings, but God looks at the sincerity of the soul, having no regard to ambition or illusion of any kind.
tgt_text.3874: What is the meaning of the distinction here made be­ tween a gift and a sacrifice ?*62. The man who slays a sacrifice, after having made a division, pours the blood around the altar and takes the flesh home;
tgt_text.3875: but he who offers it as a gift, offers as it should seem the whole to him who accepts it.
tgt_text.3876: Therefore, the man who is a lover of self is a distributor, like Cain;
tgt_text.3877: but he who is a lover of God is the giver of a free gift, as was Abel.
tgt_text.3878: How it was that Cain became aware that his offering had not pleased God?†63.
tgt_text.3879: Perhaps he resolved his doubts, an additional cause being added, for sorrow seized upon him and his counte­ nance fell.
tgt_text.3880: Therefore, he took the sorrow which he felt as an indication that be had been sacrificing what was not pleasing or approved of, when joy and happiness would have been suited to one who was sacrificing with purity of heart and spirit.
tgt_text.3881: Why is it that the expression used is not, because you do not offer rightly;
tgt_text.3882: but, because (or unless) you do not divide rightly ? ‡64.
tgt_text.3883: In the first place, we must understand that right division and improper division are nothing else but order and the want of it.
tgt_text.3884: And it is by order that the universal world and its parts were made;
tgt_text.3885: since the Creator of the world, when he began to arrange and regulate the pre­ viously untamed and unarranged power which was liable to suffering, employed section and division.
tgt_text.3886: For he placed the heavy elements which were prone to descend downwards by their own nature, namely, the earth and the water, in the centre of the universe;
tgt_text.3887: but he placed the air and the fire at a greater altitude, as they were raised on high by reason of their lightness.
tgt_text.3888: But separating and dividing the pure nature, namely heaven, he carried it round and diffused it over the universe, so that it should be completely invisible to all men;
tgt_text.3889: con­ taining within itself the whole universe in all its parts.
tgt_text.3890: Again, the statement that animals and plants are pro­ duced out of seeds, some moist and some dry, what else does it mean but the inevitable dissection and separation of distinction ?
tgt_text.3891: Therefore it follows inevitably, that this order and arrangement of the universe must be imitated in all things, especially in feeling and acknowledging gratitude;
tgt_text.3892: by which we are invited to requite in some degree and manner the kindnesses of those who have showered greater benefits liberally on us.
tgt_text.3893: Moreover, to pay one's thanks to God is an action which is intrinsically right in itself:
tgt_text.3894: and it is not to be disapproved of that he should receive the offerings due to him at the earliest moment, and fresh gifts from the first-fruits of every thing, not being dishonoured by any negligence on our part.
tgt_text.3895: Since it is not fitting that man should reserve for himself the first and most excellent things which are created, and should offer what is only second best to the all-wise God and Creator;
tgt_text.3896: for that division would be faulty and blameworthy, showing a most preposterous and unnatural arrangement.
tgt_text.3897: What is the meaning of the expression:
tgt_text.3900: He is here giving very useful advice;
tgt_text.3901: since, to do no wrong at all is the greatest of all good things:
tgt_text.3902: but he who sins, and who thus blushes and is overwhelmed with shame, is near akin to him, being, if I may use such a phrase, as the younger brother to the elder;
tgt_text.3903: for those persons who pride themselves on their errors as if they had not done wrong, are afflicted with a disease which is difficult to cure, or rather which is altogether incurable.
tgt_text.3904: Why he seems to be giving what is good into the hand of a wicked man, when he says, " And unto thee shall be his desire ?" t66.
tgt_text.3905: He does not deliver good into his hand;
tgt_text.3906: but the expression is heard with different feelings;
tgt_text.3907: since he is speaking, not of a pious man, but after the action is accom­ plished, saying of him:
tgt_text.3908: The desire and respect of the impiety of this man's wickedness will be towards you.
tgt_text.3909: Do not therefore talk about necessity, but about your own habits, in order that thus he may represent the voluntary action.
tgt_text.3910: And again, the sentence, " And you shall be his ruler over him," has a reference to the operation.
tgt_text.3911: In the first, place, you begin to act with wickedness;
tgt_text.3912: and now behold, another iniquity follows that great and injurious iniquity.
tgt_text.3913: Therefore, he both thinks and affirms that this is the principal part of all voluntary injury.
tgt_text.3914: Why he slew his brother in the field ?*67.
tgt_text.3915: That as all infecundity and sterility arises from a neglect of sowing and planting land a second time, he may be kept continually in mind of his wicked murder, and self­ blamed for it;
tgt_text.3916: since the ground was not to be the same for the future, after it was compelled, contrary to its nature, to drink of human blood, to bring forth food to that man who imbued it with the polluted stain of blood.
tgt_text.3917: Why he who knows all things asks the fratricide:
tgt_text.3919: He puts this question to him because he wishes the man to confess voluntarily and spontaneously, of his own accord, so that he may not imagine that every thing is done out of necessity;
tgt_text.3920: for he who had slain another through necessity, would have confessed unwillingly, as having done the deed unwillingly;
tgt_text.3921: since that which does not depend upon ourselves does not deserve accusation;
tgt_text.3922: but the man who has done wrong intentionally denies it;
tgt_text.3923: for those who do wrong are liable to repentance.
tgt_text.3924: Therefore, he has inter­ woven this principle in all parts of his legislation, because the Deity himself is never the cause of evil.
tgt_text.3925: Why he who had slain his brother makes answer as if he were replying to a man;
tgt_text.3926: and says, " I do not know:
tgt_text.3928: It is the opinion of an atheist to think that the eye of God does not penetrate through every thing, and behold all things at the same time;
tgt_text.3929: piercing not only through what is visible, but also through every thing which lurks in the deepest and bottomless unfathomable abysses.
tgt_text.3930: Suppose a person, said to him, " How can you be ignorant where your brother is, and how is it that you do not know that, when as yet he is one out of the only four human beings which exist in the world?
tgt_text.3931: He being one with both his parents, and you his only brother."
tgt_text.3932: To this question the reply made is:
tgt_text.3935: And whose keeper and protector ought you to have been, rather than your brother's ?
tgt_text.3936: But if you have excited your diligence to give effect to violence, and injury, and fraud, and homicide, which are the foulest and most abominable of actions, why did you consider the safety of your brother a secondary object ?
tgt_text.3937: ”What is the meaning of the expresssion, " The voice of thy brother's blood cries to me out of the earth ? " *70. This is especially an example by which to take warning;
tgt_text.3938: for the Deity listens to those who are worthy, although they be dead, knowing that they are alive as to an incorporeal life.
tgt_text.3939: But he averts his countenance from the prayers of the wicked, although they are living a flourishing life, inasmuch as he looks upon them as dead to any real life, carrying about their bodies like a sepulchre;
tgt_text.3940: and having buried their miserable souls in it.
tgt_text.3941: Why he is said to be cursed upon the earth ? t71.
tgt_text.3942: The earth is the last portion of the world, therefore if that utters curses, we must consider that the other elements do likewise pour forth adequate maledictions ;
tgt_text.3943: for instance, the fountains, and rivers, and sea, and the air, and the land, and the fire, and the light, and the sun, and moon, and stars, and in short the whole heaven.
tgt_text.3944: For if inanimate and earthly nature, throwing off the yoke, wars against injury, why may not still rather those natures do so which are of a purer character?
tgt_text.3945: But as for him, against whom the parts of the world carry on war, what hope of safety he can have for the future, I know not.
tgt_text.3946: What is the meaning of the curse, "You shall be groaning and trembling upon the earth?" *72. This also is a general principle ;
tgt_text.3947: for in all evils there are some things which are perceived immediately, and some which are felt at a later period;
tgt_text.3948: for those which are future cause fear, and those which are felt at once bring sorrow.
tgt_text.3949: What is the meaning of Cain saying, " My punishment is too great for you to dismiss me ? +73.
tgt_text.3950: In truth there is no misery greater than to be deserted and despised by God;
tgt_text.3951: for the anarchy of fools is cruel and very intolerable ;
tgt_text.3952: but to be despised by the great King, and to fall down as an abject person cast down from the govern­ ment of the- Supreme Power is an indescribable affliction.
tgt_text.3953: What is the meaning of Cain, when he says, " Everyone who shall find me will kill me:
tgt_text.3954: " when there was scarcely another human being in the world except his parents ?
tgt_text.3956: In the first place he might have received injury from the parts of the world which indeed were made for the advantage of the good and that they might partake of them, but which nevertheless, derived from the wicked no slight degree of revenge.
tgt_text.3957: In the second place it may be that he said this, because he was apprehensive of injury from beasts, and reptiles;
tgt_text.3958: for nature has brought forth these animals with the express object of their being instruments of vengeance on the wicked.
tgt_text.3959: In the third place, some people may imagine that he is speaking with reference to his parents, on whom he had inflicted an unprecedented sorrow, and the first evil which had happened to them, before they knew what death was.
tgt_text.3960: Why whoever should slay Cain should be liable to bear a sevenfold punishment ?§75.
tgt_text.3961: As our soul consists of eight portions, being accus­ tomed to be divided in its rational and irrational individuality into seven subordinate parts, namely into the five outward senses, and the instrument of vice, and the faculty of gene­ ration ;
tgt_text.3962: those seven parts exist among the causes of wicked­ ness and evil, on which account they likewise fall under judgment;
tgt_text.3963: but the death of the principal and dominant portion of man, namely of the mind, is principally the wickedness which exists in it.
tgt_text.3964: Whoever therefore slays the mind, mingling in it folly, and insensibility, instead of sense, will cause dissolution also of the seven irrational parts;
tgt_text.3965: since, just as the principal and leading part had a portion from virtue, in the same manner likewise are its subject divisions composed.
tgt_text.3966: Why a sign is put on him who had slain his brother, that no one should kill him who found him :
tgt_text.3967: when it would have been natural to do the contrary, namely, to give him over to the hands of an executioner to be put to death ?*76. This is said because, in the first place, the change of the nature of living is one kind of death;
tgt_text.3968: but continual sorrow and unmixed fear are destitute of joy and devoid of all good hope, and so they bring on many terrible and various evils which are so many sensible deaths.
tgt_text.3969: In the second place, the sacred historian designs at the very beginning of his work to enunciate the law about the incorruptibility of the soul, and to confute as deceitful those who look upon the life which is contained in this body as the only happy life ;
tgt_text.3970: for behold one of the two brothers is guilty of those enormous crimes which have already been men­ tioned, namely, impiety and fratricide ;
tgt_text.3971: and he is still alive, and begetting offspring, and building cities.
tgt_text.3972: But the other who was praised in respect of his piety is treacherously put to death;
tgt_text.3973: while the voice of the Lord not only clearly cries out that that existence which is perceptible by the outward senses is not good, and that such a death is not evil, but also that that life which is in the flesh is not life, but that there is another given to man free from old age, and more immortal, which the incorporeal souls have received;
tgt_text.3974: for that expression of the poet about Scylla, "That is not mortal but an endless woe,” + is asserted in the same familiarity about a person who lives ill and passes a long life for many years in the practice of wickedness.
tgt_text.3975: In the third place, since Cain had perpetrated this fra­ tricide of enormous guilt above all other crimes, he* presents himself to him, quite forgetful of the injury that he has done, imposing on all judges a most peaceful law for the first crime;
tgt_text.3976: not that they are not to destroy malefactors, but that resting for a while with great patience and long suffering, they shall study compassion rather than severity.
tgt_text.3977: But God himself, with the most perfect wisdom, has laid down the rule of familiarity and intelligence with reference to the first sinner :
tgt_text.3978: not slaying the homicide, but destroying him in another manner;
tgt_text.3979: since he scarcely permitted him to be enumerated among the generations of his father, but shows him proscribed not only by his parents but by the whole race of mankind, allotting him a state separate from that of others, and secluded from the class of rational animals, as one who had been expelled, and banished, and turned into the nature of beasts.
tgt_text.3980: Why Lamech, after the fifth generation, blames himself for the fratricide of his elder Cain ;
tgt_text.3981: saying, as the scripture reports, to his wives, Adah and Zillah ;
tgt_text.3982: " I have slain a man to my injury and a young man to my hurt;
tgt_text.3983: since if vengeance is taken upon Cain sevenfold, it shall certainly be taken on Lamcch seventy and sevenfold ? " *77. In numerals one is before ten, both in order and in virtue, for it is the first beginning and element and measure of all things.
tgt_text.3984: But the number ten is subsequent, and is measured by the other, being inferior to it, both in order and virtue ;
tgt_text.3985: therefore, also, the number seven is antecedent in its origin to and more ancient than the number seventy, but the number seventy is younger than the number seven, and contains the calculation of generations.
tgt_text.3986: These premises being laid down, he who first committed sin, as if he had been really always ignorant of evil, like the first odd number, namely, the unit, is chastised more simply ;
tgt_text.3987: but the second offender, because he had the first for an example, so that there cannot possibly be any excuse made for him, is guilty of a voluntary crime, and because he did not receive honourable wisdom from that more sim­ ple punishment, the consequence will be that he will both suffer all that first punishment, and will, moreover, receive this second one, which is contained in the number ten.
tgt_text.3988: For as in the horse-races they pay the groom who has trained the horse twice as great a reward as they give to the driver, so some wicked men, inclined to acts of injustice, gain the miserable triumph of victory and then are punished with a double punishment, both by the first one which is contained in the unit, and also by the second which is contained in the number ten;
tgt_text.3989: besides, Cain being the author of a homicide, when he was ignorant of the great­ ness of the pollution which he was incurring, because no death had hitherto taken place in the world, suffered a more simple punishment, namely, only a sevenfold penalty in the order of the unit;
tgt_text.3990: but as his imitator could not take refuge in the same plea of ignorance, he ought to be subjected to a twofold punishment, not only to one equal and similar to that which had been inflicted on the first offender, but also another, which should be the seventh among the decades.
tgt_text.3991: In truth, according to the law, the trial which is before the tribunal is a sevenfold one;
tgt_text.3992: first of all, the eyes are put on their trial, because they beheld what was not lawful;
tgt_text.3993: secondly, the ears are impeached, because they heard what they ought not to have heard ;
tgt_text.3994: thirdly, the smell is brought into question, as having been reduced by smoke and vapour;
tgt_text.3995: fourthly, the taste is accused, as being subservient to the pleasures of the belly ;
tgt_text.3996: fifthly, a charge is brought against the taste, by means of which, besides the operations of the senses above-mentioned, in respect of those things which prevail over the spirit, other things, also, are superadded separately, such as the takings of cities, the captivities of men.
tgt_text.3997: the destructions of those citadels of cities in which wisdom dwells ;
tgt_text.3998: sixthly, an accusation is urged against the tongue and other instruments of speech, for being silent as to what should be spoken of, and speaking of what should be buried in silence ;
tgt_text.3999: and, in the seventh place, the lower part of the belly is impeached for inflaming and exciting the passions by immoderate lust.
tgt_text.4000: This is the meaning of that expression, according to which a sevenfold vengeance was taken upon Cain, but a seventy and sevenfold vengeance upon Lamech for the causes above mentioned, because he was the second offender, not having been taught by the punishment of the first delinquent, and therefore he is altogether worthy to receive his punishment, which is the more simple one, like the unit in numerals, and, also, a manifold punishment too equal to the number ten.
tgt_text.4001: Why Adam, when he begat Seth, introduces him saying, ‟ God has raised up for me another seed in the place of Abel whom Cain slew ? "*78.
tgt_text.4002: In real truth Seth is another seed and the beginning of a second nativity of Abel, in accordance with a certain natural principle;
tgt_text.4003: for Abel is like to one who comes down below from above, on which account it was that he perished injuriously ;
tgt_text.4004: but Seth resembles one who is proceeding up­ wards from below, on which account he also increases.
tgt_text.4005: And in proof of this argument Abel is explained as having been brought back and offered upwards to God.
tgt_text.4006: But it is not proper that everything should be raised and borne upwards, but only that which is good, for God is in no respect whatever the cause of evil.
tgt_text.4007: Therefore, whatever is indistinct and uncertain, and mingled, and in confusion and disorder, has also, very properly, blame and praise mingled together:
tgt_text.4008: praise, be­ cause it honours the cause, and blame, since as the occurrence happened fortuitously, so it is without any plans having been formed or any gratitude expressed.
tgt_text.4009: Moreover, nature also separated the two sons from him;
tgt_text.4010: it rendered the good one worthy of immortality, resolving him into a voice inter­ ceding with God;
tgt_text.4011: but the wicked one it gave over to corruption.
tgt_text.4012: But the name Seth is interpreted ‟ watered," according to the variation of plants which grow by being watered, and put forth shoots and bear fruit.
tgt_text.4013: But these things are the symbols of the soul, so that it is not lawful to assert that the Divinity is the cause of all things equally, of the bad as well as of the good, but only of the good, and that alone ought to be planted alive.
tgt_text.4014: Why Enos, the son of Seth, hoped to call upon the name of the Lord God ?t79.
tgt_text.4015: The name Enos is interpreted ‟ man;
tgt_text.4016: ” and it is received as meaning, not the whole of the combined man, but as the rational part of the soul, namely, the intellect, to which it is peculiarly becoming to hope, for irrational animals are devoid of hope;
tgt_text.4017: but hope is a sort of presage of joy, and before joy there is an expectation of good things.
tgt_text.4018: Why, after the mention of hope, Moses says, " This is the book of the generations of men ?
tgt_text.4020: It is by this that he made what has been said before worthy of belief.
tgt_text.4022: Man is a being which, beyond all other races of animals, has received a copious and wonderful portion of hope;
tgt_text.4023: and this is as it were inscribed on his very nature, and celebrated there;
tgt_text.4024: for the human intellect hopes by its own nature.
tgt_text.4025: Why, in the genealogy of Adam, Moses no longer men­ tions Cain, but only Seth, who, he says, was according to his appearance and form;
tgt_text.4026: on which account he proceeds to retain the generations which descend from him in his genealogy ?t81.
tgt_text.4027: It can neither be lawful to enumerate a wicked and sinful murderer either in the list of reason or in that of number;
tgt_text.4028: for he must be cast out like dung, as some one said, looking upon him as one of such a character;
tgt_text.4029: and on this account the sacred historian neither points him out as the successor of his father who had been formed out of the dust, nor as the head of succeeding generations;
tgt_text.4030: but he distributes both these characteristics to him who was with­ out pollution, and names Seth, who is a drinker of water, as having been watered by his father, and as begetting hope in his own increase and progress;
tgt_text.4031: on which account it is not inconsiderately and foolishly that he says that he was born according to the form and appearance of his father, to the reproof of his elder brother, who, on account of the foulness of the murder which he had committed, has nothing in him resembling his father, either in body or soul.
tgt_text.4032: And on this account Moses has separated him from the family, and has given his share to his brother, being the noble privilege of the birthright of the first-born.
tgt_text.4033: What is the meaning of the verse, Enoch pleased God after he begat Methuselah, two hundred years ?*82.

tgt_text.4035: And what I mean is something of this sort.

tgt_text.4041: Why Enoch, who cultivated repentance, is said to have lived before his repentance a hundred and sixty-five years, but two hundred after his repentance ?

tgt_text.4045: And again, from that by the addition of ten numbers, which, removing the unit proceed upwards by twos, as two, four, six, eight, ten, twelve, fourteen, sixteen, eighteen, twenty, which make a hundred and ten ;
tgt_text.4046: the combination of which, with the num­ bers first mentioned, produces a hundred and sixty-five;
tgt_text.4047: and in this addition the even numbers amount to twice as much as the odd numbers;
tgt_text.4048: for the woman is more violent than the man, in the preposterous manner in which the wicked man rules over the virtuous man, the outward sense over the mind, the body over the outward sense, and matter over its cause.

tgt_text.4050: In truth, before anything else is done, the first thing is to cut off from a sick body every diseased part, and after that means of cure are to be applied to it, for this is the first step, and the other the second.
tgt_text.4051: Moreover, the number two hundred consists of fours, for it is produced as from seed, from four triangular numbers, and from four tetragons, and from four pentagons, and from four hexagons, and from four heptagons;

tgt_text.4057: and the four heptagons, one, seven, eighteen, thirty-four, make sixty;
tgt_text.4058: and all these numbers put together make two hundred.
tgt_text.4059: Why the man who lives a life of repentance is said to have lived three hundred and sixty-five years?

tgt_text.4062: therefore, by the symbol of the solar orbit, the sacred historian here indicates the life of the repentant man.
tgt_text.4063: In the second place, as the sun is the cause of day and night, performing his revolutions by day above the hemisphere of the earth, and his course by night under the earth, so also the life of the man of repentance consists of alternations of light and darkness ;

tgt_text.4069: Why, when Enoch died, the sacred historian adds the assertion, " He pleased God?"*85. In the first place, he says this because, by such a statement, he implies that the soul is immortal, inasmuch as after it is stripped of the body, it still pleases a second time.

tgt_text.4073: What is the meaning of the expression, ‟ He was not found because God translated him ?"t86.

tgt_text.4075: In the second place, in this instance something marvellous did take place;

tgt_text.4081: How it was that immediately upon the nativity of Noah his father says, " He will make us rest from labours and sorrows, and from the earth, which the Lord God has cursed ?”*87. The fathers of the saints did not prophesy except for grave reasons and on important occasions;
tgt_text.4082: for although those who were rendered worthy of prophetical panegyric did not prophecy at all times or on all subjects, they did so at all events on one occasion and on one subject, with which they were acquainted.
tgt_text.4083: Nor is this of no importance, but it is an emblem and an example, since Noah is a kind of surname of righteousness, of which, when the intellect is made a partaker, it causes us to rest from all wicked works, and releases us from sorrows and from fears, and renders us secure and joyful.
tgt_text.4084: It also causes us to rest from that earthly nature which has been previously laid under a curse, which this body, when affected by pain, is connected with, especially in those persons who give cause for it, and who wear out their lives with pleasure.
tgt_text.4085: Nevertheless, if we examine attentively the events and circumstances, and compare them with the letter of the scriptures, the prophecy which has been already produced is deceived, because, in the time of this man, there did not arise any putting down of evils, but a more vehement obstinacy in sin and great afflictions, and the unprecedented event of the deluge.
tgt_text.4086: But you must note carefully, that Noah is the tenth in generation from the earth-born Adam.
tgt_text.4087: What is meant by the three sons of Noah being named Shem, Ham, and Japhet?*88.
tgt_text.4088: These names are the symbols of three human things, what is good, what is bad, and what is indifferent;
tgt_text.4089: Shem is the symbol of what is good, Ham of what is bad, and Japhet of what is indifferent.

tgt_text.4107: Why it is said that the days of man shall be a hundred and twenty years ? ‡91.
tgt_text.4108: God appears here to fix the limit of human life by this number, indicating by it the manifold prerogative of honour;
tgt_text.4109: for in the first place this number proceeds from the units, according to combination, from the number fifteen:
tgt_text.4110: but the principle of the number fifteen is that of a more transparent appearance, since it is on the fifteenth day that the moon is rendered full of light, borrowing its light of the sun at the approach of evening, and restoring it to him again in the morning;
tgt_text.4111: so that during the night of the full moon the darkness is scarcely visible, but it is all light.
tgt_text.4112: In the second place, the number a hundred and twenty is a triangular number, and is the fifteenth number consisting of triangles.
tgt_text.4113: Thirdly, it is so because it consists of a combination of odd and even numbers, being contained by the power of the faculty of the concurring numbers, sixty-four and fifty-six;
tgt_text.4114: for the equal number of sixty-four is compounded of the uniting of these eight odd numbers, one, three, five, seven, nine, eleven, thirteen, fifteen;
tgt_text.4115: the reduction of which, by their parts into squares, makes a sum total of sixty-four, and that is a cube, and at the same time a square number.
tgt_text.4116: But again from the seven double units there arises the unequal number of fifty-six, being compounded of seven double pairs, which generate other productions of them, two, four, six, eight, ten, twelve, fourteen;
tgt_text.4117: the sum total of which is fifty-six.
tgt_text.4118: In the fourth place, it is compounded of four numbers, of one triangle, namely fifteen;
tgt_text.4119: and of another square, namely twenty-five ;
tgt_text.4120: and of a third quinquangular figure, thirty-five;
tgt_text.4121: and of a fourth a sexangular figure forty-five, by the same analogy:
tgt_text.4122: for the fifth is always received according to each appearance;
tgt_text.4123: for from the unity of the triangles the fifth num­ ber becomes fifteen;
tgt_text.4124: again the fifth of the quadrangular number from the unit makes twenty-five;
tgt_text.4125: and the fifth of the quinquangular number from the unit makes thirty-five;
tgt_text.4126: and the fifth of the sexangular number from the unit makes forty-five.
tgt_text.4127: But every one of these numbers is a divine and sacred number, consisting of fifteens as has been already shown;
tgt_text.4128: and the number twenty-five belongs to the tribe of Levi.*
tgt_text.4129: And the number thirty-five comes from the double diagram of arithmetic, geometry, and harmony;
tgt_text.4130: but sixteen, and eighteen, and nineteen, and twenty-one, the combination of which numbers amounts to seventy-four, is that according to which seven months’ children are born.
tgt_text.4131: And forty-five consists of a triple diagram ;
tgt_text.4132: but to this number, sixteen, nineteen, twenty- two, and twenty-eight, belong:
tgt_text.4133: the combination of which makes eighty-five, according to which nine months’ children are produced.
tgt_text.4134: Fifthly, this diagram has fifteen parts, and a twofold compo­ sition, peculiarly belonging to itself;
tgt_text.4135: forsooth when divided by two it gives sixty, the measure of the age of all mankind ;
tgt_text.4136: when divided by three it gives forty, the idea of prophecy;
tgt_text.4137: when divided by four it gives thirty, a nation;
tgt_text.4138: when divided by five, it makes twenty-four, the measure of day and night;
tgt_text.4139: when divided by six, it gives twenty, a beginning ;
tgt_text.4140: when divided by eight, we have fifteen, the moon in the fulness of brilliancy;
tgt_text.4141: when divided by ten, it makes twelve, the zodiac embellished with living animals;
tgt_text.4142: when divided by twelve, it makes ten, holy;
tgt_text.4143: when divided by fifteen, it gives eight, the first ark ;
tgt_text.4144: when divided by twenty, it leaves six, the number of creation;
tgt_text.4145: when divided by twenty-four, it makes five, the emblem of the outward sense;
tgt_text.4146: when divided by thirty it makes four, the beginning of solid measure ;
tgt_text.4147: when divided by forty, it gives three, the symbol of fulness, the beginning, the middle, and the end;
tgt_text.4148: when divided by sixty, it makes two, which is woman;
tgt_text.4149: and when divided by the whole number of a hundred and twenty, the product is one, or man.
tgt_text.4150: And every one of all these numbers is more natural, as is proved in each of them, but the composition of them is twofold, for the product is two hundred and forty, which is a sign that it is worthy of a twofold life;
tgt_text.4151: for as the number of years is doubled, so also we may imagine that the life is doubled too ;
tgt_text.4152: one being in connection with the body, the other being detached from the body, according to which every holy and perfect man may receive the gift of prophecy.
tgt_text.4153: Sixthly, because the fifth and sixth figures arise, the three numbers being multiplied together, three times four times five, since three times four times five make sixty ;
tgt_text.4154: so in like mail­ ner the next following numbers four times five times six make a hundred and twenty, for four times five times six make a hundred and twenty.
tgt_text.4155: Seventhly, when the number twenty has been taken in, which is the beginning of the reduction of mankind, I mean twenty, and being added to itself two or three times, so as to make twenty, forty, and sixty, these added together make a hundred and twenty.
tgt_text.4156: But perhaps the number a hundred and twenty is not the general term of human life, but only of the life of those men who existed at that time, and who were to perish by the deluge after an interval of so many years, which their kind Benefactor prolonged, giving them space for repent­ ance;

tgt_text.4189: Why God says, I am indignant that I made them?
tgt_text.4191: In the first place, Moses is here again relating what took place, as if he were speaking of some illustrious action of man, but, properly speaking, God does not feel anger, but is exempt from, and superior to, all such perturbations of spirit.
tgt_text.4192: Therefore Moses wishes here to point out, by an extravagant form of expression, that the iniquities of man had grown to such a height, that they stirred up and provoked to anger even that very Being who by his nature was incapable of anger.
tgt_text.4193: In the second place he warns us, by a figure, that foolish actions are liable to punishment, but that those which proceed from wise and deliberate counsel are praiseworthy.
tgt_text.4194: Why it is afterwards said, that Noah found grace in the sight of the Lord ? t96.
tgt_text.4195: In the first place, the time calls for a comparison ;
tgt_text.4196: since all the rest of mankind has been rejected for their ingratitude, he places the just man in the place of them all, asserting that he had found favour with God, not because he alone was deserving of favour, when the whole universal body of the human race had had benefits and mercies heaped on them, but because he alone had seemed to be mindful of the kindnesses which he had received.
tgt_text.4197: In the second place, when the whole generation had been given over to destruction, with the exception of one single family, it followed inevitably that that remaining household should be asserted to have shown itself worthy of the divine grace, that it might be, as it were, a seed and spark of a new race of mankind.
tgt_text.4198: And what could be a greater grace and mercy than that the man, of whom this is said, should be at the same time the end and beginning of the family of mankind ?
tgt_text.4199: Why does Moses enumerate the generations of Noah with reference not to his ancestors but to his virtues ?*97.
tgt_text.4200: He does this in the first place, because all the men of that age were wicked:
tgt_text.4201: secondly, he is here imposing a law upon the will, because, to an anxious follower of virtue, virtue itself stands in the place of a real generation, if indeed men are the means of the generation of men, but the virtues of minds.
tgt_text.4202: And on this account it is that he says, be was a just man, perfect, and one who pleased God;
tgt_text.4203: but justice, and perfection, and grace before God, are the greatest of virtues.
tgt_text.4204: What was the meaning of Moses when he says, " And all the earth was corrupt in the sight of God, and the earth was filled with iniquity ?"f98.
tgt_text.4205: Moses himself has given us the reason why he speaks thus, in the sentence in which he asserts that iniquity had arisen by reason of the corruption of the earth;
tgt_text.4206: for deliverance from iniquity is righteousness, both in all the parts of the world, in heaven, that is, and earth, and among men.
tgt_text.4207: What is the meaning of his saying, " All flesh had cor­ rupted his way upon the earth ?”‡99.
tgt_text.4208: In the first place, the sacred historian calls the man who is devoted to the love of himself, flesh;
tgt_text.4209: therefore, when he had already said he was flesh, he introduces not the same flesh, but the flesh of the same being, namely, of man, or per­ haps he is speaking even of man abstractedly considered;
tgt_text.4210: for every one who passes a life destitute of all civilisation, and bewildered by intemperance, is flesh.
tgt_text.4211: In the second place, he supposes here the cause of spiritual corruption to be, as in truth it is, the flesh, because that is the seat of desire;
tgt_text.4212: and from it, as from a living spring, arise all the peculiar appetites, and passions, and other affections.
tgt_text.4213: In the third place, he very naturally says, that all flesh had corrupted his way;
tgt_text.4214: for " his" is a partial case, declined from the nominative case of the pronoun " he, she, or it;
tgt_text.4215: " for as for the being to whom we refer honour, we scarcely dare to speak of him by his own name, but we call him He.
tgt_text.4216: And it is from this that the principle of the Pythagorean philosophers was derived, who said, " He said it," speaking of their master in a glorious manner, since they feared to speak of him by name.

tgt_text.4218: for the servants, when speaking of the arrival of their master, say, " Here he comes;
tgt_text.4219: " and so when the prince of any individual city arrives, they use the same form of speech, " He comes," when they speak of him.

tgt_text.4222: since, indeed, all his good qualities, and all his marvel­ lous names, are widely celebrated by the praise bestowed upon the virtues;

tgt_text.4228: for these are the enemies and opposers of the laws of continence, and par­ simony, and chastity, and fortitude, and justice;
tgt_text.4229: by which the road which leads to God is found out and widened, so that it should everywhere be a beaten and plain road.
tgt_text.4230: What is the meaning of the statement, "All the time of man has come against me, because the earth is filled with iniquity?"*100.
tgt_text.4231: Those who resist the order of fate proceed upon these and many other arguments, especially in that of sudden death, which oftentimes produces great slaughter in a short period of time;
tgt_text.4232: as, for instance, in the overthrow of houses, in confla­ grations, in shipwrecks, in civil tumults, in battles of cavalry, in wars by land and in wars by sea, and in pestilences.
tgt_text.4233: To all those who advance arguments of this kind we repeat the same assertions which are here made by the prophet, on the principle which is derived from himself.
tgt_text.4235: All the time of man has come against me," has a meaning of this kind, the term which has been determined as the period of living for all mankind, behold it is now brought to one point and terminated at once by the deluge;
tgt_text.4236: and since this is the case, they will not live any longer according to the principle of fate which has been fixed;
tgt_text.4237: so that the time of each separate individual is now reduced to one, and has received its destined termination at the same time, by I know not what harmony and periodical revolution of the stars, by which bodies the whole race of mankind is continually pre­ served or destroyed.
tgt_text.4238: Let those, therefore, all receive these things in any manner in which they choose who study these things, and those too who argue against them.
tgt_text.4239: Nevertheless we must first of all make this statement, that nothing can be found so contrary to, so opposite to, so wholly repugnant to, the wonderful virtue of the Deity as iniquity;
tgt_text.4240: therefore, after he said, " All the time of all mankind has come up against me," he adds also the reason of its contrariety to him, that the earth is filled with iniquity.
tgt_text.4241: In the second place, Time, under the name of Chronos or Saturn, is looked upon as a god by the wickedest of men, who are desirous to lose sight of the one essential Being, on which account he says, " The time of all mankind has come up against me," because in fact the heathen make human time into a god, and oppose him to the real true God.
tgt_text.4242: But, how­ ever, it is now insinuated, in other passages also of scripture, which run thus, " Time has departed to a distance from them, but the Lord is in us just as if he were to say, time is looked upon by wicked men as the cause of the world, but by wise men and virtuous men time is not looked upon in this light, but God only, from whom all times and seasons do proceed.
tgt_text.4244: God is the cause, not of all things, but only of good things and good men, and of those men and things which are in accordance with virtue;
tgt_text.4245: for as he is free from all wicked­ ness, so likewise he cannot be the cause of it.
tgt_text.4246: In the third place, by that expression which he uses in this manner, he indicates the excess of impiety, saying, ‟ that the time of all mankind has arrived," that is to say, that all men, in every part of the world, have agreed together, with one mind, to work wickedness;
tgt_text.4247: but the other assertion which is here made, that the whole earth is filled with iniquity, amounts to this, that there is no part of it whatever free from wicked­ ness, and which is also to receive and to bear righteousness.
tgt_text.4248: And the expression, " against me," establishes the proof of what has been said, inasmuch as it is only the judgment of divine election which is altogether firm and lasting.
tgt_text.4249: WHAT is the preparation of Noah ?*1.
tgt_text.4250: If any one should wish to make an examination of the question of that ark of Noah's on more natural principles, he will find it to have been the preparation of the human body, as we shall see by the examination of each particular respect­ ing it separately.
tgt_text.4251: Why does he make the ark of squared pieces of wood ?
tgt_text.4253: He does this in the first place, because the figure of a square, wherever it may be placed, is steady and firm, consist­ ing as it does of right angles, and it is confirmed in a purer and clearer manner by the nature of the human body.
tgt_text.4254: In the second place, he does this because, although our body is an instrument, and although every portion of it is rounded off, nevertheless the limbs which are compounded of all these portions do, by some manner or other, evidently reduce that circular orb to the figure of a quadrangle or square.
tgt_text.4255: For ex­ ample, take the breast which is rather square than circular;
tgt_text.4256: in the same manner take the belly, after it is swollen with food or by any natural excess, for there are some men pot­ bellied by nature, who are to be excepted from our present argument.
tgt_text.4257: But if any one looks upon the arms and hands, and back and thighs, and feet of a man, he will find all these limbs compounded of a mixture of the square, with the cir­ cular figure at the same time.
tgt_text.4258: In the third place, a quadrangular piece of wood shows in its extension nearly every sort imaginable of uneven distinction, inasmuch as its length is greater than its breadth, and its breadth greater than its depth.
tgt_text.4259: And such also is the forma­ tion of our bodies, which are compounded of one extension which is great, of another which is of moderate size, of another which is small, great in its length and small in its depth.
tgt_text.4260: Why does God say, you shall make the ark in nests ?*3. He gives this order very naturally, for the human body is formed of holes like nests ;
tgt_text.4261: every one of which is nourished and grows like a young bird, a certain spiritual force which ex­ ists in it from its earliest origin penetrating through it, as, for instance, some of the holes and nests are the eyes, in which the faculty of sight has its abode;
tgt_text.4262: other nests are the ears, which are the place where hearing is situated.
tgt_text.4263: A third class of nests are the nostrils, in which the sense of smell is lodged.
tgt_text.4264: The fourth nest, which is of larger dimensions than those already mentioned, is the mouth, which is the seat of the taste;
tgt_text.4265: and it has been made of large size, since, besides taste, there is also another still more important instrument, which is that of articulate speech, reposing in it, namely, the tongue, which, as Socrates was wont to say, by beating in every direction in various manners, and by touching different parts, composes and forms a word, being, in truth, an instru­ ment under the immediate guidance of reason.
tgt_text.4266: And the nest is placed under the skull, and that which is called the membrane of the brain is a certain nest, as it were, of the genius of each man:
tgt_text.4267: as also the chest is a nest, in which abide the lungs and the heart, and both these things are receptacles of other internal organs;
tgt_text.4268: the lungs being the place in which the power of breathing is lodged, and the heart being the abode of both the blood and the breath, for it has two venticles, which are, as it were, a certain kind of nests or receptacles in the breast;
tgt_text.4269: blood, from which the veins, as if they could perceive its operations, are irrigated;
tgt_text.4270: and a breath­ ing-hole, which again is extended over and irrigates the per­ ceptive channels of respiration.
tgt_text.4271: And both the harder as well as the softer parts do, like nests prepared for the purpose, nourish the bones as real nests nourish young birds;
tgt_text.4272: the harder portion of which, namely, the marrow, is the nest, and the softer flesh is the nest of pleasure and pain;
tgt_text.4273: and if any one should wish to investigate the other parts, he will find that, in every respect, the nature of man has much the same foundation as the ark.
tgt_text.4274: Why does God command the ark to be smeared with pitch, both on the inside and on the outside ?*4. Pitch is so called by reason of its bird-lime like tenacity, because it glues together whatever was disunited before, so as to form one indissoluble and indivisible joint.
tgt_text.4275: For everything which is held together by bird-lime is immediately held to a natural union;
tgt_text.4276: but our body being composed of many parts is united on the outside, and is held together by its own proper habit, but the previous habit of connection which binds those things together is the soul, which, being situated in the middle, penetrates through every part till it reaches the surface, and then is turned back again from the surface to the centre, so that our spiritual nature is rolled up compactly in a double fold, being united in a firm solidity and union.
tgt_text.4277: Therefore this ark is smeared with pitch, both on the inside and the outside, for the reason here given.
tgt_text.4278: But that ark which is placed in the holy of holies, and is covered over with gold, is the similitude of the world ap­ preciable only by the intellect, as is declared in the account given of it:
tgt_text.4279: since just as there is a world appreciable by the intellect incarnate in incorporeal figures existing at the same time, consisting of a union of all figures by a certain invisible harmony ;
tgt_text.4280: for, in proportion as gold is a more noble material than pitch, in the same ratio is that ark, which is in the holy of holies, superior to this one of which we are now speaking.
tgt_text.4282: God ordained that its measure should be qua­ drangular, from a regard to usefulness;
tgt_text.4283: but his object in the other ark was not so much that it should be useful as that it should be exempt from all possibility of decay;
tgt_text.4284: for the nature of incorporeal things, appreciable only by the intellect, is to be exempt from decay, being incorruptible and permanent.
tgt_text.4285: The one ark is tossed to and fro by the winds and the waters, but the other has its station constantly in the holy of holies;
tgt_text.4286: and being stable it is akin to divine nature, as the other, which is tossed about in every direction, and moved from one place to another, is akin to and the emblem of created nature.
tgt_text.4287: Besides this, that ark of the flood being, as it were, an example of cor­ ruption, is raised on high, but the other, which is in the holy of holies, imitates the incorruptible condition of eternity
tgt_text.4288: Why did God give the measures of the ark in the following manner;
tgt_text.4289: the length to be of three hundred cubits, and the breadth thereof to be fifty cubits, and the height to be thirty cubits :
tgt_text.4290: and above it was to be raised to a point in one cubit, being brought together gradually like an obelisk ? *5.
tgt_text.4291: It was necessary that so vast a work should be con­ structed in conformity with literal directions, in order that so many animals, some of them of vast size, should be received into it, as indviduals of each class were introduced with the food necessary for them;
tgt_text.4292: but if the matter is considered pro­ perly with reference to its symbolical meaning, then, for the comprehension of the formation of our body, we shall require to make use not of the quantity of cubits, but of the certain principles and proportions which are observed in them.
tgt_text.4293: But the proportions which are contained in them are of sixfold, and double, and other portions are added.
tgt_text.4294: For three hundred is six times as many as fifty, and ten times as many as thirty;
tgt_text.4295: and again fifty is by two thirds a larger number than thirty.
tgt_text.4296: Such then are also the proportions of the body;
tgt_text.4297: for if any one should choose to investigate the matter and inquire into it carefully in all its points, he will find that man is made in an exact proportion of measurement, neither being too long or too little;
tgt_text.4298: and if a string be let down from his head to his feet, he will find that to reach that distance it requires a string six times as long as the width of his chest, and ten times as long as the depth of his ribs and thei r breadth as a second part of depth added thereto.
tgt_text.4299: Such is the certain proportion, received in accordance with nature, of the human body formed on exact measurement of the most excel­ lently made men, who are incorrect neither in the way of excess nor of defect.
tgt_text.4300: But again, it was with great wisdom and propriety that God ordained the summit to be completed in cne cubit;
tgt_text.4301: for the upper part of the ark imitates the unity of the body;
tgt_text.4302: the head being forsooth as the citadel of the king, having for its inhabitant the chief of all, the intellect.
tgt_text.4303: But those parts which are below the head are divided into separate portions, as for instance into the hands, and in an especial degree into the lower parts, since the thighs, and legs, and feet are all kept distinct from one another, therefore who­ ever should wish to understand these matters, on the prin­ ciple which I have pointed out, will easily comprehend the analogy of the cubits as I have related it.
tgt_text.4304: But above all things he must not be ignorant that each of these different numbers of cubits has separately a certain ne­ cessary proportion and principle, beginning with the first, those in the length of the ark.
tgt_text.4305: Therefore in its length it is composed of three hundred units, placed next to one another in continuation, according to the augmentation of units, from these twenty-four numbers, one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, seventeen, eighteen, nineteen, twenty, twenty- one, twenty-two, twenty-three, twenty-four.
tgt_text.4306: But the twenty- fourth number is above all others a natural number, being distributed among the hours of day and night, and also among the characters of language,* and literal speech;
tgt_text.4307: and it is also com­ pounded of three cubes, being complete, full, and compacted in equality.
tgt_text.4308: For the number three constantly exhibits, as belonging to itself, the first equality of all, having a beginning, and a mid­ dle, and an end, all of which are equal to one another;
tgt_text.4309: and eight is the first cube, because it again has declared its first equality with the rest.
tgt_text.4310: But the number twenty-four has likewise a great number of other virtues, since it is the substance of the number three hundred, as has been already pointed out;
tgt_text.4311: this then is its first virtue;
tgt_text.4312: and it has another, since it is compounded of twelve quadrangular figures, joined to one another by a continuous unity;
tgt_text.4313: and besides of two long figures, and twelve double figures, being forsooth compounded of twos separately increased by two and two.
tgt_text.4314: Therefore the angular numbers which make up together the twelve quadrangular figures are these;
tgt_text.4315: one, three, five, seven, nine, eleven, thirteen, fifteen, seventeen, nineteen, twenty-one, and twenty-three;
tgt_text.4316: but the quadrangular figure combines the following numbers, one, four, nine, sixteen, twenty-five, thirty-six, forty-nine, sixty-four, eighty-one, a hundred, a hundred and twenty-one, and a hundred and twenty-four.
tgt_text.4317: But those angular numbers which compose the other long figures are these;
tgt_text.4318: one, four, six, eight, ten, twelve, fourteen, sixteen, eighteen, twenty, twenty-two, twenty-four, being twelve in all;
tgt_text.4319: and after these come the compound numbers, two, six, twelve, twenty, thirty, forty-two, fifty-six, seventy-two, ninety, a hundred and ten, a hundred and thirty-two, and a hundred and fifty-six;
tgt_text.4321: And if you put together the twelve quadrangular figures, you will find a hun­ dred and forty-four, and if you add the other twelve long figures, you will find a hundred and fifty-six;
tgt_text.4322: and from the combination of the two you will get the number three hundred, and the concord of full, and complete, and perfect nature rising up to the equal and infinite harmony;
tgt_text.4323: for a complete and perfect nature is the maker of equality, according to the nature of a triangle;
tgt_text.4324: but the equal and the infinite are the factors of inequality, according to the composition of the other long figure.
tgt_text.4325: But the universe consists of a combination of equality and inequality, on which account the Creator himself, even amid the destruction of all earthly things, placed a sort of fixed pattern of stability in the ark.
tgt_text.4326: This then is enough to say about the number three hundred.
tgt_text.4327: We must now proceed to speak of the fifty cubits, on the fol­ lowing principle ;
tgt_text.4328: for in the first place it is composed of the right angle of the quadrangular figures;
tgt_text.4329: for a right angle is compounded of three, four, and five ;
tgt_text.4330: and the square of these, is nine, sixteen, and twenty-five, the sum total of which when added together is fifty;
tgt_text.4331: in the second place, the perfect number fifty is composed of these four triangles linked toge­ ther, one, three, six, ten;
tgt_text.4332: and again of these four equal quadrangles also united together, one, four, nine, sixteen ;
tgt_text.4333: therefore these triangles when collected together make twenty;
tgt_text.4335: and twenty and thirty added together make fifty.
tgt_text.4336: But if the triangle and the quadrangle are added together, they make a heptangular figure:
tgt_text.4337: so that it is contained by its virtue in the number of fifty, that divine and holy number;
tgt_text.4338: to which the prophet had regard when he proclaimed the jubilee festival;
tgt_text.4339: and the whole of the jubilee year is free and a deliverer.
tgt_text.4340: The third theorem is three triangles beginning with the unit, connected together in a continuous series, and three cubes beginning also with the unit, and connected together in a similar manner, which together make fifty;
tgt_text.4341: the examples of the first are one, four, and nine, which make fourteen ;
tgt_text.4342: the ex­ amples of the second are, one, eight, and twenty-seven, which together make thirty-six ;
tgt_text.4343: and the sum total of the two when added together is fifty.
tgt_text.4344: Again, thirty is in an especial manner a natural number, for as in the series of units the number three is, so is the number thirty in the series of decimals ;
tgt_text.4345: and that makes up the cycle of the moon, being the collection of separate months in full delineation ;
tgt_text.4346: secondly, it is composed of four numbers, which are united in the continual series of these quadrangular figures, one, four, nine, and sixteen, which together make up thirty;
tgt_text.4347: on which account it was not without some foundation and sufficient reason that Heraclitus called that number " genera­ tion," when he said:
tgt_text.4348: a man in thirty years from the time of his birth can become a grandfather, inasmuch as he arrives at the age of puberty in his fourteenth year, at which age he is capable of becoming a father;
tgt_text.4349: and at the end of the year his offspring arrives at the birth, and again in fifteen years more begets another offspring like himself;
tgt_text.4350: and out of these names of grandfathers, fathers, and sons, as also out of the names of grandmothers, mothers, and daughters, a generation complete in its offspring is produced.
tgt_text.4351: What is the meaning of a door in the side:
tgt_text.4352: for he says, ‟Thou shalt make a door in the side ? ” *6. That door in the side very plainly betokens a human building, which he has becomingly indicated by calling it, ‟ in the side," by which door all the excrements of dung are cast out.
