tgt_text.4792: But with respect to the inner meaning of this fact, we must say this, that when the mind is about to wash off and cleanse away its sins, then it is fit for male to live with male, that is to say, for the intellect, the chief part of the man, to be as a father, united to each separate thought, as a father to his sons, without any admixture of the female race, which is in accord­ ance with the outward sense;
tgt_text.4793: since it is a time of battle, in which it is necessary to keep the order of the cohort distinct.
tgt_text.4794: and to preserve it strictly in order, that the soldiers may not be mingled in confusion, and so, instead of gaining a victory over the enemy, be conquered themselves;
tgt_text.4795: but when the puri­ fication is completed, and when the soul is dried up from all ignorance, and when a complete deliverance from everything pernicious has taken place, then it becomes the man to collect his scattered forces together, not in order that masculine conn­ sels may be rendered effeminate by softness, but that the female race, that is to say, the outward senses, may clothe them­ selves with the vigour of the male, attaining to masculine coun­ sels, and from their receiving seed for the production of a generation ;
tgt_text.4796: so that, from this time forth they may cherish, in all things, sentiments of wisdom, and honour, and justice, and courage, and, in one word, of virtue.
tgt_text.4797: But, besides this, it will be reasonable also to take notice, that when once a confusion, in the similitude of a deluge, has overwhelmed the intellect, and when the different senses, being perplexed by the affairs of this world, like so many bulwarks erected against them, begin to quarrel, it is utterly impossible that any one should be able, either to sow, or to conceive, or to generate any good thing.
tgt_text.4798: But when all the hostile attacks of various agitations and passions are checked, and when the ceaseless invasions of lawless counsels are repressed, then the soul produces virtue and excellent works, as the most fertile portion of the earth, when dried, produces fruits.
tgt_text.4799: Why did Noah build an altar without having been com­ manded to do so ?*5 0.
tgt_text.4800: The requital of gratitude which is due to God ought to be offered to him without command, and without any delay or hesitation, showing the mind to be free from vices ;
tgt_text.4801: for it be­ comes that man, who has been endued with blessings by God, to offer him his thanks with a grateful and willing mind;
tgt_text.4802: but he who delays to do so, waiting for an express command, is ungrateful, being as it were compelled by necessity to honour his benefactor.
tgt_text.4803: Why is he said to have built an altar to God, and not to the Lord ?t51.
tgt_text.4804: In passages of beneficence and regeneration, as at the creation of the world, the sacred writer only refers to the be­ neficent virtue of the Creator, by which he makes everything in its integrity, and he implies this by concealing the royal name of Lord, as one which bears with it supreme authority;
tgt_text.4805: therefore now also, since what he is describing is the begin­ ning of the renewed generation of mankind, he borrows for his description the beneficent virtue, which bears the name of God;
tgt_text.4806: for he used the kingly attribute, which declares his imperial power, by which he is called Lord, when he was describing the punishment inflicted by the flood.
tgt_text.4807: What is the meaning of the statement, " He took of the cattle and of the flying animals, and he offered whole burnt offerings on the altar ?"*52. All this is said with reference to an inward meaning, both because he received everything from God as a favour and gift;
tgt_text.4808: and also because he took of the clean sorts of animals, and burnt those which were unpolluted and clean, as entire and pure first fruits;
tgt_text.4809: for they are proper victims for good men to offer, and are themselves entire, being full of integrity;
tgt_text.4810: and they may be classed as fruits, for fruit is the end, for the sake of which the plant exists.
tgt_text.4811: This indeed is the literal statement;
tgt_text.4812: but with respect to the inner meaning, the clean cattle and the clean birds are the outward senses and intellect of the wise man, with the thoughts which are received in his mind;
tgt_text.4813: all which things it is reasonable to offer in their integrity as entire and perfect fruit, in the way of a display of gratitude to the Father, and to offer them to him as an unpolluted and clean oblation of a victim.
tgt_text.4814: Why does he offer his sacrifice to the beneficent virtue of God, but the acceptance of it takes place by means of both the qualities of the Lord and God, for Moses says, "And the Lord God smelled a savour of sweetness ?"t53.
tgt_text.4815: He says this since, when unexpectedly, after all hope is gone, we are preserved from dangers which are coming over us, we then, looking solely at the beneficence of him who has preserved us, do, on account of our joy, display ingratitude, and refer the benefits which we have received rather to the be­ neficent power than to the Lora.
tgt_text.4816: But the beneficent preserver himself, by means of both his attributes, looks down upon and honourably accepts grateful minds, that he may not appear to halt in rewarding them;
tgt_text.4817: but he declares that such a display of, gratitude is pleasing to both attributes of the one God.
tgt_text.4818: *What is the meaning of the words, "And the Lord God said, repenting him, I will not again proceed to curse the earth for the works of man, for the thoughts of the mind of man are toward, and are diligently and ceaselessly exercised in, wickedness from his youth up;
tgt_text.4819: therefore I will not now pro­ ceed to smite all living flesh as I have done at other times ?”†54. The reasons alleged appear to indicate a change of purpose, which is an affection not usual nor akin to the divine virtue;
tgt_text.4820: for the dispositions of mankind are variable and incon­ \ stant, so that all affairs among them are altogether uncertain;
tgt_text.4821: but with God nothing is uncertain, nothing incomprehensible, for he is a being of mighty and consistent determination ;
tgt_text.4822: how then, when reasons of the same kind are present to him, be­ cause he was forsooth aware from the very beginning that the mind of man was deliberately inclined to wallow in wickedness from his youth on, could he have originally intended to destroy the human race by a flood;
tgt_text.4823: and yet afterwards say, that he did not intend to destroy it any more, when the same evils still exist in the mind ?
tgt_text.4824: But we must think that every kind of expression of this sort is, by law, connected with learning and the utility of instruction rather than with the nature of truth, since there are, as it were, two kinds which occur in the whole course of the law;
tgt_text.4825: in the first place, as it is said, “ Not as a man;
tgt_text.4826: " and in the second place, as it is said, " As a man," the one God is believed to instruct his son.
tgt_text.4827: That first expression relates to the actual truth;
tgt_text.4828: for, in real fact, God is not as a man, nor again, as the sun, nor as the heaven, nor as the world, which is perceptible by the outward senses, but as God, if it is justifiable to assert that also ;
tgt_text.4829: since that most happy and blessed being will not endure similitude, or comparison, or enigmatical description;
tgt_text.4830: nay, rather he sur­ passes even blessedness and felicity itself, and whatever can be imagined as better than and preferable to them.
tgt_text.4831: But the second expression relates to instruction and direc­ tion, I mean the express words, " As a man," in order that it may be observed, that he is willing to impress us beings, born of the earth, lest perchance we should unceasingly incur his anger and his chastisement by our implacable hostility to him, without any peace ;
tgt_text.4832: for it is sufficient for him to be roused and embittered against us once, and once to exact vengeance against sinners ;
tgt_text.4833: but to inflict punishment over and over again for the same thing is the conduct of a savage and ferocious dispo­ sition:
tgt_text.4834: since, says he, “ when I shall inflict deserved retribu­ tion, as is possible, on every one, I will cause a burning recollection of my design to be preserved.
tgt_text.4835: "Therefore behold, the sacred historian has excellently ex­ pressed himself, saying, " That God observed in his mind," for his mind and disposition rejoice in a superior degree of constancy;
tgt_text.4836: but our wills are found to be inconsistent and vacillating, on which account we cannot be properly said to observe and think with our minds, since it is by the thoughts that the passage of the mind is allowed to take place,* but the human intellect is unable to be extended over everything, since it is incapable of penetrating all things in a perfect and suitable manner.
tgt_text.4837: But that expression, " I will not proceed any more to curse the earth," is used with great propriety, for it is not becoming to add more curses to what has already been done, because the evils that have been inflicted are already complete;
tgt_text.4838: because, although they are in some sense imperfect, inasmuch as the Father is kind and merciful, and most humane, still he is rather inclined to alleviate the evil than to add to men's misery.
tgt_text.4839: But that is as it were the same thing, according to a common proverb, to wash a brick, or to draw water properly, and wholly to eradicate wickedness, with all its deeply im­ printed tokens from the mind of man;
tgt_text.4840: for if it is implanted in it at first, it does not exist accidentally, but is engraven deeply on it and clings to it.
tgt_text.4841: But since the mind is a potential and principal part of the soul, he introduces that word " diligently;
tgt_text.4842: " but that which has been weighed with diligence and care is exquisite thought, examined more certainly than certainty itself.
tgt_text.4843: But this diligence does not tend to any one evil, but as is plain, to mischief, and to all mischief;
tgt_text.4844: nor does it exist in a per­ functory manner;
tgt_text.4845: but man is devoted to it from his youth, not only in a manner, but from his very cradle, as if he were in some degree united to, and nourished, and bred up with sin.
tgt_text.4846: But yet God says, " I will not any more smite all flesh giving notice that he will not, at any future time, destroy every portion of mankind altogether, but only single indi­ viduals, in ever such great numbers, who perpetrate un­ speakable wickednesses;
tgt_text.4847: for he does not leave wickedness unpunished, nor does he grant it liberty or impunity, but indulging his care for the human race on account of his original design, he of necessity fixes destruction as a punish­ ment for sinners.
tgt_text.4848: What is the meaning of the expression, " Sowing-time and harvest, cold and heat, summer and spring, shall not cease day nor night ?"*55. If taken literally this expression signifies the con­ tinuation of the duration of the annual seasons, and that the earthly temperature adapted to animals and plants is not again to be destroyed ;
tgt_text.4849: since indeed, if the weather is corrupted it would corrupt them likewise, and if it is preserved in its existing state it would preserve them also safe and sound;
tgt_text.4850: for it is according to the weather and temperature that all animals and plants are preserved safe and sound, without any infirmity, being accustomed, in some measure, to be produced separately, in an admirable way, and to grow up together.
tgt_text.4851: But nature is like a liar­ mony, composed of opposite sounds, both flat and sharp ;
tgt_text.4852: for thus, also, the world is compounded of opposite qualities, for when, in the first place, the mortal commixtures of cold and heat, of moisture and dryness, preserve their natural order, without any confusion, they are themselves a cause which prevents destruction from overwhelming everything upon the earth.
tgt_text.4853: But if we regard the inward sense of the passage, the seed time is the beginning and the harvest time is the end, and both the beginning and the end are concurrent causes of safety, for either thing alone is by itself imperfect, be­ cause the beginning requires an end, and the end has a natural inclination for the beginning;
tgt_text.4854: but cold and heat bring round winter and autumn;
tgt_text.4855: for the autumn is fiery, but only in such a degree as succeeding in its annual re­ volution to cool the fiery summer.
tgt_text.4856: And, symbolically, with reference to the mind, cold indicates fear, since it causes terror and trepidation;
tgt_text.4857: but heat indicates anger, because an angry disposition bears in itself a resemblance to flame and fire;
tgt_text.4858: for it is necessary that those things should always exist and always remain among created and corruptible beings;
tgt_text.4859: since summer and spring have been instituted for the production of fruits;
tgt_text.4860: spring for the perfecting of the seeds, and summer for the perfecting of fruits and the buds of trees.
tgt_text.4861: These things indeed are discerned symbolically in addition to the inward sense of the words, producing a double fruit;
tgt_text.4862: what is necessary being computed in the season of spring, and what is superfluous in the summer.
tgt_text.4863: Therefore neces­ sary food is for the most part for the body, being whatever is produced freely from seeds;
tgt_text.4864: as virtues are necessary for the soul.
tgt_text.4865: But as many fruits as come by way of excess from trees in summer, besides the advantage which they are to the body, do also bring corporeal goods to the mind, as external advantages:
tgt_text.4866: for these external advantages are subservient to the body, and the body is subservient to the mind, and the mind to God.
tgt_text.4867: But day and night are the measures of times and numbers ;
tgt_text.4868: and time and number exist without interruption.
tgt_text.4869: Day indicates lucid wisdom, and night betokens obscure folly.
tgt_text.4870: Why was it that God, blessing Noah and his sons, said, “ Increase, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and rule over it;
tgt_text.4871: and let your fear and the dread of you be upon all beasts, and upon flying fowls, and upon reptiles, and upon the fishes which I have placed under your hand ? " *56. This devotion of the inferior animals to man, God also at the beginning of the creation bestowed on the sixth day upon man, after he had created him in his own image;
tgt_text.4872: for the scripture saith, " And God made man;
tgt_text.4873: in the image of God created he him;
tgt_text.4874: male and female created he them.
tgt_text.4875: And God blessed them, and said, Be fruitful,-and multiply, and replenish the earth ;
tgt_text.4876: and be ye lords over it, and be ye rulers of the fishes, and of the flying fowls, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth.
tgt_text.4877: "And did he not by these words evidently intimate that Noah, at the beginning of what we may call the second creation of mankind, was found equal in honour to that creature who in the first instance was made as to his form in the likeness of himself?
tgt_text.4878: Therefore he equally assigned both to the one and to the other the principality and power over all the creatures that live upon the earth.
tgt_text.4879: But do thou diligently take notice that he showed this man, who at the time of the deluge was the only just man and the king of all the creatures which live upon the earth, to be equal in honour, not to the identical man who was first created and formed out of the earth, but to that one who was made according to the likeness and form of the true in­ corporeal entity, to whom also he gives power, making him a king, not the very created man (or the man formed out of the earth), but him who is according to his form and similitude, that is to say, incorporeal.
tgt_text.4880: Wherefore also the creation of that man, who as to his form is incorporeal, was marked to have taken place on the sixth day, in accordance with the perfect number six;
tgt_text.4881: but the creation of that man who was created after the com­ pletion of the world and subsequent to the generation of all animals on the seventh day, because it is after that that the manly figure was fashioned out of clay.
tgt_text.4882: Therefore after the days of generation he says, " on the seventh day of the world;
tgt_text.4883: " for God had not yet rained upon the earth, and no man did exist who could cultivate the earth.
tgt_text.4884: And then he proceeds to say, " But God formed a man out of the clay of the earth, and breathed into his face the breath of life, and man became a living soul.
tgt_text.4885: "Therefore how he can be made worthy of the same kingly power according to the image of the man thus formed, he, I mean, who is the beginning of the second creation of man­ kind, is indicated by the letter of the history that relates these events.
tgt_text.4886: But with reference to the inward sense of the passage we must give an explanation in the following manner.
tgt_text.4887: God wills that the souls of wise men should increase in the magnitude and multitude of the beauty of their virtues, and should fill the mind as if it were the earth with those beauties, leaving no portion empty and void so as to become occupied by folly.
tgt_text.4888: And he wills also that they should rule over, and strike terror into, and inflict alarm upon all beasts;
tgt_text.4889: that is to say, he wills that all wickedness should be subdued by their will, since wickedness is of an untamed and savage nature.
tgt_text.4890: Also he willed that they should be lords over all flying fowls, which by reason of their lightness are raised on high, being armed with courage and empty pride, and which thus cause the greatest mischief, being scarcely controlled at all by fear.
tgt_text.4891: Moreover, he made them rulers over all creeping things, which are the symbols of destructive vices, for they creep through the whole soul, namely, concupiscence, desire, sadness, and cowardice, striking and goading;
tgt_text.4892: as also they are indicated by the fishes, which eagerly cultivate a moist and delicate life, but one which is far from being sober, wise, or lasting.
tgt_text.4893: Why does God say, "Every creeping thing which lives shall be to you for food ? " *57.
tgt_text.4894: Creeping things are of a twofold nature;
tgt_text.4895: some being venomous, and others domestic.
tgt_text.4896: The venomous ones are serpents, which, instead of feet, use their bellies and breasts, creeping upon the earth;
tgt_text.4897: but the domestic ones are those which have legs above their feet.
tgt_text.4898: This is the literal meaning of the statement.
tgt_text.4899: But if we look to the inward sense of it, then the creeping things represent the foul vices, but the clean ones repre­ sent joy;
tgt_text.4900: for in connexion with the passion of concupiscence there will exist joy and pleasure;
tgt_text.4901: and in connexion with desire there will be will and counsel, and in connexion with sorrow goading and compunction, and in connexion with avidity there will be fear.
tgt_text.4902: Therefore such disordered perturbations of the passions threaten souls with death and destruction;
tgt_text.4903: but the joys do really live, as he himself has warned us in an allegory;
tgt_text.4904: and they also give life to those who possess them.
tgt_text.4905: What is the meaning of the expression, " As the green herb I have given you all things ? " *58. Some persons say that by this expression, "As the green herb I have given you all things," the eating of flesh was permitted.
tgt_text.4906: But I say that even though God had intended to give that permission, still that before all things he must have intended to establish by law the necessary use of herbs, that is to say of vegetables.
tgt_text.4907: And under the general name of herb he includes all the other additional descriptions of green food, without mentioning them ex­ pressly in the law.
tgt_text.4908: But now the power of this command is adapted not to one nation alone among all the select nations of the earth which are desirous of wisdom, among which religious continence is honoured, but to all mankind, who cannot possibly be universally prohibited from eating flesh.
tgt_text.4909: Nevertheless, perhaps the present expression has no re­ ference to eating food, but rather to the possession of the power to do so;
tgt_text.4910: for in fact every herb is not necessarily good to eat, nor again is it the uniform and invariable food of all uniform living animals;
tgt_text.4911: since God said that some herbs were poisonous and deadly, and yet they are included in the number all.
tgt_text.4912: Perhaps therefore, I say, he means to express this, that all brute beasts are subjected to the power of man, as we sow herbs and take care of them by the cultivation of the land.
tgt_text.4913: What is the meaning of the expression, " You shall not eat flesh in the blood of its life ? " t59.
tgt_text.4914: God appears by this command to indicate that the blood is the substance of the soul;
tgt_text.4915: I mean of that soul which exists by the external senses and by vitality, not of that which is spoken of with a certain especial pre-eminence, being the rational and intellectual soul;
tgt_text.4916: for there are three parts of the human soul;
tgt_text.4917: one the nutritive part, another that which is connected with the external senses, and the third that which exists in reason.
tgt_text.4918: Therefore the rational pare is the substance of the divine spirit according to the sacred writer Moses:
tgt_text.4919: for in his account of the creation of the world, he says, " God breathed into his face the breath of life," as being what was to constitute his life.
tgt_text.4920: But of that part of the soul which is connected with the external senses and with vitality, blood is the substance ;
tgt_text.4921: for he says in another place, "The blood exists in every breath of flesh.
tgt_text.4922: "It is with great propriety in fact that he has called the blood the breath of all flesh, because there are in the flesh senses and passions, but not intellect nor thoughts.
tgt_text.4923: But again by the expression "the spirit of blood," he intimates that the spirit is one thing and the blood another;
tgt_text.4924: so that the essence of the soul is truly and beyond all possible question spirit.
tgt_text.4925: But that spirit has a place not by itself separately, apart from the blood in the body;
tgt_text.4926: but it is interwoven and mingled with the blood.
tgt_text.4927: As also the veins which exhibit a pulse, as if they were vessels to convey breathing, bear with them most unmixed and pure air, but blood likewise, though perhaps in a less degree;
tgt_text.4928: for there are two vessels, the veins and the breathing channels;
tgt_text.4929: but the veins have more blood than breath, and the breathing channels have more breath than blood.
tgt_text.4930: Therefore the proper admixture in each vessel is distinct, as the greater and the lesser proportion.
tgt_text.4931: This is the meaning of these words when taken literally;
tgt_text.4932: but if we look to their inner meaning, he calls the blood of the soul that warm and fiery virtue belonging to it which we name courage.
tgt_text.4933: And he who is full of this wisdom despises all food, and every pleasure of the belly, and of those parts which are below the belly.
tgt_text.4934: But if any one adopts a profli­ gate life, and becomes a wanderer like the wind, and gradually inactive from laziness and a luxurious life, he in fact does nothing else but fall upon his belly, as a reptile creeping upon the earth, and greedily licking up earthly things, closing his life without ever tasting of that heavenly food which the souls which are desirous of wisdom receive.
tgt_text.4935: What is the meaning of the expression, "The blood of your souls will I require from every beast, and from the hand of man's brother will I require the life of man ? " *60. The multitude of creatures which do injury is'two­ fold;
tgt_text.4936: some being beasts, and others men.
tgt_text.4937: But beasts are rather the least injurious of the two, because they have no actual familiarity with those whom they wish to injure, principally because they do not fall under their power, but destroy those who have properly power over them.
tgt_text.4938: But when he speaks of brothers, he means men who are murderers, intimating these three things.
tgt_text.4939: First of all, that all we men are akin to one another, and are brothers, being connected with one another according to the relation of the highest kind of kindred;
tgt_text.4940: for we have received a lot, as being the children of one and the same mother, rational nature.
tgt_text.4941: In the second place, he intimates that very commonly numerous and terrible quarrels arise, and acts of treachery take place, between relations, and rather between brothers, on account of the division of their inheritance, or on account of some superiority of dignity in the household;
tgt_text.4942: since a quarrel between those of the same family is worse and alto­ gether unseemly, because brothers who are really so by the ties of nature meet in contest with a great knowledge of one another's internal circumstances;
tgt_text.4943: being therefore well aware what kind of attack they must employ in their present warfare.
tgt_text.4944: But, in the third place, as it appears to me, be employs the appellation of brothers in order to warn men of the im­ placable and severe punishment which is reserved for mur­ derers;
tgt_text.4945: that they, without meeting any compassion, shall suffer what they have inflicted;
tgt_text.4946: for they have not slain strangers, but their own brothers in blood.
tgt_text.4947: It is with exceeding great propriety that he calls
tgt_text.4948: God the protector and overseer of those who are slain by man ;
tgt_text.4949: for although men despise the revenge, yet let them not behave negligently, but although impure men of savage disposition escape for the moment from danger, still let them know that they are already caught and brought before the greater tribunal of justice, namely, before the divine judgment­ seat, which rises up to inflict vengeance on the wicked for the defence of those who have received shameful and un­ worthy treatment.
tgt_text.4950: This is the literal meaning of the words;
tgt_text.4951: but if we look to the inward sense of them they have a regard to the merit of the purity of the soul, to which it is suitable to avoid unceas­ ing destruction brought in from outward parts;
tgt_text.4952: which merit, that propitious and beneficent being, the most merciful and only Saviour, does not despise;
tgt_text.4953: but he expels and destroys all its enemies who stand around it, calling them beasts, and men brothers;
tgt_text.4954: for beasts are asymbolical expression for furious men threatening calamitous death;
tgt_text.4955: but men and brothers are both separate individual thoughts, and words uttered by mouth and tongue, because they are akin to them, and, by consequence, they bring on great and destructive evils, leaving no stone unturned, no work or word omitted to do injury.
tgt_text.4956: What is the meaning of the expression, "Whoso sheddeth man's blood by man shall his blood be shed ? "*61.
tgt_text.4957: There is no excess in this declaration, but rather an indication of a still more formidable denunciation, because he says, " He himself shall be poured out like blood who pours out blood."
tgt_text.4958: For that which is poured out flows forth and is lost, so that it has no longer any power or substance.
tgt_text.4959: And by this he shadows forth the fact that the souls of those who perpetrate unworthy actions imitate the mortal body in its corruption, as far as corruption is accustomed to come upon individuals;
tgt_text.4960: for the body is then dissolved into those parts of which it was composed, returning into its proper elements.
tgt_text.4961: But the miserable soul, labouring under distresses, is borne hither and thither by the overflow of a lascivious life;
tgt_text.4962: and the very evils which have grown up along with it are accustomed to suffer the same overflow, in the manner of the parts of the limbs.
tgt_text.4963: Wby is it that he speaks as if of some other god, saying that he made man after the image of God, and not that he made him after his own image ?
tgt_text.4965: Very appropriately and without any falsehood was this oracular sentence uttered by God, for no mortal thing could have been formed on the similitude of the supreme Father of the universe, but only after the pattern of the second deity, who is the Word of the supreme Being;
tgt_text.4966: since it is fitting that the rational soul of man should bear before it the type of the divine Word;
tgt_text.4967: since in his first Word God is superior to the most rational possible nature.
tgt_text.4968: But he who is superior to the Word holds his rank in a better and most singular pre-eminence, and how could the creature possibly exhibit a likeness of him in himself ?
tgt_text.4969: Nevertheless he also wished to intimate this fact, that God does rightly and correctly require vengeance, in order to the defence of virtuous and consistent men, because such bear in themselves a familiar acquaintance with his Word, of which the human mind is the similitude and form.
tgt_text.4970: What is the meaning of the words, " There shall not again be a deluge to destroy all the earth ? "*63.
tgt_text.4971: By his last saying he declares sufficiently that there may be various inundations, but that there shall never be one of such a character as to be able to change the whole earth into a lake or sea.
tgt_text.4972: This is the literal meaning of this saying.
tgt_text.4973: But if we look to its inward sense, there a divine kindness is intimated, according to which, although it is not every part of the soul which is allowed to make proficiency in every virtue, still some are adorned in a considerable degree.
tgt_text.4974: So that, supposing any one is not able to display excellence in his whole body, he still may labour with all diligence to acquire all the means in his power to display excellence;
tgt_text.4975: and that exertion is within his reach.
tgt_text.4976: And it does not follow that if any one is less highly endowed, or is unable to make every portion of his life altogether perfect, that he is on that account to despair of those things which he is able to do and to attain to.
tgt_text.4977: Since as there is power in every individual, he who does not exert himself in accordance with it is both idle and ungrateful;
tgt_text.4978: idle because of his laziness, and ungrateful because, though he has received most excellent means, he still sets himself in opposition to the essential qualities of things.
tgt_text.4979: Why does God say that, as a sign that he will never again bring a deluge over the whole earth, he will place his bow in the clouds ? †64.
tgt_text.4980: Some persons imagine that by the bow he means that thing which by some is called Jupiter's belt, from its figure, dwelling on its continual similitude to the rainbow ;
tgt_text.4981: but I do not perceive that that has been positively asserted.
tgt_text.4982: In the first place, because the bow aforesaid ought to have a pe­ culiar and essential nature of its own, because it is called the bow of God ;
tgt_text.4983: for he says, " I will set my bow in the clouds."
tgt_text.4984: But that which belongs to God and is said to have been set in any place as his, indicates plainly that it is not devoid of essence or of substance.
tgt_text.4985: But the belt of Jupiter has not, properly speaking, any separate nature of its own, but is merely an appearance of the solar rays on a wet cloud, all the phenomena of which are non-existent and incorporeal.
tgt_text.4986: And moreover, this is a further proof of that, that it is never seen at night, though clouds exist by night as well as by day.
tgt_text.4987: In the second place, we must also say that even in the day-time, when clouds obscure the whole face of heaven, the belt of Jupiter is never at all seen in them.
tgt_text.4988: But what remains may also be affirmed without any falsehood, when the Maker of the law says, "I will set my bow in the clouds;
tgt_text.4989: " for, behold, while clouds are present there is no appear­ ance of the belt of Jupiter visible.
tgt_text.4991: Where there is a collection of clouds let there be a bow seen in the clouds."
tgt_text.4992: Still it often happens, when the clouds are col­ lected and when the air is obscured and thickened, that no appearance of a rainbow is seen anywhere.
tgt_text.4993: We must consider, therefore, whether haply the sacred historian indicates something else by this mention of the bow, namely, that in the very exercise of the mercy of God, and also in the moment of his bitterness towards men on earth, there still shall not be any ultimate destruction of them, in the fashion of a bow, which is too soft and unfit for such a purpose, nor shall there be any violence added, so as to cause a rapid destruction, but there shall be a mode­ rate determination, each attribute being carefully measured;
tgt_text.4994: for the great deluge took place with a breaking asunder and disruption of the clouds and of all things ;
tgt_text.4995: as he himself asserts, when he says, " The fountains of the deep were broken up."
tgt_text.4996: And yet it was not an unmeasured vehemence.
tgt_text.4997: Moreover, a bow is not itself a weapon, but only an in­ strument for the use of weapons, namely, for the arrow which strikes ;
tgt_text.4998: and the arrow being sent forth by means of the bow strikes a part which is at a distance, while the parts which are nearest to it remain unhurt.
tgt_text.4999: And this is given as a proof that the whole earth shall never for the future suffer any deluge, since no one arrow ever hits all places, but only those which are at a distance.
tgt_text.5000: Therefore the divine virtue, being invisible, is symbolically indicated by the bow in the cloud;
tgt_text.5001: being in truth dissolved according to the figure of tranquillity, and condensed in ac­ cordance with a cloud;
tgt_text.5002: so that it does not permit all the clouds to be altogether dissolved into water, so that the earth may not be made a lake by an inundation, which it carefully forbids, and arranges the condensation of air, checking it as by a bridle, though it is at that time the more accustomed to exhibit itself as rebellious by reason of its excessive fulness.
tgt_text.5003: For by reason of the clouds it also shows itself to be replenished, dripping, and saturated.
tgt_text.5004: Why is it that after the sons of the just man have been named Shem, Ham, and Japhet, he relates only the genera­ tions of the middle one, saying, " And Ham was the father of Canaan;
tgt_text.5005: " and afterwards be adds, “These are the three sons of Noah65.
tgt_text.5006: Mentioning four men, Noah and his sons, he says that these were obedient.
tgt_text.5007: Because the grandson Canaan was in his habits like his father who begat him, on that account, instead of mentioning only one, he includes both in his enumeration, so that they are four in number, three in virtue.
tgt_text.5008: But in the meantime in the scripture he mentions only the generations of the middle one, on account of the just man whom he is going to speak of subsequently, because although he was his father, since Ham is the father of Canaan, still he does not mention the father with blame, but with respect to the man with whom he thought it fair that the son should be a partaker, he yet did not give the father a participation with him.
tgt_text.5009: In the second place, perhaps he thus gives a premonitory warning also to those persons who by the acuteness of their mental vision can see a long way off what is at a distance, namely, that he designs to take away the land of the Canaan­ ites from them after the lapse of many ages, and to give it to his chosen people who are thoroughly devoted to God.
tgt_text.5010: Therefore he chooses to designate the chief inhabitant of that region, namely Canaan, and to show that he both practised singular and peculiar wickedness of his own, and also' all the wickedness of his father, so that in every part he might be convicted of an ignoble slavery and submission.
tgt_text.5011: This is the literal meaning of these words.
tgt_text.5012: But if we have a regard to the inward sense, he does not say that Ham had a son named Canaan, but he predicates offspring of him alone, saying, “Ham was the father of Canaan."
tgt_text.5013: Since such a disposition as that of Ham is always the father of such designs as those of Canaan, and that the very names themselves intimate this.
tgt_text.5014: For if we translate them into another language, Ham means heat or hot;
tgt_text.5015: and Canaan means merchants, or buyers, or causes, or recipients.
tgt_text.5016: Accordingly, he is not now speaking manifestly of genera­ tions, nor is he saying that one man is the father or the son of another man, but he is evidently demonstrating the connec­ tion between one counsel and another, by reason of its alienation from all familiarity with virtue.
tgt_text.5017: What is the meaning of the statement, " Noah began to be a cultivator of the earth ? "*66.
tgt_text.5018: He is here comparing Noah to the first created man who was formed out of the earth ;
tgt_text.5019: for in that manner also does he speak of him when he came forth out of the ark;
tgt_text.5020: since both then and now there took place a first beginning of the cultivation of the land, each being after a deluge.
tgt_text.5021: For also, at the time of the original creation of the world the earth was, as it were, a lake, being covered by an inunda­ tion of water, for the sacred historian could not tell us that God said," Let the waters be gathered together into one body, and let the dry land appear," unless it had previously been inundated with waters which now returned into certain depths of the earth.
tgt_text.5022: Nor again is the expression a purposeless one," He began to be a tiller of the earth," for in the second generation he was himself the beginning of men, and also of seed, and of the cultivation of the land, and of the life of all other things.
tgt_text.5023: This is the literal meaning of the words.
tgt_text.5024: But if we look to their inner sense, a distinction is made between being a cultivator of the earth and a tiller'of it;
tgt_text.5025: as the murderer of his brother is represented as tilling the earth, but not as cultivating it.
tgt_text.5026: For by the earth o ur body is symbolically represented, which is by its nature earthly, and which the unjust and wicked man tills like a lazy hireling, but which the man endued with virtue cultivates like a skilful manager of plants and an agriculturist of good works appointed to superintend it.
tgt_text.5027: Because the workman of the body, the mind, as being carnal, procures carnal pleasures;
tgt_text.5028: but the cultivator of the earth is careful to produce useful fruits, those, namely, which are to be obtained by the study of continence, and modesty, and sound wisdom ;
tgt_text.5029: and he prunes away all superfluous excesses and bad habits which spring up around, like the thin and misplaced branches of trees.
tgt_text.5030: Why does the just man first plant a vineyard ?
tgt_text.5031: *It was very natural for it to be a subject of anxiety and doubt to him in what quarter he was to find any plants after the deluge, when everything upon the earth was destroyed.
tgt_text.5032: Therefore it appeared natural, as was said a little while ago, that the earth was made dry in the spring season;
tgt_text.5033: therefore when the spring produced the buds of trees, the roots and stems of the vine could easily be found by the just man still alive, and might thus be collected by him.
tgt_text.5034: But we have to consider why the first thing he did was to plant a vineyard, and why he did not rather sow wheat and barley, since the latter are necessary productions of the earth, without which life cannot be supported, but the former is only a material for superfluous pleasure.
tgt_text.5035: The answer is that Noah, adopting a salutary design, consecrated and offered up to God those things which are necessary to support life and which require no co-operation for the production of the fruit;
tgt_text.5036: but the superfluous plants he devoted to men;
tgt_text.5037: for the use of wine is superfluous and not necessary.
tgt_text.5038: As therefore God ordered fountains of water fit to drink to burst up from the earth without the co-operation of man, so he also of his own accord granted to man in a similar manner wheat and barley, in order that he himself might be the sole giver of each kind of food which serves for necessary eating and drinking.
tgt_text.5039: But he did not take away the power nor grudge them providing for themselves by their own industry those things which contribute to pleasure.
tgt_text.5040: What is the meaning of the statement, " He drank of the wine and was drunken ?" *68.
tgt_text.5041: In the first place, the just man did not drink the wine, but a portion of the wine, not the whole of it;
tgt_text.5042: in which case an incontinent and debauched man does not quit his means of debauchery, till he has first swallowed all the wine that there is before him ;
tgt_text.5043: but by the religious and sober man everything necessary for food is used in a moderate degree.
tgt_text.5044: And the expression, " be was drunken," is here to be taken simply as equivalent to " he used the wine."
tgt_text.5045: But there are two modes of getting drunk, the one is that of an intemperate sottishness which misuses wine, and this offence is peculiar to the depraved and wicked man;
tgt_text.5046: the other is the use of wine, and this belongs to the wise.
tgt_text.5047: It is therefore in the second of these meanings that the consistent and wise Noah is here called drunken, not as having misused but as having used wine.
tgt_text.5048: What is the meaning of the statement, " He was naked in his house?
tgt_text.5050: This is a praise of the wise man both in the literal sense of the words, and also in their hidden meaning, that his exhibition of nakedness took place not out of doors but in his house, being concealed by the roof and walls of his house;
tgt_text.5051: for the nakedness of the body is concealed by a house which is made of stones and beams of wood:
tgt_text.5052: but the covering and clothing of the soul is the discipline of wisdom.
tgt_text.5053: Therefore there are two kinds of nakedness, one which takes place by accident, which is the result of an involuntary offence, because the just man, using, if Imay say so, his honesty as if it were a garment with which he is clothed, stumbles out of his own accord like men who are intoxicated, or who are afflicted with insanity;
tgt_text.5054: for in such men their offences are not deliberately committed :
tgt_text.5055: but it is his task and pleasing duty to clothe himself, as with a garment, with the discipline and study of honesty.
tgt_text.5056: There is also another kind of nakedness of the soul which is caused by perfect virtue, which expels from itself the whole carnal weight of the body, as if it were flying from a tomb, as indeed it has long been buried in it as in a tomb ;
tgt_text.5057: as also it avoids pleasures, and also a great number of miseries arising from the different passions and many anxieties arising from misfortunes, and indeed all the evil effects of these different circumstances.
tgt_text.5058: He therefore, who has been able with distinction to pass through such various and great dangers, and to escape such injuries, and to emancipate himself from such evils, has attained to the destiny of hap­ piness, without any stain or disgrace ;
tgt_text.5059: for I should pronounce this to be the ornament and badge of beauty in those individuals who have been rendered worthy to pass their existence in an incorporeal manner.
tgt_text.5060: Why is it that the sacred writer has not simply said, Ham saw his nakedness, but Ham the father of Canaan saw the nakedness of his father ? *70.
tgt_text.5061: By stating the fact thus, he both blames the son in the father and the father in the son, as performing together in common the deed of folly, and iniquity, and impiety, and every other kind of wickedness.
tgt_text.5062: This is the literal meaning of the statement;
tgt_text.5063: and as to the inner sense, we must look at that in the same manner in which we have hitherto treated these subjects.
tgt_text.5064: What is the meaning of the statement, " He told it to his two brothers out of doors ? " t71. The sacred historian is here adding to the gravity of the transaction.
tgt_text.5065: In the first place, because he did not report the involuntary evil of his father to one brother only, but to both of them ;
tgt_text.5066: and no doubt if he had had any more he would have told it to them all, as he did in fact to every one he could;
tgt_text.5067: and he did so with ridicule in his very words, making a jest of what ought not to have been treated with laughter and derision, but rather with shame and fear min­ gled with reverence.
tgt_text.5069: when the historian says he told it them, not in the house but out of the house, he evidently points out that he displayed his father when naked, not only to his brothers, but also to the bystanders with whom they were, both men and women.
tgt_text.5070: This is the literal information conveyed by the words.
tgt_text.5071: But if we look to their inward meaning, then we shall see that a depraved and malignant habit of life is full of derision and contempt:
tgt_text.5072: and it is a bad thing to judge of the miseries of others even by one's self like a chastising judge.
tgt_text.5073: But in this case what has happened is worse than this, for any man with a joyful mind to ridicule the involuntary misfortune of a devoted disciple of wisdom, and to make a song of and proclaim abroad his misery, is the part of a thoroughly hostile accuser, who ought rather to have pardoned such an occurrence than to have added accusation or vituperation to it.
tgt_text.5074: Moreover, because these three things are, as I have said before, as it were brothers together ;
tgt_text.5075: namely, good, bad, and indifferent, being all the offspring of one parent thought:
tgt_text.5076: in accordance with each of these principles, they have been found to be overseers, some celebrating virtues with praise, others upholding acts of malignity, and others supporting riches and honours and other good things which, however, are not attached to and which are external to the body.
tgt_text.5077: The overseers who emulate wickedness rejoice at the fall of the wise man, and ridicule and disparage him, as if he had done no good by the part which he adopts and to which he applies himself as better for the mind, or for his body, or for his external circumstances, to his internal virtues or to any of the good things which are around and exterior to his body.
tgt_text.5078: Unless indeed that man alone is eminently able to attain his object, who applies himself to iniquity, as that alone is ac­ customed to confer advantages on human life.
tgt_text.5079: Pronouncing these and similar precepts, those who are overseers of iniquity ridicule those who devote themselves to virtue, and to those things by which virtue is produced and consolidated:
tgt_text.5080: as some look upon those things to be which are around the body, and outside it, and which may be regarded in the light of instruments serving to that end.
tgt_text.5081: What is the meaning of the statement, " Shem and Japhet, taking a garment, laid it upon both their shoulders and went backwards, and covered the nakedness of their father, and they themselves did not see it ? " *72. The literal meaning of the statement is evident;
tgt_text.5082: but with respect to the inner sense contained in it, we must say that the light man who is in too great haste only sees those things which are before his eyes and exposed to his sight:
tgt_text.5083: but that the evil man also sees those things which are at his back, that is to say, the future.
tgt_text.5084: And since what is posterior is postponed to what is an­ terior, so is what is future to what is present, the sight of which is peculiar to the virtuous and wise man, who in truth is a second Lynceus, being according to the fables gifted with eyes in every part.
tgt_text.5085: Therefore every wise man, who is not so much man as actual intellect, walks backward, that is to say, he sees what is behind him or future, as if it were placed in brilliant light;
tgt_text.5086: and seeing every thing on all sides of him with a perfect sight, and looking all around him, lie is found to be armed, and protected, and fortified, so that no part of his soul is ever found naked or in an unseemly plight, on ac­ count of any accidents which occur unfortunately.
tgt_text.5087: What is the meaning of the statement, " And Noah became sober after the wine ? "†73. The literal meaning is too notorious.
tgt_text.5088: Therefore we need only here speak of what concerns the inner sense of the words.
tgt_text.5089: When the intellect is strengthened, it is able by its soberness to discern with a certain accuracy all things, both before and behind it, both present, I mean, and future;
tgt_text.5090: but the man who can see neither what is present nor what is future with accuracy, is afflicted by blindness;
tgt_text.5091: but he who sees the present, but who cannot also foresee the future, and is not at all cautious, such a man is over­ come by drunkenness and intoxication ;
tgt_text.5092: and he, lastly, who is found to be able to look all around him, and to see, and discern, and comprehend the different natures of things, both present and future, the watchfulness of sobriety is in that man.
tgt_text.5093: Why is it that after the sacred historian has enumerated Ham in the middle of the offspring of Noah, or has placed him in the middle between his brethren, he nevertheless points out that he was the younger, saying, " Noah saw what his younger son had done to him ? ” *74. This is a manifest allegory, because he here takes as the younger, not him who was so in age and in point of time, but him who was younger in mind;
tgt_text.5094: since wickedness is unable to attain to a perception of the learning which is proper to the elder;
tgt_text.5095: but the elder thoughts belong to a will which is truly growing old, not indeed in body, but in mind.
tgt_text.5096: Why did Noah when praying for Shem speak thus:
tgt_text.5097: " Blessed is the Lord God, the God of Shem:
tgt_text.5098: and Canaan shall be his servant ?" t75.
tgt_text.5099: The names Lord and God are here used together on account of his principal attributes, both of benevolence and of kingly power by which the world was created;
tgt_text.5100: for as king he created the world according to his beneficence;
tgt_text.5101: but after he had completed it then the world was arranged and set in order by his attribute of kingly power.
tgt_text.5102: Therefore he at that time rendered the wise man worthy of a common honour, which the whole world also received, all the parts of the world being formed in an admirable manner with the attributes of the Lord and God, doing so by his especial prerogative, munificently pouring forth the favour and liberality of his beneficent power.
tgt_text.5103: And it is on this account that the beneficent power of God is mentioned twice.
tgt_text.5104: Once, as has been already stated, being placed in opposition to his kingly power;
tgt_text.5105: and a second time without any such connexion, in order, forsooth, that the wise man having been rendered worthy of his gifts, both such as are common to him with others and such as are peculiar to himself, he might also be rendered acceptable both to the world and to God;
tgt_text.5106: to the world on account of the excellence imparted to him in common with it, and to God for such as was peculiar to himself.
tgt_text.5107: Why, when Noah prayed for Japhet, did he say, " God shall enlarge Japhet, and bid him to dwell in the house of Shem :
tgt_text.5108: and Canaan shall be their servant ? " *76. Without examining the literal statement, for the meaning of that is plain, we had better approach the inner sense contained in it, and examine that, in which the second and third blessings mentioned are capable of an enlarged and ample extension.
tgt_text.5109: As, for instance, good health, and a vigorous state of the outward senses, and beauty, and strength, and opulence, and nobleness of birth, and friends, and the power of a prince, and numbers of other things.
tgt_text.5110: And on this account he said, " God shall enlarge," &c.
tgt_text.5111: Because taken separately, the abundant possession of such numerous and great blessings has of itself been injurious to many persons who have scarcely dwelt with justice, or wisdom, or any other virtues, the complete pos­ session of which dispenses to man-in an admirable manner the advantages which are external to and which surround the body;
tgt_text.5112: but the deprivation or absence of them leaves him without the enjoyment or use of them;
tgt_text.5113: and man, if deprived of all good protectors, and of the use of these enjoyments, is exposed to as much suffering as he is capable of.
tgt_text.5114: Therefore he prays on behalf of the man who has those things which are around and exterior to the body, that he may dwell in the house of the wise man ;
tgt_text.5115: so that attending to the rules of all good men he may see and regulate his own course by their example.
tgt_text.5116: Why because Ham bad sinned did God pronounce that his son Canaan should be the servant of Ham and Japhet ? t77.
tgt_text.5117: In the first place, God pronounced this sentenc3 because both father and son had displayed the same wicked­ ness, being both united together and not separated, and both indulging in the same disposition.
tgt_text.5118: But in the second place, he did so because the father would be exceedingly afflicted at the curse thus laid upon the son, being sufficiently conscious that he was punished not so much for his own sake as for that of his father.
tgt_text.5119: And so the leader and master of the two suffered the punishment of his wicked counsels, and words, and actions.
tgt_text.5120: This is the literal meaning of the statement.
tgt_text.5121: But if we look to its inward meaning, then in reality they are no more two different men than two different dispositions.
tgt_text.5122: And this is made plain by the names given to them, which manifestly denote the nature of the facts;
tgt_text.5123: for Ham being interpreted means heat or hot;
tgt_text.5124: and Canaan means mer­ chants or causes.
tgt_text.5125: Why was it that Noah lived after the deluge three hundred and fifty years ? *78.
tgt_text.5126: It is now declared that in two periods of seven years the form of the world was originally created and now renewed under Noah.
tgt_text.5127: But the wise man lives for a period of fourteen quarters of a century;
tgt_text.5128: and fourteen times twenty-five is equal to seven times fifty, or fifty times seven.
tgt_text.5129: And it is the principle of the seventh year and also of the fiftieth, which has an especial order of its own explained and ordained in Leviticus.
tgt_text.5130: Why among the three sons of Noah does Ham appear always to occupy the middle place, but the two extremities are varied ;
tgt_text.5131: for when their birth is mentioned, Shem is placed in the first rank, in this manner, Shem, Ham, and Japhet ;
tgt_text.5132: but when they are spoken of as fathers, then Japhet is mentioned first, and the beginning of the enume­ ration of the nation is derived from Japhet himself?
tgt_text.5134: Those who inquire into the literal nature of the divine writings think thus of the order in which these men are mentioned, looking upon him who is the first named, that is Shem, as the younger;
tgt_text.5135: and upon him who is named the last, that is Japhet, as the elder.
tgt_text.5136: However they may choose to think of this let them, being guided by the principle of mere opinion.
tgt_text.5137: But we who look to the real meaning of these statements think that there is here a reference to the three things, good, bad, and indifferent;
tgt_text.5138: which last are called secondary goods;
tgt_text.5139: and we must there­ fore think that the sacred writer always puts the bad in the middle, so that being confined at either extremity it may be subdued on one side by the one, and on the other side by the other;
tgt_text.5140: so that, being confined, it may be kept in and subdued.
tgt_text.5141: But the good and the indifferent, or secondary good, change the order with one another;
tgt_text.5142: for when there is such great evil present, and yet not wholly and altogether, the good rejoices in the first place, having the position of the dispenser and chief of the whole.
tgt_text.5143: But when it is placed in the position of the will in a state of conspiracy, and injustice remains not only in the intellect but is also conducted to its end by unjust works, then that first good is changed from its original order into another place, together with all the good habits which depend upon it, rejecting all education and all arrangement, as being wholly unable to attain its proposed end, just as a physician does when he sees an in­ curable disease.
tgt_text.5144: But the elder good manages that virtue which is around the body and exterior to it;
tgt_text.5145: therefore, by observing the extremities with greater caution, and closing in the beast within its toils, it is sufficiently demonstrated that it does not dare to bite or injure any more.
tgt_text.5146: But while it feels that it has done no injury, it is transferred into a more secure and more permanent position, and then, a higher and better fortified place being assigned to it, it easily retains the lower position too as one easy to be preserved;
tgt_text.5147: for, in con­ sequence of the superior power of its guardian, it is always practicable to watch it closely, since nothing is more mighty than virtue.
tgt_text.5148: Why do the people of Ceos, and of Rhodes, and the isles of the Gentiles, spring from Japhet ?*So.
tgt_text.5149: Since he has the name denoting breadth (namely Japhet), being expanded in his growth and increase, that part of the things of the world which have been assigned by nature for the use of mankind, that is to say, the earth, can no longer hold him, therefore he passes over into the other part, that is to say, the sea and the islands belonging to it.
tgt_text.5150: This is the literal meaning of the statement.
tgt_text.5151: But if we look to its inner sense, all the external bless­ ings which are bestowed by nature, such as riches, and honour, and principalities, are lavished and poured forth in every direction on those men into whose hands they come, and are also extended widely to others who are not so much within reach;
tgt_text.5152: so that in a greater, or at all events, in no less a degree do they surround and hem the man in, in accordance with the greediness of the lovers of riches and glory, since they are eager for principalities, and are never satisfied be­ cause of their insatiable desires.
tgt_text.5153: Why the eldest son of Ham is Chus.*81.
tgt_text.5154: The sacred historian has here produced a word most completely in accordance with nature, saying that Chus was the elder son of evil, Chus being the dissolved and loose nature of the earth, for the earth, when dense and fertile, and moist, is full of herbs, and hills, and trees, and is well arranged for the production of different fruits;
tgt_text.5155: but when dissolved and reduced to dust and dry, it is unfruitful and barren ;
tgt_text.5156: and besides it is tossed about in the air, when it is raised from the ground by the wind, by its dust making the air all alive.
tgt_text.5157: Such as this is the first origin and the first shoots of evil being destitute of the generation of good pursuits, and the cause of barrenness to the soul and to all its parts.
tgt_text.5158: Why was Chus the father of Nimrod, who began to be a giant and a hunter before the Lord:
tgt_text.5159: on which account they said, " Like Nimrod the mighty hunter before the Lord ?
tgt_text.5160: "tThe father in this case, having a nature truly dissolute, does not at all keep fast the spiritual bond of the soul, nor of nature, nor of consistency of manners, but rather like a giant born of the earth, prefers earthly to heavenly things, and thus appears to verity the ancient fable of the giants and Titans ;
tgt_text.5161: for in truth he who is an emulator of earthly and corruptible things is always engaged in a conflict with heavenly and admirable natures, raising up earth as a bul­ wark against heaven ;
tgt_text.5162: and those things which are below are adverse to those which are above.
tgt_text.5163: On which account there is much propriety in the expres­ sion, he was a giant against God, which thus declares the opposition of such beings to the deity ;
tgt_text.5164: for a wicked man is nothing else than an enemy, contending against God:
tgt_text.5165: on which account it has become a proverb that every one who sins greatly ought to be referred to him as the original and chief of sinners, being spoken of " as a second Nimrod.
tgt_text.5166: "Therefore his very name is an indication of his character, for it is interpreted Æthiopian, and his art is that of hunting, both of which things are detestable :
tgt_text.5167: an Æthiopian because unmitigated wickedness has no participation in light, but imitates night and darkness :
tgt_text.5168: and the practice of the hunts­ man is as much as possible at variance with rational nature, for he who lives among wild beasts wishes to live the life of a beast, and to be equal to the brutes in the vices of wicked­ ness.
tgt_text.5169: WHAT is the meaning of the expression, "I am the Lord thy God who brought thee out of the land of the Chaldæans to give thee this land for an inheritance ? " *1. As the literal statement is plain enough, we need only consider the inner meaning, which was meant to be inter­ preted in this manner.
tgt_text.5170: The law of the Chaldæans taken symbolically is mathema­ tical speculation, one part of which is recognised to be astronomy, which the Chaldæans study with great industry and with great success.
tgt_text.5171: Therefore God is here honouring the wise man with a gift;
tgt_text.5172: in the first place, by taking men out of the sect of the astrologers, that is to say, away from the hallucinations of the Chaldseans, which, as they are diffi:
tgt_text.5173: cult to detect and refute, are found to be the cause of great evils and wickedness, since they ascribe the attributes of the Creator to created things, and persuade men to worship and to venerate the works of the world as God.
tgt_text.5174: In the second place, God honours him by granting to him the wisdom which bears fruit, which he has here symboli­ cally called the earth ;
tgt_text.5175: but the Father of the universe shows that wisdom and virtue are invariable and immutable, since it is not consistent with his character that God should show to any one that which can undergo any variation or change, for that which is shown by the being who is immutable and consistent must be so too;
tgt_text.5176: but that which is liable to change, as being incessantly in the habit of suffering varia­ tion, admits of no proper or divine demonstration.
tgt_text.5177: Why does he say, " Lord, by what shall I know that I shall inherit it ? " *2. He here is seeking a sign for a ratification of the promise ;
tgt_text.5178: but two things only are described deserving of study ;
tgt_text.5179: one that which is an affection of the mind, namely, the belief in God according to his literal word;
tgt_text.5180: the other a being borne on with the most exceeding desire not to be left in want of some signs, by which the hearer may feel, to the conviction of his outer senses, a confirmation of the promise :
tgt_text.5181: and to him who has given the promise he offers worthy veneration by the appellation, " Lord.
tgt_text.5182: "For by this title he says, I know thee to be the Lord and prince of all things, who art also able to do all things, and there is no disability with thee.
tgt_text.5183: But in truth, if I have already given credence to thy promise, still I nevertheless wish to obtain speedily if not a completion of it, yet at all events some evident signs by which its consummation may be indicated ;
tgt_text.5184: in truth I am thy creature, and even if I were to arrive at the highest degree of excellence, I am not always able to restrain the violence of my desire, so as not, when I have seen or heard anything good, to be contented with obtaining it slowly and not immediately;
tgt_text.5185: therefore I entreat that thou wilt give me some means of knowledge, by which I may comprehend those future events.
tgt_text.5186: Why is it that he says, " Take for me a heifer of three years old, and a goat of three years old, and a raven of three years old, and a turtle dove and a pigeon ? "
tgt_text.5188: He here mentions five animals, which are offered on the sacred altar;
tgt_text.5189: for these are divided into classes of victims, three kinds of terrestrial animals, the ox, the goat, and the sheep;
tgt_text.5190: and two kinds of birds, the turtle dove and the pigeon;
tgt_text.5191: for the sacred writer constantly tells us that the everlasting reverence of victims derived its origin from the patriarch, who was also the origin of the race :
tgt_text.5192: but instead of the expression, " Bring to me," he has very admirably used the words, " Take for me;
tgt_text.5193: " since there is nothing especi­ ally and peculiarly belonging to the creature, but everything is the gift of and blessing bestowed by God, who is altoge­ ther willing that when any one has received anything he should offer thanks for it with all his heart.
tgt_text.5194: But he orders him to take every animal at the age of three years ;
tgt_text.5195: since three is a full and perfect number, con­ sisting of a beginning, a middle, and an end;
tgt_text.5196: but still we may raise the question, why of these three animals, he takes two females, the heifer, and the she-goat, and one male, the ram;
tgt_text.5197: may it not be perhaps because the heifer and the she- goat are offered as an atonement for sin;
tgt_text.5198: but the sheep is not, as sin arises from frailty, and the female is frail ?
tgt_text.5199: This much I have thought fit to say with especial appo­ siteness to this question;
tgt_text.5200: but I am not however ignorant that all things of this kind offer a handle to those who wish to cavil, to disparage the sacred scriptures;
tgt_text.5201: therefore in this instance they say that there is nothing here described and indicated but a command to sacrifice, by the division of the animals and an examination of their entrails ;
tgt_text.5202: and what is visible in them they affirm to be an indication of what is convenient, and of the similitude which arises from things visible.
tgt_text.5203: But those men, as it appears to me, are of that class which forms a part alone from a judgment of the whole, but which on the contrary does not from a judgment of a part form the whole, which last is the better way of coming to an opinion, as being that by which both the name and the fact are altogether established.
tgt_text.5204: Therefore the giving of the Jaw, that is to say the sacred scriptures, that I may so express myself, is a sort of living unity, the whole of which one ought to examine carefully with all one's eyes, and so discern with truth, and certainty, and clearness, the universal intention of the whole of the scripture without dissecting or lacerating its harmony, or disuniting its unity;
tgt_text.5205: by any other mode everything would appear utterly inconsistent and absurd, being disso­ ciated from all community or equity.
tgt_text.5206: What then is the intention of the delivery of the law as exhibited to us ?
tgt_text.5207: It is scientific, and so is everything which describes scientific species ;
tgt_text.5208: since the offering of sacrifice and all science admits of a consistent usage, and of expressions well adapted to them, and of various opinions, by which not only the footsteps of truth are occupied, but sometimes are even darkened, as affection is by flattery;
tgt_text.5209: but in such way that the very things which are genuine and established by experiment are perverted by things which are both inconsistent and unproved.
tgt_text.5210: And the natures of the animals above mentioned have an intimate connection with the parts of the universe;
tgt_text.5211: the ox is connected with the earth, as being an animal employed in drawing the plough and in tilling the earth;
tgt_text.5212: the goat again is connected with the water (it is called in Greek and Arme­ nian ἀἴξ, or ajx), being an animal deriving its name from driving and rushing on (from ἄγω or ἀΐσσω) ;
tgt_text.5213: since water is an impetuous thing, and the course of rivers, and the extent of the breadth of the sea, and the sea itself agitated as it is by its ebb and flow, are witnesses of the propriety of the name and of the closeness of the connection.
tgt_text.5214: And the ram (aries) is connected with the air, as being a very violent and vivacious animal, on which account too the ram is more useful to mankind than any other animal as affording them raiment.
tgt_text.5215: Therefore, on account of these reasons, as I think, God orders him first to take these two female animals, the cow and the she-goat;
tgt_text.5216: since both these elements, earth and water, are material, and for the most part feminine.
tgt_text.5217: But the third he will have a male, namely the ram;
tgt_text.5218: becaues the air or wind has been explained as masculine;
tgt_text.5219: since the natures of all things are divided into bodies or into earth and water, and female animals exist by nature.
tgt_text.5220: But that which exhibits a similitude to the soul is arranged under the head of air and the breath of life.
tgt_text.5221: And this, as I have said, is masculine.
tgt_text.5222: If therefore we arc to call that masculine which is the moving and active cause we must call that feminine which is moved and passive.
tgt_text.5223: But the whole heaven is found to be familiarly connected with flying birds such as the pigeon and turtle dove, being distributed as it is into the rotatory path of the planets and fixed stars.
tgt_text.5224: Therefore he dedicates the pigeon to the planets, for that is a tame and domestic animal, as also the planets are more familiarly connected with us as being nearer to the earth, and as having sympathies with us;
tgt_text.5225: but he consecrates the turtle dove to the fixed stars, for that animal is a lover of solitude, and flees from the conversation of the multitude, and from all connection of every kind.
tgt_text.5226: And so also the globe itself is remote, and a thing which wanders into the furthest extremities of the world.
tgt_text.5227: Therefore both the species of these two birds are assimi­ lated to the divine attributes, since as Plato, the disciple of Socrates, says it is fitting that the heaven should have a swift chariot by reason of its very swift rotatory motion, which in fact surpasses even the birds themselves in the velocity of their course.
tgt_text.5228: But the birds above mentioned are singers;
tgt_text.5229: the prophet indicating by an enigmatical expression that perfect music which exists in heaven harmoniously adapted from the motion of the stars, since it is a proof of human art when the corresponding music of the voices of animals and of living instruments is adapted together by the industry of genius.
tgt_text.5230: But this heavenly music has been abundantly extended over the earth by the Creator, as he has also extended the rays of the sun, being always prompt to exer­ cise his beneficent care for the human race.
tgt_text.5231: For such music excites frenzy in the ears, and brings un­ restrained pleasure to the mind;
tgt_text.5232: and so causes men to forget even their meat and drink, and even when hunger brings death to the door to be willing even to die out of a desire to hear music.
tgt_text.5233: And if the song of the Sirens, * as Homer tells us, invites the heavens so forcibly, that they forget while listening to it, their country, their houses, their friends, and necessary food;
tgt_text.5234: how much more must that most perfect and consum­ mate music, so truly heavenly and endowed with the highest degree of harmony, when it touches the organs of the ear, compel men to go mad and to yield to rapture.
tgt_text.5236: — Next, where the Sirens dwell, you plough the seas;
tgt_text.5237: Their song is death, and makes destruction please.
tgt_text.5238: Unblest the man, whom music wins to stay Nigh the curst shore, and listen to the lay;
tgt_text.5239: No more that wretch shall view the joys of life, His blooming offspring, or his beauteous wife !
tgt_text.5240: In verdant meads they sport, and wide around Lie human bones that whiten all the ground;
tgt_text.5241: The ground polluted floats with human gore, And human carnage taints the dreadful shore."
tgt_text.5242: And further on in the same book, the poet describes the effect of these songs upon Ulysses.
tgt_text.5246: 0 cease thy course and listen our to lay !
tgt_text.5247: Blest is the man ordained our voice to hear, The song instructs the soul, and charms the ear.
tgt_text.5249: thy soul shall into raptures rise!
tgt_text.5251: and learn new wisdom from the wise !
tgt_text.5252: We know whate'er the kings of mighty name Achieved at Hion in the field of Fame;
tgt_text.5253: Whate'er beneath the sun's bright journey lies.
tgt_text.5254: 0 stay and learn new wisdom from the wise !
tgt_text.5255: "But the reason on account of which every one of the animals to be offered is to be three years of age has already been explained ;
tgt_text.5256: and we must now discuss it under another form of mystery, since it has been seen that every one of those things which were called into existence and subsequently to the moon, such as the earth, water, and air, rejoice in an order connected with the number three.
tgt_text.5257: In the divisions of earth there is a vast quantity of dry continent, islands and peninsulas.
tgt_text.5258: Water is divided into sea, rivers, and lakes;
tgt_text.5259: and the air into the two equinoxes, the vernal and the autumnal;
tgt_text.5260: and they may be taken as one, for they have an equal proportion of day and night, and accord­ ingly the equinoxes are neither hot nor cold.
tgt_text.5261: Add to these the changes of summer and winter, for the sun is borne through those three circles into the seasons of summer, winter, and the equinoxes.
tgt_text.5262: Therefore, in the first place, the natural arrangement will be of this kind;
tgt_text.5263: and the moral arrange­ ment is properly thus.
tgt_text.5264: In every one of us there are three things flesh, the outward sense, and reason;
tgt_text.5265: therefore the calf exhibits a familiarity with the corporeal substance, since our flesh is subdued by, and kept in subservience to, and in connection with the ministrations of life ;
tgt_text.5266: also their nature is female according to matter, being calculated rather to be passive and to be subject rather than to be active.
tgt_text.5267: But the similitude of the she-goat isconnectedwith the com­ munion of the outward senses, either because all the objects of those outward senses are each borne towards their ap­ propriate sensation, or because each impulse and motion of the soul takes place in consequence of an imagination formed of the objects received through the medium of the external senses.
tgt_text.5268: And this is followed, in the first place, by a certain inflexion or alienation, which by some is called an occasion, that is to say, an impulse affecting each kind of sense.
tgt_text.5269: But since the female is the outward sense, as being passive in consequence of what is subjected to the outward senses, therefore God has adapted to it a female animal, the she-goat.
tgt_text.5270: But the ram is akin to the word, or to reason.
tgt_text.5271: In the first place, because it is a male animal;
tgt_text.5272: secondly, because it is a working animal;
tgt_text.5273: and thirdly, because it is the cause of the world, and of the firmament;
tgt_text.5274: that is to say, the ram is so by means of the clothing which it supplies;
tgt_text.5275: and reason, or the word, is so in the arrangement of life;
tgt_text.5276: for whatever is not irregular and absurd immediately exhibits reason.
tgt_text.5277: And there are two species of reason ;
tgt_text.5278: the one derived from that nature by which the affairs of the world subjected to the outward senses are finished;
tgt_text.5279: the other from that of those things which are called incorporeal species, by which the affairs of that world which is the object of the intellect are brought to their accomplishment.
tgt_text.5280: Therefore the pigeon and the turtle dove are found to resemble these.
tgt_text.5281: The pigeon, forsooth, resembles speculation in natural phi­ losophy ;
tgt_text.5282: for it is a more familiar bird, as the objects of the outward sense are exceedingly familiar to the sight:
tgt_text.5283: and the soul of the inquirer into natural science flies upward as if it were furnished with wings ;
tgt_text.5284: and being borne aloft is carried round the heaven, discerning every part of everything,and the principles of every separate thing;
tgt_text.5285: for the turtle dove imitates that species which is the subject of intellect and incorporeal;
tgt_text.5286: for as that animal is fond of solitude, so it is superior to the violent species which come under the outward sense, associat­ ing itself as it does with the invisible species by its essence.
tgt_text.5287: Why does he say, "And he took unto him all these things ? " *4. He has added also that expression, "
tgt_text.5288: And he took unto him," with especial propriety;
tgt_text.5289: for it is the sign of a soul thoroughly imbued with the love of God to ascribe whatever good and noble theories and feelings it receives, not unto itself, but wholly to God who is the giver of all benefits.
tgt_text.5290: What is the meaning of, " He divided them in the middle and laid the pieces opposite to one another ? " t5.
tgt_text.5291: Also the whole structure of the body, as of flesh, is to be looked at in such a light as this according to its whole creation;
tgt_text.5293: not as they are divided and placed opposite to one another;
tgt_text.5294: but, being naturally inclined to one another, and having a mutual regard to one another, on account of their natural co-operation;
