tgt_text.3586: and if she is such an one, let her keep what I have given her-the instruction and the connection of reason with life and of life with reason, and, what is the most necessary of all things, surety and faith.
tgt_text.3587: But let us not be laughed at as appearing to have given gifts which were not merited, while we think that we gave what is most suitable to the soul;
tgt_text.3588: for I, indeed, did what was proper for a man to do who wished to make experiment of and to test her disposition, throwing out a bait and sending a mes­ senger ;
tgt_text.3589: but he has showed me that her nature is not easily caught.
tgt_text.3590: And it is not clear to me why it is not easily caught;
tgt_text.3591: for I have seen ten thousand persons of the extremely wicked class doing the same things as those who are extremely good, but not with the same purpose, since the one class has truth and the other only hypocrisy, and it is very hard to distinguish the one from the other, for very often reality is overpowered by appearance.
tgt_text.3593: Also the person who loves virtue seeks a goat by reason of his sins, but does not find one;
tgt_text.3594: for, already, as the sacred scripture tells us, " it has been burnt.”*
tgt_text.3595: Now we must consider what is intimated under this figurative expres­ sion—how never to do any thing wrong is the peculiar attri­ bute of God;
tgt_text.3596: and to repent is the part of a wise man.
tgt_text.3597: But this is very difficult and very hard to attain to.
tgt_text.3598: Accordingly the scripture says that Moses sought and sought again" a reason for repentance for his sins in mortal life;
tgt_text.3599: for he was very anxious to find a soul which was stripped of sill, and coming forward naked of all offence without shame.
tgt_text.3600: But nevertheless he did not find one, the flame, I mean by this the very quickly moving irrational desire, rushing inwards and devouring the whole soul.
tgt_text.3601: For what is smaller in numbers is usually overpowered by what is more numerous, and what is slower by what is more speedy, and what is to come hereafter by what is present.
tgt_text.3602: Now what is contracted in quantity, and slow, and future, is repentance;
tgt_text.3603: what is numerous, and swift, and conti­ nuous in human life is, iniquity.
tgt_text.3604: Very naturally, therefore, when any one falls into error, he says that he is unable to eat of what is offered by reason of his sins, so that his conscience will not permit him to be nourished by repentance;
tgt_text.3605: on which account it is said in the scripture, “Moses heard, and it pleased him."t
tgt_text.3606: For the things which relate to the creature are very far removed from the things which relate to God ;
tgt_text.3607: for to the creature only those things which are visible are known, but to God, even those things also which are invisible.
tgt_text.3608: And that man is crazy who, speaking falsely instead of truly, while still committing iniquity, asserts that he has repented.
tgt_text.3609: It is like as if one who had a disease were to pretend that he was in good health;
tgt_text.3610: for he, as it seems, will only get more sick, since he does not choose to apply any of the remedies which are conducive to health.
tgt_text.3612: On one occasion Moses was urged on, by a desire of learning, to investigate the causes through which'the most necessary of the things in the world are brought to perfection;
tgt_text.3613: for seeing how many things come to an end, and are produced afresh in creation, being again destroyed, and again abiding, he marvelled, and was amazed, and cried out, saying, " The bush (βάτος) burns, and is not consumed.”*
tgt_text.3614: For he does not trouble his head about the inaccessible (ἄβατος) country as being the abode of divine natures.
tgt_text.3615: But now that he is about to undertake a labour which will have no success and no end, he is relieved by the mercy and providence of God, the Saviour of all men, who has given warning out of his holy shrine, " Do not approach near this place," which is equivalent to, Do not approach this consideration ;
tgt_text.3616: for it is a business requiring more labour, and more energy, and care, and fondness for investiga­ tion than can be suited to human power.
tgt_text.3617: But be content with admiring what is created;
tgt_text.3618: and do not be over-curious about the causes why each thing is created or destroyed."
tgt_text.3619: For the place," says God, “on which thou standest is holy ground."t
tgt_text.3620: What kind of place is that?
tgt_text.3621: Is it not plain that it is that which relates to the principles of causes, which is the only one that he has adapted to the divine natures, not think­ ing any more competent to aim at a clear understanding of the principles of causes ?
tgt_text.3622: But he who, out of his desire for learn­ ing, has raised his head above the whole world begins to inquire concerning the Creator of the world who this being is who is so difficult to see and whose nature it is so difficult to conjecture, whether he is a body, or an incorporeal being, or something above these things, or whether he is a simple nature like a unit, or a compound being or any ordinary existing thing.
tgt_text.3623: And when he sees how difficult to ascertain, and how difficult to understand this is, he then prays to be allowed to learn from God himself who God is ;
tgt_text.3624: for he has never hoped to be able to learn this from any other of the beings that are around him.
tgt_text.3625: But nevertheless, though inquiring into the essence of the living God he has heard nothing.
tgt_text.3626: For, says God, " thou shalt see my back parts, but my face thou shalt not behold.”*
tgt_text.3627: For it is sufficient for the wise man to know the consequences, and the things which are after God ;
tgt_text.3628: but he who wishes to see the principal essence will be blinded by the exceeding brilliancy of his rays before he can see it.
tgt_text.3630: Having now said thus much concerning the third head of our subject, we will proceed to the fourth and last of the propositions we proposed to examine, according to which discovery sometimes comes to meet us without there having been any search.
tgt_text.3631: To this order belongs every self-taught and self-instructed wise man ;
tgt_text.3632: for such an one has not been improved by consideration, and care, and labour, but from the first moment of his birth he has found wisdom ready prepared and showered upon him from above from heaven, of which he drinks an unmixed draught and on which he feasts, and con tinues being intoxicated with a sober intoxication with correct­ ness of reason.
tgt_text.3633: This is the man whom the law calls Isaac, whom the soul did not conceive at one time and bring forth at another, for says the scripture, " having conceived him she brought him forth," t as if without any consideration of time.
tgt_text.3634: For it was not a man who was now being thus brought forth, but a conception of the purest character, beautiful rather in its nature than in consequence of any study ;
tgt_text.3635: for which reason also she who brings him forth is said to have given up the usual manner of women, that is to say her usual, and reasonable, and human customs.
tgt_text.3636: For the self-taught race is something new, and beyond any description, and truly divine, existing not by any human conceptions, but by some inspired frenzy.
tgt_text.3637: Are you ignorant that the Hebrews stand in no need of midwives for their delivery?
tgt_text.3638: But they, as Moses says, “bring forth before the midwives can arrive," by which is meant that they have nature alone for a coadjutor, without having any need of methods, or arts, or sciences.
tgt_text.3639: And Moses gives very beautiful and very natural definitions of what is taught a man by himself:
tgt_text.3640: one being such a thing as is speedily discovered, the other what God himself, has given us ;
tgt_text.3641: accordingly, that which is taught by others requires a long time, but what is taught a man by himself is quick, and in a manner independent of time.
tgt_text.3642: And the one again has God for its expounder, but the other has man.
tgt_text.3643: Now the first definition he has placed in the question, " What is this that thou has found so quickly, 0 my son?”*
tgt_text.3644: But the other is contained in the answer to this question, “What the Lord God gave unto me.
tgt_text.3646: There is also a third definition of what is taught a man by himself, namely that which of its own accord rises upwards.
tgt_text.3647: For it is said in the hortatory injunctions, “ Ye shall not sow, neither shall ye reap those things which arise from the earth of their own accord."
tgt_text.3648: tFor nature has no need of any art since God himself sows those things, and by his agricultural skill brings to perfection, as if they grew of themselves, things which do not grow of themselves, except inasmuch as they stand in need of no human assistance whatever.
tgt_text.3649: But this is not so much a positive exhortation as an announcement of his opinion, for if he had been giving a positive recommendation he would have said, "Do not sow, and do not reap:
tgt_text.3650: " but as he is only giving his opinion, he says, " Ye shall not sow, neither shall ye reap."
tgt_text.3651: For as to those things with which we meet by the voluntary bounty of nature, of these we cannot find either the beginnings or the ends in ourselves as if we were the causes of them :
tgt_text.3652: therefore the beginning is the seed-time and the end the harvest time.
tgt_text.3653: And it is better to understand these things thus:
tgt_text.3654: every beginning and every end is spontaneous, that is to say, it is the work of nature and not of ourselves.
tgt_text.3656: what is the beginning of learning.
tgt_text.3657: It is plain that it is a nature in the person who is taught which is well calculated to receive the particular subjects of meditation submitted to him.
tgt_text.3658: Again what is the beginning of being made perfect ?
tgt_text.3659: If we are to speak plainly without keeping anything back, it is nature.
tgt_text.3660: Therefore he who teaches is also indeed to effect improvement, but it is God alone, the most excellent nature of all, who is able to conduct one to supreme perfection.
tgt_text.3661: He who is bred up among such doctrines as these has ever­ lasting peace, and is released from wearisome and endless labours.
tgt_text.3662: And according to the lawgiver there is no difference between peace and a week;
tgt_text.3663: for in each creation lays aside the appearance of energising and rests.
tgt_text.3664: Very properly, therefore, si it said, "
tgt_text.3665: And the sabbath of the law shall be food for you," speaking figuratively.
tgt_text.3666: For the only thing which is really nourishing and really enjoyable is rest in God ;
tgt_text.3667: which confers the greatest good, undisturbed peace.
tgt_text.3668: Peace, therefore, among cities is mixed up with civil war;
tgt_text.3669: but the peace of the soul has no mixture in it of any kind of difference.
tgt_text.3670: And the lawgiver appears to me to be recommending most manifestly that kind of discovery which is not preceded by any search, in the following words, “ When the Lord thy God shall lead thee into the land which he swore to thy fathers that he would give to thee, large and beautiful cities which thou buildedst not, houses full of all good things which thou filledst not, cisterns hewn out of the quarries which thou hewedst not, vineyards and olive gardens which thou plantedst not."*
tgt_text.3671: You see here the ungrudging abundance of all the great blessings which are ready, and poured forth for man's possession and enjoyment.
tgt_text.3672: And the generic virtues are here likened to cities, because they are of the most comprehensive kind;
tgt_text.3673: and the specific virtues are likened to houses, because they are contracted into a narrower circle;
tgt_text.3674: and the souls of a good disposition are likened to cisterns, which are well inclined to receive wisdom, as the cisterns are calculated to receive water ;
tgt_text.3675: and the improvement, and growth, and production of fruit, are compared to vineyards and olive gardens;
tgt_text.3676: and the fruit of knowledge is a life of contemplation, which produces unmixed joy, equal to that which proceeds from wine, and a light appreciable only by the intellect, as if from a flame of which oil is the nourishment.
tgt_text.3678: Having now said thus much on the subject of discovery, we will proceed in due order to what comes next in the context.
tgt_text.3679: Moses proceeds, " Therefore the angel of the Lord found her sitting by a fountain of water."
tgt_text.3680: Now a foun­ tain is spoken of in many senses ;
tgt_text.3681: in one manner our mind is meant by a fountain, in another the rational habit and instruction;
tgt_text.3682: in a third sense a bad disposition is intitimated ;
tgt_text.3683: in a fourth sense a good disposition, the contrary of the pre­ ceding ;
tgt_text.3684: in a fifth sense, the Creator and Father of the universe is himself thus spoken of in a figure;
tgt_text.3685: and there are passages written in the sacred scriptures which give proofs of these things.
tgt_text.3686: What they are we must now consider.
tgt_text.3687: Now in the very beginning of the history of the law there is a passage to the following effect:
tgt_text.3688: " And a fountain went up from the earth, and watered all the face of the eartb.”*
tgt_text.3690: then, who are not initiated in allegory and in the nature which loves to hide itself, liken the fountain here mentioned to the river of Egypt, which every year overflows and makes all the adjacent plains a lake, almost appearing to exhibit a power imi­ tating and equal to that of heaven;
tgt_text.3691: for what the heaven during winter bestows on other countries, the Nile affords to Egypt at the height of summer;
tgt_text.3692: for the heaven sends rain from above upon the earth, but the river, raining upward from below, which seems a most paradoxical statement, irrigates the corn-fields.
tgt_text.3693: And it is starting from this point that Moses has described the Egyptian disposition as an atheistical one, because it values the earth above the heaven, and the things of the earth above the things of heaven, and the body above the soul;
tgt_text.3694: but, how­ ever, we shall have an opportunity of speaking on these sub­ jects hereafter when occasion permits.
tgt_text.3695: But at present, for we must study not to be too prolix, we had better have recourse to an explanation which may be drawn from looking on the words as used figuratively ;
tgt_text.3696: and we may say that the meaning of the statement that “ a fountain went up and watered all the face of the earth," is something of this kind.
tgt_text.3697: The dominant part of us, like a fountain, pours forth many powers through the veins of the earth as it were, till they reach the organs of the external senses, that is to say, the eyes, and ears, and nostrils, and other organs;
tgt_text.3698: and these organs in every animal are situated about the head and face.
tgt_text.3699: Therefore, the face, which is the dominant portion of the body, is irrigated as from a fountain from the dominant portion of the soul;
tgt_text.3700: making the spirit, which is calculated for seeing.
tgt_text.3701: reach to the eyes, that which has the power of hearing reach the ears, the spirit of smelling reach the nostrils, that of taste the mouth, and causing that of touch to pervade the whole surface of the body.
tgt_text.3703: There are also many various fountains of instruc­ tion, by means of which most nutritious reasonings have sprung up like the trunks of palm-trees;
tgt_text.3704: " for," says Moses, " they came to Aileim, and in Aileim there were twelve foun­ tains of water and seventy trunks of palm-trees.
tgt_text.3705: And they pitched their tents there by the side of the water."*
tgt_text.3706: The name Aileim is interpreted to mean " vestibules," a symbol of the approach to virtue.
tgt_text.3707: For as vestibules are the beginning of a house, so also are the encyclical preliminary branches of instruction the beginning of virtue, and twelve is the perfect number, of which the circle of the zodiac in the heaven is a witness, studded as it is with such numbers of brilliant con­ stellations.
tgt_text.3708: The periodical revolution of the sun is another witness, for he accomplishes his circle in twelve months, and men also reckon the hours of the day and of the night as equal in number to the months of the year, and the passages are not few in which Moses celebrates this number, describing the twelve tribes of his nation, appointing by law the offering of the twelve cakes of shew'bread, and ordering twelve stones, on which inscriptions are engraved, to be woven into the sacred robe of the garment, reaching down to the feet of the high­ priest, on liis oracular dress.
tgt_text.3709: He also celebrates the number seven, multiplied by the number ten;
tgt_text.3710: at one time speaking of the seventy palm-trees by the fountains, and in other passages he speaks of the elders, who were only seventy in number, to whom the divine and prophetical Spirit was vouchsafed.
tgt_text.3711: And again, it is the same number of heifers which are sacrificed at the solemn fes­ tival of the feast of tabernacles,t in a regular and proper division and order, for they are not all sacrificed together, but in seven days, the beginning being made with thirteen bulls;
tgt_text.3712: for thus, by every day subtracting one till they come to the number seven, the arranged number of seventy is properly -completed.
tgt_text.3713: And when they have come to the gates of virtue, the pre­ liminary liberal sciences, and have seen the fountains, and the stems of the palm-trees growing by them, they are said to pitch their tents, not by the palm-trees, but by the waters.
tgt_text.3715: Because those who carry off the prizes of per­ fect virtue are adorned with palm-leaves and with fillets;
tgt_text.3716: but those who are still exercising themselves in the preliminary branches of instruction, as people thirsting for learning, settle themselves by the side of those sciences which are able to bedew and irrigate their souls.
tgt_text.3718: Such then are the fountains of intermediate in­ struction.
tgt_text.3719: Let us now consider the fountain of folly, concerning which the lawgiver speaks thus, " Whosoever shall lie with a woman who is sitting apart has uncovered her fountain, and she has uncovered the issue of her blood;
tgt_text.3721: He here calls the external sense a woman, re­ presenting the mind as her husband.
tgt_text.3722: When therefore the woman, having forsaken her legitimate husband, settles near those objects of the external sense which allures and destroys, and embraces them all in an amorous manner;
tgt_text.3723: then there­ fore, if the mind be turned to sleep when it is necessary that it should be awakened, it has uncovered the fountain of the external sense, that is itself, that is to say, it has rendered itself, without a covering and without a wall, and easy to be plotted against.
tgt_text.3724: But nevertheless the woman also has un­ covered the fountain of her blood, for every external sense, when flowing towards the external object appreciable by it, is cheered and restrained by being under the dominion of the reason ;
tgt_text.3725: and it is left in a solitary condition, being deprived of any proper governor.
tgt_text.3726: And as the most terrible misfortune for a city is to be without walls, so the most unfortunate state for a soul is to be without a guardian.
tgt_text.3727: When, then, is it without a guardian ?
tgt_text.3728: Is it not when the sight is without any covering, being poured forth upon the objects of sight;
tgt_text.3729: and when the hearing is without a covering, being occupied in drinking in all kinds of sounds ;
tgt_text.3730: and when the sense of smell is uncovered, and the kindred powers are left to themselves, and so are most ready to suffer whatever the invading enemy may be disposed to inflict?
tgt_text.3731: And that speech is uncovered and uttered which speaks ten thousand things in an unseasonable manner, without any thing to restrain its impetuosity;
tgt_text.3732: therefore flowing on unrestrainedly, it overturns many noble purposes and plans of life which were previously sailing on erect as though in calm weather.
tgt_text.3733: This is that great deluge in which " the cataracts of heaven were opened ”†—by heaven I here mean of the mind-and the fountains of the bottomless pit were revealed ;
tgt_text.3734: that is to say, of the outward sense;
tgt_text.3735: for in this way alone is the soul overwhelmed, iniquities being broken up and poured over it from above, as from the heaven of the mind, and the passions irrigating it from below, as from the earth of the outward senses.
tgt_text.3736: For which reason Moses forbids a man to uncover the nakedness of his father or his mother,* well knowing how great an evil it is not to check and to conceal the offences of the mind and of the external sense, but to bring them forward and display them as though they were good actions.
tgt_text.3738: These are the fountains of errors.
tgt_text.3739: We must now examine that of prudence.
tgt_text.3740: To this one it is that perseverance, that is to say, Rebecca, descends ;
tgt_text.3741: † and after she has filled up the whole vessel of her soul she goes up again, the lawgiver, most strictly in accordance with natural truth, calling her return an ascent;
tgt_text.3742: for whoever brings his mind to descend from over-arrogant haughtiness is raised to a great height of virtue.
tgt_text.3743: For Moses says, " And having gone down to the fountain, she filled her ewer, and went up again."
tgt_text.3744: This is that divine wisdom from which all the particular sciences are irrigated, and all the souls which love contemplation and are filled with a love of what is most excellent;
tgt_text.3745: and to this fountain the sacred scripture most appropriately assigns a name, calling it "judgment" and "holy."
tgt_text.3746: For says the historian, " Having turned back, they came to the fountain of judgment;
tgt_text.3747: this is the fountain of Caddes,”‡ and the interpre­ tation of the name Caddes is holy.
tgt_text.3748: It all but cries out and shouts that the wisdom of God is holy, bringing with it nothing of the earth, and that it is the judgment of the universe by which all contrarieties are separated from one another.
tgt_text.3750: We must now speak also concerning that highest and most excellent of fountains which the Father of the universe spake of by the mouths of the prophets;
tgt_text.3751: for he has said somewhere, " They have left me, the fountain of life, and they have digged for themselves cisterns already worn out, which will not be able to hold water ;
tgt_text.3752: "§ therefore God is the most ancient of all fountains.
tgt_text.3753: And is not this very natural ?
tgt_text.3754: For he it is who has irrigated the whole of this world;
tgt_text.3755: and I am amazed when I hear that this is the fountain of life, for God alone is the cause of animation and life, and most especially of rational animation and of that life which is in union with prudence;
tgt_text.3757: But God is something more than life;
tgt_text.3758: he is, as he himself has said, the everlasting fountain of living.
tgt_text.3759: But the wicked having fled away, and having passed their time without ever tasting the draught of immortality, have digged, insane persons that they are, for themselves, and not first for God, having preferred their own actions to the heavenly and celestial things, and the things which proceed from care to those which are spontaneous and ready.
tgt_text.3760: Then they dig, not as the wise men Abraham and Isaac did, making wells, but cisterns, which have no good nutritious stream belonging to and proceeding from themselves, but requiring an influx from without, which must proceed from instruction.
tgt_text.3761: While the teachers are always pouring into the ears of their disciples all kinds of doctrines and speculations of science altogether, admonishing them to retain them in their minds, and to preserve them when faithfully committed to memory.
tgt_text.3762: But now they are but worn-out cisterns, that is to say, all the channels of the ill-educated soul are broken and leaky, not being able to hold and to preserve the influx of those streams which are able to profit.
tgt_text.3764: We have now then said as much as the time will permit us to say on the subject of the fountains, and it is with great accuracy and propriety that the sacred scriptures represent Hagar as found at the fountain, and not as drawing water from it:
tgt_text.3765: for the soul has not as yet made such an advance as to be fit to use the unmixed draught of wisdom;
tgt_text.3766: but it is not forbidden from making its abode in its neighbour­ hood.
tgt_text.3767: And all the road which is made by instruction is easy to travel, and most safe, and most solid, and strong, on which account the scripture tells us that she was found in the road leading to Shur;
tgt_text.3768: and the name Shur being interpreted means a wall or a direction.
tgt_text.3769: Therefore its convicter, speaking to the soul, says, “ Whence comest thou, and whither goest thou?"
tgt_text.3770: And it says, not because it doubts, and not so much by way of asking a question, as in a downcast and reproachful spirit, for an angel cannot be ignorant of anything that concerns us, and a proof of this is, that he is well acquainted even with the things which are in the womb, and which are invisible to the creature, inasmuch as he says, " Behold thou art with child, and thou shalt bring forth a son, and shalt call his name Ishmael ;
tgt_text.3771: ” for to know that that which is conceived is a male child does not belong to human power, any more than it does to foretell the description of life which the child who is not yet born will adopt, namely, that it will be rude life, and not that of a citizen or of a polished man.
tgt_text.3772: The expression, '' Whence comest thou?'' is said by way of reproving the soul, which is fleeing from the better and domi­ nant opinion, of which she is the handmaiden, not in name more than in fact, and by remaining in subjection to which she would gain great glory.
tgt_text.3773: And the expression, " And whither goest thou ?" means, you are running after uncertain things, having discarded and thrown away confessed good.
tgt_text.3774: It is well, therefore, to praise her for rejoicing at this admo­ nition.
tgt_text.3775: And she shows a proof of her delighting in it, by not bringing any accusation against her mistress, and by attribut­ ing the cause of her running away to her own self, and by her making no reply to the second question, " Whither goest thou?" for it is a matter of uncertainty ;
tgt_text.3776: and it is both safe and necessary to restrain one's self from speaking of what is uncer­ tai n.XXXVIII.
tgt_text.3777: Therefore the convicter of the soul approving of her in respect of her obedience says, Return unto thy mistress;
tgt_text.3778: for the government of the teacher is profitable to the disciple, and servitude in subjection to wisdom is advantageous to her who is imperfect;
tgt_text.3779: and when thou return est, " be thou humbled under her hands:
tgt_text.3780: ” —a very beautiful humiliation, compre­ hending the destruction of irrational pride.
tgt_text.3781: For thus, after a gentle travail, thou wilt bring forth a male child, by name Ishmael, corrected by divine admonitions ;
tgt_text.3782: for Ishmael, being interpreted, means " the hearing of God ;
tgt_text.3783: " and hearing is considered as entitled to only the second prize after seeing;
tgt_text.3784: but seeing is the inheritance of the legitimate and first-born son, Israel;
tgt_text.3785: for the name Israel, being interpreted, means " seeing God.
tgt_text.3786: "For it is possible for a man to hear false statements as though they were true, because hearing is a deceitful thing;
tgt_text.3787: but seeing is a sense which cannot be deceived, by which a man perceives existing things as they really are.
tgt_text.3788: But the angel describes the characteristics of the disposition which is born of Hagar, by saying that he will be a rude man ;
tgt_text.3789: as if he had said that he would be a man wise about rude matters, and not as yet thought worthy of that which is the truly divine and political portion of life:
tgt_text.3790: and this is virtue, by means of which it is the nature of the moral character to be humanised.
tgt_text.3791: And by his saying, “His hand shall be against every man, and every man's hand against him," he means to describe the design and plan of life of a sophist, who professes an over-curious scepticism, and who rejoices in disputatious arguments.
tgt_text.3792: Such a man shoots at all the followers of learning, and in his own person opposes all men, both publicly and privately, and is shot at by all who very naturally repel him as if they were acting in defence of their own offspring, that is to say, of the doctrines which their soul has brought forth.
tgt_text.3793: He also adds a third characteristic of him, saying, " He shall dwell before the face of all his brethren."
tgt_text.3794: In these words all but expressly declaring that he will wage an everlasting battle and war against them, face to face, for ever.
tgt_text.3795: Therefore the soul, which is pregnant with sophistical reasoning, says to the convicter who is addressing her, " Thou art God, who hast be­ held mean expression equivalent to, Thou art the creator of my plans and of my offspring.
tgt_text.3796: And may we not look upon this as a very natural reply on her part ?

tgt_text.3826: Do not, however, think that the living God, he who is truly living, is ever seen so as to be comprehended by any human being;

tgt_text.3828: we have no external sense suited to that pur­ pose (for he is not an object which can be discerned by the outward sense), nor any strength adequate to it;
tgt_text.3829: therefore, Moses, the spectator of the invisible nature, the mail who really saw God (for the sacred scriptures say that he entered " into the darkness,”* by which expression they mean figuratively to intimate the invisible essence), having investigated every part of every thing, sought to see clearly the much-desired and only God;
tgt_text.3830: but when he found nothing, not even any appearance at all resembling what he had hoped to behold;
tgt_text.3831: he, then, giving up all idea of receiving instruction on that point from any other source, flies to the very being himself whom he was seeking, and entreats him, saving, “

tgt_text.3989: as, for instance, through the medium of earth, water, air, the sun, the moon, heaven, and other incorporeal powers.
tgt_text.3990: But he bestows them on others through himself alone, exhibiting himself as the inheritance of those who receive him, whom from that he thinks worthy of another appellation :
tgt_text.3991: for it is said in the scripture, " Thy name shall not be called Abram, but Abraham shall thy name be."
tgt_text.3992: Some, then, of those persons who are foud of disputes, and who are always eager to affix a stain upon what is irre­ proachable, on things as well as bodies, and who wage an implacable war against sacred things, while they calumniate everything which does not appear to preserve strict decorum in speech, being the symbols of nature which is always fond of being concealed, perverting it all so as to give it a worse ap­ pearance after a very accurate investigation, do especially find fault with the changes of names.
tgt_text.3993: And it is only lately that I heard an ungodly and impious man mocking and ridiculing these things, who ventured to say, " Surely they are great and exceeding gifts which Moses says that the Ruler of the universe offers, who, by the addition of one element, the one letter alpha, a superfluous element;
tgt_text.3994: * and then again adding another element, the letter rho, appears to have bestowed upon men a most marvellous and great benefit;
tgt_text.3995: for he has called the wife of Abram Sarrah instead of Sarah, doubling the Rho,” and connecting a number of similar arguments without drawing breath, and joking and mocking, he went.
tgt_text.3997: But at no distant period he suffered a suitable punishment for his insane wickedness ;
tgt_text.3998: for on a very slight and ordinary provocation he hanged himself, in order that so polluted and impure a person might not die by a pure and unpolluted death.
tgt_text.4000: But we may justly, in order to prevent any one else from falling into the same error, eradicate the erroneous notions which have been formed on the subject, arguing the matter on the principle of natural philosophy, and proving that these things which are here said are worthy of all attention.
tgt_text.4001: God does not bestow on men mutes and vowels, or, in short, nouns and verbs ;
tgt_text.4002: since when he created plants and animals, he sum­ moned them before man as their governor, that he might give each of them their appropriate names by a reference to the knowledge which he had of all things ;
tgt_text.4003: for, says the scripture, “ Whatever Adam called any thing, that was the name thereof, tTherefore since God did not think fit to take upon himself even the active imposition of the names, but entrusted the task to a wise man, the author of the whole race of mankind, is it reasonable to suppose that he himself gave and arranged the different parts, and syllables, and letters of nouns, disposing not only the vowels, but even the mutes, and that he did this too to make a show of liberality and exceeding beneficence ?
tgt_text.4004: It is impossible to say so.
tgt_text.4005: But such things as these are the characteristic marks of different powers ;
tgt_text.4006: small marks of great powers, marks perceptible by the outward senses of powers appreciable only by the intellect, manifest marks of powers which are indistinct;
tgt_text.4007: and the powers themselves are discerned in most excellent doctrines, in true and pure conceptions, in the improvement of souls.
tgt_text.4008: And it is easy to see a proof of this if we make a beginning with the man who is here spoken of as having his name changed;
tgt_text.4009: for the name Abram, being interpreted, means " sublime father," but Abraham means the " elect father of sound;
tgt_text.4010: " and how these names differ from one another we shall know more clearly if we first of all read what is exhibited under each of them.
tgt_text.4011: Now using allegorical language, we call that man sublime who raises himself from the earth to a height, and who devotes himself to the inspection of high things;
tgt_text.4012: and we also call him a haunter of high regions, and a meteorolo­ gist, inquiring what is the magnitude of the sun, what are his motions, how he influences the seasons of the year, advancing as he does and retreating back again, with revolutions of equal speed, and investigating as he does the subjects of the radiance of the moon, of its shape, of its waning, of its increase, and of the motion of the other stars, whether fixed or wandering;
tgt_text.4013: for the inquiry into these matters belongs not to an ill-con­ ditioned or barren soul, but to one which is eminently endowed by nature, and which is able to produce an entire and perfect offspring ;
tgt_text.4014: on which account the scripture calls the meteorolo­ gist "father," inasmuch as he is not unproductive of wisdom.X.
tgt_text.4015: Now the symbols represented by the name of Abram are thus accurately defined;
tgt_text.4016: those conveyed under the name of Abrallam are such as we shall proceed to demonstrate.
tgt_text.4017: The meanings now are three, " the father," and " elect," and “of sound."
tgt_text.4018: Now by the word " sound " here, we mean uttered speech ;
tgt_text.4019: for the sounding organ of the living animal is the organ of speech.
tgt_text.4020: Of this faculty we say that the father is the mind, for it is from the mind, as from a fountain, that the stream of speech proceeds.
tgt_text.4021: The word " elect " belongs to the mind of the wise man, for whatever is most excellent is found in him;
tgt_text.4022: therefore the man devoted to learning and occupied in the contemplation of sublime subjects, was sketched out according to the former characteristic marks, but the philoso­ pher, or I should rather say the wise man, was exhibited in accordance with those of which we have just given an outline.
tgt_text.4023: Think not, then, any longer that the Deity bestows a change of names, but consider that what lie gives is a correction of the moral character by means of symbols;
tgt_text.4024: for having invited the man who formerly busied himself about the subject of the nature of heaven, and whom some call a mathematician, to a participation in virtue, he made him wise and called him so.
tgt_text.4025: For having given an appropriate name to his transformed dis­ position, he named him, as the Hebrews would call it, "Abra­ ham," but in the language of the Greeks, " the elect father of sound ;
tgt_text.4026: ” for says he, On what account dost thou investigate the motions and periods of the stars ?
tgt_text.4027: and why hast thou bounded up so high from the earth to the heavens?
tgt_text.4028: Is it merely that you may indulge your curiosity with respect to those matters ?
tgt_text.4029: And what advantage could accrue to you from all this curiosity ?
tgt_text.4030: What destruction of pleasure would it cause ?
tgt_text.4032: What dissolution of pain or fear ?
tgt_text.4033: What eradication of the passions which disturb and agitate the soul?
tgt_text.4034: For as there is no advantage in trees unless they are productive of fruit, so in the same way there is no use in the study of natural philosophy unless it is likely to confer upon a man the acquisition of virtue, for that is its proper fruit.
tgt_text.4035: On which account some of the ancients have compared the discussion and consideration of philosophy to a field, and have likened the physical portion of it to the plants, the logical part to the hedges and fences, the moral part to the fruit, thinking that the walls which are built around for the sake of protecting the fruit have been erected by the possessors of the land, and that the plants have been created for the sake of the produc­ tion of fruit;
tgt_text.4036: thus, therefore, they said that in philosophy it is requisite for the consideration of the physical and the logical part of philosophy to be referred to the moral part, by which the moral character is improved, which has a desire at the same time for both the acquisition and the use of virtue.
tgt_text.4037: This is the lesson which we have been taught concerning the man who in word indeed had his name changed, but who in reality changed his nature from the consideration of natural to that of moral philosophy, and who abandoned the contempla­ tion of the world itself for the knowledge of the Being who created the world ;
tgt_text.4038: by which knowledge he acquired piety, the most excellent of all possessions.
tgt_text.4040: We will now speak of his wife, Sarah, for she too had her name changed to Sarrah by the addition of the one element, the letter rho.
tgt_text.4041: These, then, are the names, and we must now explain what they mean.
tgt_text.4042: Sarah, being interpreted, signifies "my authority," but Sarrah signifies “ princess;
tgt_text.4043: ” the former name, therefore, is a symbol of specific virtue, but the latter of generic virtue.
tgt_text.4044: But in proportion as genus is superior to species in regard of quantity, in the same propor­ tion does the latter name excel the former;
tgt_text.4045: for species is something small and perishable, but genus is numerous and immortal, and the intention of God is to bestow great and immortal things instead of such as are small and perishable, and this is a task suited to his dignity.
tgt_text.4046: Now the prudence which exists in the virtuous man is the authority of himself alone, and he who has it would not err if he were to say, my authority is the prudence which is in me;
tgt_text.4047: but that which has stretched out this authority is generic prudence, not any longer the authority of this or that person, but absolute intrinsic authority;
tgt_text.4048: therefore that which exists only in species will perish at the same time with its possessor, but that which, like a seal, has stamped it with an impression, is free from all mortality, and will remain for ever and ever imperishable.
tgt_text.4049: Thus also those arts which exist only in species perish along with those who have acquired them, such as geometricians, grammarians, and musicians, but the generic arts remain exempt from destruction.
tgt_text.4050: And, again, he gives an additional sketch of his meaning when he teaches by the same name that every virtue is a princess, and a queen, and a ruler of all the affairs of life.
tgt_text.4052: But it has also happened that Jacob had his name changed to Israel;
tgt_text.4053: and this, too, was a felicitous alteration.
tgt_text.4055: Because the name Jacob means “ a supplanter," but the name Israel signifies “ the man who sees God."
tgt_text.4056: Now it is the employment of a supplanter, who practises virtue, to move, and disturb, and upset the foundations of passion on which it is established, and whatever there is of any strength which is founded on them.
tgt_text.4057: But these things are not brought about without a struggle or without severe labour;
tgt_text.4058: but only when any one, having gone through all the labours of prudence, then proceeds to practise himself in the exercises of the soul and to wrestle against the reasonings which are hostile to it, and which seek to torment it ;
tgt_text.4059: but it is the part of him who sees
tgt_text.4060: God not to depart from the sacred contest without the crown of victory, but rather to carry off the prize of triumph.
tgt_text.4061: And what more flourishing and more suitable crown could be woven for the victorious soul than one by which it will be able acutely and clearly to behold the living God?
tgt_text.4062: At least a beautiful prize is thus proposed for the soul which delights in the practice of virtue, namely, the being endowed with sight adequate to the clear comprehension of the only thing which is really worth beholding.
tgt_text.4064: And it is worth while here to raise the question why Abraham, from the time that his name was changed, is always thought worthy of this same appellation, and is no longer called by his former name;
tgt_text.4065: but Jacob, who is also called Israel, is nevertheless called Jacob too, as he was before the change of his name;
tgt_text.4066: and, indeed, is called Jacob oftener than Israel.
tgt_text.4067: We must say, then, that these facts are characters by which it is seen that the virtue which is taught differs from that which is acquired by practice ;
tgt_text.4068: for the man who is improved by instruction, having received a happy and virtuous nature, uses that virtue alone which, by means of memory co-operating with it, implants in him an absence of forgetfulness, so that he comprehends and takes firm hold of all the" things which he has once learnt ;
tgt_text.4069: but he who practises virtue, since he is con­ tinually exercising himself, stops to take breath, and relaxes his efforts for- a while, collecting himself and recovering the vigour which was a little impaired by his exertions, just as those men do who have oiled their bodies for the contests in the arena
tgt_text.4070: For these men, also, labouring at their training exercises, in order to prevent their powers being utterly broken down, anoint themselves with oil on account of the violent and continued nature of their exercise
tgt_text.4071: Then the man who is improved by instruction, having an immortal monitor, receives from him a harmonious and impe­ rishable advantage, without suffering any change ;
tgt_text.4072: but the practiser of virtue is impelled to action by his own inclination alone, and he exercises himself in it, and labours at it in order to change that passion, which is akin to a created being;
tgt_text.4073: and even if he attains to perfection, he still, being fatigued, returns to his ancient kind of labour;
tgt_text.4074: for he is more inclined to endure toil, but the other is more fortunate, for he has another person as a teacher.
tgt_text.4075: But this man, by his own unassisted efforts, investigates, and inquires, and pushes his examination, investi­ gating the mysteries of nature with great earnestness, and exerting continual and incessant labour.
tgt_text.4076: For this reason God, who never changes, altered the name of Abrabam, since he was about to remain in a similar condi­ tion, in order that that which was to be firmly established might be confirmed by him who was standing firmly, and who was remaining in the same state in the same manner.
tgt_text.4077: But it was an angel who altered the name of Jacob, being the Word, the minister of God ;
tgt_text.4078: in order that it might be confessed and ascertained, that there is none of the things whose existence is subsequent to that of the living God, which is the cause or unchangeable and unvarying firmness . . . . . .
tgt_text.4079: but of that harmony which, as in a musical instrument, contains the intensity and relaxation of sounds so as to produce an artistical combination of melody.
tgt_text.4081: But, there being three leaders and authors of this race, the two at each extremity of it had their names changed, namely Abraham and Jacob :
tgt_text.4082: but the one in the middle, Isaac, always retained the same appellation.
tgt_text.4084: Because both that virtue which is derived from teaching and that which is attained to by practice, admit of improvement and advancement:
tgt_text.4085: for the man who receives instruction desires a knowledge of those matters of which he is ignorant and he who applies himself to practice desires the crowns of victory, and the prizes which -are proposed to his industrious and contemplation-loving soul.
tgt_text.4086: But the race which is self- taught and which derives all its learning from its own dili­ gence, inasmuch as it exists rather by nature than by study, was at the very beginning introduced as equal, and perfect, and even, there being no number whatever deficient of those which tend to completeness.
tgt_text.4087: Nor indeed does Joseph have any such need, he who is the president of the necessities of the body ;
tgt_text.4088: for he also changes his name, being called Psonthomphanech by the king of the country.
tgt_text.4089: And what the meaning of these names is we must explain;
tgt_text.4090: the name Joseph, being interpreted, signifies “ an addition”
tgt_text.4091: For things which are put by the side are an addition to those which exist by nature ;
tgt_text.4092: for instance, gold, silver, possessions, revenues, the ministrations of servants, abundant treasure of heirlooms, and furniture, and other superfluities, and the infinite multitude of the different efficients of pleasure which some persons possess;
tgt_text.4093: the provider and superintendant of which was called Joseph, or addition, by a very felicitous nomenclature :
tgt_text.4094: since he had undertaken the superintendence of the things which were to be brought in from without, and added to the natural things previously existing in the course of nature.
tgt_text.4095: And the sacred scriptures testify that this is the case, showing that he was the purveyor of the food of all the corporeal region, Egypt, having stored it up in his treasure-houses.
tgt_text.4097: Such a person as this, then, Joseph is recognized as being by his distinctive marks and name.
tgt_text.4098: Let us now see what sort of person is indicated by the name Psonthomphanech.
tgt_text.4099: Now this name being interpreted means, "a mouth judging in an answer ;
tgt_text.4100: ” for every foolish person thinks that the man who is very rich and overflowing with external possessions, - must at once be wise and sensible, competent to give an answer to any question which any one puts to him, aud com­ petent also of his own head to deliver advantageous and sagacious opinions.
tgt_text.4101: And, in short, by such men prudence is supposed to be identical with good fortune, while one ought, on the contrary, to consider good fortune as consisting in being prudent ;
tgt_text.4102: for it is fitting that what is unstable should be under the direction of that which stands firmly.
tgt_text.4103: And indeed his father gave to his own uterine brother the name of Benjamin :
tgt_text.4104: * but his mother called him the son of her sorrow, speaking most completely in accordance with nature.
tgt_text.4105: For the name Benjamill being interpreted means, “ the son of days:
tgt_text.4106: " and the day is illuminated by that light of the sun which is perceptible by the outward senses:
tgt_text.4107: and to this we liken vain glory.
tgt_text.4108: For that has a certain brilliancy appreciable by the outward senses in the praises which it receives from the multitude and from the common herd of men, in formally enrolled decrees, in the erection of statues and images, in purple robes and golden crowns, in chariots and teams of four horses, and processions of the multitude.
tgt_text.4109: He therefore who is an admirer and desirer of such things is very appropriately called a soil of days:
tgt_text.4110: that is to say, of that light which is per­ ceptible by the outward senses and of the brilliancy which at­ tends vain glory.
tgt_text.4111: This felicitous and appropriate name the elder word and real father imposes on him;
tgt_text.4112: but the soul which has suffered gives him a name suited to what she has suffered.
tgt_text.4113: For she calls him the son of her sorrow.
tgt_text.4115: Because those men who are borne about by vain glory are supposed in­ deed to be happy, but in real truth are unhappy.
tgt_text.4116: For the things which oppose their happiness are numerous, envy, discontent, emulation, continual strife, irreconcileable enmities lasting till death, hostilities handed down in succession to one's children's children—a destiny not at all to be desired.
tgt_text.4117: Very necessarily therefore did the divinely inspired prophet represent that vain glory as dying in the very act of bringing forth ;
tgt_text.4118: for says he, " Rachel died, having had a bad delivery."
tgt_text.4119: * Since, in truth and reality, the sowing and generation of vain glory per­ ceptible by the outward senses is the death of the soul.
tgt_text.4121: And what shall we say of the sons of Joseph, Ephra­ im and Manasseh ?
tgt_text.4122: Are they not, in strict accordance with nature, compared to the two eldest sons of Jacob, Reuben and Simeon ?
tgt_text.4123: For the scripture says, " Thy two sons who were born in Egypt, before that I came into Egypt, belong to me;
tgt_text.4124: Ephraim and Manasseh shall be to me as Reuben and as Simeon."t
tgt_text.4125: Let us now then see in what manner the one pair are likened to the other pair.
tgt_text.4126: Reuben is the symbol of a good natural disposition, for the name being interpreted means, " A seeing son;
tgt_text.4127: " since every one who is endowed with tolerable acuteness of mind and a good disposition is capable of seeing;
tgt_text.4128: and Ephraim, as we have already frequently said in other places, is a symbol of memory, for his name being interpreted signifies, " produc­ tiveness of fruit," and the most excellent fruit of the soul is memory;
tgt_text.4129: and there is no, one thing so nearly akin to another as remembering is to a man of good natural endowments.
tgt_text.4130: Again, the name of Simeon is a symbol of learning and in­ struction ;
tgt_text.4131: for, being interpreted, it signifies " listening," and it is the especial part of a learner to listen and attend to what is said.
tgt_text.4132: But Manasseh is a symbol of " recollection," for thus that art is called, from forgetfulness;
tgt_text.4133: for it must of ne­ cessity happen to the man who has advanced out of forget­ fulness to recollect, and recollecting especially belongs to learning, for very often his notions escape from the man who is learning, as out of weakness he is unable to retain them, and then again they return to him as at the beginning.
tgt_text.4134: The condition therefore which arises from this escaping of his notions is denominated forgetfulness, and that which arises from their returning to him is called recollection.
tgt_text.4135: Now is not memory very naturally spoken of as connected with good natural endowments, and recollection as akin to learning ?
tgt_text.4136: And, indeed, the same relation which Simeon bears to Reu­ ben, that is to say, learning to natural endowment, the same does Manasseh bear to Ephraim, and the same does recollec­ tion bear to memory.
tgt_text.4137: For as the man of good natural endow­ ments is better than he who is only a learner, for the one resembles the sense of seeing, the other that of hearing, and hearing is always reckoned as entitled to a lesser honour than seeing;
tgt_text.4138: so also, he who is endowed with a good memory is at all times superior to him who only recollects, because the one is combined with forgetfulness, but the other continues unal­ loyed and unadulterated from beginning to end.
tgt_text.4140: And indeed the scriptures at one time call the father-in-law of the first of the prophets Jother, and at another time Raguel-Jother, when pride is flourishing and at its height;
tgt_text.4141: for the name Jother being interpreted means " super­ fluous,” and pride is superfluous in an honest and sincere life, turning into ridicule, as it does, all that is equal and necessary to life, and honouring the unequal things of excess and covetousness.
tgt_text.4142: This passion honours human things above divine, and customs above laws, and profane above sacred things, and mortal above immortal things, and, in short, appearances above reality;
tgt_text.4143: and it even ventures of its own accord to pass on into the rank of counsellors, suggesting to the wise man not to teach those things which alone are worthy to be known, namely, " the commandments of God, and the law,"* but to study the covenants and contracts of men with one another, which are almost the causes of the society which exists among them being so little sociable.
tgt_text.4144: But the great man is obedient in all things, thinking that little things are adapted to little people, and that great things are justly added to the great;
tgt_text.4145: but very often this man who is wise in his own conceit, and who, passing over from the herds which the blind had assigned to him for him to guide, having sought out the divine herd, becomes no small portion of it;
tgt_text.4146: admiring the leader of nature, and marvelling at his way of leading which he employs in his care of his own flocks, for the name Raguel being interpreted, signifies the " pastoral care of God."*XVIII.
tgt_text.4147: The main part has now been explained;
tgt_text.4148: we will now proceed to adduce the proofs.
tgt_text.4149: In the first place the scripture represents him as the cultivator of judgment and of justice, for the name Midian, being interpreted, means " out of judgment."
tgt_text.4150: And this is said in a twofold sense, for some times it signifies both selection and rejection, such as usually happens to those who are competitors in those contests which are called sacred;
tgt_text.4151: for numbers as they appear not qualified, are rejected by the masters of the games.
tgt_text.4152: These are the men who have been initiated in the unholy rites of Beel­ phegor,f and having widened all the mouths of the body to enable them to receive the streams which are poured into them from without, for the name Beelphegor is interpreted " the mouth above the skin," for they have overwhelmed the mind, the governor of the body, and have sunk it down to the lowest depth, so that it can never emerge, nor even hold up its head in ever so slight a degree.
tgt_text.4153: And it suffered this until Phinehas, the lover of peace and manifest priest of God, came as a champion of his own accord, being by nature a hater of all that is evil, and filled with an admiration and desire for what is good;
tgt_text.4154: and as he took a coadjutor, that is to say, the well sharpened and sharp-edged word, competent to investigate and examine everything, he could not be deceived, but exerting a vigorous strength, he pierced passion through her womb, that it might not hereafter bring forth any divinely caused evil.
tgt_text.4155: Now between these men and the seeing race there is a terrible war, in which no one of the combatants differed in language,‡ but each returned home unwounded and safe, crowned with the garlands of victory.
tgt_text.4157: This now is one of the things which are shown by the name of Midian ;
tgt_text.4158: another is that more excellent and judicial species which by the affinity of marriage is connected with the prophetic race.
tgt_text.4159: The scripture then says, " The priest of judg­ ment and justice " (that is to say, of Midian) " has seven daughters by which seven daughters are frequently inti­ mated the powers of the irrational part of the soul, the power of generation and the voice, and the five outward senses, tend­ ing the flocks of their father;
tgt_text.4160: for by means of these seven powers it is that all the progresses and increases of their father, the mind, exist in the perceptions which are produced from him.
tgt_text.4161: These, then, coming each to its appropriate ob­ ject, the power of sight to colours and shapes, the sense of hearing to sounds, the faculty of smelling to scents, taste to flavours, and all the other faculties to those objects which are adapted for their exercise do in a manner imbibe some of the external objects of the outward senses, until they have filled all the channels of the soul, and from these channels they give drink to the sheep of their father;
tgt_text.4162: I mean by these sheep that most pure flock of the reason which bears safety and ornament at the same time.
tgt_text.4163: But the companions of envy and jealousy, the leaders of the wicked herd coming up, drive them away from that use of their powers which is in accordance with nature, for some conduct these things which are without, inwards to the mind as to a judge and a king, in order that they may do well from having the most excellent of governors;
tgt_text.4164: but others take the opposite side, pursuing and proclaiming the exact contrary, while it is possible for the mind to be drawn towards them, and to give up the flock which was entrusted to it to feed.
tgt_text.4166: Until the good disposition, devoted to virtue and inspired by God, which for awhile has appeared to be resting in inactivity, by name Moses, holds his shield over them and defends them from those who would attack them, nourishing the flock of his father on wholesome words, and they having escaped the attack of the enemies of intellect who admire only the external appendages, like people in tragedies, go no longer to Jother but to Raguel, for they have abandoned all connection with pride, and have connected themselves with lawful persua­ sion, choosing to become a portion of the sacred flock, of which the divine word is the leader, as his name shows, for it signifies the pastoral care of God.XX.
tgt_text.4167: But while he is taking care of his own flock, all kinds of good things are given all at once to those of the sheep who are obedient, and who do not resist his will;
tgt_text.4168: and in the Psalms we find a song in these words, " The Lord is my shepherd, therefore shall I lack nothing;
tgt_text.4169: ”* therefore the mind which has had the royal shepherd, the divine word, for its instructor, will very naturally ask of his seven daughters, " Why is it that you have contended with such great haste to come hither this day?”† for formerly, when you met with the objects of the outward sense, remaining a long time outside, you were a long time in returning again by reason of the manner in which you were allured by them, but now I do not know what it is that has happened to you, but you are speedy in your return, contrary to your usual custom.
tgt_text.4170: Therefore they will say that there were not the same causes why they should run back with such exceeding speed, making the double course from the objects of the outward sense and to the objects of the outward sense, without stopping to take breath, and with excessive impetuosity;
tgt_text.4171: but that the cause was rather the man who delivered them from the shepherds of the wild flock.
tgt_text.4172: And they call Moses an Egyptian, a man who was not only a Hebrew, but even a Hebrew of the very purest race, of the only tribe which is consecrated, because they are unable to rise above their own nature;
tgt_text.4173: for the outward senses, being on the confines between the objects of the intellect and those of the outward senses, we must be content if they aim at both of them, and are not allured by the objects of the outward sense alone.
tgt_text.4174: And to think that they are inclined only to attend to the things which are purely objects of the intellect is great folly;
tgt_text.4175: on which account they give him both these names, since when they call him a man, they indicate the things which are within the province of reason alone to contemplate, and when they call him an Egyptian, they indicate the objects of the external senses.
tgt_text.4176: When he has heard this, he will again inquire, "Where is the man ?"
tgt_text.4177: In what part of you is the reasonable species dwelling ?
tgt_text.4178: Why have you left it so easily, and have not rather after having once met with it, preserved that which was the most beautiful of possessions, and the most advantageous for yourselves ?
tgt_text.4179: But even if you have not done so before, at least call it to you now, that it may eat of and be supported by your improvement and your close connection with him ;
tgt_text.4180: for perhaps he will even dwell with you, and will bring with him the winged, and divinely inspired, and prophetical race by name Zipporah.
tgt_text.4182: Thus much we have thought fit to say on this subject.

tgt_text.4382: and at the same time it soars to such a height above the earth, that it penetrates through the air and reaches even the æther, and scarcely stops at the very furthest circle of the fixed stars.
tgt_text.4383: For the fervid and glowing heat of that region does not suffer it to rest tranquil;
tgt_text.4384: on which account, overleaping many things, it is borne far beyond every boundary perceptible by the outward senses, to that which is compounded of ideas and appearances by the law of kindred.
tgt_text.4385: On which account in the good man there is a slight change, indivisible, unapportionable, not perceptible by the outward senses, but only by the intellect, and being in a manner independent of them.
tgt_text.4387: But, perhaps, some one may say, What then ?
tgt_text.4388: is he who has once believed bound never to admit the slightest trace, or shadow, or moment of incredulity at all?
tgt_text.4389: But this man appears to me to have nothing else in his mind except an idea of proving the creature uncreated, and the mortal immor­ tal, and the corruptible incorruptible, and man, if it be lawful to say so, God.
tgt_text.4390: For lie says that the belief which man has once conceived ought to be so firm as in no respect to differ from that which is entertained of the truly living God and which is complete in every part;
tgt_text.4391: for Moses, in his greater hymn, says, " God is faithful, and there is no unrighteousness in him."*
tgt_text.4392: And it is great folly to fancy that the soul of man is able to contain the virtues of God, which never vary and which are established on the most solid footing;
tgt_text.4393: for it is sufficient, and one must be content to have been able to acquire the images of them, though they are inferior to the archetypal patterns by many and large numbers.
tgt_text.4394: And is not this reason­ able ?
tgt_text.4395: for it follows of necessity that the virtues of God must be pure and unmixed, since God is not a compound being, inasmuch as he is a single nature;
tgt_text.4396: on the other hand, the virtues of men must be mixed with some alloy, since we our­ selves are compounds, the divine and human nature being combined in us, and adapted together according to the princi­ ples of perfect music;
tgt_text.4397: and that which is composed of many separate things has a natural attraction to each of its parts.
tgt_text.4398: But he is happy to whom it has happened that for the greater portion of his life he has inclined towards the more excellent and more divine part;
tgt_text.4399: for that he should have done so all his life is impossible, since at times the mortal weight which is opposed to him has preponderated in the opposite scale, and impending over his mind, has kept watch for the opportunities of coming upon his reason at an unfavourable time, so as to drag it back again.
tgt_text.4402: but he believed as a man;
tgt_text.4403: that you may be aware of the peculiar attribute of mortals, and may learn that his fall did not happen to him in any other way than in consequence of the ordinances of nature.
tgt_text.4404: And if it was of short duration and only momentary, it is a thing to be thankful for:
tgt_text.4405: for many other men have been so overturned by the violence and impe­ tuosity of error, and by its irresistible force, that they have been utterly destroyed for ever.
tgt_text.4406: For know, my good man, that, according to the most holy Moses, virtue is not perfect in the human body, but it suffers something like torpor, and is often ever so little lame.
tgt_text.4407: For says the scripture, " The broader part of his thigh became torpid, on which he was lame."*
tgt_text.4408: And perhaps some man of an over-confident disposition may come forward and say that this is not the language of one who dis­ believes, but of one praying, so that if that most excellent of all the happy feelings were about to be produced, it would not be brought forth according to any other number than that of ninety years, that so the perfect good might arrive at its pro­ duction according to perfect numbers.
tgt_text.4409: But the aforesaid numbers are perfect, and especially ac­ cording to the sacred scriptures.
tgt_text.4410: And let us consider each of them :
tgt_text.4411: now first of all there is the son of the just Noah and the ancestor of the seeing race, and he is said to have been a hundred years old when he begot Arphaxad,† and the meaning of the name Arphaxad is, "he disturbed sorrow."
tgt_text.4412: At all events it is a good thing that the offspring of the soul should confuse, and disorder, and destroy that miserable thing iniquity, so full of evils.
tgt_text.4413: But Abraham also planted a field,‡ using the ratio of an hundred for the measurement of the ground:
tgt_text.4414: and Isaac found some barley yielding a hundred fold.§
tgt_text.4415: And Moses also made the vestibule of the sacred tabernacle in a hundred arches,|| measuring out the distance towards the east and towards the west.
tgt_text.4416: Moreover the ratio of a hundred is the first fruit of the first fruit which the Levites assign to those who are conse­ crated to the priesthood ;
tgt_text.4417: * for after they have taken the tenths from the nation they are enjoined to give unto the priests a sacred tenth of the whole share, as if from their own possessions.
tgt_text.4418: And if a person were to consider, he might find many other instances to the praise of the aforesaid number brought forward in the law of Moses, but for the present what have been enumerated are sufficient.
tgt_text.4419: But if from the hundred you set aside the tenth part as a sacred first fruit to God who produces, and increases, and brings to perfection the fruit of the soul-for how can it be anything but perfect, inasmuch as it is on the confines between the first and the tenth, in the same manner in which the Holy of Holies is separated by the veil in the middle .
tgt_text.4420: .† by which those things which are of the same genus are divided according to the differences in species ?
tgt_text.4422: Therefore the good man was speaking and saying things which were really good in his mind.
tgt_text.4423: But the bad man at times interprets good things in a very excellent manner, but nevertheless does shameful things in a most shameful one, as Shechem dues who is the offspring of folly.
tgt_text.4424: For he is the son of Hamon his father, and the name Hamon, being trranslated, means " an ass," but the name Shechem means “a shoulder" when interpreted, the symbol of labour.
tgt_text.4425: But that labour of which folly is the parent is miserable and full of suffering, as, on the other hand, that labour is useful to which prudence is related.
tgt_text.4426: Accordingly the holy scriptures tell us that, " Shechem spake according to the mind of the virgin, having first humbled lier.”‡
tgt_text.4427: Is it not said then, with great purpose and accuracy, that he spake according to the mind of the dam­ sel, for the purpose of showing distinctly that he acted in a contrary manner to that in which he spoke?
tgt_text.4429: justice the attribute seated by God, the everlasting virgin;
tgt_text.4430: for the name Dinah, being interpreted, means either thing, judgment or justice.
tgt_text.4431: Fools, then, laying violent hands upon and attempting to defile her, by means of their daily designs and practices, by their plausibility of speech escape conviction.
tgt_text.4432: Therefore they must either act in a manner consistent with the lan­ guage that they hold, or else they must hold their tongues while committing iniquity.
tgt_text.4434: Silence is one half of evil :
tgt_text.4435: " as Moses says when rebuking the man who accounted the creature worthy of the principal honour, and the immortal God worthy only of the second place, " Thou hast sinued, be silent."
tgt_text.4436: For to use bombastic language, and to boast of one's evil deeds, is a double sin :
tgt_text.4437: and men in general are very prone to this;
tgt_text.4438: for they are constantly saying what is pleasing to the ever-virgin virtue, and such things as are just:
tgt_text.4439: but they never omit any opportunity of insulting and violating her when they are able.
tgt_text.4440: For what city is there which is not full of those who are continually celebrating the praises of virtue ?—men who weary the ears of those who hear them by everlastingly dwelling on such subjects as these ;
tgt_text.4445: courage is a thing proper to be cultivated ;
tgt_text.4451: piety towards the gods is praiseworthy ;
tgt_text.4453: that which is most akin to the nature of man is to design, and to act, and to speak virtuously;
tgt_text.4454: that which is most alien from his nature is to do the contrary of all these things.
tgt_text.4455: By continually stringing together these and similar aphorisms they deceive the courts of justice, and the council cham­ bers, and the theatres, and every assembly and company which they meet;
tgt_text.4456: as men who put beautiful masks on ugly faces, with the intention of not being discovered by those who see them.
tgt_text.4457: But it is of no use ;
tgt_text.4458: for some persons will come endowed with great vigour, and occupied with a real zeal and admiration for virtue, and who will strip them of all their coverings, and disguises, and appendages which they had woven round themselves by the evil artifice of plausible speeches, and will display their soul naked by itself as it really is, and will make themselves acquainted with the secret things of their nature which are hidden as it were in recesses.
tgt_text.4459: And then having brought to light all its shame and all the reproaches to which it is liable, they will display them in broad daylight to every one, and show what sort of thing it is, how disgraceful and ridiculous, and what a spurious kind of beauty it has disguised itself with by means of its appendages and coverings.
tgt_text.4460: And those who are prepared to avenge themselves on such profane and impure dispositions are Simeon and Levi,* two indeed in number, but only one in mind ;
tgt_text.4461: on which account, in his blessings of his sons, their father numbers them together under one classification, on account of the harmonious charac­ ter of their unanimity and of their violence in one and the same direction.
tgt_text.4462: But Moses does not make any mention of them afterwards as a pair, but classes the whole tribe of Simeon under that of Levi, combining together two essences, of which he made one impressed as it were with one idea and appear­ ance, uniting hearing to doing.
tgt_text.4464: When, therefore, the virtuous man knew that the promise was uttering things full of reverence and prudent caution, according to his own mind, he admitted both these feelings into his breast, namely, faith in God, and incredulity as to the creature.
tgt_text.4465: Very naturally therefore he says, using the language of entreaty, “Would that this Ishmael might live before thee,”† using each word of those which he utters here with deliberate propriety, namely, the “this," the “might live," the " before thee."
tgt_text.4466: For it is no small number of per­ sons who have been deceived by the similarity of the names of different things, and we had better examine here what I am saying.
tgt_text.4467: The name Ishmael, being interpreted, means " the hearing of God," but some men listen to the divine doctrines to their benefit, and others listen to both his admonitions and to those of others only to their destruction.
tgt_text.4468: Do you not recollect the case of the soothsayer Balaam?‡
tgt_text.4469: He is represented as hear­ ing the oracles of God, and as having received knowledge from the Most High, but what advantage did he reap from such hearing, and what good accrued to him from such knowledge ?
tgt_text.4470: In his intention he endeavoured to injure the most excellent eye of the soul, which alone has received such instruction as to be able to behold God, but he was unable to do so by reason of the invincible power of the Saviour;
tgt_text.4471: therefore, being over­ thrown by his own insane wickedness, and having received many wounds, he perished amid the heaps of wounded, § be­ cause he had stamped beforehand the divinely inspired pro­ phecies with the sophistry of the soothsayers.
tgt_text.4472: Very righteously, therefore, does the good man pray that this his only son, Ishmael, may he sound in mind and health, because of those persons who do not listen in a sincere spirit to the sacred admonitions, whom Moses has expressly forbidden to come into the assembly of the Ruler of the universe, for those men are broken as to the generative parts of their minds, or are even rendered completely impotent in that respect, who magnify their own minds, and their external sense, as the only causes of all the events which take place among men;
tgt_text.4473: and there are others who are lovers of a system of polytheism, and who honour the company which is devoted to the service of many gods, being the sons of a harlot, having no knowledge of the one husband and father of the virtue- loving soul, namely, God;
tgt_text.4474: and are not all these men very pro­ perly driven away and banished from the assembly of God ?
tgt_text.4475: They appear to me very much to resemble those parents who accuse their sons of intemperance in wine, for they say, " This our son is disobedient.”* indicating, by the addition of the word “this," that they have other sons likewise who are temperate and self-denying, and who obey the injunctions of right reason and instruction;
tgt_text.4476: for these are the most genuine parents, by whom it is a most disgraceful thing to be accused, and a most glorious thing to be praised.
tgt_text.4477: Then as to the words, " This is Aaron and Moses, whom God directed to lead the children of Israel out of Egypt,”† and the expression, " These are they who conversed with Pharaoh the king."
tgt_text.4478: Let us not think that they are used su­ perfluously, or that they do not convey some intimations beyond the mere open meaning of the words;
tgt_text.4479: for since Moses is the purest mind, and Aaron is his speech, and moreover, since the mind has been taught to think of divine things in a divine manner, and since the speech has learnt to interpret holy things in holy language, the sophists imitating them, and adulterating the genuine coinage, say, that they also conceive rightly, and speak in a praiseworthy manner about what is most excellent.
tgt_text.4480: In order, therefore, that we may not be deceived by a placing of the base money in juxtaposition with the good, by reason of the similitude of the impression, he has given us a test by which they may be distinguished.
tgt_text.4482: To bring out of the region of the body the mind, endowed with the power of seeing, fond of contemplation and philosophical;
tgt_text.4483: for he who can do this is this same Moses;
tgt_text.4484: and he who is un­ able really to do so, but who is only said to be able, and who makes professions with infinite pomp and magnitude of lan­ guage, is laughed at.
tgt_text.4485: But he prays that Ishmael may live, not meaning to refer to the life in conjunction with the body, but he prays that the divine voice, dwelling for evermore in his soul, may awaken and vivify it.
tgt_text.4487: And he indeed prays that the hearing of sacred words and the learning of sacred doctrine may live, as has been already said;
tgt_text.4488: but Jacob, the practiser of virtue, prays that the good natural disposition may live;
tgt_text.4489: for he says, " May Reuben live and not die,"* does he then here pray for immor­ tality for him, a thing impossible for man to attain to?
tgt_text.4490: Surely not, we must then explain what it is which he intends to signify.
tgt_text.4491: All the lessons and all the admonitions of in­ struction are built up and established on the nature which is calculated to receive instruction, as on a foundation previously laid;
tgt_text.4492: but if there is no natural foundation previously in existence, everything is useless;
tgt_text.4493: for men, by nature destitute of sense, would not appear at all to differ from a stock or a lifeless stone;
tgt_text.4494: for nothing could possibly be adapted to them so as to cleave to them, but everything would rebound and spring back as from some hard body.
tgt_text.4495: But on the other hand, we may see the souls of those who are well endowed by nature, like a well-smoothed waxen tablet, neither too solid nor too tender, moderately tempered, and easily receiving all admonitions and all lessons, and themselves giving an accurate representation of any impression which has been stamped upon them, being a sort of distinct image of memory.
