tgt_text.7158: "But his father, being afraid lest from his meeting with his brothers there might arise some quarrel and disturbance with them, inasmuch as they bore ill will against him on account of the dreams which he had seen, sent them away to keep their flocks at a distance, but retained him at home till a fitting season, knowing that time is said to be a power­ ful physician for all the passions and diseases of the soul, and a remover of grief, and an extinguisher of anger, and a healer of fear;
tgt_text.7159: for it softens and mitigates everything, even such things as are, according to their own nature, hard to be cured.
tgt_text.7160: But when he conjectured that no hatred was any longer abiding in their hearts he sent this his son forth to salute his brethren, and also to bring him word how they and their flocks of sheep were.
tgt_text.7162: This expedition of his was the origin both of great evils and also of great good, each of them being excessive beyond all expectation ;
tgt_text.7163: for he, obeying the commands of his parents, went to visit his brethren ;
tgt_text.7164: but they, seeing him coming towards them while at a great distance, conversed one with another, saying nothing of good omen, inasmuch as they did not choose even to call him by his name, but called him a dreamer, and a seer of visions, and such appellations as these.
tgt_text.7165: And to such a height did they carry their rage that (1 will not say all of them, but) the greater portion of them plotted his death;
tgt_text.7166: and designed, after having slain him, for the sake of not being detected, to throw him into a deep pit dug in the earth, for there are a great many such places in that district dug as receptacles for the rain water.
tgt_text.7167: And they were very near incurring that most ex­ cessive pollution of fratricide, as they would have done if they had not been, though with difficulty, persuaded by the advice of their eldest brother, who counselled them not to meddle with such a pollution but merely to cast him into one of these pits, thinking then to contrive some means of saving him, so that when they had all departed he might send him back again to his father without having suffered any harm.
tgt_text.7168: And after they agreed to this he came forward and saluted them;
tgt_text.7169: and they took him as though he had been an enemy, and stripped him of all his garments, and let him down into a vast pit, and then, having stained his cloak with the blood of a kid, they sent it to their father on the pretence that he had been slain by a wild beast.
tgt_text.7171: But on that day it happened by some chance that certain merchants who were accustomed to convey their merchandise from Arabia to Egypt were travelling that way, and so the eleven brethren drew Joseph up out of the pit and sold him to them;
tgt_text.7172: the one of them who was the fourth in respect of age instigating this contrivance ;
tgt_text.7173: for in my opinion, he was afraid lest his brother might be treacherously slain by the others, who had conceived an irreconcilable hatred against him, and therefore he pro­ posed that he should be sold, substituting slavery for death, the lighter evil for the greater.
tgt_text.7174: But the eldest, for he was not present when he was sold, looking down into the pit, and not seeing him whom lie had left there a short time before, cried out and lamented loudly, and rent his clothes, and tossed his hands up and down like a madman, and beat his breast and tore his hair, saying, " What has become of him ?
tgt_text.7175: Tell me, is he alive, or is he dead ?
tgt_text.7176: If he is dead, show me his corpse that I may weep over his body, and so al­ leviate my grief.
tgt_text.7177: When I see him lying dead I shall be com­ forted ;
tgt_text.7178: for why should we bear ill will to the dead ?
tgt_text.7179: There is no envy excited against those who are out of sight.
tgt_text.7180: And if he is alive, to what country has he departed ?
tgt_text.7182: for I am not, as he was, an object of suspicion, so as to be distrusted by you."
tgt_text.7183: And when they replied that he had been sold, and when they showed him the money which they had received for him, he said, “ A fine trade, indeed, you have been driving ?
tgt_text.7185: let us wear crowns of victory after thus rivalling the slave-dealers, and bearing off from them the prizes of iniquity;
tgt_text.7186: we may well pride ourselves now that we have surpassed them in barbarity, for they indeed traffic in the liberty of strangers, but we in that of those who are most nearly related to and most dear to us.
tgt_text.7187: Surely here is newly contrived a great disgrace and a shame which will be known far and wide.
tgt_text.7188: Our fathers left be­ hind them in every part of the world memorials of their virtue and excellence;
tgt_text.7189: we shall leave behind us the guilt of a charge of faithlessness and treacherous inhumanity which can never be effaced ;
tgt_text.7190: for the reputation of extraordinary actions penetrates everywhere ;
tgt_text.7191: those which are praiseworthy being admired, and those which are blameable meeting with blame and accusation.
tgt_text.7192: In what manner now will our father receive the news of what has happened ?
tgt_text.7193: You will now, as far as depends upon us, have made the life of him who has hitherto been wonderfully happy and fortunate, not worth living;
tgt_text.7194: which will he pity, the child who has been sold, for his slavery ?
tgt_text.7195: or those who have sold him, for their inhumanity ?
tgt_text.7196: I am sure he will pity us much the most;
tgt_text.7197: since to do wrong is a more terrible evil than to suffer wrong, for the one has for an alleviation two consolations of the greatest influence, hope and pity ;
tgt_text.7198: but the other is destitute of both these miti­ gations, and is more unfortunate in the judgment of every one.
tgt_text.7199: But why do I mourn and bewail in this manner?
tgt_text.7200: It is better for me to be silent, lest I too should be treated in some terrible manner;
tgt_text.7201: for ye are most merciless men in your dispositions, and implacable ;
tgt_text.7202: and the rage which was kindled in each of you is still furious and vehement.
tgt_text.7204: But when their father heard, not the truth indeed, that his son had been sold, but a falsehood that he was dead, and that he had been slain by wild beasts, he was smitten in his ears by the news that was reported to him, and in his eyes by what was shown to him (for they brought to him his son's coat rent and torn and defiled with quanti­ ties of blood);
tgt_text.7205: and being wholly bewildered by the exceed­ ing greatness of the calamity, he lay for a long time without speaking, not being able even to lift up his head, the cala­ mity overwhelming and completely prostrating him;
tgt_text.7206: then suddenly pouring forth as it were a stream of tears with bitter lamentations, he bedewed his cheeks, and his ehin, and his breast, and all the garments on his chest, saying at the same time sueh words as these, " It is not thy death that grieves me, 0 my son, but such a tomb as has fallen to your lot;
tgt_text.7207: for if you had been buried in your own land I should have been comforted;
tgt_text.7208: I would have cherished you, I would have tended you in siekness if you had died before me, I would have given you my last embrace, I would have closed your eyes, I would have wept over your dead body lying before me, I would have buried you sumptuously, I would have omitted none of the customary observances.
tgt_text.7209: "Again, even if you had died in a foreign land, I should have said, nature has claimed what was due to, and what belonged to her;
tgt_text.7210: and therefore, 0 my mind, be not east down ;
tgt_text.7211: for living men have indeed their separate countries, but the whole earth is the grave of the dead;
tgt_text.7212: and all men are destined to a speedy death;
tgt_text.7213: for even the longest lived man is but short lived if compared with eternity;
tgt_text.7214: but if it was necessary that he should die violently and by treachery, it would have been a lighter evil to me for him to have been slain by men, who would have laid out his corpse, and have pitied him so far as to scatter dust over him, and at least to have concealed his body;
tgt_text.7215: and even if they had been the most merciless of all people, what more could they have done than have thrown him out unburied, and so got rid of him ?
tgt_text.7216: And then perhaps, some one of the passers by on the road, standing by, and beholding him, and conceiving pity for our common nature, would have thought him worthy of some care, and of burial;
tgt_text.7217: but now, as the saying is, 0 my son, thou hast become a feast, and a banquet for savage and carnivorous wild beasts, who will eat and devour thy bowels ;
tgt_text.7218: I am compelled to endure distresses whieh I never had imagined, I am without any cause practised in enduring many miseries;
tgt_text.7219: I am a wanderer, a stranger, a slave, living under compulsion, having even my very life plotted against by those whom it least became to do so.
tgt_text.7220: And I have seen many things, and I have heard many things, and I have suffered many things, all of which have been incurable evils, which however I have learnt to bear with moderation, so as not to yield to them."
tgt_text.7221: But nothing has ever happened more intolerable than this misfortune which has now befallen me ;
tgt_text.7222: which has consumed and destroyed all the vigour of my soul;
tgt_text.7223: for what can be a greater or more pitiable calamity ?
tgt_text.7224: The garment of my child has been brought to me, who am his father;
tgt_text.7225: but of him himself there is no portion brought, not a limb, not a small fragment, but he has been wholly and entirely destroyed and devoured, not being able even to receive burial;
tgt_text.7226: and it seems to me that even his garment would never have been sent to me at all if it had not been by way of a reminder of my grief, and as a refreshment of my memory as to the sufferings which he endured, so as to afflict me with a never to be forgotten and never ending sorrow.
tgt_text.7227: He indeed bewailed his son in these terms ;
tgt_text.7228: but the merchants sold his son in Egypt to one of the king's eunuchs who was his chief cook.
tgt_text.7230: It is worth while, however, after having thus explained the literal account given to us of these events, to proceed to explain also the figurative meaning concealed under that account;
tgt_text.7231: for we say that nearly all, or that at all events, the greater part of the history of the giving of the law is full of allegories;
tgt_text.7232: now the disposition which we have at present under consideration, is called by the Hebrews Joseph;
tgt_text.7233: but the name being interpreted in the Greek language means, " the addition of the Lord," a name most felicitously given, and most appropriate to the account given of the person so called;
tgt_text.7234: for the democratic constitution in vogue among states is an addition of nature which has sovereign authority over everything;
tgt_text.7235: for this world is a sort of large state, and has one constitution, and one law, and the word of nature enjoins what one ought to do, and forbids what one ought not to do:
tgt_text.7236: but the cities themselves in their several situations are unlimited in number, and enjoy different constitutions, and laws which are not all the same;
tgt_text.7237: for there are different customs and established regulations found out and established in different nations;
tgt_text.7238: and the cause of this the want of union, and participation existing not merely between the Greeks and the barbarians, or between the barbarians and the Greeks, but also between the different tribes of each of these respective nations.
tgt_text.7239: Then they, as it would seem, blaming those things which do not deserve blame, such as unexpected occurrences or opportunities, deficiency of crops, badness of soil, their own situation either as being by the sea-side, or inland, or insular, or on the continent, or anything of that sort, are silent as to the real truth.
tgt_text.7240: The real truth is their covetousness, their want of good faith towards and confidence in one another, on which account they have not been satisfied with the laws of nature, but have called those regulations, which have ap­ peared to be for the common advantage of the agreeing and unanimous multitudes, laws, so that the individual constitu­ tions do naturally appear rather in the light of additions to the one great general constitution of nature;
tgt_text.7241: for the laws of individual cities are additions to the one right reason of nature;
tgt_text.7242: and so also the man who is occupied with political affairs is an addition to the man who lives in accordance with nature.
tgt_text.7244: And it is not without a particular and correct mean­ in,, that Joseph is said to have had a coat of many colours.
tgt_text.7245: For a political constitution is a many-coloured and multi­ form thing, admitting of an infinite variety of changes in its general appearance, in its affairs, in its moving causes, in the peculiar laws respecting strangers, in numberless differ­ ences respecting times and places.
tgt_text.7246: For as the master of a ship collects together all the moans which may tend to ensure him a favourable voyage with reference to and in dependency on the changes of the wind, not always guiding his vessel in one and the same way;
tgt_text.7247: and as a physician does not apply one and the same means of cure to every sick person, nor even to one person if his disease varies in its character, but watches the periods of its abatement, and of its intensity, and of its becoming full or empty, and the alterations of the causes of the sickness, and so varies his remedies as much as possible to secure the safety of his patient, applying one remedy at one time and another at another;
tgt_text.7248: in the same manner I conceive that the man immersed in political affairs is of necessity a multiform man, assuming many different appearances, one in time of peace and another in time of war;
tgt_text.7249: and a different cha­ racter according as those who are opposed to him are numerous or few in number, withstanding a small number with vigorous resolution, but using persuasion and gentle means towards a large body.
tgt_text.7250: And in some cases where there is much danger, still for the sake of the common advantage he will take the place of every one, and manage the business in hand by himself;
tgt_text.7251: in other cases, where it is merely a question of labour he will let others minister to him as his assistants.
tgt_text.7252: It was appropriately said that the man was sold.
tgt_text.7253: For the haranguer of the people and the demagogue, mounting the tribunal, like slaves who are being sold and exposed to view, is a slave instead of a free man, by reason of the honours which he seems to be receiving, being led away by ten thousand masters ?
tgt_text.7254: The same person is also represented as having been torn by wild beasts;
tgt_text.7255: and vainglory, which lies in wait for a man, is an untameable wild beast, tearing and destroying all who give into it.
tgt_text.7256: And they who have been purchasers are likewise sellers ;
tgt_text.7257: for there is one master only to the citizens who live in any city;
tgt_text.7258: but there is a multitude of masters, one succeeding another in a certain succession and regular order.
tgt_text.7259: But those who have been sold three times change their masters like bad slaves, not remaining with their original ones, by reason of the speedily satisfied irregularity of their dispositions, always thirsting after novelty.
tgt_text.7261: This is enough to say on this part of the subject.
tgt_text.7262: Accordingly, the young man, having been conducted into Egypt, and there, as has already been stated, having become the slave of a eunuch, gave in a few days such proofs of virtue and excellence of disposition, that he had authority over his fellow servants given to him, and the management of the whole household committed to his charge ;
tgt_text.7263: for already his master had learnt by many circumstances to perceive that his servant in all his words and in all his actions was under the immediate direction of divine providence.
tgt_text.7264: Accordingly, in consequence of this opinion of his purchaser, he was appointed superintendent of his house, apparently indeed by his master, but, in fact and reality, by nature her­ self, which procured for him the government of a mighty city, and nation, and country.
tgt_text.7265: For it was necessary that one who was destined to be a statesman should be previously practised and trained in the management of a single house­ hold ;
tgt_text.7266: for a household is a city on a small and contracted scale, and the management of a household is a contracted kind of polity;
tgt_text.7267: so that a city may be called a large house, and the government of a city a widely spread economy.
tgt_text.7268: And from these considerations we may see that the manager of a household and the governor of a state are identical, though the multitude and magnitude of the things com­ mitted to their charge may be different, as is the case too with the arts of painting and statuary;
tgt_text.7269: for the good statuary or painter, whether he is making many and colossal figures, or only few and those of a small size, is still the same person, and the art which he is practising is the same art.
tgt_text.7271: But while he is earning a very high reputation in the matters connected with the management of his master's house, he is plotted against by the wife of his master, because of the incontinent love which she had conceived for him;
tgt_text.7272: for she, being maddened by the beauty of the young man, and being unable to restrain the violence of her frenzy and passion, addressed a proposal of illicit intercourse to him;
tgt_text.7273: but he resisted it vigorously, and would not at all endure to approach her, by reason of the orderly and temperate dis­ position implanted in him by nature and habit.
tgt_text.7274: But when she, inflaming and exciting her lawless desire, kept con­ tinually tempting him, and continually throwing herself in his way, and continually failing in her object, she at last, in the violence of her passion, had recourse to force, and seizing hold of his cloak dragged him vigorously towards the bed, her passion endowing her strength with greater vigour, as it often does strengthen even the weak.
tgt_text.7275: But he, proving more powerful than even the alluring opportunity, uttered a cry becoming a free man, and worthy of his race, saying, What are you forcing me to ?
tgt_text.7276: We, the descendants of the Hebrews, are guided by special customs and laws of our own;
tgt_text.7277: in other nations the youths are permitted, after they are fourteen years of ago, to use concubines and prostitutes, and women who make gain by their persons, without restraint.
tgt_text.7278: But among us a harlot is not allowed even to live, but death is appointed as a punishment for any one who adopts such a way of life.
tgt_text.7279: Therefore, before our lawful marriage we know nothing of any connection with any other woman, but, with­ out ever having experienced any similar cohabitation, we approach our virgin brides as pure as themselves, proposing as the end of our marriage not pleasure but the offspring of legitimate children.
tgt_text.7280: I therefore, having kept myself pure to this day, will not begin now to transgress the law by adultery which is the greatest of all sins, when I ought rather, even if ,in past time I had lived in an irregular manner, and had been led away by the impulses of youth, and had imitated the licen­ tiousness of the natives, still not to seek to pollute the marriage of another man, an offence which who is there who would not avenge with blood ?
tgt_text.7281: For though different nations differ in other points, still all agree in this alone, that all men think him worthy of ten thousand deaths who does so, and give up the man who is detected in adultery without trial to the husband who has detected him.
tgt_text.7282: But you, pressing me thus to load myself with guilt, would add even a third pollution in my case, since you bid me not merely commit adultery, but also to violate my mistress and my master's wife, unless, indeed, this is to be looked upon as the reason for which I entered your house, that I might neglect the duties which a servant ought to perform, and get drunk, and become intoxicated with hopes fit for my master who has bought me, polluting his marriage, and his house and his family.
tgt_text.7283: Nevertheless I am induced to honour him not merely as my master, but also as one who has before now been my benefactor.
tgt_text.7284: He has committed to my care the whole management of his household;
tgt_text.7285: there is nothing whatever, be it great or small, which is withdrawn from my superin­ tendence, except you who are his wife.
tgt_text.7286: In return for these kindnesses is it fitting for me to requite him with such an action as you recommend to me ?
tgt_text.7287: I will rather, as becomes me, endeavour with honourable service to requite the kind­ ness of which he has set me the example, and which is due to him.
tgt_text.7288: He, being my master, has made me, who was a captive and a slave, a free man and a citizen by his great goodness, as far at least as depended on him;
tgt_text.7289: and shall I, who am a slave, compare myself to my master as if he were a stranger and a captive ?
tgt_text.7290: And with what disposition can I commit this unholy action ?
tgt_text.7291: and with what face can I be impudent enough to look upon him ?
tgt_text.7292: The consciousness of guilt which I shall have contracted will not suffer me to look him in the face, even if I should be able to be undis­ covered, but in fact I shall never escape detection, for there are innumerable witnesses of all the things which are done privily who may not be silent.
tgt_text.7293: I forbear to say that, even if no one else should know it, or being privy to it should not divulge it, still I never­ theless shall be a witness against myself by my complexion, by my look, by my voice, as I said a little while ago, being convicted by my own conscience ;
tgt_text.7294: and if no one else informs against me, shall I not fear nor respect, justice the assessor of God, and the overlooker of all human actions ?X.
tgt_text.7295: He put all these arguments together and philoso­ phised in this way till she ceased to importune him;
tgt_text.7296: for the desires are powerful, to cast in the shade even the most powerful of the outward senses, which he, being aware of, fled from them, leaving his garment in her hands, as she had seized hold of him.
tgt_text.7297: This circumstance gave her an opportunity to contrive a story, and to invent a plausible tale against the young man, by means of which she might revenge herself on him;
tgt_text.7298: for when her husband came from the public assembly, she, pretending to play the part of a modest and orderly woman, even among the intemperate habits by which she was surrounded, said to him, with excessive indignation, " You brought a servant into us, a slave of the Hebrews, who has not only corrupted his soul, since you, in a simple manner without due inquiry, com­ mitted your household to him, but has even dared to assault my body.
tgt_text.7299: For he was not contented with seducing only his fellow servants, inasmuch as he has become a most lascivious and debauched man, but he has attempted to defile even me, his mistress, and to use force to me;
tgt_text.7300: and the proofs of his insane lust are visible and clear ;
tgt_text.7301: for when, having been very ill-treated by him, I cried out, calling to my aid assistants from within;
tgt_text.7302: he fled, from fear of being apprehended.
tgt_text.7303: "And showing his garment, she appeared to give a proof of the truth of what she said;
tgt_text.7304: and his master thinking that it was true, ordered his officers to conduct the man to prison, erring in two most important points :
tgt_text.7305: first, that with­ out giving him any time to defend himself, he, without a trial, condemned one who had done no wrong, as if he had com­ mitted the greatest crimes;
tgt_text.7306: secondly, because the garment which the woman displayed as having been left behind bv the young man, was indeed a proof of violence, but not of that which he had committed, but rather of that which had been offered to him, and of the fortitude with which he endured it from the woman ;
tgt_text.7307: for if he had been offering violence, it was probable that he might have laid hold of the garment of his mistress ;
tgt_text.7308: but it was owing to his having had violence offered to him that he was deprived of his own.
tgt_text.7309: But perhaps he should be pardoned for his excessive igno­ rance, inasmuch as he lived chiefly in the cook's house, being filled with blood, and smoke, and ashes, his reasoning having no opportunity to become tranquillized and to enjoy leisure in itself, because it was confused still more, or, at all events, not less than the body.
tgt_text.7311: I have already sketched out three characters of the man immersed in civil business ;
tgt_text.7312: that of him who is occupied as a shepherd, that of the regulator of a house, and that of the man possessed of fortitude :
tgt_text.7313: and we have now discussed the two first of these sufficiently.
tgt_text.7314: But the temperate man is no less connected with the regulation of political affairs than those two are;
tgt_text.7315: for tem­ perance is a beneficial and saving thing for all the affairs of life;
tgt_text.7316: and in affairs of state it is most especially so, as those who wish to understand the matter may learn from nume­ rous and easily obtained proofs.
tgt_text.7317: For who is there who does not know that great calamities have befallen nations, and districts, and whole countries all over the world, both by land and sea, in consequence of intemperance ;
tgt_text.7318: for the most numerous and most serious wars have been kindled on account of love, and adultery, and the wiles of women;
tgt_text.7319: by which the most numerous and most excellent portion both of the Grecian and barbarian race has been destroyed, and the youth of the cities has perished.
tgt_text.7320: And of the conse­ quences of intemperance, are domestic seditions, and wars, and evils upon evils in unutterable number.
tgt_text.7321: It is plain that the consequences of temperance, are stability, and peace, and the acquisition and enjoyment of perfect bless­ ings.
tgt_text.7323: It is worth while, however, to proceed in regular order, and by this course to exhibit what is intended to be intimated by'this figurative history.
tgt_text.7324: The man who brought this servant of whom we are speaking is said to have been a eunuch;
tgt_text.7325: very naturally, for the multitude which pur­ chases the services of a man skilful in affairs of state is truly a eunuch, having in appearance, indeed, the organs of generation, but being deprived of all the power requisite for generating;
tgt_text.7326: just as those persons who have a confused sight though they have eyes, are nevertheless deprived of the active use of them, inasmuch as they are not able to see clearly.
tgt_text.7327: What, then, is the resemblance of eunuchs to the multitude ?
tgt_text.7328: That the multitude too is unable to generate wisdom, but that it studies virtue ;
tgt_text.7329: for when a multitude of men, brought promiscuously together from all quarters and of different races, meets in the same place, what is said in­ deed may be proper and becoming, but what is intended and what is done is quite the contrary;
tgt_text.7330: since the multi­ tude embraces what is spurious in preference to what is genuine, because it is carried away by false opinion, and has not studied what is truly honourable.
tgt_text.7331: On which account (though it seems a most unnatural thing), a wife is represented as cohabiting with this eunuch ;
tgt_text.7332: for the multitudes court desire, as a man courts a woman ;
tgt_text.7333: for the sake of which it says and does everything, making it its counsellor in everything which should and should not be spoken, trifling or important, being not at all accustomed to attend to considerations of calm wisdom;
tgt_text.7334: therefore the sacred historian very appropriately calls him the chief cook.
tgt_text.7335: For as a cook studies nothing beyond the insatiable and im­ moderate pleasures of the belly, in the same manner the multitude, which is occupied with public affairs, studies only those pleasures and allurements which are conveyed by means of the hearing, by which the energies of the mind are relaxed, as one may say the nerves of the soul are in a man­ ner loosened.
tgt_text.7336: And who is there who is not aware of the great quarrel which exists between physicians and cooks;
tgt_text.7337: since the first exert all their diligence and ingenuity in preparing things which are salutary, even if they are not pleasant;
tgt_text.7338: but the others, on the contrary, prepare only what is pleasant, dis­ regarding what is advantageous ?
tgt_text.7339: Therefore, the laws which exist among a people and those who govern in accordance with the laws resemble physicians, and so also do those counsellors and judges who have a regard to the common safety and security of the state, and who use no flattery to the people.
tgt_text.7340: But the chief body of the younger men resem­ bles cooks;
tgt_text.7341: for their object is not to supply what will be beneficial to the people, but only to contrive for the present moment to reap gratification.
tgt_text.7343: And the desire of the multitude, like an inconti­ nent woman, loves the man who is experienced in state affairs, and says to him:
tgt_text.7344: Go forth, my good man, unto the multitude among which you are dwelling, and forget all your own individual disposition, and the pursuits, and dis­ courses, and actions in which you have been brought up.
tgt_text.7345: And be guided by me, and attend to me, and do every thing which is agreeable to me;
tgt_text.7346: for I cannot endure any thing that is austere and obstinate, and foolishly fond of truth, and pertinaciously adhering to justice, which puts on an air of importance and dignity on all occasions, which yields in no point, and never proposes to itself any object but plain expediency, without any thought of gratifying the hearers.
tgt_text.7347: And you do not know the innumerable calumnies which some persons load you with, uttering them to my husband and your master, the multitude;
tgt_text.7348: for up to this time you appear to me to have been behaving like a free man, and you seem not at all to know that you are the slave of a very tyrannical master.
tgt_text.7349: But if you had understood that independence of action belongs to a free man, but obedience to the orders of others to a slave, you would then, laying aside your self-willed obstinacy, have learnt to look upon me who am his wife, being desire, and to do every thing with a reference to my gratification, by which means you yourself also will receive the greatest pleasure.
tgt_text.7351: But the statesman is not in reality ignorant that the people has the authority of a master, but still he will not admit that he himself is its slave, but looks upon him­ self as free, and as entitled to consider mainly the gratifica­ tion of the soul.
tgt_text.7352: And he will say in plain words:
tgt_text.7353: I have not learnt to be a slave to the will of the populace, nor will I ever study such a practice, but being desirous to attain to the government and administration of the city like a good steward or well-intentioned father, I will save it in a guile­ less and honourable manner, without any hostile character.
tgt_text.7354: And while I cherish these sentiments I shall be open to examination, concealing nothing, and not hiding any thing like a thief, but keeping my conscience clear as in the light of the sun and of day ;
tgt_text.7355: for the truth is the light.
tgt_text.7356: And I shall fear none of the evils with which they menace me, not even if they threaten me with death;
tgt_text.7357: for hypocrisy is in my eyes a more grievous evil than death.
tgt_text.7358: And why should I encounter what I look upon in such a light ?
tgt_text.7359: For even if the populace be a despot, am I therefore a slave, I who am born of as noble ancestors as any one in the world, entitled to be enrolled as a free citizen in the greatest and most admirable state in this whole world ?
tgt_text.7360: For as I am not influenced by gifts, nor by exhortations, nor by a love of honours, nor by a desire of power, nor by insolence, nor by a desire of seeming different from what I am, nor by intemperance, nor by cowardice, nor by injustice, nor by any other motive partaking of either passion or wickedness ;
tgt_text.7361: what can, then, be the dominion of which 1 have need to fear?
tgt_text.7362: Surely it can only be the dominion of men.
tgt_text.7363: But they claim authority, indeed, over my body, but none at all over me ;
tgt_text.7364: for I estimate myself by the more excellent part of myself, namely, by the mind in accordance with which I have determined to live, thinking but little of my mortal body, which sticks to me like a limpet, and even if it is injured by something or other, I shall not be grieved at having got rid of cruel masters and mistresses who arc settled within, inasmuch as I shall have escaped the most formidable necessity.
tgt_text.7365: If, therefore, it shall be necessary for mc to act as a judge, I will decide, neither adhering to any rich man for the sake of his riches, nor gratifying a poor man by reason of my compassion for his misfortunes, but putting out of sight the rank and outward circumstances of those respecting whom I am to judge, I will honestly pronounce in favour of what shall appear to me to be just.
tgt_text.7366: And if I am called to counsel I will bring forward such opinions as shall appear to me to be for the common advantage, even though they may not be palatable.
tgt_text.7367: And if I am a member of the assembly, leaving flattering speeches to others, I will adopt only such as are advantageous and salutary, reproving, admonishing, correct­ ing, and studying not a frantic and insane license of speech, but a sober freedom.
tgt_text.7368: And if any one dislikes improvement, let such a one find fault with parents, and guardians, and teachers, and with all who have the care of youth, because they reprove their own children, or their orphan wards, or their pupils, and some­ times even beat them ;
tgt_text.7369: and yet they are not to be accused of evil speaking, nor of insolent violence, but on the contrary, they must be looked upon as friends and real well-wishers;
tgt_text.7370: for it would be utterly unworthy for me who am experienced in affairs of state, and who have all the interests of the people entrusted to me in discussions respecting what is for the advantage of the commonwealth to behave worse than a man would who has studied the art of a physician;
tgt_text.7371: for be would not in the least regard the brilliant position or the accre­ dited good fortune of his patient, nor whether he is of noble birth or of large fortune, nor whether he is the most renowned monarch or tyrant of all his contemporaries, but would attend to one object alone, that, namely, of preserving his health to the best of his power.
tgt_text.7372: And if it should be necessary to use excision or cautery, he, though a subject, or as some might say a slave, would cut or burn his governor or his master.
tgt_text.7373: But I, who have got for my patient not one man but a whole city sick with those more grievous diseases which the kindred desires have brought upon it, what ought I to do ?
tgt_text.7374: Shall I, abandoning all idea of what will be of general advantage to the whole state seek to please the ears of this or that man with an ungentleman-like and thoroughly slavish flattery ?
tgt_text.7375: I would rather choose to die than to speak merely with the object of gratifying the ear, and to conceal the truth, disregarding all thought of what is really advan­ tageous.
tgt_text.7376: " Now then," as the tragedian says:
tgt_text.7377: " Now then let fire, let biting steel come on ;
tgt_text.7378: Burn, scorch my flesh, and glut your appetite Drinking my dark, warm blood ;
tgt_text.7379: for here I swear Sooner shall those bright stars which deck the heaven Descend beneath the earth, the earth itself Soar upwards to the sky, than servile words
tgt_text.7380: Of flattery creep from out my mouth to thee.
tgt_text.7381: "But the people, when it is the master, cannot endure a statesman of so masculine a spirit, and one who keeps so completely aloof from the passions, from pleasure, from fear, from grief, from desire;
tgt_text.7382: but it arrests its well-wisher and friend, and punishes him as an enemy, in doing which it first of all inflicts upon itself the most grievous of all punish­ ments, namely, ignorance;
tgt_text.7383: in consequence of which state it does not itself learn that lesson which is the most beautiful and profitable of all, namely, obedience to its governor, from which the knowledge how to govern subsequently springs.
tgt_text.7385: Having now discussed this matter at sufficient length, let us see what follows next.
tgt_text.7386: The young man, having been calumniated to his master by his master's wife, who was in love with him, and who had invented against him the accusation to which she her­ self was liable, is not allowed to make any defence, but is led away to prison.
tgt_text.7387: And while he was in the prison he dis­ played such exceeding virtue that even the most abandoned persons there marvelled and were amazed, and looked upon it as an alleviation of their calamities to have found such a man as the averter of evil from them.
tgt_text.7388: And of the cruelty and inhumanity of which gaolers are full there is no one who is ignorant.
tgt_text.7389: For they are both by nature pitiless, and also by constant practice they are made more and more brutal, and increase in ferocity day by day, never seeing, or saying, or doing any good thing, but committing only acts of violence and barbarity.
tgt_text.7390: For as men who have very strongly knit bodies, when besides their natural strength they add to it the practice of wrestlers, become stronger still, and acquire an irresistible power and a surpassing perfection of body, so in the same manner when an untameable and implacable nature adds habit to its natural ferocity, it becomes inaccessible to, and immovable by any kind of pity or any single respectable or humane feeling.
tgt_text.7391: And as those who associate with good men are improved in their disposition by such association, rejoicing in the pleasant and good persons with whom they are living;
tgt_text.7392: so also do they who are living with the wicked take the impres­ sion of their wicked ways ;
tgt_text.7393: for habit is a very powerful thing to put a force upon nature, and to make it resemble itself:
tgt_text.7394: now keepers of prisons live among thieves and robbers, and housebreakers, and men of insolence and vio­ lence, and murderers, and adulterers, and plunderers of temples, from every one of whom they contract some wicked­ ness, and collect a sort of contribution:
tgt_text.7395: and from their manifold mixture, make up one thoroughly confused and wholly polluted iniquity.
tgt_text.7397: Nevertheless, even such a man as this was pro­ pitiated by the virtue of this young man, and not only gave him liberty and security, but even entrusted to him a share of authority over all the prisoners ;
tgt_text.7398: so that in word, indeed, and as far as the title went, he continued to be the goaler;
tgt_text.7399: but in reality he had made over all the active part of the work to the young man, in consequence of which conduct of his the prisoners were benefited in no slight degree.
tgt_text.7400: Accordingly they no longer thought fit to call the place a prison, but a house of correction :
tgt_text.7401: for instead of tortures and punishments which they had previously undergone night and day, being beaten and bound with chains, and suffering every imaginable kind of ill-treatment;
tgt_text.7402: they were now ad­ monished with the language and doctrines of philosophy, and also by the life and conduct of their teacher, which was more effective than any discourse in the world;
tgt_text.7403: for he, by placing his own life full of temperance and every kind of virtue before them, as a picture and well-constructed model of virtue, changed even those who had appeared to be utterly incurable, so that the long diseases of their souls now got a respite, since they were afflicting themselves for what they had hitherto done, and were repenting of it, and uttering such expressions as these, " Where was there all this good formerly which we originally failed to find?
tgt_text.7405: now it shines forth to such a degree that we are ashamed to face it, seeing our deformity in it as in a looking-glass.
tgt_text.7407: AVhile they thenwere being improved in this manner two of the king's eunuchs are brought into the prison;
tgt_text.7408: the one being his chief butler, and the other his chief baker, having been accused and condemned for malversation in the offices committed to their charge.
tgt_text.7409: And Joseph took the same care of them that he took of the others, praying that he might be able to make all those who were entrusted to his care in no respect inferior to irreproachable persons.
tgt_text.7410: And when no long period had elapsed, he went to visit his pri­ soners on one occasion, when he saw these eunuchs more full of perplexity, and more downcast than they bad been before ;
tgt_text.7411: and conjecturing from their excessive grief that some strange event had befallen them, he inquired the rea­ son of their sorrow.
tgt_text.7412: And when they answered him, that they were full of distress and perplexity because they had seen dreams, and because there was no one who could in­ terpret them to them, he said "
tgt_text.7413: Be of good cheer, and relate them to me;
tgt_text.7414: for so, if God will, you shall be led to un­ derstand them;
tgt_text.7415: for he is willing to reveal, to those who are desirous of the truth, those things which are concealed in darkness.
tgt_text.7416: "Then the chief butler spoke first, and said, " I thought that a great vine grew up, having three roots, and one very vigorous trunk, and flourishing, and bearing bunches of grapes as if in the height of autumn, and when the grapes became dark and ripe I picked the bunches, and squeezed the grapes into the king's cup, in order to convey to my sovereign a sufficient quantity of unmixed wine."
tgt_text.7417: And Jo­ seph, pausing for awhile, said, " Thy vision announces good fortune to thee, and a recovery of thy former situation ;
tgt_text.7418: for the three roots of the vine signify figuratively three days, after which the king will remember thee, and will send for thee from hence, and will pardon thee, and will permit thee to resume thy former rank, and shalt again pour him out wine for confirmation of thy authority, and shalt give the cup into thy master's hand."
tgt_text.7419: And the chief butler rejoiced when he heard these things.
tgt_text.7421: And the chief baker, gladly receiving this inter­ pretation, and rejoicing in the idea that he too had seen a favourable dream (though his dream was of a very contrary character), being deceived by the fair hopes which were held out to the other, spoke as follows :
tgt_text.7423: And I, too, fancied that I was carrying a basket, and that I was holding three baskets full of cakes upon my head.
tgt_text.7424: And the upper basket was full of all sorts of cakes which the king was accustomed to eat;
tgt_text.7425: and there were in it confections and delicacies of all kinds imaginable for the king's food:
tgt_text.7426: and the birds flew down and took them from off my head, and devoured them insatiably till they had eaten them all up ;
tgt_text.7427: and none of the things which I had so skilfully prepared were left."
tgt_text.7428: But Joseph replied, " I wish that the vision bad not appeared to you, or that, having appeared, it had been concealed in silence;
tgt_text.7429: or that, if any one would speak of it, he had done so at a distance, so that I might not have heard him, and that his account had been given out of the reach of my ears, for I disliked to be a messenger of evil:
tgt_text.7430: for I sympa­ thise with those who are in distress, being greatly grieved at what befalls them by reason of my own humanity.
tgt_text.7431: But since interpreters of dreams are bound to speak the truth, since they are interpreters of the divine oracles, and pro­ phets of the divine will, I will explain your dream to you, and conceal nothing;
tgt_text.7432: for to speak truly is in every case the best thing, and is, moreover, the most holy of all holy speeches."
tgt_text.7433: The three baskets are a symbol of three days :
tgt_text.7434: and after three days the king will command you to be crucified, and your head to be cut off, and the birds will fly down and feast upon your flesh, until you are wholly devoured."
tgt_text.7435: And the chief baker, as was natural, was confused at this, and cast down greatly, expecting the fate which was thus de­ nounced against him, and being full of misery in his mind.
tgt_text.7436: But when the three days had passed, the king's birth-day came, on which all the natives of the country made an as­ sembly and a feast, and especially those in the king's palace.
tgt_text.7437: Therefore, while the magistrates were feasting, and while all the household and all the servants were revelling as in a public banquet, the king, remembering his eunuchs who were in prison, commanded them to be brought;
tgt_text.7438: and when he had seen them he confirmed the interpretation of their dreams which Joseph had given, ordering one of them to be crucified, and to have his head cut off, and restoring to the other the office which he had formerly enjoyed.
tgt_text.7440: But the chief butler, after he was released, forgot him who had foretold his release to him, and who had alleviated all the misfortunes which had befallen him, perhaps, indeed, because every ungrateful man is forgetful of bene­ fits, and perhaps, too, because of the providence of God, who designed that the prosperity of the young man should not be owing to man, but rather to himself;
tgt_text.7441: for after two years he, by means of a dream, and by two visions, pre­ dicted to the king the good and.
tgt_text.7442: evil which was about to happen to his land, each of the visions indicating the same thing, so as to produce a firmer belief in them.
tgt_text.7443: For he thought that seven oxen were coming slowly up out of the river, fat and very well fleshed, beautiful to look upon, and that they began to feed by the river;
tgt_text.7444: after which seven others, equal in number, destitute of flesh in a strange degree, and very lean, came up, exceedingly ill-favoured, and they too fed alongside of the others.
tgt_text.7445: Then, on a sudden, the better oxen were devoured by the inferior ones, and yet those who ate them were in none, not even in the very slightest degree, increased in bulk in their bodies, but were still leaner than before, or, at all events, not less lean ;
tgt_text.7446: and when he had awakened and gone to sleep a second time, he bad a second vision appear to him;
tgt_text.7447: for he thought that seven ears of wheat sprang up from one root, equal in mag­ nitude, and that they grew and flourished, and rose up to a height with great vigour;
tgt_text.7448: and then that seven other ears, thin and weak, grew up near them, and the root with good ears was devoured by the weak ears when they too had grown up.
tgt_text.7449: Seeing this sight he remained sleepless all the rest of the night, for cares stinging and wounding him kept him awake, and at dawn he sent for the sophists and related his dream;
tgt_text.7450: and as none of them was able, by any probable conjectures, to trace out the truth, the chief butler came forward and said, " 0 master, there is a hope that you may find the man whom you are seeking;
tgt_text.7451: for when I and the chief baker had done evil against you you ordered us to be committed to prison ;
tgt_text.7452: and in that prison there was a servant of the chief cook, a Hebrew, to whom both the chief baker and I related some dreams which had appeared to us, and be answered them with such felicity and accuracy of inter­ pretation, that all that he foretold to either of us came to pass, the punishment to the chief baker, which was ap­ pointed to him, and I found you favourable and merciful to me.
tgt_text.7454: Therefore the king hearing these things, orders men to go in haste and summon the young man before him;
tgt_text.7455: but they having cut his hair, for the hair, both of his head and of his beard, had grown very long while he was kept in prison, and having given him a splendid garment instead of a sordid one, and having adorned him in other ways, led him before the king;
tgt_text.7456: who, perceiving from his appearance that he was a free-born and noble man (for there are certain outward characteristics which are stamped upon the persons of some people whom one sees, which are not visible to all, but only to such as have very clear-sighted eyes in their mind), said, "
tgt_text.7457: My soul forebodes that my dreams will not be altogether permanently hidden in uncertainty;
tgt_text.7458: for this young man exhibits an appearance of, wisdom, by which he will be able to reveal the truth, and, as it were, dissipate the darkness by light, and the ignorance of the sophists at our court by his knowledge," " And then he related to him his dream.
tgt_text.7459: But Joseph, without being at all dismayed at the rank and majesty of the speaker, conversed with him rather as a king with a subject than like a subject with a king, using freedom of speech, though mingled with respect, and he said:
tgt_text.7460: God has shown you before what he is about to do in your country.
tgt_text.7461: Do not imagine that the two visions which have appeared to thee are two different dreams ;
tgt_text.7462: they are but one and the reduplication of them is not superfluous, but is intended to produce the conviction of a firmer belief;
tgt_text.7463: for the seven fat oxen, and the seven flourishing and vigorous ears of corn, show seven years of great fertility and plenty;
tgt_text.7464: and the seven lean and ill-favoured oxen which came up after the fat ones, and the seven withered and shrivelled - ears of corn, denote seven other years of famine;
tgt_text.7465: therefore the first period of seven years thus denoted will arrive first, having great and abundant fertility of crops, in which the river will every year overflow all the land of Egypt with inundations, and all the plains, as if they had never been irrigated or fertilised before.
tgt_text.7466: And after these years there will come a period of seven years entirely contrary to them bringing with it a terrible want and scarcity of necessary things, during which time the river will not overflow, nor will the earth be fertilised, so that it will forget its former prosperity, and so that all that was left from the former abundance of the crops will be consumed.
tgt_text.7467: This then is the interpretation of the dreams which have appeared to you.
tgt_text.7468: But there is something divine which prompts me and communicates some suggestions to me which may be salutary in this disease;
tgt_text.7469: and the most terrible disease of all cities and countries is famine, which must be checked or mitigated to some degree that it may not be so exceedingly strong as to devour the inhabitants ;
tgt_text.7471: That which shall be more than sum­ cient of the crop in the seven years, during which the plenty lasts, after having taken so much as is adequate to the nourishment of the people, and that will be perhaps a fifth part, must be stored up in granaries in the cities and villages, not removing the erops to any great distance, but storing them in the countries to which they belong, and keeping them there for the relief of the people who dwell in each district;
tgt_text.7472: and it will be wellto bring together the crop with the sheaves, not thrashing it out, nor winnowing, nor sifting it at all, for four reasons.
tgt_text.7473: First of all, because if it is thus protected by the straw it will remain uninjured a longer time;
tgt_text.7474: secondly, in order that every year the people may be reminded of the former period of plenty while they are threshing and winnowing ;
tgt_text.7475: for the imitation of the former real blessings is calculated to pro­ duee a second pleasure ;
tgt_text.7476: thirdly, in order to prevent any exact calculation of the quantity stored up, as, while the erop is in the ear and in the sheaf, it is of uncertain amount and not easily to be described;
tgt_text.7477: that so the hearts of the people of the land may not faint beforehand at the consumption of what has been treasured up, but may use with eheerfulness the nourishment of the eorn which is thus provided for them, (for hope is of all things the most strengthening), and so may to a certain extent feel relief in the bitter disease of scarcity;
tgt_text.7478: fourthly, because in this way fodder may also be provided for the eattle, as the straw and the ehaff derived from the threshing of the wheat will be of use to them in this way.
tgt_text.7479: And you must appoint a man to superintend all these measures, of great prudence, and great aeuteness, and well approved in all matters, who may be able without incurring hatred or envy to do all that I have here described in a proper manner, without giving to the multitude any reason to suspect the impending famine;
tgt_text.7480: for it would be a sad thing for them to anticipate their distress, and so to faint in their souls through despair;
tgt_text.7481: and if any one should inquire the reason of all this being done, the superintendent may say that, as in peace it is right to provide things that may be necessary in war, so also it is desirable in years of plenty to provide against want;
tgt_text.7482: and that wars and famines are in their nature uncertain, and in short so are all the different events which befall men unexpectedly at different times;
tgt_text.7483: for which therefore it is necessary to be prepared ;
tgt_text.7484: and not when such things have befallen one, then to seek a remedy when it is no longer of any avail.
tgt_text.7486: And when the king had heard these words, and had seen that the interpretation of the dreams did thus with felicity and accuracy of conjecture arrive at the truth, and that the advice which the young man gave appeared to be of exceeding use in the way of providing against the uncer­ tainty of the future, he ordered those who were about him to approach nearer so that they might hear what he said ;
tgt_text.7487: and then he spoke as follows:
tgt_text.7488: Can we, 0 men, find any man equal to this man who has the spirit of God resting on him ?
tgt_text.7489: And when they all praised his words, and raised their voices in accordance with them, he looked on Joseph as he was standing before him and said:
tgt_text.7490: The man whom you advise me to seek out is near at hand;
tgt_text.7491: the wise and intelligent man whom we have need of is at no great distance;
tgt_text.7492: you yourself are he whom, in accordance with your recommendation, we ought to seek for, for you do not appear to me to have been inspired by anything short of God him­ self, when you said what you have now said to me.
tgt_text.7493: Go then, and take the superintendence of my household and the government of all Egypt;
tgt_text.7494: and no one will blame my indifference or easiness, as if I were yielding to indolence and selfish love of ease, under this calamity so difficult to be remedied;
tgt_text.7495: for great natures are often tested without requir­ ing a long time for their examination, compelling men by their intrinsic weight and power to be rapid, and to discard all delay in receiving them, and some affairs do not admit of any delay or procrastination when the occasions compel us to necessary promptness of action.
tgt_text.7496: After speaking thus, Pharaoh appointed Joseph his lieutenant in the kingdom, or rather, if one is to speak the exact truth, actual king, leaving to himself only the name of kingly power;
tgt_text.7497: but in reality yielding up the whole sovereignty to him, and behaving in every respect so as to confer honour on the young man.
tgt_text.7498: Therefore he gave him a royal seal, and a sacred robe, and a golden circlet to go round his neck, and he made him to ride in the second chariot which he had, and commanded him in that state to go round the city, a herald also going round with him, and announcing his appointment to those who were ignorant of it.
tgt_text.7499: Moreover, he changed his name with reference to his interpretation of dreams, giving him an appellation according to the language of the country, and he gave him for his wife the most beautiful and noble of all the women in Egypt, the daughter of the priest of the sun.
tgt_text.7500: These things happened when Joseph was about thirty years of age.
tgt_text.7501: And such is the end of pious persons;
tgt_text.7502: for, even if they stumble they do not wholly fall, but rise again after an interval, and are re-established in a firm and solid manner, so as not to be completely prostrated.
tgt_text.7503: For who would ever have expected that in one day the same man would become a master from having been a slave, and from having been a prisoner would rise up the most illustrious of men, and that the under turnkey of the keeper of the prison would become the king's lieutenant, and that he would dwell in the king's palace instead of in the gaol, having the highest honour in the whole land instead of being held in tho greatest disrepute ?
tgt_text.7504: Nevertheless these things really did come to pass, and similar things often will come to pass when it seems good to God.
tgt_text.7505: Only let there be one single spark of excellence and virtue implanted in the soul, and that must some day or other be fanned into a flame and shine forth.
tgt_text.7507: But since we have proposed to ourselves to give not only an explanation of the literal account given to us, but also of its more figurative meaning, we must say what is necessary to be said concerning that also.
tgt_text.7508: Perhaps now some persons of rash and inconsiderate dispositions will laugh;
tgt_text.7509: nevertheless, I will speak without concealing anything.
tgt_text.7510: And I will say that the statesman is at all times an interpreter of dreams, not classing him by this statement among the charlatans and vain chatterers, and men who put forth sophistical pretences by way of making money, or among those who profess the explanation of visions which have appeared to persons in their sleep in the hope of acquiring gain;
tgt_text.7511: but I mean that the statesman is accustomed to in­ terpret accurately the great, and common, and universal general dreams, not only of sleeping but alsoof waking persons.
tgt_text.7512: And this dream, to speak the truth, is the life of man;
tgt_text.7513: for as in the visions which appear to us in sleep, which see­ ing we do not see, and hearing we do not hear, and tasting and touching we do not either taste or touch, and speaking we do not speak, and walking we do not walk, and while ap­ pearing to exert other motions or to win other positions we are not in reality in any such motions or positions ;
tgt_text.7514: but they are mere empty fancies without any truth in them of the mind which fancies to itself a sketch;
tgt_text.7515: and makes to itself a repre­ sentation of things which are not, as if they were;
tgt_text.7516: and in like manner the fancies which occur to waking people re­ semble the dreams of sleepers.
tgt_text.7517: They have come, they have departed ;
tgt_text.7518: they have appeared, they have disappeared;
tgt_text.7519: before they could be scarcely comprehended they have flown away.
tgt_text.7520: And let every one who dreams in this way inquire within him­ self and he will find a proof of these things within, and with­ out any proofs from me he will know the truth of what I say, especially if he happens to be at all an old man.
tgt_text.7521: He was at one time an infant, and after that a child, and then a boy, and then a youth, and subsequently a young man, and then a man, and last of all an old man, but he was not all these things at the same time.
tgt_text.7522: Did not the infant disappear before the child, and the child before the boy, and the boy before the youth, and the youth before the young man, and the young man before the full-grown man, and the man in the prime of life before the old man ?
tgt_text.7523: and did not old age disappear in death ?
tgt_text.7524: Perhaps, also, every one of the different ages of life yields in vigour to the one which comes next to it, and so dies before its time, nature by these means teaching us not to fear the death which comes upon all men, inasmuch as we have found it easy to bear the previous deaths, the death that is of the infant, and that of the child, and that of the boy, and that of the youth, and that of the young man, and that of the full grown man, not one of whom exist any longer when old age has arrived.
tgt_text.7526: And are not all the other things, relating to the body, dreams ?
tgt_text.7527: Is not beauty an ephemeral thing, wasting away almost before it comes to its prime ?
tgt_text.7528: And is not health an unsure thing by reason of the weaknesses which lie in wait to upset it ?
tgt_text.7529: Again, is not strength a thing easily destroyed by diseases arising from innumerable causes ?
tgt_text.7530: and is not the accuracy of all our outward senses easily over­ turned by the entrance of any vicious humour ?
tgt_text.7531: As to ex­ ternal things, who is there who is ignorant of the uncer­ tainty of them ?
tgt_text.7532: In one day vast riches have often come absolutely to nothing ?
tgt_text.7533: Numbers of persons who have been of the highest consideration, and who have enjoyed the highest honours that the earth affords, have come into disre­ pute from causes which they neglected or despised.
tgt_text.7534: The most mighty powers and authority of kings have been over­ thrown, and have disappeared in a very brief moment of time.
tgt_text.7535: There is an example to testify to the truth of my argu­ ment in Dionysius, who lived at Corinth, who had been tyrant of Sicily, and who, after he was expelled from his dominions, took refuge in Corinth;
tgt_text.7536: and though he had been so mighty a sovereign, became a schoolmaster.
tgt_text.7537: There is another witness to the same point in Crcesus, the king of Lydia, the wealthiest of all monarchs, who, having conceived the hope of destroying the kingdom of the Persians, not only lost all his men, but was taken prisoner, and was at the point of being burnt alive.
tgt_text.7538: And there are witnesses of dreams not only among men, but also among cities, and na­ tions, and countries ;
tgt_text.7539: Greece is such, and the region of the barbarians, and inhabitants of continents, and islanders, and Europe and Asia, and the west, and the east;
tgt_text.7540: for absolutely nothing whatever has ever remained in its original condi­ tion ;
tgt_text.7541: but everything has in every particular been subject to change.
tgt_text.7542: Egypt had once the supreme authority over many nations, but now it is a slave.
tgt_text.7543: The Macedonians at one time were so flourishing and powerful that they had ob­ tained the supreme dominion over the whole world;
tgt_text.7544: but now they pay yearly tribute, which is levied on them by their masters, to the collectors of the revenue.
tgt_text.7545: Where is the house of the Ptolemies, and the glory of all the individual successors of Alexander which at one time shone over all the bounds both of earth and sea ?
tgt_text.7546: Where is the liberty of so many independent nations and cities ?
tgt_text.7547: On the other hand, where is the slavery of those which were subject to them ?
tgt_text.7548: Did not the Persians at one time reign over the Parthians ?
tgt_text.7549: and do not the Parthians now, through, the changes of human affairs, and through the ex­ traordinary and total alterations which are continually taking place, rule over the Persians ?
tgt_text.7550: Some persons flatter them­ selves with ideas of long and interminable prosperity ;
tgt_text.7551: but they find that their good fortune is only the beginning of great calamities ;
tgt_text.7552: and hastening forward as if to an in­ heritance of good things, they find instead, terrible reverses;
tgt_text.7553: and on the contrary it has often happened, that when they have expected evil fortune they have met with good.
tgt_text.7554: Athletes, who have prided themselves on their personal good condition, and power, and vigour of body, and who have hoped to obtain an indisputable victory, have often been either refused permission to contend for the prize at all, not having been approved of, or else, after they have descended into the arena, they have been defeated;
tgt_text.7555: while others who have despaired of arriving even at the second honours, have been crowned with the garland of victory, and have carried off the first prize.
tgt_text.7556: Again, some persons setting sail in the summer (for that is the season for fair voyages) have been shipwrecked;
tgt_text.7557: while others, who have expected to be overwhelmed by reason of being forced to put to sea, have reached their harbour un­ injured, without having even incurred any danger.
tgt_text.7558: As some merchants hasten forward as if to confessed gain, being ignorant of the losses which are awaiting them ;
tgt_text.7559: while others who have anticipated losses, have in effect met with great profits—so very uncertain is fortune on either side, whether for good or evil;
tgt_text.7560: and human affairs are as it were, weighed in a scale, being lightened or depressed according as the weights in each scale are unequal.
tgt_text.7561: And a terrible indis­ tinctness and dense darkness is spread over human affairs.
tgt_text.7562: And we wander about as if in a deep sleep, without being able to arrive at anything with perfect accuracy of reason­ ing, or to seize hold of anything with a firm and retentive grasp ;
tgt_text.7563: for all things are like shadows and phantoms.
tgt_text.7564: And as in processions, what comes first passes by quickly and escapes the sight;
tgt_text.7565: and as in torrents, the stream which is hurried by outruns, by its swiftness and rapidity, the comprehension of man, so likewise do the affairs of life, being rapidly borne onwards, and passing by swiftly, appear indeed, to be stationary, but in fact, do not stand still a moment, but are continually being dragged onwards.
tgt_text.7566: And men awake too, who, as far as the uncertain character of their comprehensions goes, are in no respect different from people asleep, deceiving themselves, think themselves com­ petent to contemplate the nature of things with reasoning powers which cannot err ;
tgt_text.7567: in whose case every one of their external senses is a hindrance to knowledge, being hurried by spectacles, and by peculiarities of flavours or odours, to which they incline, and by which they are perverted, and in consequence of which they prevent any part of the soul from being in a sound state, and from advancing without stumbling as if along a level road.
tgt_text.7568: And humble pride, and great littleness, and all other similar states which are made up of inequality and anomaly, compel men to walk in a sort of giddiness, and create great dizziness and per­ plexity.
tgt_text.7570: Since, then, life is full of all this irregularity, and confusion, and indistinctness, it is necessary that the statesman as well as the philosopher should approach the science of the interpretation of dreams, so as to under­ stand the dreams and visions which appear by day to people who believe themselves to be awake, being guided by pro­ bable conjectures and rational probabilities, and in this way he must explain each separate one, and show that such and such a thing is honourable, another disgraceful, that this is good or that is bad ;
tgt_text.7571: that this thing is just, that thing is on the contrary unjust;
tgt_text.7572: and so on in the same way with respect to prudence, and courage, and piety, and holiness, and expediency, and usefulness ;
tgt_text.7573: and in like manner of the opposite things, with respect to what was not useful nor reasonable, what was ignoble, impious, unholy, inexpedient, pernicious, and selfish.
tgt_text.7574: Moreover, lie warns you in this way :
tgt_text.7575: is this something belonging to another ?
tgt_text.7578: use it as not using it.
tgt_text.7581: for the beauty of riches is not in the purse, but in the power it gives one to succour those who are in need.
tgt_text.7583: do not envy those who have much ;
tgt_text.7584: no one will pity a poor man who is always envious.
tgt_text.7585: Are you in high reputation, and are you held in much honour ?
tgt_text.7586: be not insolent on that account.
tgt_text.7587: Are you lowly in your fortunes ?
tgt_text.7588: still let not your spirit be depressed.
tgt_text.7589: Does everything succeed with you according to your wish ?
tgt_text.7592: hope for good fortune here­ after ;
tgt_text.7593: for the changes of human affairs are apt to be in a direction opposite to the course they have formerly taken.
tgt_text.7594: The moon and the sun, indeed, and the whole of the heaven has clearness bright and distinct, inasmuch as all things are alike which exist permanently in the heaven;
tgt_text.7595: and as they are all measured by the rules of truth itself, in har­ monious order and in the most admirable agreement.
tgt_text.7596: But as for earthly things, which are full of great disorder and confusion, they are inharmonious and discordant, to speak with perfect correctness, so that dense darkness has over­ taken some of them, while others resemble the most brilliant light, or rather they are themselves the clearest and purest of light.
tgt_text.7597: If, therefore, any one should wish to look closely into the nature of things, he will find that heaven is everlasting day, free from all participation in night or in any kind of shade, inasmuch as it is surrounded uninterruptedly by a brilliant display of inextinguishable and unadulterated light.
tgt_text.7598: And in the same proportion as among us those who are awake are superior to those who are asleep, so also in the universal world the things of heaven are superior to the things of earth;
tgt_text.7599: since the one enjoys an everlasting wakefulness which knows no sleep, on account of its energies which never stray, and never stumble, and which proceed rightly and successfully in every thing;
tgt_text.7600: while the others are oppressed by sleep, and if they wake up for a short time they are again pulled down and buried in slumber;
tgt_text.7601: because they are unable to look steadfastly and correctly at any thing with their souls, but are always straying and stumbling.
tgt_text.7602: For they are overshadowed by false opinions, by which they are compelled to submit to dreams, and are always behind the real truth, and are unable to comprehend any thing with a firm and tenacious grasp.
tgt_text.7604: Moreover, Joseph is figuratively said to have been mounted upon the second best chariot which the king had, for the following reason.
tgt_text.7605: The statesman stands in the second rank next to the king ;
tgt_text.7606: for he is not a private indivi­ dual nor a king, but some one on the confines between the two.
tgt_text.7607: Being indeed superior to a private individual, and inferior in respect of authority to an absolute and indepen­ dent king, having the people for his king, on behalf of whom he has determined to do every thing with a pure and per­ fectly guileless good faith;
tgt_text.7608: and he is borne as it were on high in a well-built chariot, being lifted on high both by the things committed to his charge and by the people, and especially so when he contains in his mind every thing, whether small or great, without any one ever opposing or resisting him, but all being cheerfully governed by him under God to their own safety like sailors enjoying a fair voyage.
tgt_text.7609: And the ring which the king gives him is the most mani­ fest proof of confidence which the people, his king, places in the statesman, and also of that trust with which the states­ man relies on the people which is as powerful as a king.
tgt_text.7610: And the golden circlet round his neck appears to indicate figuratively both high reputation and punishment at the same moment.
tgt_text.7611: For as long as all the affairs which concern the administration of the state proceed prosperously as far as he is concerned, he is proud, and is looked upon with veneration, and is honoured' by the multitudes.
tgt_text.7612: But the moment that any unforeseen mishap occurs to him, not indeed intended, for such error deserves reproach, but arising from pure chance, which always deserves pardon, he is not the less dragged downwards by the ornament around his neck, and is humbled, his master all but saying to him in plain words, ',I, indeed, gave you this circlet to be around thy neck, to be both an ornament while my affairs were going on well, and a halter when they were proceeding unfavourably."XX.
tgt_text.7613: Moreover, I have also heard people discussing this passage with great apparent accuracy in a more figurative manner and according to quite a different interpretation.
tgt_text.7614: And their notion of it is this.
tgt_text.7615: They say that the king of Egypt means our mind:
tgt_text.7616: the governor of the region of the body in every individual in us, and who like a king claims the supreme power.
tgt_text.7617: And by him when he has become devoted to the service of the body three objects are especially laboured at as being accounted worthy of exceeding care, namely, meat, and sweetmeats, and drinkables.
tgt_text.7618: With reference to which fact he also employs three persons to superintend the objects aforesaid, his chief baker, and his chief butler, and his chief cook.
tgt_text.7619: The one of whom presides over those things which relate to eating, the second over those things which belong to drinking, and the last to those sweetenings and sauces which belong to the confections.
tgt_text.7621: because the man who is devoted to pleasure is barren and unproductive of every thing which is most necessary, such as modesty, temperance, continence, justice, and every kind of virtue.
tgt_text.7622: For there is no one thing so hostile to another as pleasure is to virtue, for the sake of which most people neglect all those matters which alone it is worth while to attend to, gratifying their unrestrained appetites, and sub­ mitting to all the commands which they impose upon them.
tgt_text.7623: Therefore, the chief cook is not committed to prison at all, nor does he fall into any misfortune, because his sauces and sweetenings are not among the things which are very necessary, not being pleasures but only provocations to pleasure, such as are easily extinguished.
tgt_text.7624: But of the two who are occupied in the employment of the miserable belly, the chief baker and the chief butler, since eating and drink­ ing are of all the things which are useful to life those which have the greatest power to keep the being together, and those who have the management of those things, if they bestow great care upon them, do very justly obtain praise;
tgt_text.7625: while, if they neglect them, they are thought worthy of anger or punishment.
tgt_text.7626: But there is a difference in their punishments, because the need of the two things is different;
tgt_text.7627: that of food being the most indispensable, but that of wine not being very useful;
tgt_text.7628: for men can live without any wine, using only the pure drink of spring water.
tgt_text.7629: On which account there is a reconciliation made with, and pardon bestowed upon, the chief butler, as upon one who has erred in the least import­ ant particular.
tgt_text.7630: But the offences of the chief baker admit of no reconciliation and of no forgiveness, but incur an anger which leads to death, as he has been guilty of wrong in the most necessary matters;
tgt_text.7631: for want of food is followed by death.
tgt_text.7632: On which account he who has erred on these points very appropriately is put to death by hanging, suffer­ ing an evil similar to that which he has inflicted;
tgt_text.7633: for lie also has hanged, and suffocated, and stretched out the famishing man by means of hunger.
tgt_text.7635: This is enough to say on this subject.
tgt_text.7636: Accord­ ingly Joseph, being appointed the king's lieutenant, and having undertaken the government and superintendence of the whole of Egypt, went forth in order to become acquainted with all the natives, and investigated all the laws that were established in the different cities, and caused a great affec­ tion for himself to arise in the breasts of those who saw him, not only because of the services which he conferred upon every one of them, but also by the unspeakable and unrivalled graces of his appearance and by the courtesy with which he associated with them.
tgt_text.7637: But when, in accord­ ance with the interpretation of the dreams, the first seven years of fertility arrived, he collected one-fifth of the pro­ duce every year by means of his subordinate officers and others who were employed under him in the public offices, and by this means he collected such a vast quantity of sheaves of corn as no one recollected as having ever existed at any previous time.
tgt_text.7638: And the most evident proof of this is that they could not possibly be counted, even although thousands and thousands of persons were occupied in the task, whose sole business it was to devote all their energies to count them.
tgt_text.7639: And when these seven years had passed, during which the plain of Egypt was fertile, the famine began, which, as it proceeded and increased, was not confined to Egypt;
tgt_text.7640: for as it became diffused, and from time to time extended, so as to be always comprehending fresh cities and countries in suc­ cession, it reached to the farthest borders of the land, both in the eastern and western direction, so as to reach at last over the whole world all around.
tgt_text.7641: Accordingly, it is said that no general pestilence ever extended so widely, not even that which the sons of the physicians call the creeping pestilence ;
