tgt_text.681: And after he had endowed it with fair proportions, he clothed it with beauty of flesh, and embellished it with an exquisite corn­ plexion, wishing, as far as was possible, that man should appear the most beautiful of beings.
tgt_text.683: And that he is superior to all these animals in regard of his soul, is plain.
tgt_text.684: For God does not seem to have availed himself of any other animal existing in creation as his model in the formation of man ;
tgt_text.685: but to have been guided, as I have said before, by his own reason alone.
tgt_text.686: On which account, Moses affirms that this man was an image and imitation of God, being breathed into in his face in which is the place of the sensations, by which the Creator endowed the body with a soul.
tgt_text.687: Then, having placed the mind in the dominant part as king, he gave him as a body of satellites, the different powers calculated to perceive colours and sounds, and flavours and odours, and other things of similar kinds, which man could never have distinguished by his own resources without the sen­ sations.
tgt_text.688: And it follows of necessity that an imitation of a perfectly beautiful model must itself be perfectly beautiful, for the word of God surpasses even that beauty which exists in the nature which is perceptible only by the external senses, not being embellished by any adventitious beauty, but being itself, if one must speak the truth, its most exquisite embellishment.
tgt_text.690: The first man, therefore, appears to me to have been such both in his body and in his soul, being very far supe­ rior to all those who live in the present day, and to all those who have gone before us.
tgt_text.691: For our generation has been from men :
tgt_text.692: but he was created by God.
tgt_text.693: And in the same proportion as the one Author of being is superior to the other, so too is the being that is produced.
tgt_text.694: For as that which is in its prime is superior to that the beauty of which is gone by, whether it be an animal, or a plant, or fruit, or anything else whatever of the productions of nature ;
tgt_text.695: so also the first man who was ever formed appears to have been the height of perfection of our entire race, and subsequent generations appear never to have reached an equal state of perfection, but to have at all times been inferior both in their appearance and in their power, and to have been constantly degenerating, which same thing I have also seen to be the case in the instance of the sculptors' and painters' art.
tgt_text.696: For the imitations always fall short of the ori­ ginal models.
tgt_text.697: And those works which are painted or fashioned from models must be much more inferior, as being still further removed from the original.
tgt_text.698: And the stone which is called the magnet is subject to a similar deterioration.
tgt_text.699: For any iron ring which touches it is held by it as firmly as possible, but another which only touches that ring is held less firmly.
tgt_text.700: And the third ring hangs from the second, and the fourth from the third, and the fifth from the fourth, and so on one from another in a long chain, being all held together by one attractive power, but still they are not all supported in the same degree.
tgt_text.701: For those which are suspended at a distance from the original attraction, are held more loosely, because the attractive power is weakened, and is no longer able to bind them in an equal'degree.
tgt_text.702: And the race of mankind appears to be subject to an in­ fluence of the same kind, since in men the faculties and dis­ tinctive qualities of both body and soul are less vivid an'd strongly marked in each succeeding generation.
tgt_text.703: And we shall be only saying what is the plain truth, if we call the original founder of our race not only the first man, but also the first citizen of the world.
tgt_text.704: For the world was his house and his city, while he had as yet no structure made by hands and wrought out of the materials of wood and stone.
tgt_text.705: And in this world lie lived as in his'own country, in all safety, removed from any fear, inasmuch as he had been thought worthy of the do­ minion over all earthly things;
tgt_text.706: and had everything that was mortal crouching before him, and taught to obey him as their master, or else constrained to do so by superior force, and living himself surrounded by all the joys which peace can be­ stow without a struggle and without reproach.
tgt_text.708: But since every city in which laws are properly estab­ lished, has a regular constitution, it became necessary for this citizen of the world to adopt the same constitution as that which prevailed in the universal world.
tgt_text.709: And this constitution is the right reason of nature, which in more appropriate lan­ guage is denominated law, being a divine arrangement in ac­ cordance with which everything suitable and appropriate is assigned to every individual.
tgt_text.710: But of this city and constitution there must have been some citizens before man, who might be justly called citizens of a mighty city, having received the greatest imaginable circumference to dwell in ;
tgt_text.711: and having been enrolled in the largest and most perfect commonwealth.
tgt_text.712: And who could these have been but rational divine natures, some of them incorporeal and perceptible only by intellect, and others not destitute of bodily substance, such in fact as the stars ?
tgt_text.713: And he who associated with and lived among them was naturally living in a state of unmixed happiness.
tgt_text.714: And being akin and nearly related to the ruler of all, inasmuch as a great deal of the divine spirit had flowed into him, he was eager both to say and to do everything which might please his father and his king, following him step by step in the paths which the virtues prepare and make plain, as those in which those souls alone are permitted to proceed who consider the attaining a likeness to God who made them as the proper end of their existence.
tgt_text.716: We have now then set forth the beauty of the first created man in both respects, in body and soul, if in a way much inferior to the reality, still to the extent of our power, and the best of our ability.
tgt_text.717: And it cannot be but that his descendants, who all partake of his original character, must preserve some traces of their relationship to their father, though they may be but faint.
tgt_text.719: Every man in regard of his intellect is connected with divine reason, being an impression of, or a fragment or a ray of that blessed nature ;
tgt_text.720: but in regard of the structure of his body he is connected with the universal world.
tgt_text.721: For he is composed of the same materials as the world, that is of earth, and water, and air and fire, each of the elements having contributed its appropriate part towards the completion of most sufficient ma­ terials, which the Creator was to take in order to fashion this visible image.
tgt_text.722: And, moreover, mail dwells among all the things that have been just enumerated, as most appropriate places having the closest connection with himself, changing his abode, and going at different times to different places.
tgt_text.723: So that one may say with the most perfect propriety that mail is every kind of animal, terrestrial, aquatic, flying, and celestial.
tgt_text.724: For inasmuch as he dwells and walks upon the earth he is a terrestrial animal;
tgt_text.725: but inasmuch as he often dives and swims, and sails, he is an aquatic creature.
tgt_text.726: And merchants and cap­ tains of ships and purple dyers, and all those who let down their nets for oysters and fish, are a very clear proof of what is here said.
tgt_text.727: Again, inasmuch as his body is raised at times above the earth and uses high paths, lie may with justice be pronounced a creature who traverses the air;
tgt_text.728: and, moreover, he is a celestial animal, by reason of that most important of the senses, sight;
tgt_text.729: being by it brought near the sun and moon, and each of the stars, whether planets or fixed stars.
tgt_text.731: And with great beauty Moses has attributed the giving of names to the different animals to the first created man, for it is a work of wisdom and indicative of royal authority, and man was full of intuitive wisdom and self-taught, having been created by the grace of God, and, moreover, was a king.
tgt_text.732: And it is proper for a ruler to give names to each of his subjects.
tgt_text.733: And, as was very natural, the power of domination was exces­ sive in that first-created man, whom God formed with great care and thought worthy of the second rank in the creation, making him his own viceroy and the ruler of all other crea­ tures.
tgt_text.734: Since even those who have been born so many genera­ tions afterwards, when the race is becoming weakened by reason of the long intervals of time that have elapsed since the be­ ginning of the world, do still exert the same power over the irrational beasts, preserving as it were a spark of the dominion and power which has been handed down to them by succession from their first ancestor.
tgt_text.736: God brought all the animals to man, wishing to see what names he would give to each."
tgt_text.737: Not because he was in doubt, for nothing is unknown to God, but because he knew that he had formed in mortal man a rational nature capable of moving of its own accord, in order that he might be free from all participation in vice.
tgt_text.738: But he was now trying him as a master might try his pupil, stirring up the disposition which he had implanted in him ;
tgt_text.739: and more­ over exciting him to a contemplation of his own works, that he might extemporise them names which should not be inappro­ priate nor unbecoming, but which should well and clearly dis­ play the peculiar qualities of the different subjects.
tgt_text.740: For as the rational nature was as yet uncorrupted in the soul, and as no weakness, or disease, or affliction had as yet come upon it, man having most pure and perfect perceptions of bodies and of things, devised names for them with great felicity and cor­ rectness of judgment, forming very admirable opinions as to the qualities which they displayed, so that their natures were at once perceived and correctly described by him.
tgt_text.741: And he was so excellent in all good things that he speedily arrived at the very perfection of human happiness.
tgt_text.743: But since nothing in creation lasts for ever, but all mortal things are liable to inevitable changes and alterations, it was unavoidable that the first man should also undergo some disaster.
tgt_text.744: And the beginning of his life being liable to re­ proach, was his wife.
tgt_text.745: For, as long as he was single, he resembled, as to his creation, both the world and God ;
tgt_text.746: and he represented in his soul the characteristics of the nature of each, I do not mean all of them, but such as a mortal constitution was capable of admitting.
tgt_text.747: But when woman also was created, man perceiving a closely connected figure and a kindred for­ mation to his own, rejoiced at the sight, and approached her and embraced her.
tgt_text.748: And she, in like manner, beholding a creature greatly resembling herself, rejoiced also, and addressed him in reply with due modesty.
tgt_text.749: And love being engendered, and, as it were, uniting two separate portions of one animal into one body, adapted them to each other, implanting in each of them a desire of connection with the other with a view to the generation of a being similar to themselves.
tgt_text.750: And this desire caused likewise pleasure to their bodies, which is the beginning of iniquities and transgressions, and it is owing to this that men have exchanged their previously immortal and happy existence for one which is mortal and full of mis­ fortune.
tgt_text.752: But while man was still living a solitary life, and before woman was created, the history relates that a paradise was planted by God in no respect resembling the parks which are seen among men now.
tgt_text.753: For parks of our day are only life­ less woods, -full of all kinds of trees, some evergreen with a view to the undisturbed delectation of the sight;
tgt_text.754: others bud­ ding and germinating in the spring season, and producing fruit, some eatable by men, and sufficient, not only for the ne­ cessary support of nature as food, but also for the superfluous enjoyment of luxurious life ;
tgt_text.755: and some not eatable by men, but of necessity bestowed upon the beasts.
tgt_text.756: But in the paradise, made by God, all the plants were endowed in the souls and reason, producing for their fruit the different virtues, and, moreover, imperishable wisdom and prudence, by which honour­ able and dishonourable things are distinguished from one another, and also a life free from disease, and exempt from corruption, and all other qualities corresponding to these al­ ready mentioned.
tgt_text.757: And these statements appear to me to be dictated by a philosophy which is symbolical rather than strictly accurate.
tgt_text.758: For no trees of life or of knowledge have ever at any previous time appeared upon the earth, nor is it likely that any will appear hereafter.
tgt_text.759: But I rather conceive that Moses was speaking in an allegorical spirit, intending by his paradise to intimate the dominant character of the soul, which is full of innumerable opinions as this figurative paradise was of trees.
tgt_text.760: And by the tree of life he was shadowing out the greatest of the virtues-namely, piety towards the gods, by means of which the soul is made immortal;
tgt_text.761: and by the tree which had the knowledge of good and evil, he was intimating that wisdom and moderation, by means of which things,' contrary in their nature to one another, are distinguished.
tgt_text.763: Therefore, having laid down these to be boundaries as it were in the soul, God then, like a judge, began to consider to which side men would be most inclined by nature.
tgt_text.764: And when he saw that the disposition of man had a tendency to wickedness, and was but little inclined to holiness or piety, by which qualities an immortal life is secured, he drove them forth as was very natural, and banished him from paradise;
tgt_text.765: giving no hope of any subsequent restoration to his soul which had sinned in such a desperate and irremediable manner.
tgt_text.766: Since even the opportunity of deceit was blameable in no slight degree, which I must not pass-over in this place.
tgt_text.767: It is said that the old poisonous and earthborn reptile, the serpent, uttered the voice of a man.
tgt_text.768: And he on one occasion coming to the wife of the first created man, reproached her' with her slowness and her excessive prudence, because she delayed and hesitated to gather the fruit which was com­ pletely beautiful to look at, and exceedingly sweet to enjoy, and was, moreover, most useful as being a means by which men might be able to distinguish between good and evil.
tgt_text.769: And she, without any inquiry, prompted by an unstable and rash mind, acquiesced in his advice, and ate of the fruit, and gave a portion of it to her husband.
tgt_text.770: And this conduct suddenly changed both of them from innocence and simplicity of cba­ racter to all kinds of wickedness ;
tgt_text.771: at which the Father of all was indignant.
tgt_text.772: For their actions deserved his anger, inasmuch as they, passing by the tree of eternal life, the tree which might have endowed them with perfection of virtue, and by means of which they might have enjoyed a long and happy life, preferred a brief and mortal (I will not call it life, but) time full of unhappiness ;
tgt_text.773: and, accordingly, he appointed them such punishment as was befitting.
tgt_text.775: And these things are not mere fabulous inventions, in which the race of poets and sophists delights, but are rather types shadowing forth some allegorical truth, according to some mystical explanation.
tgt_text.776: And any one who follows a reasonable train of conjecture, will say with great propriety, that the aforesaid serpent is the symbol of pleasure, because in the first place lie is destitute of feet, and crawls on his belly with his face downwards.
tgt_text.777: In the second place, because he uses lumps of clay for food.
tgt_text.778: Thirdly, because he bears poison in his teetb, by which it is his nature to kill those who are bitten by him.
tgt_text.779: And the man devoted to pleasure is free from none of the aforementioned evils;
tgt_text.780: for it is with difficulty that he can raise his head, being weighed down and dragged down, since intemperance trips him up and keeps him down.
tgt_text.781: And he feeds, not on heavenly food, which wisdom offers to contem­ plative men by means of discourses and opinions ;
tgt_text.782: but on that which is put forth by the earth in the varying seasons of the year, from which arise drunkenness and voracity, and licen­ tiousness, breaking through and inflaming the appetites of the belly, and enslaving them in subjection to gluttony, by which they strengthen the impetuous passions, the seat of which is beneath the belly;
tgt_text.784: And they lick up the result of the labours of cooks and tavern-keepers ;
tgt_text.785: and at times some of them in ecstasy with the flavour of the delicious food, moves about his head and reaches forward, being desirous to participate in the sight.
tgt_text.786: And when he sees an ex­ pensively furnished table, he throws himself bodily upon the delicacies which are abundantly prepared, and devotes himself to them, wishing to be filled with them all together, and so to depart, having no other end in view than that he should allow nothing of such a sumptuous preparation to be wasted.
tgt_text.787: Owing to which conduct, he too, carries about poison in his teeth, no less than the serpent does ;
tgt_text.788: for his teeth are the ministers and servants of his insatiability, cutting up and smoothing everything which has a reference to eating, and committing them, in the first place to the tongue, which decides upon, and distinguishes between the various flavours, and, subsequently, to the larynx.
tgt_text.789: But immoderate indulgence in eating is natu­ rally a poisonous and deadly habit, inasmuch as what is so devoured is not capable of digestion, in consequence of the quantity of additional food which is heaped in on the top of it, and arrives before what was previously eaten is converted into juice.
tgt_text.790: And the serpent is said to have uttered a human voice, because pleasure employs innumerable champions and de­ fenders who take care to advocate its interests, and who dare to assert that the power over everything, both small and great, does of right belong to it without any exception whatever.
tgt_text.792: Now, the first approaches of the male to the female have a pleasure in them which brings on other pleasures also, and it is through this pleasure that the formation and genera­ tion of children is carried on.
tgt_text.793: And what is generated by it appears to be attached to nothing rather than to it, since they rejoice in pleasure, and are impatient at pain, which is its con­ trary.
tgt_text.794: On which account even the infant when first brought forth cries, being as it seems in pain at the cold.
tgt_text.795: For coming forth on a sudden into the air from a very warm, and indeed, hot region-namely, the womb, in which it has been abiding a considerable time, the air being a cold place and one to which it is wholly unaccustomed, it is alarmed, and pours forth tears as the most evident proof of its grief and of its impatience at pain.
tgt_text.796: For every animal, it is said, hastens to pleasure as to the cud which is most indispensable and necessary to its very existence ;
tgt_text.797: and, above all other animals, this is the case with mail.
tgt_text.798: For other animals pursue pleasure only in taste and in the acts of generation;
tgt_text.799: but man aims at it by means of his other senses also, devoting himself to whatever sights or sounds can impart pleasure to his eyes or ears.
tgt_text.800: And many other things are said in the way of praise of this inclination, especially that it is one most peculiar and kindred to all animals.
tgt_text.802: But what has been already said is sufficient to show what the reasons were on account of which the serpent appears to have uttered a human voice
tgt_text.803: And it is on this account that Moses appears to me in the particular laws also which be issued in the respect to animals, deciding what were proper to be,eaten, and what were not, to have given especial praise to the animal called the serpent fighter.
tgt_text.804: This is a reptile with jointed legs above its feet, by which it is able to leap and to raise itself on high, in the same manner as the tribe of locusts.
tgt_text.805: For the serpent fighter appears to me to be no other than temperance expressed under a symbolical figure, waging an interminable and unrelenting warfare against intemperance and pleasure.
tgt_text.806: For temperance especially embraces economy and frugality, and pares down the necessities to a small number, preferring a life of austerity and dignity.
tgt_text.807: But intemperance is devoted to extravagance and superfluity, which are the causes of luxury and effeminacy to both soul and body, and to which it is owirg that in the opinion of wise men life is but a faulty thing, and more miserable than death.
tgt_text.809: But its juggleries and deceits pleasure does not ven­ ture to bring directly to the man, but first offers them to the woman, and by her means to.
tgt_text.811: acting in a very natu­ ral and sagacious manner.
tgt_text.812: For in human beings the mind occupies the rank of the man, and the sensations that of the woman.
tgt_text.813: And pleasure joins itself to and associates itself with the sensations first of all, and then by their means cajoles also the mind, which is the dominant part.
tgt_text.814: For, after each of the senses have been subjected to the charms of pleasure, and has learnt to delight in what is offered to it, the sight being fasci-
tgt_text.815: Hated by varieties of colours and shapes, the hearing by liar­ monious sounds, the taste by the sweetness of flowers, and the smell by the delicious fragrance of the odours which are brought before it, these all having received these offerings, like handmaids, bring them to the mind as their master, leading with them persuasion as an advocate, to warn it against reject­ ing any of them whatever.
tgt_text.816: And the mind being immediately caught by the bait, becomes a subject instead of a ruler, and a slave instead of a master, and an exile instead of a citizen, and a mortal instead of an immortal.
tgt_text.817: For we must altogether not be ignorant that pleasure, being like a courtesan or mistress, is eager to meet with a lover, and seeks for panders in order by their means to catch a lover.
tgt_text.818: And the sensations are her panders, and conciliate love to her, and she employing them as baits, easily brings the mind into subjection to her.
tgt_text.819: And the sensations conveying within the mind the things which have been seen externally, explain and display the forms of each of them, setting their seal upon a similar affection.
tgt_text.820: For the mind is like wax, and receives the impressions of appearances through the sensations, by means of which it makes itself master of the body, which of itself it would not be able to do, as I have already said.
tgt_text.822: And those who have previously become the slaves of pleasure immediately receive the wages of this miserable and incurable passion.
tgt_text.823: For the woman having received vehement pains, partly in her travail, and partly such as are a rapid suc­ cession of agonies during the other portions of her life, and especially with reference to the bringing forth and bringing up of her children, to their diseases and their health, to their good or evil fortune, to an extent that utterly deprives her of her freedom and subjects her to the dominion of the man who is her companion, finds it unavoidable'to obey all his com­ mands.
tgt_text.824: And the man in his turn endures toils and labours, and continual sweats, in order to the providing of himself with necessaries, and he also bears the deprivation of all those spontaneous good things which the earth was originally taught to produce without requiring the skill of the farmer, and he is subjected to a state in which he lives in incessant labour, for the purpose of seeking for food and means of subsistence, in order to avoid perishing by hunger.
tgt_text.825: For I think that as the sun and the moon do continually give light, ever since they were originally commanded to do so at the time of the original creation of the universe, and as they constantly obey the divine injunction, for the sake of no other reason but because evil and disobedience are banished to a distance far from the boundaries of heaven :
tgt_text.826: so in the same way would the fertile and productive regions of the earth yield an immense abundance in the various seasons of the year, without any skill or co-operation on the part of the husbandman.
tgt_text.827: But at present the ever-flowing fountains of the graces of God have been checked, from the time when wicked­ ness began to increase faster than the virtues, in order that they might not be supplying men who were unworthy to be benefited by them.
tgt_text.828: Therefore, the race of mankind, if it had met with strict and befitting justice, must have been utterly destroyed, because of its ingratitude to God its benefactor and its Saviour.
tgt_text.829: But God, being merciful by nature, took pity upon them, and moderated their punishment.
tgt_text.830: And he per­ mitted the race to continue to exist, but he no longer gave them food as he had done before from ready prepared stores, lest if they were under the dominion of his evils, satiety and idleness, they should become unruly and insolent.
tgt_text.832: Such is the life of those who originally were men of innocence and simplicity, and also of those who have come to prefer vice to virtue, from whom one ought to keep aloof.
tgt_text.833: And in his beforementioned account of the creation of the world, Moses teaches us also many other things, and especially five most beautiful lessons which are superior to all others.
tgt_text.834: In the first place, for the sake of convicting the atheists, he teaches us that the Deity has a real being and existence.
tgt_text.835: Now, of the atheists, some have only doubted of the existence of God, stating it to be an uncertain thing ;
tgt_text.836: but others, who are more audacious, have taken courage, and asserted positively that there is no such thing ;
tgt_text.837: but this is affirmed only by men who have darkened the truth with fabulous inventions.
tgt_text.838: In the second place he teaches us that God is one;
tgt_text.839: having reference here to the assertors of the polytheistic doctrine ;
tgt_text.840: men who do not blush to transfer that worst of evil constitu­ tions, ochlocracy, from earth to heaven.
tgt_text.841: Thirdly, he teaches, as has been already related, that the world was created;
tgt_text.842: by this lesson refuting those who think that it is uncreated and eternal, and who thus attribute no glory to God.
tgt_text.843: In the fourth place we learn that the world also which was thus created is one, since also the Creator is one, and he, making his creation to resemble himself in its singleness, em­ ployed all existing essence in the creation of the universe.
tgt_text.844: For it would not have been complete if it had not been made and composed of all parts which were likewise whole and com­ plete.
tgt_text.845: For there are some persons who believe that there are many worlds, and some who even fancy that they are boundless in extent, being themselves inexperienced and ignorant of the truth of those things of which it is desirable to have a correct knowledge.
tgt_text.846: The fifth lesson that Moses teaches us is, that God exerts his providence for the benefit of the world.
tgt_text.847: For it follows of necessity that the Creator must always care for that which he has created, just as parents do also care for their children.
tgt_text.848: And he who has learnt this not more by hearing it than by his own understanding, and has impressed on his own soul these marvellous facts which are the subject of so much contention- namely, that God has a being and existence, and that he who so exists is really one, and that he has created the world, and that he has created it one as has been stated, having made it like to himself in singleness ;
tgt_text.849: and that he exercises a con­ tinual care for that which he has created will live a happy and blessed life, stamped with the doctrines of piety and holiness.
tgt_text.851: And the heaven and the earth and all their world was completed.”*
tgt_text.852: Having previously related the creation of the mind and of sense, Moses now proceeds to describe the perfection which was brought about by them both.
tgt_text.853: And he says that neither the indivisible mind nor the particular sen­ sations received perfection, but only ideas, one the idea of the mind, the other of sensation.
tgt_text.854: And, speaking symbolically, he calls the mind heaven, since the natures which can only be comprehended by the intellect are in heaven.
tgt_text.855: And sensation he calls earth, because it is sensation which has obtained a corporeal and somewhat earthy constitution.
tgt_text.856: The ornaments of the mind are all the incorporeal things, which are percep­ tible only by the intellect.
tgt_text.857: Those of sensation are the cor­ poreal things, and everything in short which is perceptible by the external senses.
tgt_text.859: And on the sixth day God finished his work which he.
tgt_text.861: It would be a sign of great simplicity to think that the world was created in six days, or indeed at all in time;
tgt_text.862: because all time is only the space of days and nights, and these things the motion of the sun as he passes over the earth and under the earth does necessarily make.
tgt_text.863: But the sun is a portion of heaven, so that one must confess that time is a thing posterior to the world.
tgt_text.864: Therefore it would be cor­ rectly said that the world was not created in time, but that time had its existence in consequence of the world.
tgt_text.865: For it is the motion of the heaven that has displayed the nature of time.
tgt_text.866: When, therefore, Moses says, " God completed his works on the sixth day," we must understand that he is speaking not of a number of days, but that he takes six as a perfect number.
tgt_text.867: Since it is the first number which is equalin its parts, -in the half, and the third and sixth parts, and since it is produced by the multiplication of two unequal factors, two and three.
tgt_text.868: And the numbers two and three exceed the incorporeality which exists in the unit;
tgt_text.869: because the number two is an image of matter being divided into two parts and dissected like matter.
tgt_text.870: And the number three is an image of a solid body, because a solid can be divided according to a threefold division.
tgt_text.871: Not but what it is also akin to the motions of organic animals.
tgt_text.872: For an organic body is naturally capable of motion in six directions, forward, backwards, upwards, downwards, to the right, and to the left.
tgt_text.873: And at all events he desires to show that the races of mortal, and also of all the immortal beings, exist according to their appropriate numbers ;
tgt_text.874: measuring mortal beings, as I have said, by the number six, and the blessed and immortal beings by the number seven.
tgt_text.875: First, therefore, having desisted from the creation of mortal creatures on the seventh day, he began the formation of other and more divine beings.
tgt_text.877: For God never ceases from making something or other;
tgt_text.878: but, as it is the property of fire to burn, and of snow to chill, so also it is the property of God to be creating.
tgt_text.879: And much more so, in proportion as he himself is to all other beings the author of their working.
tgt_text.880: Therefore the expression, " he caused to rest," is very appropriately employed here, not " he rested.” , For he makes things to rest which appear to be producing others, but which in reality do not effect anything;
tgt_text.881: but he himself never ceases from creating.
tgt_text.882: On which account Moses says, " He caused to rest the things which he had begun."
tgt_text.883: For all the things that are made by our arts when completed stand still and remain ;
tgt_text.884: but all those which are accomplished by the knowledge of God are moved at subsequent times.
tgt_text.885: For their ends are the beginnings of other things ;
tgt_text.886: as, for instance, the end of day is the beginning of night.
tgt_text.887: And in the same way we must look upon months and years when they come to an end as the beginning of those which are just about to follow them.
tgt_text.888: And so the generation of other things which are de­ stroyed, and the destruction of others which are generated is completed, so that that is true which is said that-
tgt_text.889: And nought that is created wholly dies;
tgt_text.890: But one thing parted and combined with others Produces a fresh form.
tgt_text.892: But nature delights in the number seven.
tgt_text.893: For there are seven planets, going in continual opposition to the daily course of the heaven which always proceeds in the same direc­ tion.
tgt_text.894: And likewise the constellation of the Bear is made up of seven stars, which constellation is the cause of communica­ tion and unity among men, and not merely of traffic.
tgt_text.895: Again, the periodical changes of the moon, take place according to the number seven, that star having the greatest sympathy with the things on earth.
tgt_text.896: And the changes which the moon works in the air, it perfects chiefly in accordance with its own configura­ tions on each seventh day.
tgt_text.897: At all events, all mortal things, as I have said before, drawing their more divine nature from the heaven, are moved in a manner which tends to their pre­ servation in accordance with this number seven.
tgt_text.898: For who is there who does not know that those infants who are born at the end of the seventh month are likely to live, but those who have taken a longer time, so as to have abided eight months in the womb, are for the most part abortive births ?
tgt_text.899: And they say that man is a reasoning being in his first seven years, by which time he is a competent interpreter of ordinary nouns and verbs, making himself master of the faculty of speaking.
tgt_text.900: And in his second period of seven years, he arrives at the perfection of his nature ;
tgt_text.901: and this perfection is the power of generating a being like himself ;
tgt_text.902: for at about the age of fourteen we are able to beget a creature resembling ourselves.
tgt_text.903: Again, the third period of seven years is the termination of his growth ;
tgt_text.904: for up to the age of one and twenty years man keeps on in­ creasing in size, and this time is called by many maturity.
tgt_text.905: Again, the irrational portion of the soul is divisible into seven portions ;
tgt_text.906: - the five senses, and the organ of speech, and the power of generation.
tgt_text.907: Again, the motions of the body are.
tgt_text.909: the six organic motions, and the rotatory motion.
tgt_text.910: Also the entrails are seven-the stomach, the heart, the spleen, the liver, the lungs, and the two kidneys.
tgt_text.911: In like manner the limbs of the body amount to an equal number-the head, the neck, the chest, the two hands, the belly, the two feet.
tgt_text.912: Also the most important part of the animal, the face, is divisible according to a sevenfold division-the two eyes.
tgt_text.913: and the two ears, and as many nostrils, and in the seventh place, the mouth.
tgt_text.914: Again, the secretions are seven — tears, mucus from the nose, saliva, the generative fluid, the two excremental dis­ charges, and the sweat that proceeds from every part of the body.
tgt_text.915: Moreover, in diseases the seventh day is the most critical period-and in women the catamenial purifications extend to the seventh day.V.
tgt_text.916: And the power of this number has extended also to the most useful of the arts-namely, to grammar.
tgt_text.917: At all events, in grammar, the most excellent of the elements, and those which have the most powers, are the seven vowels.
tgt_text.918: And like­ wise in music, the lyre with seven strings is nearly the best of all instruments;
tgt_text.919: because the euharmonic principle which is the most dignified of all the principles of melody, is especially perceived in connection with it.
tgt_text.920: Again, it happens that the tones of the voice are seven-the acute, the grave, the contracted, the aspirate, the lene, the long and the short sound
tgt_text.921: The number seven is also the first number which is compounded of the perfect number, that is to say of six, and of the unit.
tgt_text.922: And in some sense the numbers which are below ten are either generated by, or do themselves generate those numbers which are below ten, and the number ten itself.
tgt_text.923: But the number seven neither generates any of the numbers below ten, nor is it generated by any of them.
tgt_text.924: On which account the Pythagoreans compare this number to the Goddess always a virgin who was born without a mother,* because it was not generated by any other, and will not gene­ rate any other.
tgt_text.926: Accordingly, on the seventh day, God caused to rest from all his works which he had made.”†
tgt_text.927: Now, the meaning of this sentence is something of this kind.
tgt_text.928: God ceases from forming the races of mortal creatures when he begins to create the divine races, which are akin to the nature of the number seven.
tgt_text.929: And the reference which is here contained to their moral character is of the following nature.
tgt_text.930: When that reason which is holy in accordance with the number seven has entered into the soul the number six is then arrested, and all the mortal things which this number appears to make.
tgt_text.931: VII. " And God blessed the seventh day, and hallowed it."
tgt_text.932: God blesses the manners which are formed in accordance with the seventh and divine light, as being truly light, and imme­ diately declares them holy.
tgt_text.933: For that which is blessed, and that which is holy, are closely connected with one another.
tgt_text.934: On this account he says, concerning him who has vowed a great vow, that "
tgt_text.935: If a sudden change comes over him, and pollutes his mind, he shall no longer be holy.
tgt_text.937: *But the previous days were not taken into the calculation, as was natural, For those manners which are not holy are not counted, so that which is blessed is alone holy.
tgt_text.938: Correctly therefore, did Moses say that "
tgt_text.939: God blessed the seventh day and hallowed it," because on it he " caused to rest from all his works which he had begun to make."
tgt_text.940: And this is the reason why he who lives and conducts himself in accor­ dance with the seventh and perfect light is blessed and holy, since it is in accordance with his nature, that the creation of mortal beings was terminated.
tgt_text.942: when the light of virtue, which is brilliant and really divine, rises up, then the generation of the contrary nature is checked.
tgt_text.943: And we have shown that God never desists from creating something, but that when he appears to do so he is only be­ ginning the creation of something else;
tgt_text.944: as being not only, the Creator, but also the Father of everything which exists.
tgt_text.946: “This is the book of the generation of heaven and earth, when they were created."t
tgt_text.947: This is perfect reason, which is put in motion in accordance with the number seven, being the beginning of the creation of that mind which was arranged according to the ideas, and also of the sensation ar­ ranged according to the ideas, and perceptible only by the in­ tellect, if one can speak in such a manner.
tgt_text.948: And Moses calls the word of God a book, in which it is come to pass that the formations of other things are written down and engraved.
tgt_text.949: But, lest you should imagine that the Deity does anything ac­ cording to definite periods of time, while you should rather think that everything done by him is inscrutable in its nature, uncertain, unknown to, and incomprehensible by the race of mortal men.
tgt_text.950: Moses adds the words, " when they were cre­ ated," not defining the time when by any exact limitation, for what has been made by the Author of all things has no limitation.
tgt_text.951: And in this way the idea is excluded, that the universe was created in six days.
tgt_text.953: On which day God created the heaven and the earth, and every green herb of the field, before it appeared upon the earth, and all the grass of the field before it sprang up.
tgt_text.954: For God did not rain upon the earth, and man did not exist to cul­ tivate the earth."
tgt_text.955: This day Moses has previously called a book, since at least he describes the generation of both heaven and earth in each place.
tgt_text.956: For by his most conspicuous and brillant'word, by one command, God makes both things :
tgt_text.957: the idea of mind, which, speaking symbolically, he calls heaven, and the idea of sensation, which by a sign he named earth.
tgt_text.958: And he likens the idea of mind, and the idea of sen sation to two fields;
tgt_text.959: for the mind brings forth fruit, which consists in having intellectual perception;
tgt_text.960: and sensation brings forth other fruits which consist in perceiving by the agency of the external senses.
tgt_text.961: And what he says has the following meaning ;
tgt_text.962: -as there was a previously existing idea of the particular mind, and also of the indivisible minds to serve as an archetype and model for either ;
tgt_text.963: and also a pre- existent idea of particular sensation, being, so to say, a sort of seal which gave impressions of forms, so before particular things perceptible only by the intellect had any existence, there was a pre-existent abstract idea of what was perceptible only by intellect, by participation in which the other things also received their names;
tgt_text.964: and before particular objects perceptible by the.
tgt_text.965: external senses, existed, there was also a generic some­ thing perceptible by the external senses, in accordance with a participation in which, the other things perceptible by the external senses were created.
tgt_text.966: By " the green herb of the field," Moses means that portion of the mind which is perceptible only by intellect.
tgt_text.967: For as in the field green things spring up and flourish, so also that which is perceptible only by the intellect is the fruit of the mind.
tgt_text.968: Therefore, before the particular something percepti­ ble only by intellect existed, God created the general some­ thing perceptible only by intellect, which also he correctly denominated the universe.
tgt_text.969: For since the particular something perceptible only by intellect is incomplete, that is not the universe;
tgt_text.970: but that which is generic is the universe, as being complete.X. "
tgt_text.971: And all the grass of the field," he proceeds, "before it sprang up."
tgt_text.972: That is to say, before the particular things per­ ceptible by the external senses sprang up, there existed the generic something perceptible by the external senses through the fore-knowledge of the Creator, which he again called “the universe."
tgt_text.973: And very naturally he likened the things per­ ceptible by the external senses to grass.
tgt_text.974: For as grass is the food of irrational animals, so also that which is perceptible by the external senses is assigned to the irrational portion of the soul.
tgt_text.975: For why, when he has previously mentioned " the green herb of the field," does he add also " and all the grass," as if grass were not green at all ?
tgt_text.976: But the truth is, that by the green herb of the field, he means that which is perceptible by the intellect only, the budding forth of the mind.
tgt_text.977: But grass means that which is perceptible by the external senses, that being likewise the produce of the irrational part of the soul."
tgt_text.978: For God did not rain upon the earth, and man did not exist to cultivate the earth," speaking in ihe strictest accor­ dance with natural philosophy.
tgt_text.979: For if God did not shed the perceptions of things subject to them, like rain upon the senses, in that case the mind too would not labour nor employ itself about sensation.
tgt_text.980: For he himself would be unable to effect anything by himself, unless he were to pour forth, like rain or dew, colours upon the sight, and sounds upon the hearing, and flavour on the tastes, and on all the other senses, the things proper to produce the requisite effects.
tgt_text.981: But when God begins to rain sensation on the things perceptible by the external senses, then also the mind is perceived to act like the cultivator of fertile soil.
tgt_text.982: But the idea of sensation, which he, speaking figuratively, has called the earth, is in no need of nourishment.
tgt_text.983: But the nourishment of the senses, are the particular objects perceptible by the external senses ;
tgt_text.985: But an idea is a thing different from bodies.
tgt_text.986: Before, therefore, there existed any individual compound substances, God did not rain upon that idea of sensation to which he gave the name of the earth.
tgt_text.987: And that means that he did not furnish it with any nourishment;
tgt_text.988: for, indeed, it had altogether no need of any object perceptible by the external sensesBut when Moses says, " And man did not exist to cultivate the earth," that means that the idea of intellect did not labour upon the idea of the sensations.
tgt_text.989: For my intellect and yours work up the sensations by means of things perceptible by the the external senses :
tgt_text.990: hut the idea of mind as must be the case while there is no individual body connected with it does not work upon the idea of sensation.
tgt_text.991: For if it did so work, it would of course -work by means of objects, perceptible by the external senses.
tgt_text.992: But there is no such object in ideas.
tgt_text.993: XI. " But a fountain went up upon the earth, and watered all the face of the earth."
tgt_text.994: He here calls the mind the foun­ tain of the earth, and the sensations he calls the face of the earth, because there is the most suitable place in the whole body for them, with reference to their appropriate energies, a place that nature which foreknows everything, has assigned to them.
tgt_text.995: And the mind waters the sensations like a fountain, sending appropriate streams over each.
tgt_text.996: See now how all the powers of a living animal depend upon one another like a chain.
tgt_text.997: For as the mind, and sensations, and the object perceptible by the external sense are three different things, the middle term is sensation;
tgt_text.998: and the mind, and the object perceptible by the external sense, are the two extremes.
tgt_text.999: But the mind is unable to work ;
tgt_text.1000: that is to say, to energize according to sensation, unless God rains upon and irrigates the object perceptible by the external senses, nor is there any advantage from the object perceptible to the ex­ ternal sense when watered, unless the mind, like a fountain, extending itself as far as the sensation, puts it in motion when it is quiet, and leads it on to a comprehension of the subject.
tgt_text.1001: So that the mind, and the object perceptible by the external senses, are always endeavouring to reciprocate with one another, the one the being subject to the sensations as a kind of material would be, and the mind stirring up the sensations to­ wards the external object, as a workman would do, in order to create an appetite.
tgt_text.1002: For a living animal is superior to that which is not a living animal in two points, imagination and appetite.
tgt_text.1003: Accordingly, imagination consists in the approach of the external object striking the mind by means of the sen­ sations.
tgt_text.1004: And appetite is the brother of imagination, according to the intensive power of the mind, which the mind keeps on the stretch, by means of the sensation, and so touches the sub­ ject matter, and comes over to it, being eager to arrive at and comprehend it.
tgt_text.1006: And God created man, taking a lump of clay from the earth, and breathed into his face the breath of life:
tgt_text.1007: and man became a living soul."
tgt_text.1008: The races of men are twofold ;
tgt_text.1009: for one is the heavenly man, and the other the earthly man.
tgt_text.1010: Now the heavenly man, as being born in the image of God, has no participation in any corruptible or earth-like essence.
tgt_text.1011: But the earthly man is made of loose material, which he calls a lump of clay, On which account he says, not that the heavenly man was made, but that lie ,was fashioned according to the image of God;
tgt_text.1012: but the earthly man he calls a thing made, and not begotten by the maker.
tgt_text.1013: And we must consider that the man who was formed of earth, means the mind which is to be infused into the body, but which has not yet been so infused.
tgt_text.1014: And this mind would be really earthly and corrup­ tible, if it were not that God had breathed into it the spirit of genuine life ;
tgt_text.1015: for then it " exists," and is no longer made into a soul ;
tgt_text.1016: and its soul is not inactive, and incapable of proper formation, but a really intellectual and living one.
tgt_text.1017: “ For man," says Moses, “ became a living soul.
tgt_text.1019: But some one may ask, why God thought an earth­ horn mind, which was wholly devoted to the body, worthy of divine inspiration, and yet did not treat the one made after his own idea and image in the same manner.
tgt_text.1020: In the second place he may ask, what is the meaning of the expression " breathed into."
tgt_text.1021: And thirdly, why he breathed into his face :
tgt_text.1022: fourthly also, why, since he knew the name of the Spirit when he says, " And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters,"* he now speaks of breath, and not of the Spirit.
tgt_text.1023: Now in reply to the first question we must say this one thing;
tgt_text.1024: God being very munificent gives his good things to all men, even to those who are not perfect;
tgt_text.1025: inviting them to a partici­ pation and rivalry in virtue, and at the same time displaying his abundant riches, and showing that it is sufficient for those also who will not be greatly benefited by it;
tgt_text.1026: and he also shows this in the most evident manner possible in other cases;
tgt_text.1027: for when he rains on the sea, and when he raises up fountains in desert places, and waters shallow and rough and unproduc­ tive land, making the rivers to overflow with floods, what else is he doing but displaying the great abundance of his riches and of his goodness ?
tgt_text.1028: This is the cause why he has created no soul in such a condition as to be wholly barren of good, even if the employment of that good be beyond the reach of some people.
tgt_text.1029: We must also give a second reason, which is this:
tgt_text.1030: Moses wished to represent all the actions of the Deity as just-therefore a man who had not had a real life breathed into him, but who was ignorant of virtue, when he was chas­ tised for the sins which he had committed would say that he was punished unjustly, in that it was only through ignorance of what was good that he had erred respecting it;
tgt_text.1031: and that he was to blame who had not breathed any proper wisdom into him;
tgt_text.1032: and perhaps he will even say, that he has absolutely committed no offence whatever;
tgt_text.1033: since some people affirm that actions done involuntarily and in ignorance have not the nature of offences.
tgt_text.1034: Now the expression " breathed into" is equivalent to " in­ spired," or “ gave life to" things inanimate:
tgt_text.1035: for let us take care that we are never filled with such absurdity as to think that God employs the organs of the mouth or nostrils for the purpose of breathing into anything;
tgt_text.1036: for God is not only de­ void of peculiar qualities, but he is likewise not of the form of man, and the use of these words shows some more secret mys tery of nature ;
tgt_text.1037: for there must be three things, that which breathes in, that which receives what is breathed in, and that which is breathed in.
tgt_text.1038: Now that which breathes in is God, that which receives what is breathed in is the mind, and that which is breathed in is the spirit.
tgt_text.1039: What then is collected from these three things ?
tgt_text.1040: A union of the three takes place, through God extending the power, which proceeds from him­ self through the spirit, which is the middle term, as far as the subject.
tgt_text.1041: Why does he do this, except that we may thus derive a proper notion of him ?
tgt_text.1042: Since how could the soul have perceived
tgt_text.1043: God if he had not inspired it, and touched it accord­ ing to his power?
tgt_text.1044: For human intellect would not have dared to mount up to such a height as to lay claim to the nature of God, if God himself had not drawn it up to himself, as far as it was possible for the mind of man to be drawn up, and if he had not formed it according to those powers which can be comprehended.
tgt_text.1045: And God breathed into man's face both physically and morally.
tgt_text.1046: Physically, when he placed the senses in the face:
tgt_text.1047: and this portion of the body above all others is vivified and inspired ;
tgt_text.1048: and morally, in this manner, as the face is the dominant portion of the body, so also is the mind the domi­ nant portion of the soul.
tgt_text.1049: It is into this alone that God breathes;
tgt_text.1050: but the other parts, the sensations, the power of speech, and the power of generation, he does not think worthy of his breath, for they are inferior in power.
tgt_text.1051: By what then were these subordinate parts inspired ?
tgt_text.1052: beyond all question by the mind;
tgt_text.1053: for of the qualities which, the mind has received from God, it gives a share to the irrational portion of the soul, so that the mind is vivified by God, and the irrational part of the soul by the mind;
tgt_text.1054: for the mind is as it were a god to the irrational part of the soul, for which reason Moses did not hesitate to call it " the god of Pharaoh.
tgt_text.1056: *For of all created things some are created by God, and through him :
tgt_text.1057: some not indeed by God, but yet through him:
tgt_text.1058: and the rest have their existence both by him and through him.
tgt_text.1059: At all events Moses as he proceeds says, that God planted a paradise, and among the best things as made both by God and through God, is the mind.
tgt_text.1060: But the irrational part of the soul was made indeed by God but not through God, but through the reasoning power which bears rule and sovereignty in the soul;
tgt_text.1061: and Moses has used the word " breath," not "spirit," as there is a difference between the two words;
tgt_text.1062: for spirit is conceived of according to strength, and intensity, and power;
tgt_text.1063: but breath is a gentle and moderate kind of breeze and exhalation;
tgt_text.1064: therefore the mind, which was created in accordance with the image and idea of God, may be justly said to partake in his spirit, for its reasoning has strength:
tgt_text.1065: but that which is derived from matter is only a partaker in a thin and very light air, being as it were a sort of exhalation, such as arises from spices ;
tgt_text.1066: for they, although they be preserved intact, and are not exposed to fire or fumigation, do never­ theless emit a certain fragrance.
tgt_text.1068: And God planted a paradise in Eden, in the east:
tgt_text.1069: and there he placed the man whom he had formed :
tgt_text.1070: " * for he called that divine and heavenly wisdom by many names ;
tgt_text.1071: and he made it manifest that it had many appellations;
tgt_text.1072: for he called it the beginning, and the image, and the sight of God.
tgt_text.1073: And now he exhibits the wisdom which is conversant about the things of the earth (as being an imitation of this archetypal wisdom), in the plantation of this Paradise.
tgt_text.1074: For let not such impiety ever occupy our thoughts as for us to suppose that God cultivates the land and plants paradises, since if we were to do so, we should be presently raising the question of why he does so :
tgt_text.1075: for it could not be that he might provide himself with pleasant places of recreation and pastime, or with amuse­ ment.
tgt_text.1076: Let not such fabulous nonsense ever enter our minds ;
tgt_text.1077: for even the whole world would not be a worthy place or habi­ tation for God, since he is a place to himself, and he himself is full of himself, and he himself is sufficient for himself, filling up and surrounding everything else which is deficient in any respect, or deserted, or empty ;
tgt_text.1078: but he himself is sur­ rounded by nothing else, as being himself one and the universe.
tgt_text.1079: God therefore sows and implants terrestrial virtue in the human race, being an imitation and representation of the heavenly virtue.
tgt_text.1080: For, pitying our race, and seeing that it is exposed to abundant and innumerable evils, lie firmly planted terrestrial virtue as an assistant against and warder-off of the diseases of the soul;
tgt_text.1081: being, as I have said before, an imitation of the heavenly and archetypal wisdom which he calls by various names.
tgt_text.1082: Now virtue is called a paradise metaphorically, and the ap­ propriate place for the paradise is Eden;
tgt_text.1084: and the most appropriate field for virtue is peace, and ease, and joy;
tgt_text.1085: in which real luxury especially consists.
tgt_text.1086: Moreover, the plantation of this paradise is represented in the east;
tgt_text.1087: for right reason never sets, and is never extinguished, but it is its nature to be always rising.
tgt_text.1088: And as I imagine, the rising sun fills the darkness of the air with light, so also does virtue when it has arisen in the soul, irradiate its mist and dissipate the dense darkness. "
tgt_text.1089: And there," says Moses, " he placed the man whom he had formed :
tgt_text.1090: ” for God being good, and having formed our race for virtue, as his work which was most akin to himself, places the mind in virtue, evidently in order that it, like a good husband, may cultivate and attend to nothing else except virtue.
tgt_text.1092: And some one may ask here, why, since it is a pious action to imitate the works of God, it is forbidden to me to plant a grove near the altar, and yet God plants a paradise?
tgt_text.1093: For Moses says, " You shall not plant a grove for yourself;
tgt_text.1094: you shall not make for yourself any tree which is near the altar of the Lord your God.”*
tgt_text.1095: What then are we to say?
tgt_text.1096: That it is right for God to plant and to build up the virtues in the soul.
tgt_text.1097: But the selfish and atheistical mind, thinking itself equal with God while it appears to be doing something, is found in reality to be rather suffering.
tgt_text.1098: And though God sows and plants good things in the soul, the mind which says, "I plant," is acting impiously.
tgt_text.1099: You shall not plant therefore where God is planting :
tgt_text.1100: but if, 0 mind, you fix plants in the soul, take care to plant only such trees as bear fruit, and not a grove ;
tgt_text.1101: for in a grove there are trees of a character to bear cultivation, and also wild trees.
tgt_text.1102: But to plant vice, which is unproductive in the soul, along with cultivated and fertile virtue, is the act of a double-natured and confused leprosy.
tgt_text.1103: If, however, you bring into the same place things which ought not to be mingled together, you must separate and disjoin them from the pure and incorrupt nature which is accustomed to make blameless offerings to God ;
tgt_text.1105: for it is inconsistent with this to say that there is any such thing as a work of the soul, when all things are referred to God, and to mingle barren things with those which are productive ;
tgt_text.1107: but they are blameless things which are offered to God.
tgt_text.1108: If therefore you transgress any one of these laws, 0 soul!
tgt_text.1109: you will be injuring yourself, not God.
tgt_text.1110: On this account God says, " You shall not plant for yourself:
tgt_text.1111: " for no one works for God, and especially what is evil does not.
tgt_text.1114: And in another place he says, " You shall not make gods of silver with me, and you shall not make gods of gold for yourselves."
tgt_text.1115: For he who conceives either that God has any distinctive quality, or that he is not one, or that he is not uncreated and imperishable, or that he is not unchange­ able, injures himself and not God. "
tgt_text.1116: For you shall not make them for yourselves," is what he says.
tgt_text.1117: For we must conceive that God is free from distinctive qualities, and imperishable, and unchangeable;
tgt_text.1118: and he who does not conceive thus of him is filling his own soul with false and atheistical opinions.
tgt_text.1119: Do you not see that-even though God were to conduct us to virtue, and though when we had been thus conducted we were to plant no tree which was barren, but only such as produce fruit, he would still command us to purify its impurity, that is to say, the appearing to plant.
tgt_text.1120: For he here orders us to cut away vain opinions;
tgt_text.1121: and vain opinions are a thing impure by nature.
tgt_text.1123: "And the man whom he had formed," Moses says, " God placed in the Paradise,"* for the present only Who, then, is he in reference to whom he subsequently says that " The Lord God took the man whom he had formed, and placed him in the Paradise to cultivate it and to guard it.”†
tgt_text.1124: Must not this man who was created according to the image and idea of God have been a different man from the other, so that two men must have been introduced into the Paradise together, the one a fictitious man, and the other modelled after the image of God?
tgt_text.1125: Therefore, the man modelled after the idea of God, is perceived not only amid the planting of the virtues, but, besides this, he is their cultivator and guardian ;
tgt_text.1126: that is to say, he is mindful of the things which he has heard and practised.
tgt_text.1127: But the man who is factitious, neither cultivates the virtues, nor guards them, but is only introduced into opinions by the abundant liberality of God, being on the point of immediately becoming an exile from virtue.
tgt_text.1128: Therefore, he calls that man whom he only places in Paradise, factitious;
tgt_text.1129: but him whom he appoints to be its culti­ vator and guardian he calls not factitious, but "the man whom he had made."
tgt_text.1130: And him he takes, but the other he casts out.
tgt_text.1131: And him whom he takes he thinks worthy of three things, of which goodness of nature especially consists:
tgt_text.1132: namely, expert­ ness, perseverance, and memory.
tgt_text.1133: Now, expertness is his position in Paradise ;
tgt_text.1134: memory is the guarding and preservation of holy opinions ;
tgt_text.1135: perseverance is the effecting of what is good, the performance of virtuous actions.
tgt_text.1136: But the factitious mind neither remembers what is good, nor does it, but is only expert, and nothing more;
tgt_text.1137: on which account, after it has been placed in Paradise, in a short time afterwards it runs away, and is cast out.
tgt_text.1139: And God caused to rise out of the earth every tree which is pleasant to the sight and good for food, and the tree of life he raised in the middle of the Paradise, and also the tree of the knowledge of good and evil."
tgt_text.1140: He here gives a sketch of the trees of virtue which he plants in the soul.
tgt_text.1141: And these are the particular virtues, and the energies in accordance with them, and the good and successful actions, and the things which by the philosophers are called fitting;
tgt_text.1142: these are the plants of the Paradise.
tgt_text.1143: Nevertheless, he describes the charac­ teristics of these same trees, showing that that which is desira­ ble to be beheld is likewise most excellent to be enjoyed.
tgt_text.1144: For of the arts some are theoretical and not practical, such as geometry and astronomy.
tgt_text.1145: Some, again, are practical and not theoretical, such as the art of the architect, of the smith, and all those which are called mechanical arts.
tgt_text.1146: But virtue is both theoretical and practical;
tgt_text.1147: for it takes in theory, since the road which leads to it is philosophy in three of its parts-the reasoning, and the moral, and the physical part.
tgt_text.1149: for virtue is art conversant about the whole of life;
tgt_text.1150: and in life all actions are exhibited.
tgt_text.1151: Still, although it takes in both theory and practice, nevertheless it is most excellent in each particular.
tgt_text.1152: For the theory of virtue is thoroughly excellent, and its practice and observation is a worthy object to contend for.
tgt_text.1153: On which account Moses says that the tree was pleasant to the sight, which is a symbol of theoretical excellence;
tgt_text.1154: and likewise good for food, which is a token of useful and practical good.
tgt_text.1156: But the tree of life is that most general virtue which some people call goodness;
tgt_text.1157: from which the particular virtues are derived, and of which they are composed.
tgt_text.1158: And it is on this account that it is placed in the centre of the Paradise;
tgt_text.1159: having the most comprehensive place of all, in order that, like a king, it may be guarded by the trees on each side of it.
tgt_text.1160: But some say that it is the heart that is meant by the tree of life ;
tgt_text.1161: since that is the cause of life, and since that has its position in the middle of the body, as being, according to them, the dominant part of the body.
tgt_text.1162: But these men ought to be made aware that they are expounding a doctrine which has more reference to medical than to natural science.
tgt_text.1163: But we, as has been said before, affirm that by the tree of life is meant the most general virtue.
tgt_text.1164: And of this tree Moses expressly says, that it is placed in the middle of the paradise ;
tgt_text.1165: bnt as to the other tree, that namely of the knowledge of good and evil, he has not specified whether it is within or outside of the Paradise ;
tgt_text.1166: but after he has used the following expression, " and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil," he says no more, not mentioning where it is placed, in order that any one who is uninitiated in the principles of natural philosophy, may not be made to marvel at his know­ ledge.
tgt_text.1168: That this tree is both in the Paradise and also out of it.
tgt_text.1169: As to its essence, indeed, in it;
tgt_text.1170: but as to its power, out of it.
tgt_text.1172: The dominant portion of us is capable of receiving everything, and resembles wax, which is capable of receiving every impression, whether good or bad.
tgt_text.1173: In reference to which fact, that supplanter Jacob makes a confession where he says, " all these things were made for me.”*
tgt_text.1174: For the unspeakable formations and impressions of all the things in the universe, are all borne forward into, and comprehended by the soul, which is only one.
tgt_text.1175: When, there­ fore that receives the impression of perfect virtue, it has become the tree of life ;
tgt_text.1176: but when it has received the impression of vice, it has then become the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, and vice and all evil have been banished from the divine company.
tgt_text.1177: Therefore the dominant power which has received it is in the Paradise according to its essence ;
tgt_text.1178: for there is in it that characteristic of virtue, which is akin to the Paradise.
tgt_text.1179: But again, according to its power it is not in it, because the form of virtue is inconsistent with the divine operations ;
tgt_text.1180: and what I here say, any one may understand in this manner.
tgt_text.1181: At this moment, the dominant part is in my body, according to its essence, but according to its power it is in Italy, or Sicily, when it applies its consideration to those countries, and in heaven when it is contemplating the heaven.
tgt_text.1182: On which principle it often happens that some persons who are in pro­ fane places, according to their essence, are in the most sacred places, thinking of those things which relate to virtue.
tgt_text.1183: And again, others who are in the temples of the gods, are profane in their minds, from the fact of their minds receiving a change for the worse, and evil impressions ;
tgt_text.1184: so that vice is neither in the Paradise, nor not in it.
tgt_text.1185: For it is possible that it may be in it according to its essence, but it is not possible that it should be according to its power.
tgt_text.1187: And a river goes forth out of Eden to water the Paradise.
tgt_text.1188: From thence it is separated into four heads:
tgt_text.1189: the name of the one is Pheison.
tgt_text.1190: That is the one which encircles the whole land of Evilat.
tgt_text.1191: There is the country where there is gold, and the gold of that land is good.
tgt_text.1192: There also are the car­ buncle and the sapphire stone.
tgt_text.1193: And the name of the second river is Gihon;
tgt_text.1194: this is that which encircles the whole land of Ethiopia.
tgt_text.1195: And the third river is the Tigris.
tgt_text.1196: This is the river which flows in front of the Assyrians.
tgt_text.1197: And the fourth river is the Euphrates."*
tgt_text.1198: In these words Moses intends to sketch out the particular virtues.
tgt_text.1199: And they also are four in number, prudence, temperance, courage, and justice.
tgt_text.1200: Now the greatest river from which the four branches flow off, is generic virtue, which we have already called goodness ;
tgt_text.1201: and the four branches are the same number of virtues.
tgt_text.1202: Generic virtue, therefore, derives its beginning from Eden, which is the wisdom of God ;
tgt_text.1203: which rejoices and exults, and triumphs, being delighted at and honoured on account of nothing else, except its Father, God.
tgt_text.1204: And the four particular virtues, are branches from the generic virtue, which like a river waters all the good actions of each, with an abundant stream of benefits.
tgt_text.1205: Let us examine the expressions of the writer:
tgt_text.1206: "A river," says he, " goes forth out of Eden, to water the Paradise."
tgt_text.1208: and this issues forth out of the Eden of the wisdom of God, and that is the word of God.
tgt_text.1209: For it is according to the word of God, that generic virtue was created.
tgt_text.1210: And generic virtue waters the Paradise :
tgt_text.1211: that is to say, it waters the particular virtues.
tgt_text.1212: But it does not derive its beginnings from any principle of locality, but from a principle of pre-eminence.
tgt_text.1213: For each of the virtues is really and truly a ruler and a queen.
tgt_text.1214: And the expression, " is separated," is equivalent to "is marked off by fixed boundaries ;
tgt_text.1215: ” since wis­ dom appoints them settled limits with reference to what is to be done.
tgt_text.1216: Courage with respect to what is to be endured ;
tgt_text.1217: temperance with reference to what is to be chosen;
tgt_text.1218: and justice in respect of what is to be distributed.
tgt_text.1220: “The name of one river is Pheison.
tgt_text.1221: This is that river which encircles all the land of Evilat;
tgt_text.1222: there is the country where there is gold.
tgt_text.1223: And the gold of that land is good ;
tgt_text.1224: there also are the carbuncle and the sapphire stone."
tgt_text.1225: One of the four virtues is prudence, which Moses here calls Pheison:
tgt_text.1226: because the soul abstains* from, and guards against, acts of iniquity.
tgt_text.1227: And it meanders in a circle, and flows all round the land of Evilat;
tgt_text.1228: that is to say, it preserves a mild, and gentle, and favourable constitution.
tgt_text.1229: And as of all fusible essences, the most excellent and the most illustrious is gold, so also the virtue of the soul which enjoys the highest reputation, is prudence.
tgt_text.1230: And when he uses the expression, " that is the country where there is gold," he is not speaking geographically, that is, where gold exists, but that is the country in which that valuable possession exists, brilliant as gold, tried in the fire, aud valuable, namely, prudence.
tgt_text.1231: And this is confessed to be the most valuable possession of God.
tgt_text.1232: But with reference to the geographical position of virtue, there are two personages, each invested with distinctive qualities.
tgt_text.1233: One, the being who has prudence, the other, the being who exerts it;
tgt_text.1234: and these he likens to the carbuncle and the emerald.
tgt_text.1235: XXI, " And the name of the second river is Gihon.
tgt_text.1236: This is that which encircles all the land of Ethiopia."
tgt_text.1237: Under the symbol of this river courage is intended.
tgt_text.1238: For the name of Gihon being interpreted means chest, or an animal which attacks with its horns;
tgt_text.1239: each of which interpretations is em­ blematical of courage.
tgt_text.1240: For courage has its abode about the chest, where also is the seat of the heart, and where man is prepared to defend himself.
tgt_text.1241: For courage is the knowledge of what is to be withstood, and of what is not to be withstood, and of what is indifferent.
tgt_text.1242: And it encircles and surrounds Ethiopia, making demonstrations of war against it;
tgt_text.1243: and the name of Ethiopia, being interpreted, means humiliation.
tgt_text.1244: And cowardice is a humiliating thing;
tgt_text.1245: but courage is adverse to humiliation and to cowardice."
tgt_text.1246: And the third river is the Tigris ;
tgt_text.1247: this is that which flows in front of Assyria."
tgt_text.1248: The third virtue is temperance, which resolutely opposes that kind of pleasure which appears to be the directress of human infirmity.
tgt_text.1249: For the translation of the name Assyrians in the Greek tongue is εὑθύνοvτες, (directors).
tgt_text.1250: And he has likened desire to a tiger, which is the most un­ tameable of beasts ;
tgt_text.1251: it being desire about which temperance is conversant.
tgt_text.1253: It is worth while therefore to raise the question why courage has been spoken of as the second virtue, and tempe­ rance as the third, and prudence as the first;
tgt_text.1254: and why Moses has not also explained the course of action of the other virtues.
tgt_text.1255: Now we must understand that our soul is divided into three parts, and that it has one portion which is conversant about reason;
tgt_text.1256: another which is subject to passion;
tgt_text.1257: and another which is that in which the desires are conceived.
tgt_text.1258: And we find that the proper place and abode of the reasoning part of the soul, is the head ;
tgt_text.1259: of the passionate part, the chest;
tgt_text.1260: and of the part in which the desires are conceived, the stomach.
tgt_text.1261: And we find that appropriate virtues are adapted to each of these parts.
tgt_text.1263: in it is the office of reason, to have a knowledge of what one might, and of what one ought not to do, And the virtue of the passionate part of the soul is courage :
tgt_text.1264: and of the appetitive part, temperance.
tgt_text.1265: For it is through temperance that we remedy and cure the appetites.
tgt_text.1266: For as the head is the principle and uppermost part of the animal, and the chest the next highest, and the liver the third, in point both of importance and of position ;
tgt_text.1267: so in the soul again, the first is the rational part, the second the passionate part, and the third the appetitive part.
tgt_text.1268: In the same way again of the virtues;
tgt_text.1269: the first is that which is con­ versant about the first portion of the soul, which is the reason­ ing portion, and which at the same time has its abode in the head of the body;
tgt_text.1271: And the second of the virtues is courage, because it is conversant about the second portion of the soul, namely, about passion, and has its abode in the second portion of the body, namely, in the chest.
tgt_text.1272: And the third virtue is temperance, which is placed in the stomach which is the third portion of the body, and it is conversant about the appetitive part, which has been allotted the third part of the soul, as being its subject matter.
tgt_text.1274: And the fourth river,” continues Moses, "is the river Euphrates."
tgt_text.1275: And this name Euphrates means fertility ;
tgt_text.1276: and symbolically taken, it is the fourth virtue, namely, justice, which is most truly a productive virtue, and one which gladdens the intellect.
tgt_text.1278: When the the three parts of the soul are all in harmony with one another ;
tgt_text.1279: and harmony among them is in reality the predominance of the most important;
tgt_text.1280: as for instance, when the two inferior parts, the passionate and the appetitive part, are disposed to yield to the superior part, then justice exists.
tgt_text.1281: For it is just that the better portion should rule at all times, and in all places, and that the inferior part should be ruled.
tgt_text.1282: Now the rational part is the better part, and the appetitive and the passionate parts are the inferior ones.
tgt_text.1283: But when, on the contrary, passion and appetite get riotous and disobey the reins, and by the violence of their impetuosity throw off and disregard the cha rioteer, that is to say reason, and when each of these passions get hold of the reins themselves, then there is injustice
tgt_text.1284: For it is inevitable, that through any ignorance or vice of the cha­ rioteer, the chariot must be borne down over precipices, and must fall into the abyss ;
tgt_text.1285: just as it must be saved when the charioteer is endowed with skill and virtue.
tgt_text.1287: Again, let us look at the subject in this way also.
tgt_text.1288: Pheison, being interpreted, is the change of the mouth ;
