tgt_text.1289: and Evilat means bringing forth, and by these two names prudence is signified.
tgt_text.1290: For people in general think a man prudent who is an inventor of sophistical expressions, and clever at explain­ ing that which he has conceived in the mind.
tgt_text.1291: But Moses considered such an one a man fond of words, but by no means a prudent man.
tgt_text.1292: For in the changing of the mouth, that is to say of the power of speaking and explaining one's ideas, pru­ dence is seen.
tgt_text.1293: And prudence is not a certain degree of acute­ ness in speech, but ability which is beheld in deeds and in serious actions.
tgt_text.1294: And prudence surrounds Evilat, which is in travail, as it were with a wall, in order to besiege it and destroy it.
tgt_text.1295: And " bringing forth," is an especially appropriate name for folly, because the foolish mind, being always desirous of what is unattainable, is at all times in travail.
tgt_text.1296: When it is desirous of money it is in labour, also when it thirsts for glory, or when it is covetous of pleasure, or of any thing else.
tgt_text.1297: But, though always in labour, it never brings forth.
tgt_text.1298: For the soul of the worthless man is not calculated by nature to bring any thing to perfection which is likely to live.
tgt_text.1299: But every thing which it appears to bring forth is found to be abortive and immature.
tgt_text.1301: Eating up the half of its flesh, and being like a death of the soul.”*
tgt_text.1302: On which account that holy word Aaron entreats the pious Moses, who was beloved by God, to heal the leprosy of Miriam, in order that her soul might not be occupied in the labour of bringing forth evil things.
tgt_text.1304: " Let her not become like unto death, as an abortion proceeding out of the womb of her mother, and let her not devour the half of her own flesh."
tgt_text.1305: tXXV. " That," says Moses, " is the country, where there is gold."
tgt_text.1306: He does not say that that is the only place where there is gold, but simply that is the country where there is gold.
tgt_text.1307: For prudence which he likened to gold, being of a nature free from deceit, and pure, and tried in the fire, and thoroughly tested, and honourable, exists there in the wisdom of God.
tgt_text.1308: And being there, it is not a possession of wisdom, but something belonging to the God who is its creator and owner, whose work and possession this wisdom likewise is.
tgt_text.1309: "And the gold of that land is good."
tgt_text.1310: Is there, then, any other gold which is not good ?
tgt_text.1312: for the nature of prudence is twofold, there being one prudence general, and another particular.
tgt_text.1313: Therefore, the prudence that is in me, being particular prudence, is not good;
tgt_text.1314: for when I perish that also will perish together with me;
tgt_text.1315: but general or universal prudence, the abode of which is the wisdom of God and the house of God, is good ;
tgt_text.1316: for it is imperishable itself, and dwells in an imperishable habitation.
tgt_text.1318: There also is the carbuncle and the emerald."
tgt_text.1319: The two beings endowed with distinctive qualities, the prudent man and the man who acts prudently, differ from one another;
tgt_text.1320: one of them existing according to prudence, and the other acting wisely according to the rules of wisdom.
tgt_text.1321: For it is on account of these two beings thus endowed with distinctive qualities God implanted prudence and virtue in the earth-born man.
tgt_text.1322: For what would have been the use of it, if there had been no reasoning powers in existence to receive it, and to give impressions of its form ?
tgt_text.1323: So that virtue is very properly conjoined with prudence, and the prudent man is rightly joined with him who displays prudence in his actions;
tgt_text.1324: the two being like two precious stones.
tgt_text.1325: And may not they be Judah and Issachar?
tgt_text.1326: For the man who puts in practice the prudence of God confesses himself to be bound to feel gratitude, and to feel it towards him who has given him what is good without grudging;
tgt_text.1327: and he also does honourable and virtuous actions.
tgt_text.1328: Accordingly Judah is the symbol of a man who makes this confession " in respect of whom Leah ceased from child-bear­ ing."*
tgt_text.1329: But Issachar is the symbol of the man who does good actions, " For he put forth t his shoulder to labour and became a man tilling the earth."
tgt_text.1330: With respect to whom Moses says, hire is in his soul after he has been sown and planted, so that his labour is not imperfect, but is rather crowned and honoured with a reward by God.
tgt_text.1331: And that he is making mention of these things, he shows when speaking on other subjects;
tgt_text.1332: when describing the garment, which reached to the feet he says, " And thou shalt weave in it sets of stones in four rows.
tgt_text.1333: The row of stones shall be the sardine stone, the topaz, and the emerald are the first row."
tgt_text.1334: Reuben, Simeon, and Levi are here meant. "
tgt_text.1335: And the second row," he says, " are the carbuncle and the sapphire.”†
tgt_text.1336: And the sapphire is the same as the green stone.
tgt_text.1337: And in the carbuncle was inscribed the name of Judah, for he was the fourth son :
tgt_text.1338: and in the sapphire the name of Issachar.
tgt_text.1339: Why then as he had called the sapphire the green stone, did he not also speak of the red stone ?
tgt_text.1340: Because Judah, as the type of a disposition inclined to confession, is a being immaterial and incorporeal.
tgt_text.1341: For the very name of confession (ἐξομολογήσεως) shows that it is a thing external to (ἐϰτὸς) himself.
tgt_text.1342: For when the mind is beside itself, and bears itself upwards to God, as the laughter of Isaac did, then it makes a confession to him who alone has a real being.
tgt_text.1343: But as long as it considers itself as the cause of something, it is a long way from yielding to God, and confessing to him.
tgt_text.1344: For this very act of confessing ought to be considered as being the work not of the soul, but of God who teaches it this feeling of gratitude.
tgt_text.1345: Accordingly Judah, who practises confession, is an immaterial being.
tgt_text.1346: But Issachar who came forth out of labour is in need of corporeal matter;
tgt_text.1347: since if it were otherwise how could a stu­ dious man read without his eyes ?
tgt_text.1348: And how could any one hear words exhorting him to any cause, if he were not endowed with hearing ?
tgt_text.1349: And how could he obtain meat and drink without a belly, and without a wonder working art exercised towards it ?
tgt_text.1350: And it is on this account that he was likened to a precious stone.
tgt_text.1351: Moreover the colours of the two are different.
tgt_text.1352: For the colour of a coal when on fire is akin to that of the man who is inclined to confession:
tgt_text.1353: for he is inflamed by gratitude to God, and he is intoxicated with a certain sober intoxication:
tgt_text.1354: but the colour of the green stone is more appropriate to the man who is still labouring:
tgt_text.1355: for those who are devoted to constant labour are pale on account of .
tgt_text.1356: the wearing nature of toil, and also by reason of their fear that perhaps they may not attain to such an end of their wish as is desired in their prayers.
tgt_text.1358: And it is worth while to raise the question why the two rivers the Pheison and the Gihon encircle certain countries, the one surrounding Evilat, and the other Ethiopia, while neither of the other rivers is represented as encompasing any country.
tgt_text.1359: The Tigris is indeed said to flow in front of the land of the Assyrians, but the Euphrates is not mentioned in connection with any country whatever.
tgt_text.1360: And yet in real truth the Euphrates does both encircle some countries, and has several also in front of it.
tgt_text.1361: But the truth is that the sacred writer is here speaking not of the river, but of the correction of manners.
tgt_text.1362: It is necessary therefore to say that prudence and courage are able to raise a wall and a circle of fortification against the opposite evils, folly, and cowardice;
tgt_text.1364: for both of them are powerless and easy to be taken.
tgt_text.1365: For the foolish man is easily to be defeated by the prudent one ;
tgt_text.1366: and the coward falls before the valiant man.
tgt_text.1367: But temperance is unable to surround appetite and pleasure;
tgt_text.1368: for they are formidable adversaries and hard to be subdued.
tgt_text.1369: Do you not see that even the most temperate men are compelled by the necessities of their mortal body to seek meat and drink;
tgt_text.1370: and it is in those things that the pleasures of the belly have their existence.
tgt_text.1371: We must be content therefore to oppose and con­ tend with the genus appetite.
tgt_text.1372: And it is on this account that the river Tigris is represented as flowing in front of the Assyrians, that is to say temperance is in front of or arrayed against pleasure.
tgt_text.1373: But justice, according to which the river Euphrates is represented, neither besieges any one, nor draws lines of circumvallation round any one, nor opposes any one;
tgt_text.1375: Because justice is conversant about the distribution of things according to merit, and does not take the part either of accuser or of defendant, but acts as a judge.
tgt_text.1376: As therefore a judge does not desire beforehand to defeat any one, nor to oppose and make war upon any one;
tgt_text.1377: but delivers his own opinion and judges, deciding for the right, so also justice, not being the adversary of any one, distributes its due to every thing.
tgt_text.1379: And the Lord God took the man whom he had made and placed him in the Paradise, to cultivate and to guard it."
tgt_text.1380: The man whom God made differs from the factitious man, as I have said before.
tgt_text.1381: For the factitious mind is somewhat earthly;
tgt_text.1382: but the created mind is purer and more immaterial, having no participation in any perishable matter, but having received a purer and more simple constitution.
tgt_text.1383: Accordingly God takes this pure mind, not permitting it to proceed out of itself, and after he has taken it, he places it among the virtues which are firmly rooted and budding well, that it may cultivate and guard them.
tgt_text.1384: For many men who were originally prac­ tisers of virtue, when they come to the end fall off;
tgt_text.1385: but he to whom God gives lasting knowledge is also endowed by him with both qualities, namely with the disposition to cultivate the virtues, and the resolution never to desert them, but always to minister to and guard every one of them.
tgt_text.1386: So Moses here uses the expression "cultivate" as equivalent to "act," and the word " guard" instead of " remember.
tgt_text.1388: And the Lord God commanded Adam, saying, Of every tree that is in the Paradise thou mayest freely eat;
tgt_text.1389: but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil ye shall not eat;
tgt_text.1390: but in the day on which ye eat of it ye shall die the death.
tgt_text.1391: "A question may arise here to what kind of Adam he gave this command and who, this Adam was.
tgt_text.1392: For Moses has not made any mention of him before ;
tgt_text.1393: but now is the first time that he has named him.
tgt_text.1394: Are w'e then to think that he is desirous to supply you with the name of the factitious man ? "
tgt_text.1395: And he calls him, " continues Moses, " Earth."
tgt_text.1396: For this is the interpretation of the name of Adam.
tgt_text.1397: Accordingly, when you hear the name Adam, you must think that he is an earthly and perishable being ;
tgt_text.1398: for he is made according to an image, being not earthly but heavenly.
tgt_text.1399: But we must inquire how it was that after he had given names to all the other animals, he did not give one also to himself.
tgt_text.1400: What then are we to say about this ?
tgt_text.1401: The mind which is in each of us is able to comprehend all other things, but has not the capability of understanding itself.
tgt_text.1402: For as the eye sees all other things, but cannot see itself, so also the mind perceives the nature of other things but cannot understand itself.
tgt_text.1403: For if it does, let it tell us what it is, or what kind of thing it is, whether it is a spirit, or blood, or fire, or air, or any other substance :
tgt_text.1404: or even only so much whether it is a substance at all, or something incorporeal.
tgt_text.1405: Are not those men then simple who speculate on the essence of God ?
tgt_text.1406: For how can they who are ignorant of the nature of the essence of their own soul, have any accurate knowledge of the soul of the universe ?
tgt_text.1407: For the soul of the universe is according to our definition,—God.XXX.
tgt_text.1408: It is therefore very natural that Adam, that is to say the mind, when he was giving names to and displaying his comprehension of the other animals, did not give a name to himself, because he was ignorant of himself and of his own nature.
tgt_text.1409: A command indeed is given to man, but not to the man created according to the image and idea of God ;
tgt_text.1410: for that being is possessed of virtue without any need of exhortation, by his own instinctive nature, but this other would not have wisdom if it had not been taught to him :
tgt_text.1411: and these three things are different, command, prohibition, and recommendation.
tgt_text.1412: For prohibition is conversant about errors, and is directed to bad men, but command is conversant about things rightly done;
tgt_text.1413: recommendation again is addressed to men of intermediate character, neither bad nor good.
tgt_text.1414: For such a one does not sin so that any one has any need to direct prohibition to him, nor does he do right in every case in accordance with the injunc­ tion of right reason.
tgt_text.1415: But he is in need of recommendation, which teaches him to abstain from what is evil, and exhorts him to aim at what is good.
tgt_text.1416: Therefore there is no need of addressing either command, or prohibition, or recommendation to the man who is perfect, and made according to the image of God ;
tgt_text.1417: For the perfect man requires none of these things ;
tgt_text.1418: but there is a necessity of addressing both command and prohibition to the wicked man, and recommendation and instruction to the ignorant man.
tgt_text.1419: Just as the perfect gramma­ rian or perfect musician has need of no instruction in the matters which belong to his art, but the man whose theories on such subjects are imperfect stands in need of certain rules, as it were, which contain in themselves commands and prohi­ bitions, and he who is only learning the art requires instruction.
tgt_text.1420: Very naturally, therefore, does God at present address com­ mands and recommendations to the earthly mind, which is neither bad nor good, but of an intermediate character.
tgt_text.1421: And recommendation is employed in the two names, in that of the Lord and of God.
tgt_text.1422: For the Lord God commanded that if man obeyed his recommendations, he should be thought worthy of receiving benefits from God;
tgt_text.1423: but if he rejected his warnings, he should then be cast out to destruction by the Lord, as his Master and one who had authority over him.
tgt_text.1424: On which account, when he is driven out of Paradise, Moses repeats the same names ;
tgt_text.1425: for he says, " And the Lord God sent him forth out of the Paradise of happiness, to till the ground from which he had been taken."*
tgt_text.1426: That, since the Lord had laid his commands on him as his Master, and God as his Benefactor, he might now, in both these characters, chastise him for having disobeyed them ;
tgt_text.1427: for thus, by the same power by which he had exhorted him does he also banish him, now that he is dis­ obedient.
tgt_text.1429: And the recommendations that he addresses to him are as follows :
tgt_text.1430: "Of every tree that is in the Paradise thou mayest freely eat."t
tgt_text.1431: He exhorts the soul of man to derive advantage not from one tree alone nor from one single virtue, but from all the virtues;
tgt_text.1432: for eating is a symbol of the nourishment of the soul, and the soul is nourished by the reception of good things, and by the doing of praiseworthy actions.
tgt_text.1433: And Moses not only says, " thou mayest eat," but he adds " freely," also ;
tgt_text.1434: that is to say, having ground and prepared your food, not like an ordinary individual, but like a wrestler, you shall thus acquire strength and vigour.
tgt_text.1435: For the trainers recommend the wrestlers not to cut up their food by biting large pieces off, but to masticate it slowly, in order that it may contribute to their strength ;
tgt_text.1436: for I and an athlete are fed in different manners.
tgt_text.1437: For I feed merely for the purpose of living, but the wrestler feeds for the purpose of acquiring flesh and deriving strength from it;
tgt_text.1438: on which account one of his rules of training and exercise is to masticate his food.
tgt_text.1439: This is the meaning of the expression, " Thou mayest freely eat.
tgt_text.1440: "Again let us endeavour to give a still more accurate expla­ nation of it.
tgt_text.1441: To honour one's parents is a nourishing and cherishing thing.
tgt_text.1442: But the good and the wicked honour them in different manners.
tgt_text.1443: For the one does it out of habit, as men eat who do not eat freely, but who merely eat.
tgt_text.1444: When, then, do they also eat freely ?
tgt_text.1445: When having investigated and deve­ loped the causes of things they form a voluntary judgment that this is good, and the causes of their eating freely, that is to say, of their honouring their parents in a proper spirit, is­ they became our parents;
tgt_text.1448: they have been the causes of all good things to us.
tgt_text.1449: Again, to honour the living God is spoken of symbolically as to eat.
tgt_text.1450: But to eat " freely," is when it is done with a proper explanation of the whole matter, and a correct assignment of the causes of it.
tgt_text.1452: " But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil ye shall not eat."
tgt_text.1453: Therefore this tree is not in the Paradise.
tgt_text.1454: For God encourages them to eat of every tree that is in the Paradise.
tgt_text.1455: But when he forbids them to eat of this tree, it is plain that it is not in the Paradise ;
tgt_text.1456: and this is in accordance with natural philosophy.
tgt_text.1457: For it is there in its essence, as I have said before, and it is not there in its power.
tgt_text.1458: For as in wax there are potentially many seals, but in actual fact only one which has been carved on it, so also in the soul, which resembles wax, all impressions whatever are contained poten­ tially ;
tgt_text.1459: but in really one single characteristic which is stamped upon it has possession of it;
tgt_text.1460: until it is effaced by some other which makes a deeper and more conspicuous impression.
tgt_text.1461: Again, this, also, may be made the subject of a question.
tgt_text.1462: When God recommends men to eat of every tree in the Para­ dise, he is addressing his exhortation to one individual:
tgt_text.1463: but when he forbids him to eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil he is speaking to him as to many.
tgt_text.1464: For in the one case be says, “ Thou mayest freely eat of all;
tgt_text.1465: " but in the second instance, " Ye shall not eat;
tgt_text.1467: In the day in which ye shall eat," not thou shalt eat;
tgt_text.1469: Ye shall die," not “ Thou shalt die."
tgt_text.1470: We must, therefore, say this,-that the first good is rare, imparted to but few;
tgt_text.1472: On this account it is a hard matter to find one single man wise and faithful, but the number of bad men is beyond all computation.
tgt_text.1473: Very appro­ priately, therefore, God does not address his exhortation to nourish one's self amid the virtues, to one individual, but he encourages many to abstain from extravagant wickedness;
tgt_text.1474: for innumerable men are addicted to it.
tgt_text.1475: In the second place, for the due comprehension and adoption of virtue man requires one thing alone, namely reason.
tgt_text.1476: But the body not only does not co-operate in it at all, but rather impedes the progress of the reason towards it.
tgt_text.1477: For it may be almost called the peculiar task of wisdom to alienate itself from the body and from the corporeal appetites.
tgt_text.1478: But for the enjoy­ ment of evil it is not only necessary for a man to have mind in some degree, but also senses, and reason, and a body.
tgt_text.1479: For the bad man has need of all these things for the completion of his own wickedness.
tgt_text.1480: Since how will he be able to divulge the sacred mysteries unless he has the organ of voice?
tgt_text.1481: And how will he be able to indulge in pleasures if he be deprived of the belly and the organs of sensation?
tgt_text.1482: Very properly, therefore, does Moses address reason alone on the subject of the acquisition of virtue, for reason is, as I have said before, the only thing of which there is need for the establishment of virtue.
tgt_text.1483: But for indulgence in vice a man requires many things—soul, and reason, and the external senses of the body;
tgt_text.1484: for it is through all these organs that vice is exhibited.
tgt_text.1486: Accordingly God says, " In the day in which ye eat of it ye shall die the death."
tgt_text.1487: And yet, though they have eaten of it, they not only do not die, but they even beget children, and are the causes of life to other beings besides themselves.
tgt_text.1488: What, then, are we to say?
tgt_text.1489: Surely that death is of two kinds ;
tgt_text.1490: the one being the death of the man, the other the peculiar death of the soul-now the death of the man is the separation of his soul from his body, but the death of the soul is the destruction of virtue and the admission of vice ;
tgt_text.1491: and con­ sequently God calls that not merely " to die," but " to die the death;
tgt_text.1492: " showing that he is speaking not of common death, but of that peculiar and especial death which is the death of the soul, buried in its passions and in all kinds of evil.
tgt_text.1493: And we may almost say that one kind of death is opposed to the other kind.
tgt_text.1494: For the one is the separation of what was pre­ viously existing in combination, namely, of body and soul.
tgt_text.1495: But this other death, on the contrary, is a combination of them both, the inferior one, the body, having the predominance, and the superior one, the soul, being made subject to it When, therefore, God says, "to die the death," you must remark that he is speaking of that death which is inflicted as punishment, and not of that which exists by the original ordi­ nance of nature.
tgt_text.1496: The natural death is that one by which the soul is separated from the body.
tgt_text.1497: But the one which is inflicted as a punishment, is when the soul dies according to the life of virtue, and lives only according to the life of vice.
tgt_text.1498: Well, therefore, did Heraclitus say this, following the doc­ trine of Moses;
tgt_text.1499: for he says, " We are living according to the death of those men ;
tgt_text.1500: and we have died according to their life."
tgt_text.1501: As if he had said, Now, when we are alive, we are so though our soul is dead and buried in our body, as if in a tomb.
tgt_text.1502: But if it were to die, then our soul would live according to its proper life, being released from the evil and dead body to which it is bound.
tgt_text.1503: I. " AND the Lord God said,
tgt_text.1504: It is not good for man to be alone :
tgt_text.1505: let us make him a help meet for bim."
tgt_text.1506: Why, 0 pro­ phet, is it not good for man to be alone ?
tgt_text.1507: Because, says he, it is good, that he who is alone should be alone.
tgt_text.1508: But God is alone, and by himself, being one;
tgt_text.1509: and there is nothing like unto God.
tgt_text.1510: So that, since it is good that he who only has a real existence should be alone (for that which is about itself alone is good), it cannot be good for man to be alone.
tgt_text.1511: But the fact of God being alone one may receive in this sense;
tgt_text.1512: that neither before the creation was there anything with God, nor, since the world has been created, is anything placed in the same rank with him;
tgt_text.1513: for he is in need of absolutely nothing whatever.
tgt_text.1514: But the better way of understanding this passage is the fol­ lowing :
tgt_text.1519: but each of us, and every other animal in the world, are compound beings:
tgt_text.1520: for instance, I myself am made up of many things, of soul and body.
tgt_text.1521: Again, the soul is made up of a rational part and an irrational part:
tgt_text.1522: also of the body, there is one part hot, another cold ;
tgt_text.1525: But God is not a compound being, nor one which is made up of many parts, but one which has no mixture with anything else;
tgt_text.1526: for whatever could be com­ bined with God must be either superior to him, or inferior to him, or equal to him.
tgt_text.1527: But there is nothing equal to God, and nothing superior to him, and nothing is combined with him which is worse than himself;
tgt_text.1528: for if it were, he himself would be deteriorated;
tgt_text.1529: and if he were to suffer deterioration, he would also become perishable, which it is impious even to imagine.
tgt_text.1530: Therefore God exists according to oneness and unity;
tgt_text.1531: or we should rather say, that oneness exists according to the one God, for all number is more recent than the world, as is also time.
tgt_text.1532: But God is older than the world, and is its Creator.
tgt_text.1534: But it is not good for any man to be alone.
tgt_text.1535: For there are two kinds of men, the one made according to the image of God, the other fashioned out of the earth;
tgt_text.1536: for it longs for its own likeness.
tgt_text.1537: For the image of God is the antitype of all other things, and every imitation aims at this of which it is the imitation, and is placed in the same class with it.
tgt_text.1538: And it is not good for either the man, who was made according to the image of God, to be alone:
tgt_text.1539: nor is it any more desirable for the factitious man to be alone, and indeed it is impossible.
tgt_text.1540: For the external senses, and the passions, and the vices, and innumerable other things, are combined with and adapted to the mind of this man.
tgt_text.1541: But the second kind of man has a help-meet for him, who, in the first place, is created;
tgt_text.1542: " For I will make him," says God, " a help-meet for him."
tgt_text.1543: And, in the second place, is younger than the object to be helped;
tgt_text.1544: for, first of all, God created the mind, and subsequently he pre­ pares to make its helper.
tgt_text.1545: But all this is spoken allegorically, in accordance with the principles of natural philosophy;
tgt_text.1546: for external sensation and the passions of the soul are all younger than the soul, and how they help it we shall see hereafter, but at present we will consider the fact of their being helpers younger than the object helped.
tgt_text.1548: As, according to the most skilful physicians and na­ tural philosophers, the heart appears to be formed before the rest of the body, after the manner of the foundation of a house or the keel of a ship, aud then the rest of the body is built upon it;
tgt_text.1549: on which account, even after death, the phy­ sicians say, that the heart still quivers, as having been created before the rest of the body, and being destroyed after it;
tgt_text.1550: so also does the dominant portion of the soul appear to be older than the whole of the soul, and the irrational part to be younger;
tgt_text.1551: the formation of which Moses has not yet men­ tioned, but he is about to give a sketch of it, how the irrational part of the soul is the external sensation, and the passions which spring from it, especially if the judgments are our own.
tgt_text.1552: And this assistant of God is younger, aud created, being thus described with perfect propriety.
tgt_text.1553: But now let us see how that part, which was postponed be­ fore, acts as an assistant:
tgt_text.1554: how does our mind comprehend that such and such a thing is black or white, unless it employs sight as its assistant?
tgt_text.1555: and how does it know that the voice of the man who is singing to his harp is sweet, or, on the con­ trary, out of tune, if it has not the assistance of the faculty of, hearing to guide it ?
tgt_text.1556: And how can it tell that exhalations are fragrant or foul-smelling, unless it makes use of the sense of smell as its ally ?
tgt_text.1557: How again does it judge of the different flavours, except through the instrumentality of its assistant, taste ?
tgt_text.1558: How can it distinguish between what is rough and what is smooth, except by touch ?
tgt_text.1559: There is also another class of assistants, as I have already said, namely, the passions:
tgt_text.1560: for pleasure also is an assistant, co-operating towards the dura­ bility of our race, and in like manner coucupiscence, and pain, and fear, biting the soul, lead it to treat nothing with indif.
tgt_text.1562: Anger, again, is a defensive weapon, which has been of great service to many people, and so too have the other passions in the same manner.
tgt_text.1563: On which account Moses has said, with great felicity, “ that he was an assistant to him­ self:
tgt_text.1564: " for he is in reality an assistaut to the mind, as if he were its brother and near kinsman :
tgt_text.1565: for the external sensations and the passions are parts of one soul, and are its offspring.
tgt_text.1567: Now of assistants there are two kinds, the one consist­ ing in the passions and the other in the sensations.... *
tgt_text.1568: But the prior kind is that of generation, for Moses says, " And God proceeded and made all the beasts of the field out of the earth, and all the birds of heaven;
tgt_text.1569: and he brought them to Adam to see what he would call them, and whatever Adam called any living soul that became its name."
tgt_text.1570: You see here who are our assistants, the beasts of the soul, the passions.
tgt_text.1571: For after God had said, " I will make him a help- meet for him," Moses adds subsequently, " He made the beasts," as if the beasts also were assistants to us.
tgt_text.1572: But these are not, properly speaking, assistants, but are called so only in a catachrestic manner, by a kind of abuse of language, for they are found in reality to be enemies to man.
tgt_text.1573: As also in the case of cities, the allies turn out at times to be traitors and deserters;
tgt_text.1574: and in the case of friendship, flatterers are found to be enemies instead of companions;
tgt_text.1575: and Moses here speaks of the heaven and the field synonymously, describing the mind in this allegorical manner;
tgt_text.1576: for the mind, like the field, has innumerable periods of rising and budding forth;
tgt_text.1577: and, like the heaven, has brilliant, and divine, and happy characteristics of nature.
tgt_text.1578: But the passions he compares to beasts and birds, because they injure the mind, being untamed and wild, and because, after the manner of birds, they descend upon the intellect;
tgt_text.1579: for their onset is swift and difficult to withstand;
tgt_text.1580: and the word " besides," as attached to " he made," is not super­ fluous.
tgt_text.1582: because he has previously said, that the beasts were formed before the creation of man, and he shows it in the following words, which are an account of what was done on the sixth day."
tgt_text.1583: And God said, Let the earth bring forth living creatures after their kind, four-footed animals, and creeping things, and wild beasts."
tgt_text.1584: Why, then, is it that he makes other animals now, not being content with those already existing?
tgt_text.1585: now this must be stated according to the principles of moral phi­ losophy.
tgt_text.1586: The species of evil are abundant in created man, so that the most evil things are continually produced in him;
tgt_text.1587: and this other thing must be affirmed on principles of natural philosophy.
tgt_text.1588: First of all, in the six days he created the differ­ ent kinds of passions, and the ideas, but now, in addition to them, he is creating the species.
tgt_text.1589: On which account Moses says, " And besides he made . . .” and that what had been previously created were genera is plain from what he says, “ Let the earth bring forth living souls," not according to species but according to genus.
tgt_text.1590: And this is found to be the course taken by God in all cases;
tgt_text.1591: for before making the spe­ cies he completes the genera, as he did in the case of man:

tgt_text.1595: and this is au explanation, partly figurative and partly literal, which is worthy of our admiration.

tgt_text.1598: but Moses speaks more correctly in the first place, because he attributes this giving of names, not to some of those men who lived in early times, but to the first man who was created upon the earth ;
tgt_text.1599: so that, just as he himself was created to be the beginning of creation to all other animals, he might also be considered the beginning of conversation and language:
tgt_text.1600: for if there were no such things as names there could be no such thing as language:
tgt_text.1601: and, secondly, because, if many dif­ ferent persons gave names, they must have been different and devoid of all connexion, since different persons would have given different names :
tgt_text.1602: but if only one person did so, the name given by one was sure to be adapted to the thing:

tgt_text.1608: (why ?) as when we say, why (n) have you washed yourself?

tgt_text.1612: when therefore Moses says, " to see what he would call them," you must understand him as if he had said δια τί (why), instead of ri (what):

tgt_text.1614: Is it then only for the sake of what is necessary that the mor­ tal race is of necessity implicated in passions and vices ?
tgt_text.1615: or is it also on account of that which is immoderate and super­ fluous?
tgt_text.1616: And again, is it because of the requirements of the earth-born mali, or because the mind judges them to be most excellent and admirable things;
tgt_text.1617: as for instance, is it necessary for every created thing to enjoy pleasure ?
tgt_text.1618: But the bad man flies to pleasure as to a perfect good, but the good man seeks it only as a necessary;
tgt_text.1619: for without pleasure nothing whatever is done among the human race.
tgt_text.1620: Again, the bad mail considers the acquisition of riches as the most perfect good possible;
tgt_text.1621: but the good man looks upon riches only as a necessary and useful thing.
tgt_text.1622: Very naturally, therefore, God desires to see and to learn how the mind de­ nominates and appreciates each of these things, whether it looks upon them as good, or as things indifferent, or as evil in themselves, but nevertheless in some respects necessary.
tgt_text.1623: On which account, thinking that everything which he invited towards himself, and embraced as a living soul, was of equal value and importance with the soul, this became the name, not only of the thing which was thus invited, but also of him who invited it:
tgt_text.1624: as for instance, if the man embraced pleasure, he was called a man devoted to pleasure;
tgt_text.1625: if he embraced ap­ petite, he was called a man of appetite;
tgt_text.1626: if he invited intem­ perance, he himself also acquired the name of intemperate;
tgt_text.1627: if he admitted cowardice, he was called cowardly;
tgt_text.1628: and so on in the case of the other passions.
tgt_text.1629: For as he who has any dis­ tinctive qualities according to the virtues, is called from that virtue with which he is especially endowed, prudent, or temperate, or just, or courageous, as the case may be;
tgt_text.1630: so too in respect of the vices, a man is called unjust, or foolish, or unmanly, when he has invited and embraced these habits of mind and conduct.

tgt_text.1634: The literal statement conveyed in these words is a fabulous one ;
tgt_text.1635: for how can any one believe that a woman was made of a rib of a man, or, in short, that any human being was made out of another?
tgt_text.1636: And what hindered God, as he had made man out of the earth, from making woman in the same manner?
tgt_text.1637: For the Creator was the same, and the material was almost inter­ minable, from which every distinctive quality whatever was made.
tgt_text.1638: And why, when there were so many parts of a man, did not God make the woman out of some other part rather than out of one of his ribs ?
tgt_text.1639: Again, of which rib did he make her?
tgt_text.1640: And this question would hold even if we were to say, that he had only spoken of two ribs;
tgt_text.1641: but in truth he has not specified their number.
tgt_text.1642: Was it then the right rib, or the left rib ?
tgt_text.1643: Again, if he filled up the place of the other with flesh, was not the one which he left also made of flesh ?
tgt_text.1644: and indeed our ribs are like sisters, and akin in all their parts, and they consist of flesh.
tgt_text.1645: What then are we to say ?
tgt_text.1646: ordinary custom calls the ribs the strength of a man;
tgt_text.1647: for we say that a man has ribs, which is equivalent to saying that he has vigour;
tgt_text.1648: and we say that a wrestler is a man with strong ribs, when we mean to express that he is strong:

tgt_text.1650: Now that this has been premised we must also say, that the mind, while naked and free from the entanglement of the body (for our present discussion is about the mind, while it is as yet entangled in nothing) has many powers, namely, the possessive power, the progenitive power, the power of the soul, the power of reason, the power of comprehension, and part of others innumerable both in their genus and species.
tgt_text.1651: Now the possessive power is common to it with other inanimate things, with stocks and stones, and it is shared by the things in us, which are like stones, namely, by our bones.
tgt_text.1652: And natural power extends also over plants:
tgt_text.1653: and there are parts in us which have some resemblance to plants, namely, our nails and our hair:
tgt_text.1654: and nature is a habit already put in motion, but the soul is a habit which has taken to itself, in addition, imagi­ nation and impetuosity;
tgt_text.1655: and this power also is possessed by man in common with the irrational animals;
tgt_text.1656: and our mind has something analogous to the soul of an irrational animal.•
tgt_text.1657: Again, the power of comprehension is a peculiar property of the mind;
tgt_text.1658: and the reasoning power is perhaps common to the more divine natures, but is especially the property of the mortal nature of man :
tgt_text.1659: and this is a twofold power, one kind being that in accordance with which we are rational creatures, partaking of mind;
tgt_text.1660: and the other kind being that faculty by which we converse.
tgt_text.1661: There is also another power in the soul akin to these, the power of sensation, of which we are now speaking;
tgt_text.1662: for Moses is describing nothing else on this occasion except the form­ ation of the external sense, according to energy and according to reason.
tgt_text.1664: For immediately after the creation of the mind it was necessary that the external sense should be created, as an assistant and ally of the mind ;
tgt_text.1665: therefore God having entirely perfected the first, proceeded to make the second, both in rank and power, being a certain created form, an external sense according to energy, created for the perfection and com­ pletion of the whole soul, and for the proper comprehension of such subject matter as might be brought before it.
tgt_text.1666: How then was this second thing created?
tgt_text.1667: As Moses himself says in a subsequent passage, when the mind was gone to sleep:
tgt_text.1668: for, in real fact, the external sense then comes forward when the mind is asleep.
tgt_text.1669: And again, when the mind is awake the out­ ward sense is extinguished;
tgt_text.1670: and the proof of this is, that when we desire to form an accurate conception of anything, we retreat to a desert place, we shut our eyes, we stop up our ears, we discard the exercise of our senses;
tgt_text.1671: and so, when the mind rises up again and awakens, the outward sense is put an end to.
tgt_text.1672: Let us now consider another point, namely, how the mind goes to sleep:
tgt_text.1673: for when the outward sense is awakened and has become excited, when the sight beholds any works of painting or of sculpture beautifully wrought, is not the mind then without anything on which to exercise its functions, con­ templating nothing which is a proper subject for the intellect ?
tgt_text.1675: When the faculty of hearing is attending to some melodious combination of sound, can the mind turn itself to the contemplation of its proper objects ?
tgt_text.1677: And it is much more destitute of occupation, when taste rises up and eagerly devotes itself to the pleasures of the belly;
tgt_text.1678: on which account Moses, being alarmed lest some day or other the mind might not merely go to sleep, but might become ab­ solutely dead, says in another place, " And it shall be to you a peg in your girdle;
tgt_text.1679: and it shall be, that when you sit down you shall dig in it, and, heaping up earth, shall cover your shame.
tgt_text.1681: *Speaking symbolically, and giving the name of peg to reason which digs up secret affairs;
tgt_text.1682: and he bids him to bear it upon the affection with which he ought to be girded, and not to allow it to slacken and become loosened;
tgt_text.1683: and this must be done when the mind.
tgt_text.1684: departing from the intense con­ sideration of objects perceptible by the intellect, is brought down to the passions, and sits down, yielding to, and being guided by, the necessities of the body:
tgt_text.1685: and this is the case when the mind, being absorbed in luxurious associations, for­ gets itself, being subdued by the things which conduct it to pleasure, and so we become enslaved, and yield ourselves up to unconcealed impurity.
tgt_text.1686: But if reason be able to purify the passion, then neither when we drink do we become intoxicated, nor when we eat do we become indolent through satiety, but we feast soberly with­ out indulging in folly.
tgt_text.1687: Therefore, the awakening of the out­ ward senses is the sleep of the mind;
tgt_text.1688: and the awakening of the mind is the discharge of the outward senses from all occu­ pation.
tgt_text.1689: Just as when the sun arises the brightness of all the rest of the stars becomes invisible;
tgt_text.1690: but when the sun sets, they are seen.
tgt_text.1691: And so, like the sun, the mind, when it is awakened, overshadows the outward senses, but when it goes to sleep it permits them to shine.

tgt_text.1694: " The Lord God," says Moses, " cast a deep trance upon Adam, and sent him to sleep."
tgt_text.1695: He speaks here with great correctness, for a trance and perversion of the mind is its sleep.

tgt_text.1698: And the expres­ sion, “ it is in a trance," is very well employed, as it means that it is perverted and changed, not by itself, but by God, who presents to it, and brings before it, and sends upon it the change which occurs to it.

tgt_text.1716: Sensa­ tion is spoken of in a twofold manner ;
tgt_text.1717: -the one kind being according to habit, which exists even when we are asleep, and the other being according to energy.
tgt_text.1718: Now, in the former kind, the one according to habit, there is no use :
tgt_text.1719: for we do not com­ prehend any one of the objects presented to our view by its means.
tgt_text.1720: But there is use in the second, in that which exists according to energy;
tgt_text.1721: for it is by means of this that we arrive at a comprehension of the objects perceptible by the outward senses.
tgt_text.1722: Accordingly, God, having created the former kind of sensa­ tion, that existing according to habit, when he was creating the mind (for he was furnishing that with many faculties in a state of rest), desires now to complete the other kind which exists according to energy.
tgt_text.1723: And this one according to energy is perfected when the one which exists according to habit is put in motion, and extended as far as the flesh and the organs of sense.
tgt_text.1724: For as nature is perfected when the seed is put in motion, so, also, energy is perfected when the habit is put in motion.
tgt_text.1726: "And he filled the space with flesh instead of it."
tgt_text.1727: That is to say, he filled up that external sense which exists according to habit, leading it on to energy and extending it as far as the flesh and the whole outward and visible surface of the body.
tgt_text.1728: In reference to which Moses adds that " he built it up into a woman:
tgt_text.1729: " showing by this expression that woman is the most natural and felicitously-given name for the exter­ nal sense.

tgt_text.1742: But the mind, perceiving the power which it previously had (and which, while it was existing according to habit was in a state of tranquillity), now have to become a complete operation and energy, and to be in a state of motion, marvels at it, and utters an exclamation, saying that it is not unconnected with it, but very closely akin to it.

tgt_text.1749: It is also worth while to consider why Adam adde word "now," for he says, "This now is bone of my bone."
tgt_text.1750: The explanation is, external sensation exists now, having its existence solely with reference to the present moment.
tgt_text.1751: For the mind touches three separate points of time;
tgt_text.1752: for it per­ ceives present circumstances, and it remembers past events, and it anticipates the future.
tgt_text.1753: But the external sensations have neither any anticipation of future events, nor are they subject to any feeling resembling expectation or hope, nor have they any recollection of past circumstances;
tgt_text.1754: but are by nature capable only of being affected by that which moves them at the moment, and is actually present.
tgt_text.1755: As, for example, the eye is made white by a white appearance presented to it at the moment, but it is not affected in any manner by that which is not present to it.
tgt_text.1756: But the mind is agitated also by that which is not actually present, but which may be past;
tgt_text.1757: in which case it is affected by its recollection of it;
tgt_text.1758: or it may be future, in which case it is, indeed, the influence of hope and expectation.

tgt_text.2066: And of all the passions the most mis­ chievous is pleasure.
tgt_text.2068: Because all things are the slaves of pleasure;
tgt_text.2069: and because the life of the wicked is go­ verned by pleasure as by a master.
tgt_text.2070: Accordingly, the things which are the efficient causes of pleasure are found to be full of all wickedness:
tgt_text.2071: gold and silver, and glory and honours, and powers and the objects of the outward senses, and the mechanical arts, and all other things which cause pleasure, being very various, and all injurious to the soul;
tgt_text.2072: and there are no sins without extreme wickedness;
tgt_text.2073: therefore do thou array against it the wisdom which contends with serpents;
tgt_text.2074: and struggle in this most glorious struggle, and labour to win the crown in the contest against pleasure, which subdues every one else;
tgt_text.2075: winning a noble and glorious crown, such as no assembly of men can confer.
tgt_text.2076: I. "AND Adam and his wife hid themselves from the face of the Lord God in the midst of the trees of the Paradise."*
tgt_text.2077: A doctrine is introduced here which teaches us that the wicked man is inclined to run away.
tgt_text.2078: For the proper city of wise men is virtue, and he who is incapable of becoming a partaker in that is driven from his city;
tgt_text.2079: and no bad man is capable of becoming a partaker of it;
tgt_text.2080: therefore the bad man alone is driven away and becomes a banished man.
tgt_text.2081: But he who is banished from virtue is at once concealed from the face of God, for if the wise men are visible to God, inasmuch as they are dear to him, it follows plainly that the wicked are all concealed from him, and enveloped in darkness, as being enemies and adversaries to right reason.
tgt_text.2082: Now that the wicked man is destitute of a city and destitute of a home, Moses testifies in speaking of that hairy man who was also a man of varied wickedness, Esau, when he says, " But Esau was skilful in hunting, and a rude man."t
tgt_text.2083: For it is not natural for vice which is inclined to be subservient to the passions to inhabit the city of virtue, inasmuch as it is devoted to the pursuit of rudeness and ignorance, with great folly.
tgt_text.2084: But Jacob, who is full of wis­ dom, is both a citizen and one who dwells in a house, that is to say, in virtue.
tgt_text.2085: Accordingly Moses says of him, “ But Jacob is a man without guile, dwelling in a house;
tgt_text.2086: ” On which account also " the midwives, since they feared God made themselves houses.
tgt_text.2087: ”*For they, being inclined to seek out the secret mysteries of God, one of which was that the male children should be pre­ served alive, build up the actions of virtue, in which they had previously determined to dwell.
tgt_text.2088: Accordingly, in this account it is shown how the wicked man is destitute of a city and des­ titute of a home :
tgt_text.2089: inasmuch as he is an exile from virtue, but that the virtuous man has a city and is allotted a home, namely wisdom.
tgt_text.2091: And let us in the next place consider how any one is said to be concealed from God;
tgt_text.2092: but unless any one receives this as an allegorical saying it would be impossible to compre­ hend what is here stated.
tgt_text.2093: For God has completed everything and has penetrated every thing, and has left no one of all his works empty or deserted.
tgt_text.2094: What kind of place then can any one occupy in which God is not?
tgt_text.2095: And Moses testifies to this in other passages, when he says, " God is in the heaven above, and in the earth beneath;
tgt_text.2096: and there is nothing anywhere but he.”†
tgt_text.2097: And in another place he speaks in this manner, " I stood here before you did." ‡ For God is of older date than any created being, and he will be everywhere, so that it cannot be possible for any one to be concealed from him :
tgt_text.2098: and what need we wonder at ?
tgt_text.2099: For even if any thing were to happen to us we should not be able to escape the notice of, and to conceal ourselves from the most elementary of created things ;
tgt_text.2100: for instance, let any one try to flee from the earth, or the water, or the air, or the heaven, or the entire universe, and he will fail;
tgt_text.2101: for it is impossible but what he must be contained in these things, for no one will be able to flee out of the world.
tgt_text.2102: Again how could any man who is unable to conceal himself from the'parts of the world, and from the whole world itself, be able to escape the notice of God ?
tgt_text.2104: What then is the meaning of the expression, " they hid them­ selves?"
tgt_text.2105: The bad man thinks that God is in a certain place, not surrounding it, but being surrounded by it.
tgt_text.2106: On which account also he thinks that he can conceal himself from him, as if God were without any prevailing reason at a distance from that part of the world in which he has determined to lurk.
tgt_text.2108: And we must understand this in the following manner.
tgt_text.2109: In the wicked man the true opinion concerning God is over­ shadowed and kept out of sight, for he is full of darkness, having no divine irradiation, by means of which he may be able to contemplate things as they are.
tgt_text.2110: And such a man is a fugitive from the divine company just as a leper is or a man with any other impure disease, the one bringing together into the same place God and Creation, two opposite natures of two different complexions, as the causes of things, when there is really but one cause, the great Creator ;
tgt_text.2111: and the other, a man afflicted with a foul disease, believing that everything is created from the world, and again is dissolved into the world, but thinking that nothing has been created by God, being a follower of the doctrine of Heraclitus introduces covetousness and indigence, and one universe, and all kinds of things alter­ nately.
tgt_text.2112: In reference to which the Holy Scripture says "
tgt_text.2113: Let them send forth from the holy soul every leper, and every one afflicted with foul disease, and every one who is impure in his soul, both male and female, and all mutilated persons, and all these who are emasculated, and all whoremongers,”* men who flee from the authority of one God, and who are expressly forbidden " to come into the assembly of God ;
tgt_text.2114: ” † but wise reasons are not only not concealed, but are even eager to manifest themselves.
tgt_text.2115: Do you not see that Abraham was still standing in the place of the Lord, and coming near to him said " do not then destroy the righteous with the impious, ” ‡ him who is manifest to you and well known by you, with him who flees from you and seeks to escape your notice, for he indeed is impious, but the righteous man is one who stands before you and does not flee.
tgt_text.2116: For it is right indeed master that you alone should be honoured, but it does not follow that as an impious man is discovered so also is a pious man ;
tgt_text.2117: but it is sufficient if he is just.
tgt_text.2118: On which account he says "do not then destroy the righteous with the wicked."
tgt_text.2119: For not even one single man on earth honours God in a worthy manner, but only according to righteousness.
tgt_text.2120: For when it is not possible for a man to exhibit due gratitude even to his parents, for it is impossible for him to become their parents in his turn;
tgt_text.2121: how can it be anything but absolutely impossible adequately to requite God, or worthily to praise him who created the whole universe out of things that had no previous existence.
tgt_text.2123: Be thou therefore 0 my soul in all your entirety always visible to God, for three separate times, that is to say for time divided according to a threefold division;
tgt_text.2124: not drawing after ,you the female passion arising from external sensation, but offering up to him manly thought, the encourager to and prac­ tiser of persevering courage.
tgt_text.2125: For at three seasons of the year every male must appear before the Lord the God of Israel"* this is the injunction of the holy scriptures.
tgt_text.2126: On this account Moses when he appears to God in.
tgt_text.2127: visible form, flees from the dispersing disposition, that is from Pharaoh, who boasts, saying, that he does not know the Lord, " for Moses,” says he, " retreated from the presence of Pharaoh, and dwelt in the land of Midian” † that is to say, being interpreted, in the judgment of the nature of things;
tgt_text.2128: and sat down upon a well, waiting to see what good which might be drank in God would rain upon his thirsting and eager soul.
tgt_text.2129: Accordingly he retreats from the impious opinion which is the mistress of the passions, namely from Pharaoh;
tgt_text.2130: and he retreats into Midian, that is to say into judgment, considering anxiously whether he ought to live in tranquil inactivity or whether he ought again to contend with that wicked man to his own destruction.
tgt_text.2131: And he considers whether if he attacks him he shall be able to gain the victory, from which consideration he restrains him­ self waiting, as I have already said, to see if God will give to his deep and not frivolous consideration, a fountain sufficient to wash away the impetuosity of the king of Egypt, that is to say of his own passions.
tgt_text.2132: And he is thought worthy of grace, for having fought the good fight in behalf of virtue he never ceases from warring till he sees the pleasures overthrown and baulked of their object.
tgt_text.2133: And with this view Moses does not flee from Pharaoh, for if he had done so he would have fled without returning ;
tgt_text.2134: but withdraws for a time, that is to say he makes a truce from the war, after the fashion of a wrestler who seeks a respite and collects his breath again, until, having aroused the alliance of prudence and the other virtues he attacks his enemy once more, by divine reason, with the most vigorous power.
tgt_text.2135: But Jacob, for he is a supplanter, having acquired virtue by regu­ lar system and discipline, not without hard labour, for his name had not as yet been changed to Israel, " fled from the affairs of labour *" that is to say from colours and figures, and in short from bodies the nature of which is to wound the soul through the objects of outward sense ;
tgt_text.2136: for since, when he was present, he could not entirely and utterly subdue them, he fled, fearing to be subdued by them.
tgt_text.2137: And he is very worthy of praise for so doing;
tgt_text.2138: for " says Moses you will make the children of Israel cautious,† " but not bold, or covetous of those things, which do not belong to them.V.
tgt_text.2139: "And Jacob concealed himself from Laban the Syrian, in that he told him not that he was about to flee from him, and he fled from him, taking with him all that he had, and he crossed the river, and proceeded towards the Mount Gilead."
tgt_text.2140: It was most natural for him to conceal that he was about to flee, and not to inform Laban, who was a man de­ pending wholly on thoughts such as arise from the outward senses, just as if you have seen some excellent beauty and are charmed with it, and are likely to be led into error in respect of it, you should privily flee from the imagination of it, and never tell it to your mind, that is to say, never think of it again nor give it any consideration, for continued recollec­ tions of anything are not without making some distinct im­ pression, and injure the intellect and turn it out of the right way, even against its will.
tgt_text.2141: And the same reasoning applies to all temptations which arise in respect of any one of the ex­ ternal senses, for in all such cases secret flight is the preserver from danger.
tgt_text.2142: But to keep recalling the temptation to one's mind, and to talk of it and dwell upon it subdues and enslaves the reason by force.
tgt_text.2143: Do not these then ever, 0 my mind, report to yourself any object of outward sense that has been seen by you, if you are likely to be led away captive by it, and do not dwell on it, in order that you may not become miser­ able by being subdued by it, but rather, while you are still free, rise up and flee, preferring untamed liberty to slavery and subjection to a master.
tgt_text.2145: But why now, as if Jacob had been ignorant that Laban was a Syrian, does Moses say, " And Jacob concealed himself from Laban the Syrian."
tgt_text.2146: This expression, however, has a reason in it which is not superfluous;
tgt_text.2147: for the name Syria, being interpreted, means high.
tgt_text.2148: Jacob, therefore, being an experienced man, that is to say, being mind, when he sees passion low and powerless, abides it, thinking that he shall be able to subdue it by force :
tgt_text.2149: but when he beholds it high, and bearing its neck haughtily, and full of arrogance, then ex­ perienced mind flees first, and afterwards the other parts of his experience do also flee, namely reading, meditation, care, the recollection of what is honourable, temperance, the energy in pursuit of what is becoming;
tgt_text.2150: and so he crosses over the river of the objects affecting the outward senses, which wash over and threaten to submerge the soul by the impetuosity of the passions, and having crossed over he proceeds towards the high and lofty reason of perfect virtue;
tgt_text.2151: for " he proceeded to­ wards the Mount of Gilead;
tgt_text.2152: " and Gilead being interpreted means the migration of testimony, since God caused the soul to migrate from the passions which surrounded Laban, and bore witness to it, that it should migrate and receive another settlement, because it was profitable and expedient, and con­ ducted it onwards from the evils calculated to render the soul base, and seeking the things that are on the earth, to the height and magnitude of virtue.
tgt_text.2153: On this account Laban, the friend of the outward senses, and one who energised according to them and not according to his mind, is indignant, and pursues after him and says, " why did you flee from me secretly, and not remain for the enjoy­ ment of your soul, and for the opinions which judge concerning the body and the external good things of the world ?"
tgt_text.2154: But in fleeing from this opinion you have despoiled me also of my prudence, Leah and Rachel;
tgt_text.2155: for they, when they remained in the soul created, prudence in it, but now that they have de­ parted they have left it ignorance and inexperience."
tgt_text.2156: On which account he adds, " You have stripped me," that is to say, you have robbed me of my prudence.
tgt_text.2158: And what that prudence was he will proceed to tell us, for he adds, "
tgt_text.2159: And you have led away my daughters as captives;
tgt_text.2160: and if you had told me, I would myself have sent you away."*
tgt_text.2161: You would not have sent away things which were at variance with one another, for if you had sent them | away really, and had emancipated the soul, yon would have removed from it all bodily sounds, and such as affect the out­ ward senses;
tgt_text.2162: for in this way the intellect is emancipated from evils and passions.
tgt_text.2163: But now you say that you send it away free, but by your actions you confess that you would have re­ tained it in a prison;
tgt_text.2164: for if you had sent it on its way with musical instruments, and drums and harps, and all the plea­ sures which affect the outward senses, you would not in reality have released it at all;
tgt_text.2165: for it is not you then only from whom we are fleeing, 0 Laban, thou companion of bodies and colours, but we are also escaping from everything that is thine, in which the voices of the outward senses sound in harmony with the energies of the passions.
tgt_text.2166: For we, if at least we are practisers of virtue, have meditated a very necessary meditation, which Jacob also meditated, namely, to overthrow and destroy those gods who are hostile to the soul, gods made by hands, gods whom Moses forbade the people to make ;
tgt_text.2167: * and these gods are the destruction of virtue and of a good state of the passions, but the consolidation and confirmation of vice and the appetites;
tgt_text.2168: for that metal which is cast, after it has been fused, is soon consolidated again.
tgt_text.2170: But Moses speaks thus, " And they gave to Jacob the foreign gods which were in their hands, and the earrings which were in their ears;
tgt_text.2171: and Jacob hid them under the tur­ pentine tree which was in Shechem. ”†
tgt_text.2172: These are the gods of the wicked, but Jacob is not said to have taken them, but to have concealed and destroyed them, for every case being most accurately described, for the virtuous man will take nothing from wickedness for his own advantage, but will conceal all such things and destroy them secretly.
tgt_text.2173: Just as Abraham tells the king of Sodom, when he was proposing to give him things of irrational nature in exchange for rational animals, namely, horses in exchange for men, " that he would take nothing that belonged to him, but that he would stretch out “ the action of his soul ..... which, speaking symbolically, he called " his hand," to the most high God;
tgt_text.2174: t " for that he had not taken from a thread even to a shoe-latchet of all that was his (the king of Sodom's), in order that the king might never say that he had made the discerning man," namely Abraham, " rich," exchanging poverty for wealthy virtue.
tgt_text.2175: The passions are always concealed and guarded in Shechem ;
tgt_text.2176: and the name Shechem being interpreted means " the shoul­ der for he who labours concerning pleasures is inclined to preserve them.
tgt_text.2177: But the passions are concealed and destroyed by the wise man, and that too not for a brief space of time, but up to this present day, that is to say, for ever, for all time is measured by the present day, for the cycle of one day is the measure of all time.
tgt_text.2178: On which account Jacob gives Joseph Shechem,* as an especial portion beyond the rest of his brethren, meaning thereby the bodily things which are the objects of the outward senses, since he had gone through labour in respect of them;
tgt_text.2179: but to Judah the confessor he gave not presents but praise, and hymns and divine songs, in which he should be celebrated by his brethren.
tgt_text.2180: And Jacob did not receive Shechem as a gift from God, but he took it with his sword and with his bow, that is to say, by words, which had the power of cutting and repelling;
tgt_text.2181: for the wise man subjects all secondary things to himself, and when he has so subjected them he does not retain them, but makes a pre­ sent of them to him who is by nature adapted to them.
tgt_text.2182: Do you not see that also, when he appeared to take the gods, he did not take them, but concealed them and put them out of the way, and destroyed them out of his sight for ever.
tgt_text.2183: Now to what soul could it have happened to conceal vice and to put it out of the way, except to that soul to which God was re­ vealed, and which he considered worthy to receive the reve­ lation of his unspeakable mysteries ?
tgt_text.2184: For he says, " shall I hide from Abraham my son that thing which I am doing ?"t
tgt_text.2185: Well done, 0 Saviour, in that thou showest thy works to the soul which desires good things, and has concealed from it no one of thy works:
tgt_text.2186: and by reason of this conduct of thine he is able to avoid evil, and to conceal it and keep it out of sight, and to destroy for ever the passions which are injurious.
tgt_text.2188: We have shown, therefore, in what manner the wicked man is a fugitive, and how he conceals himself from God;
tgt_text.2189: but now let us consider where he conceals himself.
tgt_text.2191: In the middle," says Moses, " of the trees of the garden;
tgt_text.2192: ”‡ that is to say, in the middle of the mind, which again is itself the centre of the whole soul, as the trees are of the garden.
tgt_text.2193: For the man who escapes from God flees to himself, for, since there are two things, the mind of the universe, which is God, and also the separate mind of each individual, he who escapes from the mind which is in himself flees to the mind of the universe;
tgt_text.2194: and conversely, he who forsakes his own individual mind, confesses that all the things of the human mind are of no value, and attributes everything to God ;
tgt_text.2195: again, he who seeks to escape from God asserts, by so doing, that God is not the cause of anything, but looks upon himself as the cause of everything that exists.
tgt_text.2196: At all events it is affirmed by many people, that everything in the world is borne on spontaneously without any guide or governor, and that the human mind, by its own single power, has invented arts and pursuits, and laws and customs, and all the principles of political and individual, and common justice, with reference both to men and to irrational animals.
tgt_text.2197: But dost thou not see, 0 soul, the unreasonable character of these opinions?
tgt_text.2198: For one of them having the particular mind, which was created and which is mortal, does in reality ascribe it to the mind of the universe, which is uncreated and im­ mortal :
tgt_text.2199: and the other again, repudiating God, most inconsist­ ently drags forward, as an ally, that mind which is unable even to assist itself.
tgt_text.2201: On this account also Moses says, that "
tgt_text.2202: If a thief be de­ tected in the act of breaking into a house, and be smitten so that he die, that shall not be imputed as murder to him who has smitten him;
tgt_text.2203: but if the sun be risen upon him, then he is liable, and shall die in retaliation."*
tgt_text.2204: For if any one cuts down and destroys that reason which stands upright and is sound and correct, which testifies to God that he alone is able to do everything, and is found in the act of breaking in upon it, that is to say, standing over this reason thus wounded and destroyed, and who recognises his own mind as energising, and not God, is a thief, taking away what belongs to others, for all things belong to God;
tgt_text.2205: so he who attributes anything to himself is taking away what belongs to another, and receives a very severe blow and one difficult to heal, namely, arro­ gance, a thing nearly akin to imprudence and ignorance.
tgt_text.2206: But he says nothing as to the name of him who has smitten him, for the smiter is not a different person from him who is smitten.
tgt_text.2207: But as a man who rubs himself is likewise a person who is rubbed, and as he who stretches himself out is also the person who is streched out, for he himself both exerts the power of the agent, and also fills the part of the patient.
tgt_text.2208: In like manner is he, who steals the things which belong to God, and attributes them to himself, subjected to the tortures of his own impiety and arrogance.
tgt_text.2209: Would that the man so stricken might die, that is to say might perish before he had succeeded in his objects, for then he will appear to be less sinful, for of vice one kind is discerned in habit, and another kind in motion ;
tgt_text.2210: but the one which is discerned in motion has an inclination towards the perfecting of its operation, on which account it is more mischievous than the one which is discerned only in habit.
tgt_text.2211: If therefore the mind, which imagines itself and not God to be the cause of things, dies, that is to say, becomes inactive and contracts itself, then there is no cause of death in it;
tgt_text.2212: it has not absolutely destroyed the living opinion, which attributes all power, and all exertion of power to God, but if the Sun rises, that is to say the mind which appears brilliant in us, and if it appears to see through everything and to judge everything, and not to flee from itself, it then becomes liable to death, and shall die in retaliation for the living doctrine which it has destroyed ;
tgt_text.2213: according to which God alone is the cause of everything, being found to be wholly unable to effect any good purpose, and to be truly dead in as much as it has shown itself the interpreter of a lifeless and dead and departed doctrine.
tgt_text.2215: And it is in reference to this that the Holy Scripture curses " any one who has placed in any secret place any carved thing, or any thing made of cast metal, the work of the hands of an artist."*
tgt_text.2216: For why, 0 mind, do you store and treasure up within yourself depraved opinions, that God is a being of such and such qualities, (he who has no distinctive qualities) like a carved work;
tgt_text.2217: or that he who is imperishable is perish­ able like images that are cast in the foundry;
tgt_text.2218: and why do you not rather bring them forward openly that you may learn what is right from men who practise the truth?
tgt_text.2219: For you think that you are endowed with some great skill because you have devised absurd opinions imposing upon you by an appearance of probability, in opposition to the truth :
tgt_text.2220: but in reality you are proved to be destitute of skill, in as much as you are unwilling to be healed of that terrible disease of the soul, ignorance,XII.
tgt_text.2221: But that the wicked man sinks into and is concealed within his own scattered mind, fleeing from the real mind or truth, is testified by Moses who smote the Egyptian and buried him in the sand," * the meaning of which is that he by his arguments convinced him who asserted that the good things of the body were the most excellent, and who thought that the good things of the soul were of no value, and who likewise esteemed the pleasures as the end of life.
tgt_text.2222: For when lie had comprehended the labour of him who beholds God, which the king of Egypt had imposed on him, (and by the king of Egypt is meant vice, which is the guide of the passions) he sees an Egyptian man, that is to say human passions operating at a seasonable moment, beating and insulting the man who beholds God, and looking round upon the whole soul on this side and on that side, and seeing no one standing by except the true God, and everything else in a state of con­ fusion and disorder, having stricken down and convicted the lover of pleasure, he hides him in the dispersed and agitated mind, which is deprived of all kindred with and comprehension of what is good.
tgt_text.2223: This man then is hidden in himself, but the man who is opposite to him escapes from himself, and flees to the God of all existing things.
tgt_text.2225: On which account Moses says moreover, " He led him forth out of doors and said to him, look up to heaven, and count the stars," t which we should be glad indeed to see thoroughly and to comprehend ;
tgt_text.2226: since we are insatiable in our love for notice, but nevertheless we are unable to measure the riches of God.
tgt_text.2227: Nevertheless thanks be to that magnifi­ cent and bounteous
tgt_text.2228: God because he says that he has implanted in the soul seeds as brilliant, as visible at a distance, and as eternally new as the stars in heaven.
tgt_text.2229: And it is not a super­ fluous addition when after having said " he led him forth," he subjoins " out of doors," for who is ever led forth in doors ?
tgt_text.2230: But perhaps what he says here has some such meaning as this ;
tgt_text.2231: he led him forth into the outermost place, not into some place or other out of doors, which might he surrounded by other places.
tgt_text.2232: For as in dwelling houses the man's character is outside the woman's chamber, and the inner chamber is within, and the vestibule is outside of the hall but within the doorway, so also in the case of the soul that which is within one thing may be outside of some other thing.
tgt_text.2233: This then is the sense in which we must understand this passage;
tgt_text.2234: he led the mind forth into the outermost place, for what was the use of his leaving the body and fleeing to the outward senses;
tgt_text.2235: and what would have been the use of his discarding the outward senses, and subjecting that which exists to the voice?
tgt_text.2236: For it is fitting that the mind which is about to be led forth, and to be dismissed in freedom should be emancipated from all cor­ poreal necessities, from all the organs of the outward senses, from all sophistical ratiocinations, and plausible persuasions, and last of all from itself.
tgt_text.2238: On which account in another passage also he boasts, saying " the Lord the God of Heaven, and the God of earth who took me out of the house of my father."*
tgt_text.2239: For it is not possible for one who dwells in the body and belongs to the race of mortals to be united with God, but he alone can be so whom God delivers from that prison house of the body.
tgt_text.2240: On which account also, that joy of the soul, Isaac, when he is conversing and discoursing privately with God, comes forth forsaking himself and his own mind, for he says, " Come forth, 0 Isaac, to converse in the plain towards evening, "t and Moses, that word of prophecy, says, “When I go forth from the city," that is from my soul, (for the soul is the city of the living creature, in as much as it is the soul which gives it its laws and customs), " I will stretch forth my hands,”‡ and I will reveal and unfold all my actions to God, invoking him as a witness and inspector of every one of them, from whom it is impossible by its own nature that vice should be hidden, but to whom it must be unfolded and by whom it must be clearly discerned.
tgt_text.2241: When therefore the soul is made manifest in all its sayings and doings, and is made a partaker of the divine nature, the voices of the external senses are reduced to silence, and so likewise are all troublesome and ill-omened sounds, for the objects of sight often speak loudly and invite the sense of sight to themselves ;
tgt_text.2242: and so do voices invite the sense of hear­ ing;
tgt_text.2243: scents invite the smell, and altogether each varied object of sense invites its appropriate sense.
tgt_text.2244: But all these things are put at rest when the mind going forth out of the city of the soul, attributes all its own actions and conceptions to God.XV. "
tgt_text.2245: For the hands of Moses are heavy.* "
tgt_text.2246: For since the actions of the wicked man are like the wind and light, those of the wise man on the other hand are heavy and immoveable, and not easily shaken;
tgt_text.2247: in reference to which his hands are held up by Aaron, who is reason, or by Ur, who is light.
tgt_text.2248: Now of all existing things there is nothing clearer than the truth;
tgt_text.2249: therefore Moses intends here to signify by a symbolical form of expression, that the actions of the wise man are supported by the most necessary of all qualities, rea­ son and truth.
tgt_text.2250: On this account also, when Aaron dies, that is to say, when the truth is completely asserted, he ascends up to Ur,t that is to say, to Light;
tgt_text.2251: for the proper end of reason is truth, which is more visible than any light, and to it reason is always striving to come.
tgt_text.2252: Do you not see that also when he received the tabernacle from God, and this tabernacle is wisdom, in which the wise man tabernacles and, dwells, he fixed it firmly and founded and built it up strongly, not in the body but out of it;
tgt_text.2253: for he likens this to an encampment, to a camp I say full of wars and of all the evils which war causes, and which has no portion with peace."
tgt_text.2254: And it was called the tabernacle of testimony that is to say wisdom was borne witness to by God.
tgt_text.2255: For every one who seeks the Lord went forth out of his house.
tgt_text.2257: For if you seek God, 0 my mind, go forth out of your­ self, and so seek for him;
