tgt_text.2258: but if you remain in the substance of the body, or in the vain opinions of the mind, you are then without any real wish to search into divine things, even if you do put on the appearance and pretence of seeking them.
tgt_text.2259: If when you search you will find God, is uncertain;
tgt_text.2260: for there have been many persons to whom he has not revealed himself, but they have expended a vain labour all their time.
tgt_text.2261: But the mere act of seeking for him is sufficient to entitle you to a participation in good things, for the desire for what is good, even if it fails in attaining the end which it seeks, does at all events always gladden the heart of those who cherish it.
tgt_text.2262: Thus the wicked man who flees from virtue, and who seeks to conceal himself from God, flees to a powerless ally, that is his own mind, but the good man on the contrary seeking to escape from himself turns to the knowledge of the one God, and is victorious in the honourable race, and in that contest which is of all the most excellent.]
tgt_text.2263: 6. " And the Lord God called Adam, and said unto him, where art thou ? "*
tgt_text.2264: Why now is Adam, alone called, when his wife also was concealed together with him ?
tgt_text.2265: In the first place we must say that the mind is summoned, and asked where it is.
tgt_text.2266: When it is converted, and reproved for its offence, not only is it summoned itself but all its faculties are also sum­ moned, for without its faculties the mind by itself is found to be naked, and to be absolutely nothing, and one of its faculties is also the outward sense, that is to say the woman.
tgt_text.2267: The woman therefore, that is the outward sense is also sum­ moned together with Adam, that is the mind, but separately God does not summon her.
tgt_text.2269: Because being destitute of reason she is incapable of being convicted by herself.
tgt_text.2270: For neither can sight, nor hearing, nor any one of the other external senses be taught, and moreover none of them are capable of receiving the comprehension of things;
tgt_text.2271: for the Creator has not made them capable of distinguishing anything but bodies only.
tgt_text.2272: But the mind is able to receive teaching:
tgt_text.2273: on account of which fact God calls that, but not the external senses.
tgt_text.2274: 17. And the expression “Where art thou?" admits of being interpreted in many ways.
tgt_text.2275: In the first place it may be taken not as an interrogation, but as an affirmation, equivalent to the words "
tgt_text.2276: You are somewhere," if you alter the accent on the particle που "where."
tgt_text.2277: For, since you have thought that God was walking in the garden, and was surrounded by it, learn now that in this you were mistaken, and hear from God who knows all things that most true statement that God is not in any one place.
tgt_text.2278: For he is not surrounded by anything, but he does himself surround everything.
tgt_text.2279: For that which is created is in place;
tgt_text.2280: for it is inevitable that it must be surrounded, and not be the thing which surrounds.
tgt_text.2281: In the second place, that which is said is equivalent to this, Where hast thou been, 0 soul ?
tgt_text.2282: What evils has thou chosen instead of what good things ?
tgt_text.2283: When God invited you to a participation in virtue, have you pursued vice?
tgt_text.2284: And when he offered to you for your enjoyment the tree of life, that is to say the tree of wisdom by which you might live, have you has­ tened into ignorance and to destruction, preferring misery, tho death of the soul to the happiness of eternal life ?
tgt_text.2285: The third interpretation is the interrogative one;
tgt_text.2286: to which there may be two answers given.
tgt_text.2287: The one, if the answer be given to the inquirer, " Where art thou?" is, " Nowhere."
tgt_text.2288: For the soul of the wicked man has no place to which it can go, or in which it can be situated.
tgt_text.2289: In respect of which fact the wicked man is said to be destitute of place;
tgt_text.2290: but an evil desti­ tute of place is one which is difficult to manage.
tgt_text.2291: And such is the man who is void of good qualities, being always agitated and in a state of confusion, and wavering about after the fashion of an unsteady breeze being altogether the companion of no single steady opinion.
tgt_text.2292: The other answer may be of this kind;
tgt_text.2293: that which Adam himself uses. " Hear where I am," where those are who are unable to see God ;
tgt_text.2294: where those are who do not listen to God ;
tgt_text.2295: where those are who endeavour to conceal themselves from him who is the author of all things:
tgt_text.2296: where those are who flee from virtue, where those are who are destitute of wisdom, where those are who are alarmed and tremble because of the unmanliness and cowardice of their souls.
tgt_text.2297: For when Adam says, "I heard thy voice in the paradise and I was afraid because I was naked and I hid myself," he exhibits all the qualities enumerated above, as I have shown, more at length, in the former books of this treatise.
tgt_text.2299: And yet Adam is not now naked.
tgt_text.2300: It has been said a little before that " they made themselves girdles," but by this expression Moses intends to teach you that he is not meaning here to speak of the nakedness of the body, but of that in res­ pect of which the mind is found to be wholly deficient in and destitute of virtue.
tgt_text.2301: "The woman," says Adam, “whom you gave to be with me, she gave me of the tree and I did eat.
tgt_text.2302: ”The expression here is very accurate, inasmuch as he does not say, " The woman whom you gave to me," but " The woman whom you gave to be with me."
tgt_text.2303: For you did not give me the outward senses as a possession, but you left them free and unim­ peded, and in some sort not at all yielding to the injunctions of my intellect.
tgt_text.2304: If therefore the mind were to be inclined to command the sight not to see, it nevertheless would see any subject which came before it.
tgt_text.2305: And the hearing also will in every case apprehend any sound which falls upon it, even if the mind in its jealousy were to command it not to hear.
tgt_text.2306: And again the smell will smell every scent which reaches it, even if the mind were to forbid it to apprehend it.
tgt_text.2307: On this account it is that God did not give the outward sense to the creature, but to be with the creature.
tgt_text.2308: And the meaning of this is, the inward sense in conjunction with our mind knows every thing, and does so too at the same moments with the mind.
tgt_text.2309: As for instance the sense of sight in con­ junction and simultaneously with the mind strikes upon the subject of sight;
tgt_text.2310: for the eye sees the substance, and imme­ diately the mind comprehends the thing seen, that is black or white, or pale, or red, or triangular, or quadrangular, or round, or that is of any other colour or shape as the case may be.
tgt_text.2311: And so again the sense of hearing is affected by a sound, and with the sense of hearing the mind is also affected;
tgt_text.2312: and the proof of it is this;
tgt_text.2313: the mind immediately distinguishes the character of the voice, that it is thin, or that it has substance, or that it is melodious and tuneful;
tgt_text.2314: or, on the other hand, that it is out of tune and inharmonious.
tgt_text.2315: And the same is found to be the case in respect of the rest of the inward senses.
tgt_text.2316: And very appropriately do we see that Adam adds this assertion, " She gave me of the tree;
tgt_text.2317: " but he gives an habi­ tation made of wood and perceptible by the outward senses to the mind except that outward sense itself.
tgt_text.2318: For what gave to the mind to be able to distinguish body, or whiteness ?
tgt_text.2320: And what enabled it to distinguish sounds ?
tgt_text.2322: What, again, endowed it with the faculty of judging of smells?
tgt_text.2323: Was it not the sense of smell ?
tgt_text.2324: What enabled it to decide upon flavours?
tgt_text.2326: What invested it with the power of distinguishing between rough and smooth ?
tgt_text.2328: Cor­ rectly, therefore, and with complete truth was it said by the mind, that it was the outward sense alone which gave me the power to comprehend the corporeal substance.
tgt_text.2330: And God said to the woman, " What is this that thou hast done ?"
tgt_text.2331: And she said, " The serpent beguiled me and I did eat."
tgt_text.2332: God asks one question of the outward sense, and she replies to a different one.
tgt_text.2333: For he is putting a question which has reference to the man ;
tgt_text.2334: but she in her reply speaks not of the man but of herself, saying, " I ate," not I gave.
tgt_text.2335: May we then by the use of allegory solve the question which was here put, and show that the woman gave a felicitous and correct answer to the question ?
tgt_text.2336: For it follows of necessity that when she had eaten, her husband did also eat, for when the outward sense striking upon its object is filled with its appearance, then immediately the mind joins it and takes its share of it, and is in a manner made perfect by the nourish­ ment which it receives from it.
tgt_text.2337: This therefore is what she says, I unintentionally gave it to my husband, for while I was applying myself to what was presented to me, he, being very easily and quickly moved, impressed its appearance and image upon himself.
tgt_text.2339: But take notice that the man says that the woman gave it to him;
tgt_text.2340: but that the woman does not say that the serpent gave it to her, but that he beguiled her;
tgt_text.2341: for it is the especial property of the outward sense to give, but it is the attribute of pleasure which is of a diversified and serpent-like nature to deceive and to beguile.
tgt_text.2342: For instance, the outward sense presents to the mind the image of what is white by nature, or black, or hot, or cold, not deceiving it, but acting truly;
tgt_text.2343: for the subjects of the outward sense are of such a character, as also is the imagination which presents itself to man from them, in the case of the great majority of men who do not carry their knowledge of natural philosophy to any accurate extent.
tgt_text.2344: But pleasure does not present to the mind that the subject is such as it is in reality, but deceives it by its artifice, thrusting that, in which there is no advantage, into the class of things profitable.
tgt_text.2345: For as we may at times see ill-looking courtezans dyeing and painting their faces in order to conceal the plainness of their countenances, so also may we see the intemperate man acting who is inclined to the pleasures of the belly.
tgt_text.2346: He looks upon great abundance of wine and a luxurious store of food as a good thing, though he is injured by them both in his body and in his soul.
tgt_text.2347: Again, we may often see lovers madly eager to be loved by the ugliest of women, because pleasure deceives them and all but affirms positively to them that beauty of form, and delicacy of complexion, and healthiness of flesh, and symmetry of limb, exists in those who have the exact contraries to all these qualifications.
tgt_text.2348: Accordingly, they over­ look those who are truly possessed of perfectly irreproachable beauty, and waste away with love for such creatures as I have mentioned.
tgt_text.2349: Every kind of deceit therefore is closely con­ nected with pleasure ;
tgt_text.2350: and every kind of gift with the outward sense:
tgt_text.2351: for the one bewilders the mind with sophistry and misleads it, representing to it anything that comes before it, not in the character which really belongs to it, but in one that does not.
tgt_text.2352: But the outward sense presents bodies, plainly as they are according to their real nature, without any device or artifice.
tgt_text.2354: And the Lord God said to the serpent, Because thou hast done this thing, thou art cursed above all cattle and every beast of the field ;
tgt_text.2355: upon thy breast and upon thy belly shalt thou go, and dust shalt thou eat all the days of thy life.
tgt_text.2356: And I will put enmity in the midst between thee and between the woman, and in the midst between thy seed and between her seed, He shall bruise thy head, and thou shalt bruise his heel."*
tgt_text.2357: What is the reason why he curses the serpent without allowing him to make any defence, when in another place he commands that " both the parties between whom there is any dispute shall be heard,"t and that one shall not be believed till the other has been heard ?
tgt_text.2358: And indeed in this case you see that he did not give a prejudged belief to Adam's statement against his wife ;
tgt_text.2359: but he gave her also an oppor­ tunity of defending herself, when he asked her, " Why hast thou done this?"
tgt_text.2360: But she confessed that she had erred through the deceitfulness of serpent-like and diversified plea­ sure.
tgt_text.2361: Why, therefore, when the woman had said, " The serpent deceived me,"t did he forbid the putting of the question to the serpent whether it was he who had thus deceived her ;
tgt_text.2362: and why did he thus appoint him to be condemned without trial and without defence ?
tgt_text.2363: We must say, therefore, that the external senses are not a a peculiar property of either bad or good men, but that they are of an intermediate nature, and common to both the wise man and the fool, and when they are found in the fool, they are bad;
tgt_text.2364: but when they are found in the wise man, they are good.
tgt_text.2365: Very naturally therefore, since it has a nature which is not necessarily and intrinsically evil, but one which being capable of either character, inclines at different times and under different circumstances towards either extremity, it is not condemned till it has itself confessed that it followed the worse inclination.
tgt_text.2366: But the serpent, that is pleasure, is of itself evil.
tgt_text.2367: On this account it is absolutely not found at all in the virtuous man;
tgt_text.2368: but the wicked man alone enjoys it.
tgt_text.2370: God curse it before it has time to make any defence, inasmuch as it has no seed of virtue within it, but is at all times and in all places blameable and polluting.
tgt_text.2372: On this account also, God " saw that Er was wicked,"* without any apparent cause for this judgment of his character, and he slew him.
tgt_text.2373: For God is not unaware that that leathern mass which covers us, namely, the body;
tgt_text.2374: for Er being interpreted means leather, is an evil thing, and one which plots against the soul, and which is at all times lifeless and dead.
tgt_text.2375: For what else does he compel any one of us to do but to carry about a dead body, our soul raising up the body which as far as its own nature goes is dead, and bearing it almost without difficulty?
tgt_text.2376: And just consider, if you will, the great energy of the soul, for the most vigorous athlete would not be able to carry about a statue of himself for even a short time ;
tgt_text.2377: but the soul, without any exertion and without any fatigue, carries about the statue of a man occa­ sionally even for as long a time as a hundred years;
tgt_text.2378: for even at the end of that period it does not kill it, but only gets rid of a body which was dead from the beginning.
tgt_text.2379: And it is evil by nature, as I have said before, and a thing which plots against the soul, but which is not visible to all men, but only to God, and to such men as are friends to God. "
tgt_text.2380: For the wicked Er," says Moses, " was an enemy of the Lord.
tgt_text.2381: "For when the mind busies itself with sublime contem­ plations, and becomes initiated into the mysteries of the Lord, it judges the body to be a wicked and hostile thing;
tgt_text.2382: but when it abandons its investigations of divine things, it then looks upon the body as something friendly, and belonging to and nearly akin to itself;
tgt_text.2383: and accordingly it flies to the things which are dear to it.
tgt_text.2384: On this account the soul of the athlete and the soul of the philosopher differ;
tgt_text.2385: for the athlete attri • butes all his importance to the good condition of his body, and would throw away his soul itself in the cause of his body, as being a man devoted to his body;
tgt_text.2386: but the philosopher, being a lover of what is'virtuous, cares for that which is alive within him, namely his soul, and disregards his body which is dead, having no other object but to prevent the most excellent portion of him, namely his soul, from being injured by the evil and dead thing which is connected with it.
tgt_text.2388: You see that it is not the Lord who is here spoken of as slaying Er, but God.
tgt_text.2389: For he does not kill the body in respect of the absolute and irresponsible power which he possesses, and by which he rules and governs the universe, but in respect of that authority which he possesses in consequence of his goodness and excellence, for God is the name of goodness, the cause of all things ;
tgt_text.2390: that you may understand that he also created all inanimate things, not by his authority, but by his goodness, by which also he created all living things;
tgt_text.2391: for it was requisite for the manifestation of the better things, that there should also be a subordinate creation of the inferior things, through the power of the same goodness which was the cause of all, which is God.
tgt_text.2393: shall you most especially consider that you have gained a victory?
tgt_text.2394: Will it not be when you are made perfect, and when you have been thought worthy,of decisions in your favour and of crowns ?
tgt_text.2395: For then you will be a lover of God, not of the body, and you will receive prizes, inasmuch as your wife shall be Thamar the bride of Judah, and Thamar being interpreted means the palm-tree, the symbol of victory.
tgt_text.2396: And a proof of this is, that when Er married her, he was at once discovered to be a wicked man, and was slain ;
tgt_text.2397: for Moses says, " And Judah took a wife for Er, his first-born soil, whose name was Thamar;
tgt_text.2398: " and immediately afterwards he adds, " And Er was a wicked man before the Lord, and God slew him ;
tgt_text.2399: ” for when the mind has carried off the prize of virtue, it condemns the dead body to death.
tgt_text.2400: You see that God also curses the serpent without allowing it to make any defence, for it is pleasure :
tgt_text.2402: Er without any visible cause being alleged, for Er is the body.
tgt_text.2403: And if you consider, 0 good friend, you will find that God has created in the soul some natural qualities which are in themselves faulty and blameless, and also in every soul some which are virtuous and praiseworthy, as is the case likewise with plants and animals.
tgt_text.2404: Do you not see that the Creator has made some plants capable of cultivation and useful and salutary, and others incapable of cultivation, wild, pernicious, the causes of diseases and destruction;
tgt_text.2405: and ani­ mals too of similar variety of character, as beyond all question is the serpent, of which we are now speaking;
tgt_text.2406: for he is a destructive and deadly animal by his intrinsic nature.
tgt_text.2407: And as the serpent affects man, so does pleasure too affect the soul;
tgt_text.2408: in reference to which fact the serpent has been compared to pleasure.
tgt_text.2410: As, therefore, God hates pleasure and the body without any especial cause, so also does he give pre-eminent honour to virtuous natures without any visible cause;
tgt_text.2411: not alleging any action of theirs before the praises of them which he utters.
tgt_text.2412: For if any one were to ask why Moses says that " Noah found grace before the Lord God,"* without having previously done any good thing, as far at least as we know, we shall be very properly answered, that he was proved to be a praiseworthy character and order of creation ;
tgt_text.2413: for the name Noah, being interpreted, means rest, or just:
tgt_text.2414: and it follows of necessity that one who is resting from acts of injustice and from sins, and who, so resting, lives with virtue and justice, must find grace before God;
tgt_text.2415: and to find grace, is not only, as some call it, equivalent to the expression " pleasing God," but it has some such meaning as this.
tgt_text.2416: The just man seeking to understand the nature of all exist­ ing things, makes this one most excellent discovery, that everything which exists, does so according to the grace of God, and that there is nothing ever given by, just as there is nothing possessed by, the things of creation.
tgt_text.2417: On which account also it is proper to acknowledge gratitude to the Crea­ tor alone.
tgt_text.2418: Accordingly, to those persons who seek to investi­ gate what is the origin of creation, we may most correctly make answer, that it is the goodness and the grace of God, which he has bestowed on the human race;
tgt_text.2419: for all the things which are in the world, and the world itself, are the gift and benefaction and free grace of God..XXV.
tgt_text.2420: Moreover, God made Melchisedek, the king of peace, that is of Salem, for that is the interpretation of this name, "his own high priest,"* without having previously mentioned any particular action of his, but merely because he had made him a king, and a lover of peace, and especially worthy of his priesthood.
tgt_text.2421: For he is called a just king, and a king is the opposite of a tyrant, because the one is the interpreter of law, and the other of lawlessness.
tgt_text.2422: Therefore the tyrannical mind imposes violent and mischievous commands on both soul and body, and such as have a tendency to cause violent suffering, being commands to act according to vice, and to indulge the passions with enjoyment.
tgt_text.2423: But the other, the kingly mind, in the first place, does not command, but rather persuades, since it gives recommendations of such a character, that if guided by them, life, like a vessel, will enjoy a fair voyage through life, being directed in its course by a good governor and pilot;
tgt_text.2424: and this good pilot is right reason.
tgt_text.2425: We may therefore call the tyrannical mind the ruler of war, and the kingly mind the guide to peace, that is Salem.
tgt_text.2426: And this kingly mind shall bring forth food full of cheerful­ ness and joy;
tgt_text.2427: for " he brought forth bread and wine," which the Ammonites and Moabites were not willing to give to the beholder, that is Israel;
tgt_text.2428: by reason of such unwillingness they are shut out from the companionship and assembly of Grod.
tgt_text.2429: For the Ammonites being they who are sprung from the out­ ward sense of the mother, and the Moabites, who originate in the mind of the father, are two different dispositions, which look upon the mind and the outward sense as the efficient causes of all existing things, but take no notice of God.
tgt_text.2430: Therefore they shall not come," says Moses, into the assembly of the Lord, because they did not come to meet you with bread and water when you came out of Egypt,"t that is, out of the passions.
tgt_text.2432: But Melchisedek shall bring forward wine instead of water, and shall give your souls to drink, and shall cheer them with unmixed wine, in order that they may be wholly occupied with a divine intoxication, more sober than sobriety itself.
tgt_text.2433: For reason is a priest, having, as its inheritance the true God, and entertaining lofty and sublime and magnificent ideas about him, " for he is the priest of the most high God."*
tgt_text.2434: Not that there is any other God who is not the most high;
tgt_text.2435: for God being one, is in the heaven above, and in the earth beneath, and there is no other besides him.”†
tgt_text.2436: But he sets in motion the notion of the Most High, from his conceiving of God not in a low and grovelling spirit, but in one of ex­ ceeding greatness, and exceeding sublimity, apart from any conceptions of matter.
tgt_text.2438: And what good thing had Abraham done as yet when God called him and bade him become a stranger to his country and to this " generation," and to dwell in the land which the Lord should give him?‡
tgt_text.2439: And that is a good and populous city, and one of great happiness.
tgt_text.2440: For the gifts of God are great and honourable.
tgt_text.2441: But he made this position of Abraham also to be typical, containing an emblem worthy of attentive consideration.
tgt_text.2442: For Abraham, being interpreted, means " Lofty Father ;
tgt_text.2443: "§ a title of admiration in both its divi­ sions.
tgt_text.2444: For when the mind does not, like a master, threaten the soul, but rather guides it, like a father, not indulging it in the pleasant things, but giving it what is expedient for it, even against its will, and also turning it away from all lowly things and such as lead it to mortal paths, it leads it to sublime con­ templations and makes it dwell amid speculations on the world and its constituent parts.
tgt_text.2445: And, moreover, mounting up higher, it investigates the Deity itself, and his nature, through an un­ speakable lore of knowledge, in consequence of which it cannot be content to abide in the original decrees, but, being improved I itself, becomes also desirous of removing to a better habitation.
tgt_text.2447: But there are some persons whom, even before their creation, God creates and disposes excellently;
tgt_text.2448: respecting whom he determines beforehand that they shall have a most excellent inheritance.
tgt_text.2449: Do you not see what he says about Isaac to Abraham, when he had no hope of any such thing, namely, that he should become the father of such an offspring, but did rather laugh at the promise, and asked, " Shall a son be born to me, who am a hundred years old;
tgt_text.2450: and shall Sarah, who is ninety years old, bring forth a child ?"*
tgt_text.2451: But God asserts it positively, and ratifies his promise saying, " Yea, behold Sarah, thy wife;
tgt_text.2452: shall bear theea son, and thou shalt call his name Isaac, and I will establish my covenant towards him for an everlasting covenant.
tgt_text.2453: ”What then is the reason which caused this man, also, to be praised before his birth ?
tgt_text.2454: There are some good things which are an advantage to a man both when they are past, and when they are present, such as good health, a sound condition of the outward senses, riches, if he be endowed with them, a good reputation;
tgt_text.2455: for all these things may, by a slight perver­ sion of words, be called good things.
tgt_text.2456: But some are so not merely when they have been given to us, but even when it is predicted that they shall be so given, as joy is a good affection of the soul;
tgt_text.2457: for this does not cheer a man only when it is present and energises actively in him, but it delights him also by anticipations when it is hoped for-for it has this especial quality ;
tgt_text.2458: all other good qualities have their own separate opera­ tion and effect, but joy is both a separate good and a common good, for it comes as a crowning one after all the rest-for we feel joy at good health, and we feel joy at liberty and at honour, and at all other such things, so that one may say with propriety that there is not one single good thing which has not the addi­ tional good of joy.
tgt_text.2459: But not only do we rejoice at other good things which are already previously past and also at those which are present, but we rejoice also at good things when about to happen to us and expected;
tgt_text.2460: as for instance, when we hope that we shall become rich, or that we shall obtain power, or that we shall receive praise, or that we shall find a means to get rid of an illness, or that we shall acquire vigour and strength, or that we shall become learned instead of ignorant, in all these cases we are rejoiced in no slight degree.
tgt_text.2461: Since, then, joy diffuses itself over and cheers the soul, not only while it is present but also even when it is expected, it was very consistent and natural for God to think Isaac worthy of a good name and of a great gift before he was born, for the name of Isaac, being interpreted, means laughter of soul, and delight, and joy.
tgt_text.2463: Again, they say that Jacob and Esau, the former being the ruler, and governor, and master, and Esau being the subject and the slave, had their several estates appointed to them while they were still in the world.
tgt_text.2464: For God, the creator of all living things, is thoroughly acquainted with all his works, and before he has completely finished them he comprehends the faculties with which they will hereafter be endowed, and altogether he foreknows all their actions and passions.
tgt_text.2465: For when Rebecca, that is the patient soul, proceeds to ask an oracle from God, the answers are, " Two nations are in thy womb, and two people shall come forth from thy bowels, and one people shall be stronger than the other people, and the elder shall save the younger."*
tgt_text.2466: For that which is wicked and void of reason is, by its own nature, a slave in the eye of God ;
tgt_text.2467: but that which is good and endowed with reason and better, is looked upon as powerful and free by him.
tgt_text.2468: And this is the case not only when each of these two different characters is per feet in the soul, but when there is a doubt on the subject;
tgt_text.2469: for, altogether, a slight breeze of virtue shows power and supre­ macy, and not freedom only, and on the other hand, the existence of even an ordinary degree of vice enslaves the reason, even though not by any means as yet come to maturity.
tgt_text.2471: Again, why did the same Jacob when Joseph brought him his two sons, the elder being Manasses and the younger Ephraim, change his hands, and put his right hand upon the younger brother Ephraim, and his left hand upon the elder brother Manasses ?
tgt_text.2472: And when Joseph thought this a grievous thing, and thought that his father had unintentionally made a mistake in the matter of the imposition of hands, Jacob said, " I did not make a mistake, but I knew, my son, I knew that this one should be a father of a nation, and should be exalted;
tgt_text.2473: but, nevertheless, his younger brother shall be greater than he.''t
tgt_text.2474: What, then, must we say but this ?
tgt_text.2475: That two natures, both utterly necessary, were created in the soul by God, one memory and the other recollection, of which memory is the best and recollection the worst.
tgt_text.2476: For the one has its perceptions fresh and harmonious and clear, so that it never errs through ignorance.
tgt_text.2477: But forgetfulness does, in every case, precede re­ collection, which is but a mutilated and blind thing.
tgt_text.2478: And, although recollection is worse, it is nevertheless older than memory, which is better than it, and is also conjoined with and inseparable from it;
tgt_text.2479: for when we are first introduced to any art we are unable at once to make ourselves masters of all the speculations which bear upon it.
tgt_text.2480: Being, therefore, affected with forgetfulness at first, we subsequently recollect, until from a frequent recurrence of forgetfulness and a frequent recurrence of recollection, memory at last prevails in us in a lasting manner.
tgt_text.2481: On which account it is younger than recollection, for it is later in its existence.
tgt_text.2482: And Ephraim is a symbolical name, being, to be interpreted, memory.
tgt_text.2483: For, being interpreted, it means the fertility of the soul of the man fond of learning, which brings forth its appro­ priate fruit when it has confirmed its speculations, and preserves them in its memory.
tgt_text.2484: But Manasses, being interpreted, means recollection, for he is spoken of as one who has been translated from forgetfulness, and he who escapes from forgetfulness does unquestionably recollect.
tgt_text.2485: Most correctly, therefore, does that supplanter of the passions and practiser of virtue, Jacob, give his right hand to that prolific memory, Ephraim, while he places Manasses, or recollection, in the second rank.
tgt_text.2486: And, Moses, also, of all those who sacrificed the passover, praised those who sacrificed first most, because they having crossed over from the passions, that is to say, from Egypt, remained by the passage, and did not hasten any more to the passions which they had quitted ;
tgt_text.2487: and the others he also thinks worthy to be placed in the second rank, for, having turned back, they retraced their steps, and, as if they had forgotten what it became them to do, they again hastened to do the same things ;
tgt_text.2488: but the former men continued in their course without turning back.
tgt_text.2489: There­ fore, Manasses, who is born of forgetfulness, resembles those who were the second party to sacrifice the passover;
tgt_text.2490: but the fertile Ephraim is like those who had sacrificed previously.
tgt_text.2492: On which account God also calls Bezaleel by name, and says that "
tgt_text.2493: He will give him wisdom and knowledge, and that He will make him the builder and the architect of all the things which are in his tabernacle that is to say, of all the works of the soul, when he had up to this time done no work which anyone could praise—we must say, therefore, that God impressed this figure also on the soul, after the fashion of an approved coin.
tgt_text.2494: And we shall know what the impression is if we previously examine the interpretation of the name.
tgt_text.2495: Now, Bezaleel, being interpreted, means God in his shadow.
tgt_text.2496: But the shadow of God is his word, which he used like an in­ strument when he was making the world.
tgt_text.2497: And this shadow, and, as it were, model, is the archetype of other things.
tgt_text.2498: For, as God is himself the model of that image which he has now called a shadow, so also that image is the model of other things, as he showed when he commenced giving the law to the Israelites, and said, " And God made man according to the image of God,"* as the image was modelled according to God, and as man was modelled according to the image, which thus received the power and character of the model.
tgt_text.2500: Let us now, then, examine what the character which is impressed upon man is.
tgt_text.2501: The ancient philosophers used to inquire how we obtained our conceptions of the Deity?
tgt_text.2502: Men who, those who seemed to philosophise in the most excel­ lent manner, said that from the world and from its several parts, and from the powers which existed in those parts, we formed our notions of the Creator and cause of the world.
tgt_text.2503: For as, if a man were to see a house carefully built and well provided with outer courts and porticoes, and men's chambers and women's chambers, and all other necessary apartments, he would form a notion of the architect;
tgt_text.2504: for he would never suppose that the house had been completed without skill and without a builder;
tgt_text.2505: and, as he would argue in the same manner respecting any city, or any ship, or anything whatever that is made, whether it be great or small, so likewise any one entering this world, as an exceedingly large house or large city, and seeing the heaven revolving round it in a circle and comprehending everything within it, and all the planets and fixed stars moving onwards in the same manner and on the same principles, all in regular order and in due harmony and in such a manner as is most advantageous for the whole created universe, and the earth stationed in the central situation, and the effusions of air and water fixed on the boundaries, and, moreover, all the animals, both mortal and immortal, and the different kinds of plants and fruits, he will surely consider that undoubtedly all these things were not made without skill, but that God both was and is the creator of this whole universe.
tgt_text.2506: They, then, who draw their conclusions in this manner perceive God in his shadow, arriving at a due comprehension of the artist through his works.
tgt_text.2508: There is also a more perfect and more highly purified kind which has been initiated into the great mysteries, and which does not distinguish the cause from the things created as it would distinguish an abiding body from a shadow;
tgt_text.2509: but which, having emerged from all created objects, receives a clear and manifest notion of the great uncreated, so that it com­ prehends him through himself, and comprehends his shadow, too, so as to understand what it is, and his reason, too, and this universal world.
tgt_text.2510: This kind is that Moses, who speaks thus, " Show thyself to me;
tgt_text.2511: let me see thee so as to know thee,"* for do not thou be manifested to me through the medium of the heaven, or of the earth, or of water, or of air, or, in short, of anything whatever of created things, and let me not see thy appearance in any other thing, as in a looking-glass, except in thee thyself, the true God.
tgt_text.2512: For the images which are presented to the sight in executed things are subject to dis­ solution ;
tgt_text.2513: but those which are presented in the One uncreate may last for ever, being durable, eternal, and unchangeable.
tgt_text.2515: God called Moses to him and conversed with him,"t and he also called Bezaleel to him, though not in the same way as he had called Moses, but lie called the one so that he might receive an idea of the appearance of God from the Creator himself, but the other so that he might by cal­ culation form an idea of the Creator as if from the shadow of the things created.
tgt_text.2516: On this account you will find the taber­ nacle and all its furniture to have been made in the first instance by Moses, and again subsequently by Bezaleel.
tgt_text.2517: For Moses fashioned the archetypal forms, and Bezaleel made the imitations of them.
tgt_text.2518: For Moses had God himself for an in­ structor, as he tells us, when he represents God as saying to him, "Thou shall make every thing according to the example which was shown thee in the Mount.”‡
tgt_text.2519: And Bezaleel had Moses for his instructor;
tgt_text.2521: For Aaron the word, and Miriam the outward sense, when they rose up against Moses were expressly told that "If there shall arise a prophet to the Lord, God shall be made known to him in a vision, and in a shadow, but not clearly.
tgt_text.2522: § But with Moses, who is faithful in all his house, God will speak mouth to mouth in his own form, and not by riddles.
tgt_text.2524: Since therefore we find that there are two natures which have been created and fashioned and accurately and skilfully framed by God;
tgt_text.2525: the one being in its own intrinsic nature pernicious and open to reproach, and accursed, and the the other beneficial and praiseworthy, the one too having a spurious stamp upon it, but the other having undergone a strict test;
tgt_text.2526: we will utter a beautiful and suitable prayer which Moses also addressed to God, praying that God may open his treasurehouse, and may lay before us his sublime word pregnant with divine lights, which he calls the heaven, and may bind fast the storehouses of evil.
tgt_text.2527: For, just as there are storehouses of good things so are there also storehouses of evil things with God;
tgt_text.2528: as he says in his great song, " Behold are not these things collected with me, and sealed up in my treasurehouses, against the day of vengeance when their foot shall be tripped up ?
tgt_text.2529: You see then that there are several storehouses of evil things, and only one of good things.
tgt_text.2530: For since God is One, so also is his storehouse of good things one likewise.
tgt_text.2531: But there are many storehouses of evil things because the wicked are in­ finite in number.
tgt_text.2532: And in this observe the goodness of the true God, He opens the treasurehouse of his good things freely, but he binds fast that which contains the evil things.
tgt_text.2533: For it is an especial property of God to offer his good things freely and to be beforehand with men in bestowing gifts upon them.
tgt_text.2534: but to be slow in bringing evil on them, and Moses dwelling at length upon the munificent and gracious nature of God, says that not only have his storehouses of evil things been sealed up in all other times, but also when the soul is tripped up in the path of right reason, when it is especially fair that it should be considered worthy of punishment;
tgt_text.2535: for he says that, “ In the day of vengeance the storehouses of evil things have been sealed up," the sacred word of scripture showing that God does not visit with his vengeance even those who sin against him, immediately, but that he gives them time for repentance, and to remedy and correct their evil conduct.
tgt_text.2537: And the Lord God said to the serpent, "Thou art cursed over every creature and over all the beasts of the field."
tgt_text.2538: As joy being a good state of the passions is worthy to be prayed for;
tgt_text.2539: so also pleasure is worthy to be cursed being a passion, which has altered the boundaries of the soul, and has rendered it a lover of the passions instead of a lover of virtue.
tgt_text.2540: And Moses says in his curses, that "
tgt_text.2541: He is cursed who re­ moves his neighbour's land mark,''* for God placed virtue, that is to say, the tree of life, to be a land mark, and a law unto the soul.
tgt_text.2542: But pleasure has removed this, placing in its stead the land mark of vice, the tree of death, " Cursed indeed is he who causeth the blind man to wander in the road."
tgt_text.2543: This also is done by that most impious tiling pleasure, for the outward sense, inasmuch as it is destitute of reason, is a thing blinded by nature, since the eyes of its reason are put out.
tgt_text.2544: In reference to which we may say that it is by reason alone that we attain to a comprehension of things, and no longer by the outward sense;
tgt_text.2545: for they are bodies alone that we acquire a conception of by means of the outward senses.
tgt_text.2546: Pleasure therefore has deceived the outward sense which is destitute of any proper comprehension of things, inasmuch as though it might have been turned to the mind, and have been guided by it, it has hindered it from being so, leading it to the external objects of outward sense, and making it desirous of every thing which can call it into operation, in order that the outward sense being defective may follow a blind guide.
tgt_text.2547: namely the object of the outward sense, and then the mind being guided by the two things, which are themselves both blind, may plunge headlong to destruction and become utterly unable to restrain itself.
tgt_text.2548: For if it were to follow its natural guide then it would be proper for defective things to follow reason which sees clearly, for in that way mischievous things would be less formidable in their attacks.
tgt_text.2549: But now, pleasure has put such great artifices in operation to injure the soul, that it has compelled it to use them as guides, cheating it, and persuading it to exchange virtue for evil habits, and to give good habits in exchange for vice.
tgt_text.2551: But the holy scripture has prohibited such an exchange as this when it says, "Thou shalt not exchange good for evil”†
tgt_text.2552: On this account therefore pleasure is accursed, and let us now see how well adapted to it are the curses which the scripture denounces against it, "Thou shalt be cursed" says God, " above all creatures."
tgt_text.2553: Therefore, the whole race of animals is irrational and under the guidance only of the external senses;
tgt_text.2554: but every one of the outward senses curses pleasure as a most inimical and hostile thing to it;
tgt_text.2555: for it is in reality hostile to the outward senses.
tgt_text.2556: And the proof of this is that, when we are sated with an immoderate indulgence in pleasure, we are not able either to see, or to hear, or to smell, or to taste, or to touch with any clearness of our faculties, but we make all our essays and approaches in an obscure and imbecile manner.
tgt_text.2557: And this happens to us when we are for a moment at a distance from its infection ;
tgt_text.2558: but at the exact moment of the enjoyment of pleasure we are com­ pletely deprived of all such perception as can arise from the operation of the outward senses, so that we seem to be mutilated.
tgt_text.2559: How then can it be anything but natural for the outward sense to denounce curses upon pleasure which thus deprives it of its faculties.?XXXVII. "
tgt_text.2560: And he is accursed beyond all the beasts of the field."
tgt_text.2561: And I mean by this, beyond all the passions of the soul, for it is only there that the mind is wounded and destroyed.
tgt_text.2562: Why then does this one appear to be worse than all the other passions ?
tgt_text.2563: Because it is almost at the bottom of them all, as a sort of base or foundation for them, for desire originates in the love of pleasure, and pain consists in the removal of pleasure ;
tgt_text.2564: and fear again is caused by a desire to guard against its absence.
tgt_text.2565: So it is plain that all the passions are anchored on pleasure ;
tgt_text.2566: and perhaps one might say that they would absolutely have had no existence at all if pleasure had not been previously laid down as a foundation to support them.
tgt_text.2568: Upon thy breast and upon thy belly shalt thou go.”*
tgt_text.2569: For passion works around these parts, the breast and the belly, like a serpent in his hole ;
tgt_text.2570: when pleasure has its efficient causes and its subject-matter, then it is in operation around the belly and the parts adjacent to the belly;
tgt_text.2571: and when it has not these efficient causes and this subject-matter, then it is occupied about the breast which is the seat of anger, for lovers of pleasure when deprived of their pleasures become embittered by their anger.
tgt_text.2572: But let us see what is shown by this sentence with greater accuracy.
tgt_text.2573: It so happens that our soul is divisible into three parts, and that one of its parts is the seat of reason, the second, the seat of courage, the third, the seat of the appetites.
tgt_text.2574: Some therefore of the philosophers have separated these parts from one another only in respect of their operations, and some have distinguished them also by their places.
tgt_text.2575: And then they have assigned the parts about the head to the residing part, saying where the king is, there also are his guards, and the guards of the mind are the external senses, which are seated about the head, so that the king may very naturally have his abode there too, as if he had been assigned the highest part of the city to dwell in.
tgt_text.2576: The chest is assigned to the courageous part, and they say, it is on this account, that nature has fortified that part with a dense and strong defence of closely conjoined bones, as though she had been arming a valiant soldier with a breastplate and shield to defend himself against his enemies.
tgt_text.2577: To the appetitive part they have assigned a situation about, the liver and the belly, for there it is that appetite dwells, being an irrational desire.
tgt_text.2579: If therefore you shall ever inquire, 0 my mind, what situation has been assigned to pleasure, do not take into your consideration the parts about the head, where the reasoning faculties of man have their abode, for you will not find it there;
tgt_text.2580: since reason is at war with passion, and cannot possibly remain in the same place with it.
tgt_text.2581: For the moment that reason gets the upper hand pleasure is discarded ;
tgt_text.2582: but as soon as ever pleasure prevails, reason is put to flight.
tgt_text.2583: But seek first rather in the breast and in the belly, where courage and anger, and appetite abide, all which are parts of the irrational faculties.
tgt_text.2584: For it is there that our judgment is discovered, and also our passions.
tgt_text.2585: Therefore, the mind is not hindered by any external force from abandoning the legitimate objects of its attention, which can only be perceived by the intellect, and surrendering itself to those which are worse;
tgt_text.2586: but still this never happens except when there is a war in the soul, for then indeed it follows of necessity that reason must fall under the power of the inferior part of man, inasmuch as it is not of a warlike character, but is fond of peace.
tgt_text.2588: At all events the holy scripture being well aware how great is the power of the impetuosity of each passion, anger and appetite, puts a bridle in the mouth of each, having appointed reason as their charioteer and pilot
tgt_text.2589: And first of all it speaks thus of anger, in the hope of pacifying and curing it;
tgt_text.2590: "And you shall put manifestation and truth (the Urim and the Thummim), in the oracle of judgment, and it shall be on the breast of Aaron when he comes into the holy place before the Lord." *
tgt_text.2591: Now by the oracle is here meant the organs of speech which exist in us, which is in fact the power of language.
tgt_text.2592: Now language is either inconsiderate, and such as will not stand examination, or else it is judicious and well approved, and it brings us to form a notion of discreet speech.
tgt_text.2593: For Moses here speaks not of a random spurious oracle, but of the oracle of the judgment, which is equivalent to saying, a well-judged and carefully examined oracle;
tgt_text.2594: and of this well approved kind of language he says that there are two supreme virtues, namely, distinctness and truth, and he says well.
tgt_text.2595: For it is language which has in the first place enabled one man to make affairs plain and evident to his neighbour, when without it we should not be able to give any intimation of the impression produced on our soul by outward circumstances, nor to show of what kind they are.XLI
tgt_text.2596: On which account we have been compelled to have recourse to such signs as are given by the voices, that is nouns and verbs, which ought by all means to be universally known, in order that our neighbours might clearly and evidently com­ prebend our meaning;
tgt_text.2597: and, in the next place, to utter them at all times with truth.
tgt_text.2598: For of what advantage would it be to make our assertions clear and distinct, but nevertheless false ?
tgt_text.2599: For it follows inevitably that if this were allowed the hearer would be deceived, and would reap the greatest possible in­ jury with ignorance and delusion.
tgt_text.2600: For what would be the advantage of my speaking to a boy distinctly and clearly, and telling him, when I show him the letter A, that it is G, or that the letter E is 0 ?
tgt_text.2601: Or what would be the good of a musician pointing out to a pupil who comes to him to learn the rudiments of his art that the harmonic scale was the chromatic;
tgt_text.2603: or that the highest string was the middle one ;
tgt_text.2604: or that conjoined sounds were separated ;
tgt_text.2605: or that the highest tone in the tetrachord scale was a supernumerary note ?
tgt_text.2606: No doubt, a man who said this might speak clearly and distinctly, but he would not be speaking truly, but by such assertions he would be emplanting wickedness in language.
tgt_text.2607: But when he joins both distinctness and truth, then he makes his language profitable to him who is seeking information, employing both its virtues, which in fact are nearly the only ones of which language is capable.
tgt_text.2609: Moses, therefore, says that discreet discourse, having its own peculiar virtues, is placed on the breast of Aaron, that is to say, of anger, in order that it may in the first instance be guided by reason, and may not be injured by its own defi­ ciency in reason, and, in the second place, by distinctness, for there is no natural influence which makes anger a friend to distinctness.
tgt_text.2610: At all events, not only are the ideas of angry men, but all their expressions also, full of disorder and confu­ sion, and therefore it is very natural for the want of clearness on the part of anger to be rectified by clearness, and, in addition, by truth;
tgt_text.2611: for, among other things, anger has also this particular property of being inclined to misrepresent the truth.
tgt_text.2612: At all events, of all those who give way to this disposition scarcely any one speaks the strict truth, as if it were his soul and not his body that is under the influence of its intoxication.
tgt_text.2613: These, then, are the chief remedies suitable for that part of the soul which is influenced by anger, namely, reason, disinterestedness of language, and truth of language, for the three things are in power only one, namely, reason, curing anger, which is a per­ nicious disease of the soul, by means of the virtues truth and perspicuity.
tgt_text.2615: To whom, or to what, then, does it belong to bear these things?
tgt_text.2616: Not to my mind, or to that of any chance person, but to the consecrated and purely sacrificial intellect, that, namely, of Aaron.
tgt_text.2617: And not even to this at all times, for it is frequently subject to change, but only when it is going on unchangeably, when it is entering into the holy place, when reason is entering in together with holy opinions, and is not abandoning them.
tgt_text.2618: But it often happens that the mind is at the same time entering into sacred and holy and purified opinions, but still such as are only human ;
tgt_text.2619: such, for instance, as opinions on what is expedient;
tgt_text.2621: opinions on what is in accordance with established law;
tgt_text.2622: opinions concerning virtue as it exists among men.
tgt_text.2623: Nor is the mind, when disposed in this way, competent to bear the oracle on its breast together with the virtues, but only that one which is going in before the Lord, that is to say, that one which doeth everything for the sake of God, and which estimates no­ thing as superior to the things of God;
tgt_text.2624: but attributes to them also their due rank, not indeed dwelling on them, but ascend­ ing upwards to the knowledge and understanding of an appre­ ciation of the honour due to the one God.
tgt_text.2625: For, in a mind which is thus disposed, anger will be directed by purified reason, which takes away its irrational part, and remedies what there is confused and disorderly in it by the application of dis­ tinctness, and eradicates its falsehood by truth.
tgt_text.2627: Aaron, therefore, for he is a second Moses, restrain­ ing the breast, that is to say, the angry passions, does not allow them to be carried away by undistinguishing impulse, fearing lest, if they obtain complete liberty, they may become restiff, like a horse, and so trample down the whole soul.
tgt_text.2628: But he attends to and cures it, and bridles it in the first instance by reason, that so, being under the guidance of the best of charioteers, it may not become exceedingly unmanageable, and in the second place, by the virtues of language, distinct­ ness, and truth.
tgt_text.2629: For, if the angry passions were educated in such a way as to yield to reason and distinctness, and to culti­ vate the virtue of truthfulness, they would deliver themselves from great irritation and make the whole soul propitious.
tgt_text.2631: But he, as I have already said, having this passion, endeavours to cure it by the saving remedies already enumerated.
tgt_text.2632: But Moses thinks that it is necessary completely to extirpate and eradicate anger from the soul, being desirous to attain not to a state of moderation in the indulgence of the passions, but to a state in which they shall have absolutely no existence whatever, and the most Holy Scriptures bear witness to what I am here saying;
tgt_text.2633: for it says, " Moses having taken the breast took it that it might be an offering before the Lord, from the ram of consecration, and this was Moses's part."*
tgt_text.2634: Speaking very accurately, for it was the conduct of one who was both a lover of virtue and a lover of God, after having contemplated the whole soul, to take hold of the breast, which is the seat of the angry passions, and to take it away and eradicate it, that so when the warlike part had been wholly removed, the remainder might enjoy peace.
tgt_text.2635: And he removes this part not from any chance animal, but from the ram of consecration, although, indeed, a young heifer had been sacrificed;
tgt_text.2636: but, passing by the heifer, he came to the ram, because that is by nature an animal inclined to pushing and full of anger' and impetuosity, in reference to which fact the makers of military engines call many of their warlike machines rams.
tgt_text.2637: This ramlike and impetuous and undistinguishing character in us, therefore, is something fond of contention, and, contention is the mother of anger.
tgt_text.2638: In reference to which fact, they who are somewhat quarrelsome are very easily made angry in investigations and other discussions.
tgt_text.2639: Moses, therefore, does very properly endeavour to eradicate anger, that pernicious offspring of a contentious and quarrelsome soul, in order that the soul may become barren of such offspring and may cease from bringing forth mischievous things, and may become a portion consistent with the character of a lover of virtue, not being identical with either the breast or with anger, but with the absence of those qualities, for God has endowed the wise man with the best of all qualities, the power, namely, of eradicating his passions.
tgt_text.2640: You see, then, how the perfect man is always endeavouring to attain to a complete emancipation.
tgt_text.2641: from the power of the passions.
tgt_text.2642: But he who eradicates them being next to him, that is Aaron, labours to arrive at a state in which the passions have only a moderate power, as I have said before;
tgt_text.2643: for he is unable to eradicate the breast and the angry passions.
tgt_text.2644: But he bears the oracle, on which is distinctness and truth even beyond the guide himself, together with the appropriate and kindred virtues of language.
tgt_text.2646: And he will, moreover, make the difference more evident to us by the following expression :
tgt_text.2648: For the wave­ breast and the heave-shoulder have I taken of the children of Israel from off the sacrifices of their peace offerings, and have given them to Aaron the priest, and unto his sons, for ever.""'
tgt_text.2649: You see here that they are not able to take the breast alone, but they must take it with the shoulder;
tgt_text.2650: but Moses can take it without the shoulder.
tgt_text.2652: Because he, being per­ fect, has no inadequate or lowly ideas, nor is he willing to remain in a state in which the passions have even a moderate influence ;
tgt_text.2653: but he, by his exceeding power, does utterly extirpate the whole of the passions, root and branch.
tgt_text.2654: But the others, who go with faint endeavours and with but slight strength to war against the passions, are inclined to a reconciliation with them, and make terms with them, proposing terms of accommodotion, thinking that thus, like a charioteer, they may be able to bridle their extravagant impetuosity.
tgt_text.2655: And the shoulder is a symbol of labour and of the endurance of hardship ;
tgt_text.2656: and such a person is he who has the charge of and the care of administering the holy things, being occupied with constant exercise and labour.
tgt_text.2657: But he has no labour to whom God has given his perfect good things in great abundance, and he who attains to virtue by labour will be found to be less vigorous and less perfect than Moses, who received it as a gift from God without any labour or difficulty.
tgt_text.2658: For the mere fact of labouring is of itself inferior to and worse than the condition of being exempt from labour, so, also, what is imperfect is inferior to that which is perfect, and that which learns anything to that which has knowledge spontaneously and naturally.
tgt_text.2659: On this account it is that Aaron can only take the breast with the shoulder, but Moses can take it without the shoulder.
tgt_text.2660: And he calls it the heave-shoulder for this reason, because reason ought to be set over and to be predominant above the violence of anger, as a charioteer who is driving a hard-mouthed and restiff horse.
tgt_text.2661: And then the shoulder is no longer called the heave-shoulder, but the shoulder of removal, on this account, because it is fitting that the soul should not attribute to itself labour in the cause of virtue, but should remove it from itself and attribute it to God, confessing that it is not its own strength or its own power which has thus acquired what is good, but He who gave it a love for goodness.
tgt_text.2662: And so neither the breast nor the shoulder is taken, except from the virtue which bringeth salvation, as is natural, for then the soul is sacred when the angry passions are under the guidance of reason, and when labour does not bring conceit to the labourer, but when he owns his inferiority to God, his benefactor.
tgt_text.2664: Now that pleasure dwells not only in the breast but also in the belly, we have already stated, showing that the belly is the most appropriate situation for pleasure;
tgt_text.2665: for we may almost call pleasure the vessel which contains all the pleasures ;
tgt_text.2666: for when the belly is filled, then the desires for all other pleasures are intense and vigorous, but when it is empty, then they are tranquil and steady.
tgt_text.2667: On which account Moses says, in another place, " Every animal that goeth upon its belly, every animal which goeth on four legs at all times, and that has a multitude of feet, is unclean."*
tgt_text.2668: And such a creature is the lover of pleasure, inasmuch as he is always going upon his belly and pursuing the pleasures which relate to it.
tgt_text.2669: And God unites the animal which goes on four legs with him that crawls upon his belly, naturally ;
tgt_text.2670: for the passions of those who are absorbed in pleasure are four, as one most egregious account teaches.
tgt_text.2671: Therefore he who devotes himself as a slave to one of them, namely, to pleasure, is impure as much as he who lives in the indulgence of the whole four.
tgt_text.2672: This much having been premised, behold again the difference between the perfect man and him who is still advancing towards perfection.
tgt_text.2673: As, therefore, the perfect man was, just now, found to be competent to eradicate the whole of the angry feelings from the contentious soul and to make it submissive and man­ ageable, and peaceable and gentle to every one, both in word and deed ;
tgt_text.2674: and as he who is still advancing towards perfection is not able wholly to eradicate passion, for he bears the breast about with him, though he does educate it by the aid of judi­ cious language, which is invested with two virtues perspicuity and truth.
tgt_text.2676: So, also, now he who is perfectly wise, that is, Moses, will be found to have utterly shaken off and discarded the pleasures.
tgt_text.2677: But he who is only advancing towards perfec­ tion will be found to have escaped not from every pleasure, but to cling still to such as are desirable and simple, and to depre­ cate those which are superfluous and extravagant as unnecessary additions, for, in the case of Moses, God speaks thus :
tgt_text.2678: "And he washed his belly and his feet, with the blood of the entire burnt offering."†
tgt_text.2679: Speaking very truly, for the wise man consecrates his entire soul as what is worthy to be offered to God, because it is free from all reproach, whether wilfully or unintentionally incorrect, and being thus disposed, he washes his whole belly and all the pleasures which it knows, and all which pursue it, and cleanses them and purifies them from all nncleanliness, not being content with any partial cleansing.
tgt_text.2680: But he is disposed to regard pleasure so contemptuously that he has no desire for even the necessary meat or drink, but nourishes himself wholly on the contemplation of divine things.
tgt_text.2681: On which account in another passage, he bears witness to himself, " For forty-eight years he did not eat bread, and he did not drink water,"* because he was in the holy mount listening to the oracular voice of God, who was giving him the law.
tgt_text.2682: But not only does he repudiate the whole belly, but he also at the same time washes off all the dirt from his feet, that is to say, to the supports in which pleasure proceeds.
tgt_text.2683: And the sup­ ports of pleasure are the efficient causes of it.
tgt_text.2684: For he who is advancing onwards to perfection is said " to wash his bowels and his feet,"t and not his whole belly.
tgt_text.2685: For he is not capable of rejecting the whole of pleasure, but he is content if he can purify his bowels, that is to say, his inmost parts from it, which the lovers of pleasure say are certain additions to preceding pleasures, and which originate in the superfluous ingenuity of cooks and makers of delicacies and laborious gourmands.
tgt_text.2687: And he also displays, in a further degree, the mo­ deration of the passions of the man who is advancing towards perfection, by the fact that the perfect mail discards all the pleasures of the belly without being prompted by any command to do so, but that he who is only advancing onwards towards perfection only does so in consequence of being commanded.
tgt_text.2688: For, in the case of the wise man, we find the following expres­ sion used :
tgt_text.2690: He washes his belly and his feet with water,"‡ without any command, in accordance with his own unbidden inclination.
tgt_text.2691: But, in the case of the priests, he spoke thus:
tgt_text.2692: " But their bowels and their feet," not they have washed, but " they do wash ;
tgt_text.2693: "§ speaking with very cautious exactness, for the perfect man must be moved in his own inclination towards the energies in accordance with virtue.
tgt_text.2694: But he who is only practising virtue must be instigated by reason, which points out to him what he ought to do, and it is an honourable thing to obey the injunctions of reason.
tgt_text.2695: But we ought not to be ignorant that Moses repudiates the whole of the belly, that is to say, the filling and indulging the belly, and almost renounces all the other passions likewise ;
tgt_text.2696: the lawgiver giving a lively representation of the whole from one part, starting from a universal example, and discussing, poten­ tially at least, the other points as to which he was silent.
tgt_text.2698: The filling of the belly is a most enduring and universal thing;
tgt_text.2699: and, as it were, a kind of foundation of the other passions.
tgt_text.2700: At all events, there is not one of them which can find any existence if it is not supported by the belly, on which nature has made everything to depend.
tgt_text.2701: On this account, when the goods of the soul had previously been born of Leah, and had ended in Judah,* that is to say, in confession, God being about to create also the improvements of the body, prepared Bilhah, the hand-maid of Rachel, to bear children on behalf of and before her mistress.
tgt_text.2702: And the name Bilhah, being inter­ preted, means deglutition.
tgt_text.2703: For he knew that not one of the corporeal faculties can exist without imbibing moisture and without the belly;
tgt_text.2704: but the belly is predominant over and the ruler of the whole body, and the preserver of this corporeal mass in a state of existence.
tgt_text.2705: And observe the subtle way in which all this is expressed;
tgt_text.2706: for you will not find a single word used superfluously.
tgt_text.2707: Moses indeed " takes away the breast," but as for the belly he does not take that away, but he washes it.t
tgt_text.2709: Because the perfectly wise man is able to repudiate and to eradicate all the angry passions, making them rise up and abandon anger ;
tgt_text.2710: but he is unable to cut out and discard the belly, for nature is compelled to use the necessary meats and drinks, even if a man, being content with the scantiest possible supply of ne­ cessaries should despise it, and purpose to himself to abjure eating.
tgt_text.2711: Let him therefore wash and purify it from all super­ fluous and unclean preparations;
tgt_text.2712: for to be able to do even this is a very sufficient gift from God to the lover of virtue.
tgt_text.2714: On this account Moses says, with respect to the soul which is suspected of having committed adultery,‡ that, if having abandoned right reason, which is man living according to the law, it shall be found to have gone over to passion, which pollutes the soul, " it shall become swollen in the belly," which means it shall have all the pleasures and appe­ tites of the belly unsatisfied and insatiable, and it shall never cease to be greedy through ignorance, but pleasures in bound­ less number shall flow into it, and thus its passions shall be interminable.
tgt_text.2715: Now I know many people who have fallen into error in respect of the appetites of the belly, that while still devoting themselves to their gratifications, they have again rushed with eagerness to wine and other luxuries;
tgt_text.2717: petites of the intemperate soul bear no analogy to the mass of the body.
tgt_text.2718: But some men, like vessels made to hold a certain measure, desire nothing extravagant, but discard everything that is superfluous;
tgt_text.2719: but appetite on the other hand is never satisfied, but remains always in want and thirsty.
tgt_text.2720: In refer­ ence to which the expression, that " the thigh shall fall away," is added in immediate connexion with the denunciation that " her belly shall swell;
tgt_text.2721: " for then right reason, which has the seeds and originating principles of good, falls from the soul."
tgt_text.2722: If therefore," says Moses, " she has not been corrupted, then she shall be pure;
tgt_text.2723: and free from all infliction from ge­ neration to generation;
tgt_text.2724: " that is to say, if she has not been polluted by passion, but has kept herself pure in respect of her legitimate husband, sound reason, her proper guide, she shall have a productive and fertile soul, bearing the offspring of prudence and justice and all virtue.
tgt_text.2726: Is it then possible for us, who are bound up in our bodies, to avoid complying with the necessities of the body ?
tgt_text.2727: And if it is possible, how is it possible ?
tgt_text.2728: But consider, the priest recommends him who is led away by his bodily neces­ sities to indulge in nothing beyond what is strictly necessary.
tgt_text.2729: In the first place, says he, " Let there be a place for thee outside of'the camp meaning by the camp virtue, in which the soul is encamped and fortified;
tgt_text.2730: for prudence and a free indulgence in the necessities of the body cannot abide in the same place.
tgt_text.2731: After that he says, " And you shall go out there."
tgt_text.2733: Because the soul, which is abiding in coin­ panionship with prudence and dwelling in the house of wis­ dom, cannot indulge in any of the delights of the body, for it is at that time nourished on a diviner food in the sciences, in consequence of which it neglects the flesh, for when it has gone forth beyond the sacred thresholds of virtue, then it turns to the material substances, which disarrange and op­ press the soul.
tgt_text.2734: How then am I to deal with them?
tgt_text.2735: "It shall be a peg," says Moses, " upon thy girdle, and thou shalt dig with it that is to say, reason shall be close to you in the case of the passion, which digs out and equips and clothes it properly;
tgt_text.2736: for he desires that we should be girded up in respect of the passions, and not to have them about us in a loose and dissolute state.
tgt_text.2737: On which account, at the time of the passage through them, which is called the passover, he enjoins us all " to have our loins girded,"* that is to say, to have our appetites under restraint.
tgt_text.2738: Let the peg, therefore, that is to say reason, follow the passion, preventing it from becoming dissolute;
tgt_text.2739: for in this way we shall be able to con­ tent ourselves with only so much as is necessary, and to abstain from what is superfluous.
tgt_text.2741: And in this way when we are at entertainments, and when we are about to come to the enjoyment and use of luxuries that have been prepared for us, let us approach them taking reason with us as a defensive armour, and let us not fill ourselves with food beyond all moderation like cormorants, nor let us satiate ourselves with immoderate draughts of strong wine, and so give way to intoxication which compels men to act like fools.
tgt_text.2742: For reason will bridle and curb the violence and impetuosity of such a passion.
tgt_text.2743: I myself, at all events, know that it has done so with regard to many of the passions, for when I have gone to entertainments where no respect was paid to discipline, and to sumptuous banquets, whenever I went without taking Reason with me as a guide, I became a slave to the luxuries that lay before me, being under the guid­ ance of masters who could not be tamed, with sights and sounds of temptation, and all other such things also as work pleasure in a man by the agency of his senses of smell and taste.
tgt_text.2744: But when I approach such scenes in the company of reason, I then become a master instead of a slave:
tgt_text.2745: and with­ out being subdued myself win a glorious victory of self-denial and temperance;
tgt_text.2746: opposing and contending against all the appetites which subdue the intemperate.
tgt_text.2748: Thou shalt be armed," Moses therefore says, "with the peg."†
tgt_text.2749: That is to say, you, by the aid of reason, shall lay bare the nature which each of the separate passions has, eating, and drinking, and indulging in the pleasures of the belly, and you shall distinguish between them, that when you have so distinguished you may know the truth.
tgt_text.2750: For then you shall know that there is no good in any of these things, but only what is necessary and useful. "
tgt_text.2751: And bringing it over, you shall cover what is inde­ corous,"‡ speaking very appropriately.
tgt_text.2752: For come to me, 0 my soul, bring reason to everything by which all unseemliness of flesh and of passion is concealed, and overshadowed and hidden.
tgt_text.2753: For all the things which are not in combination with reason are [disgraceful, just as those which are done in union with reason are seemly.
tgt_text.2754: Therefore the man who is devoted to pleasure goes on his belly, but the perfect man washes his whole belly, and he who is only advancing towards perfection washes the things in his belly.
tgt_text.2755: But he who is now beginning to be instructed proceeds out of doors when he is intent upon curbing the passions of the belly by bringing reason to work upon the necessities of the belly, and reason is called symboli­ cally a peg.
tgt_text.2757: Moses therefore does well when he adds, " Thou shalt go upon thy breast and upon thy belly."*
tgt_text.2758: For pleasure is not one of the things which is tranquil and steady, but is rather a thing which is in constant motion and full of confusion, for as flame is excited by being moved, so passion when it is put in motion in the soul, being in some respects like a flame, does not suffer it to rest.
tgt_text.2759: On which account he does not agree with those who pronounce pleasure a stable feeling, for tranquillity is connected with stones and trees, and all kinds of inanimate things, but is quite inconsistent with pleasure;
tgt_text.2760: for it is fond of tickling and convulsive agitation, and with regard to some of its indulgences it has not need of tranquillity but of an intense and violent unseemliness of commotion.
tgt_text.2763: And dust shalt thou eat'all the days of thy life," is also used with great propriety.
tgt_text.2764: For the pleasures which are derived from the food of the body are all earthly.
tgt_text.2765: And may we not reasonably speak thus?
tgt_text.2766: There are two several parts of which we consist, the soul and the body;
tgt_text.2767: now the body is made of earth, but the soul consists of air, being a fragment of the Divinity, for " God breathed into man's face the breath of life, and man became a living soul."†
tgt_text.2768: It is therefore quite consistent with reason to say that the body which was fashioned out of the earth has nourish.
tgt_text.2769: ment which the earth gives forth akin to the matter of which it is composed;
tgt_text.2770: but the soul, inasmuch as it is a portion of the ethereal nature, is supported by nourishment which is ethereal and divine, for it it is nourished on knowledge, and not on meat or drink, which the body requires.
tgt_text.2772: But that the food of the soul is not earthly but hea­ venly the Holy Scriptures will testify in many passages, " Behold I will rain upon you bread from heaven, and the people shall come forth, and shall collect from day to day, when I will try them, whether they will walk according to ray law or not."*
tgt_text.2773: You see that the soul is nourished not on earthly and corruptible food, but on the reasons which God rains down out of his sublime and pure nature, which he calls heaven.
tgt_text.2774: "Let the people indeed go forth and the whole system of the soul likewise, and let it collect science and begin knowledge, not in large quantities but from day to day."
tgt_text.2775: For, in the first place, in that way it will not exhaust all at once the abundant riches of the grace of God:
tgt_text.2776: but it will over­ flow like a torrent with their superfluity.
tgt_text.2777: Secondly, it will happen that when they have taken such good things as are sufficient for them and duly measured, they will think God the dispenser of the rest.
tgt_text.2778: But he who endeavours to collect everything at once is only acquiring for himself despair with great sorrow,!
tgt_text.2779: for he becomes full of despair if he expects that God will only rain good things upon him at the present moment, and that he will not do so hereafter.
tgt_text.2780: And he becomes inclined to infidelity if he does not believe that the graces of God will be both at present and in all time abund­ antly poured upon those who are worthy of them.
tgt_text.2781: And he is foolish, moreover, if he thinks that he shall be a competent • guardian of what he has collected contrary to God's will.
tgt_text.2782: For a very slight inclination is sufficient to make the mind, which in its boastfulness attributes safety and stability to itself, an impotent and unsure keeper of those things of which it fancied itself a safe guardian.
