tgt_text.2784: Collect therefore, 0 my soul, what is sufficient and proper, and in such a quantity as shall neither exceed by being more than is sufficient, nor fall short by being less than what is requisite:
tgt_text.2785: that so, using just measures you may not be led into the commission of injustice.
tgt_text.2786: For while meditating on the migration from the passions and sacrificing the passover you ought to take the advance towards perfection, that is to say the sheep, in a moderate spirit. "
tgt_text.2787: For each person of you," says Moses, " shall take a sheep, such as shall be sufficient for him according to the number of his house.
tgt_text.2788: '*And in the case of the manna therefore, and of every gift which God gives to the race of mankind, the principle being guided by numbering and by measure, and of not taking what is more than is necessary for us, is good ;
tgt_text.2789: for the opposite conduct is covetousness.
tgt_text.2790: Let therefore one soul collect what is sufficient for it from day to day,* that it may show that it is not itself which is the guardian of good things, but the bounteous giver, God.
tgt_text.2792: And this appears to me to be the reason why the sentence which I have ci ted above was uttered.
tgt_text.2793: Day is an emblem of light, and the light of the soul is instruction.
tgt_text.2794: Many persons therefore have provided for themselves the lights that can exist in the soul against night and darkness, but not against day-time and light;
tgt_text.2795: such lights for instance, as are derived from rudimental instruction, and those branches of education which are called encyclical, and philosophy itself, which is sought after for the sake both of the pleasure which is derived from it, and also of the influence which it gives among rulers.
tgt_text.2796: But the good man seeks the day for the sake of the day, and the light for the light's sake;
tgt_text.2797: and he labours to acquire what is good for the sake of the good itself, and not of anything else, on which account Moses adds, "In order that I may tempt them and see whether they will walk according to my law or not," † for the divine law enjoins us to honour virtue for its own sake.
tgt_text.2798: Accordingly, right reason tests those who practise virtue as one might test a coin, to see whether they have contracted any stain, referring the good things of the soul to any of the external things;
tgt_text.2799: or whether they decide upon it as good money, preserving it in the intellect alone.
tgt_text.2800: These men are nourished not on earthly things, but on heavenly knowledge.
tgt_text.2802: And Moses shows this in other passages also, when he says, " And in the morning the dew lay round about the hosts;
tgt_text.2803: and when the dew that lay in the morning was gone up, behold!
tgt_text.2804: upon the face of the wilderness there lay a small round thing, small as coriander seed,!
tgt_text.2805: and white like the hoar- frost upon the earth.
tgt_text.2806: And when they saw it, they said one to another, what is this ?
tgt_text.2807: for they knew not what it was, and Moses said to them, This is the bread which the Lord hath given you to eat, this is the thing which the Lord hath com­ manded you."
tgt_text.2808: *You see now what kind of thing the food of the Lord is, it is the continued word of the Lord, like dew, surrounding the whole soul in a circle, and allowing no portion of it to be without its share of itself.
tgt_text.2809: And this word is not apparent in every place, but wherever there is a vacant space, void of passions and vice;
tgt_text.2810: and it is subtle both to understand and to be understood, and it is exceedingly transparent and clear to be distinguished, and it is like coriander seed.
tgt_text.2811: And agricul­ turists say that the seed of the coriander is capable of being cut up and divided into innumerable pieces, and if sown in each separate piece and fragment, it shoots up just as much as the whole seed could do.
tgt_text.2812: Such also is the word of God, being profitable both in its entirety and also in every part, even if it be ever so small.
tgt_text.2813: May it not be also likened to the pupil of the eye ?
tgt_text.2814: For as that, being the smallest portion of the eye, does nevertheless behold the entire orbs of existing things and the boundless sea, and the vastness of the air, and the whole immeasurable space of heaven, which the sun, whether rising in the east or setting in the west, can bound;
tgt_text.2815: so also is the word of God, very sharp- sighted, so as to be capable of beholding every thing, and by which all things that are worth seeing can be beheld, in reference to which fact it is white.
tgt_text.2816: For what can be more brilliant or visible at a greater distance than the divine word, by participation in which all other things can repel mists and darkness, being eager to share in the light of the soul ?
tgt_text.2818: There is a certain peculiarity which is attached to this word.
tgt_text.2819: For when it calls the soul to itself, it excites a congealing power in everything which is earthly, or corporeal, or under the influence of the external senses.
tgt_text.2820: On which account it is said to be " like the hoar-frost on the earth." t
tgt_text.2821: For when the man who beholds God, meditates a flight from the passions, "the waves are frozen," that is to say, the im­ petuous rush, and the increase, and the haughty pride of the waves are arrested, in order that he who might behold the living God might then pass over the passion.
tgt_text.2823: Therefore the souls inquire of one another, those, that is, that have clearly felt the influence of the word, but which are not able to say what it is.
tgt_text.2824: For very often, when sensible of a sweet taste, we are nevertheless ignorant of the flavour which has caused it, and when we smell sweet scents, we still do not know what they are.
tgt_text.2825: And in the same manner also the soul very often, when it is delighted, is yet unable to explain what it is that has delighted it;
tgt_text.2826: but it is taught by the hierophant and prophet Moses, who tells it, "This is the bread, the food which God has given for the soul,"* explaining that God has brought it, his own word and his own reason;
tgt_text.2827: for this bread which he has given us to eat is this word of his.
tgt_text.2829: He says also in Deuteronomy, " And he has humbled thee, and suffered thee to hunger, and fed thee with manna, which thou knowest not, neither did thy fathers know, that he might make thee know that man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word which proceedeth out of the mouth of the Lord doth man live."t
tgt_text.2830: Now this ill-treating and humbling of them is a sign of his being propitiated by them, for he is propitiated as to the souls of us who are wicked on the tenth day.
tgt_text.2831: For when he strips us of all our pleasant things, we appear to ourselves to be ill-treated, that is in truth to have God propitious to us.
tgt_text.2832: And God also causes us hunger, not that which proceeds from virtue, but that which is engendered by passion and vice.
tgt_text.2833: And the proof of this is, that he nourishes us with his own word, which is the most universal of all things, for manna being interpreted, means "what?" and "what" is the most universal of all things;
tgt_text.2834: for the word of God is over all the world, and is the most ancient, and the most universal of all the things that are created.
tgt_text.2835: This word our fathers knew not;
tgt_text.2836: I speak not of those who are so in truth, but of those who are grey with age, who say, "Let us give them a guide, and let us turn back" ‡ unto passion, that is to say, to Egypt.
tgt_text.2837: Therefore, let God enjoin the soul, saying to it that, "Man shall not live by bread alone," speaking in a figure, " but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God," that is to say, he shall be nourished by the whole word of God, and by every portion of it.
tgt_text.2838: For the mouth is the symbol of the language, and a word is a portion of it.
tgt_text.2839: Accordingly the soul of the more perfect man is nourished by the whole word ;
tgt_text.2840: but we must be contented if we are nourished by a portion of it.
tgt_text.2842: But these men pray to be nourished by the word ot God:
tgt_text.2843: but Jacob, raising his head above the word, says that he is nourished by God himself, and his words are as follows:
tgt_text.2844: " The God in whom my father Abraham and Isaac were well­ pleased ;
tgt_text.2845: the God who has nourished me from my youth upwards to this day ;
tgt_text.2846: the angel who has delivered me from all my evils, bless these children."*
tgt_text.2847: This now being a symbol of a perfect disposition, thinks
tgt_text.2848: God himself his nourisher, and not the word :
tgt_text.2849: and he speaks of the angel, which is the word, as the physician of his evils, in this speaking most naturally.
tgt_text.2850: For the good things which lie has previously mentioned are pleasing to him, inasmuch as the living and true God has given them to him face to face, but the secondary good things have been given to him by the angels and by the word of God.
tgt_text.2851: On this account I think it is that God gives men pure good health, which is not preceded by any disease in the body, by himself alone, but that health which is an escape from disease he gives through the medium of skill and medical science, attributing it to science, and to him who can apply it skilfully, though in truth, it is God himself who heals both by these means, and without these means.
tgt_text.2852: And the same is the case with regard to the soul, the good things, namely food, he gives to men by his power alone ;
tgt_text.2853: but those which contain in them a deliverance from evil, he gives by means of his angels and his word.
tgt_text.2855: And he uttered this prayer, blaming Joseph the statesman and governor, because he had ventured to say, " I will feed them in that land,"t for, " hasten ye," said Joseph, " and go up to my father, and say unto him, Thus says Joseph," and so on, and presently he adds, " Come down unto me, and do not tarry, come with all thou hast, and I will feed thee in that land;
tgt_text.2856: for still the famine lasts for five years."
tgt_text.2857: Jacob, therefore, speaks as he does reproving and at the same time instructing this imaginary wise man, and he says to him, " 0 my friend, know thou that the food of the soul is knowledge, which it is not the word which is intelligible by the external j senses that can bestow, but God only who has nourished me from youth, and from my earliest age till the time of perfect manhood, he shall fill me with it.
tgt_text.2858: Joseph therefore was treated in the same way with his mother Rachel, for she also thought that the creature had some power;
tgt_text.2859: on which account she used the expression, " Give me children," but the supplanter, adhering to his proper character, says to her, " You have used a great error;
tgt_text.2860: for I am not in the peace of God, who alone is able to open the womb of the soul,* and to implant virtues in it, and to cause it to be pregnant, and to bring forth what is good.
tgt_text.2861: Consider also the history of thy sis­ ter Leah, and you will find that she did not receive seed or fertility from any creature-but from God himself.""
tgt_text.2862: For the Lord, seeing that Leah was hated, opened her womb, but Rachel was barren."t
tgt_text.2863: And consider, now, in this sentence, again, the subtlety of the writer spoken of.
tgt_text.2864: God opens the wombs, implanting good actions in them, and the womb, when it has received virtue from God, does not bring forth to God, for the living and true God is not in need of any thing, but she brings forth sons to me, Jacob, for it was for my sake, probably, that God sowed seed in virtue, and not for his own.
tgt_text.2865: Therefore, another husband of Leah is found to be passed over in silence, and another father of Leah's children, for he is the husband who openeth the womb, and he is the father of the children to whom the mother is said to bear them.
tgt_text.2867: "And I will place enmity between thee and between the woman."‡
tgt_text.2868: In reality, pleasure is hostile to the external sense, although, to some persons, it appears to be especially friendly to it.
tgt_text.2869: But as one would not call a flatterer a corn panion (for flattery is a disease of friendship), nor would one call a courtezan friendly to her lover, for she adheres only to those who give her presents, and not to those who love her;
tgt_text.2870: so, also, if you investigate the nature of pleasure, you will find that she has but a spurious connection with the external senses.
tgt_text.2871: When we are sated with pleasure, then we find that the organs of the external senses in us lose their tone.
tgt_text.2872: Or do not you perceive the state of those men who from love of wine get drunk ?-that seeing they do not see, and hearing they do not hear;
tgt_text.2873: and, in the same way, they are deprived of the accu­ rate energies of the other external senses ?
tgt_text.2874: And, at times, through immoderate indulgence in food, all the vigour of the external senses is relaxed when sleep overtakes them, which has derived its name from the relaxation of them.
tgt_text.2875: For, at that time, the organs of the external senses are relaxed, just as they are on the stretch in our waking hours, when they no longer receive unintelligible blows from external things, but such as speak loudly and are evident, and which transmit their impressions to the mind.
tgt_text.2876: For the mind, when stricken, must recognize the external thing, and receive a visible impression from it.
tgt_text.2878: And take notice here, that Moses does not say, " I will cause enmity to thee and the woman," but, " I will place enmity between thee and between the woman:
tgt_text.2880: because the war between these two is concerning what is in the middle, and what lies, as it were, on the borders of pleasure and of the outward sense.
tgt_text.2881: And that which lies between them is what is drinkable, and what is eatable, and what is inclined to all such things, every one of which is an object to be appreciated by the outward sense, and an efficient cause of pleasure.
tgt_text.2882: When, therefore, pleasure wallows immoderately in these things, it at once by so doing inflicts injury on the outward sense.
tgt_text.2883: And again, the expression, " between thy seed and between her seed," is uttered with strict natural propriety, for all seed is the beginning of generation.
tgt_text.2884: But the beginning of pleasure is not passion, but an emotional impulse of the outward sense, set in motion by the mind.
tgt_text.2885: For from this, as from a fountain, the faculties of the outward senses are derived, especially, according to the most sacred Moses, who says that the woman was formed out of Adam, that is to say, the outward sense was formed out of the mind.
tgt_text.2886: The part, therefore, that pleasure acts towards the outward sense, passion also acts towards the mind.
tgt_text.2887: So that, since the two former are at enmity with one another, the two latter must likewise be in a state of hostility.
tgt_text.2889: And the war between these things is manifest.
tgt_text.2890: At all events, according to the superiority of the mind when it applies itself to incorporeal objects, which are perceptible only to the intellect, passion is put to flight.
tgt_text.2891: And, on the other hand, when this latter gains a shameful victory, the mind yields, being hindered from giving its attention to itself and to all its actions.
tgt_text.2892: At all events, he says in another place, " When Moses lifted up his hands Israel prevailed, and when he let them down Amalek prevailed."*
tgt_text.2893: And this statement implies, that when the mind raises itself up from mortal affairs and is elevated on high, it is very vigorous because it beholds God ;
tgt_text.2894: and the mind here means Israel.
tgt_text.2895: But when it relaxes its vigour and becomes powerless, then immediately the passions will prevail, that is to say, Amalek;
tgt_text.2896: which name, being interpreted, means, the people licking.
tgt_text.2897: For lie does, of a verity, devour the whole soul, and licks it up, leaving no seed behind, nor anything which can excite'virtue;
tgt_text.2898: in reference to which it is said, " Amalek is the beginning of nations;
tgt_text.2899: "t because passion governs, and is the absolute lord of nations, all mingled and confused and jumbled in disorder, without any settled plan;
tgt_text.2900: and, through passion, all the war of the soul is fanned and kept alive.
tgt_text.2901: For God makes a promise to the same minds to which he grants peace, that he will efface the memorial of Amalek from all the lands beneath the heaven.
tgt_text.2903: And the expression, "He shall watch thy head, and thou shalt watch his heel,"‡ is, as to its language, a barbarism, but, as to the meaning which is conveyed by it, a correct expression.
tgt_text.2905: It ought to be expressed with respect to the woman :
tgt_text.2906: but the woman is not he, but she.
tgt_text.2907: What, then, are we to say ?
tgt_text.2908: From his discourse about the woman he has digressed to her seed and her beginning.
tgt_text.2909: Now the beginning of the outward sense is the mind.
tgt_text.2910: But the mind is masculine, in respect of which one may say, he, his, and so on.
tgt_text.2911: Very correctly, therefore, does God here say to pleasure, that the mind shall watch your principal and predominant doctrine, and you shall watch the traces of the mind itself, and the foundations of the things which are pleasing to it, to which the heel has very naturally been likened,LXVIII.
tgt_text.2912: But the words, " shall watch," intimate two things :
tgt_text.2913: in the first place it means as it were "shall keep," and " shall preserve."
tgt_text.2914: And, in the second place, it is equiva­ lent to " shall watch for the purpose of destroying."
tgt_text.2915: Now it is inevitable that the mind must be either bad or good.
tgt_text.2916: Now, if it be bad, it would be but a foolish guardian and dis­ penser of pleasure, for it rejoices in it.
tgt_text.2917: But the good mail is an enemy to it, expecting that, when he once attacks it, he will be able utterly to destroy it.
tgt_text.2918: And, indeed, on the other hand, pleasure watches the footsteps of the foolish man, but endeavours to trip up and undermine the standing ground of the wise man, thinking that he is always meditating its destruction ;
tgt_text.2919: but that the fool is always considering the means by which its safety may be best secured.
tgt_text.2920: But, nevertheless, though pleasure appears to trip up and to deceive the good man, it will in reality be tripped up itself by that experienced wrestler, Jacob ;
tgt_text.2921: and that, too, not in the wrestling of the body, but in that struggle which the soul carries on against the dispositions which are antagonistic to it, and which attack it through the agency of the passions and vices;
tgt_text.2922: and it will not let go the heel of its antagonist, passion, before it surren­ ders, and confesses that it has been twice tripped up and defeated, both in the matter of the birthright, and also in that of the blessing.
tgt_text.2923: For " rightly," says Esau, " is his name called Jacob, for now has he supplanted me for the second time ;
tgt_text.2924: the first time he took away my birthright, and now he has taken away my blegsing.
tgt_text.2926: *But the bad man thinks the things of the body the more important, while the good man assigns the preference to the things of the soul, which are in truth and reality the more important and the first, not, indeed, in point of time, but in power and.
tgt_text.2927: dignity, as is a ruler in a city.
tgt_text.2928: But the mistress of the concrete being is the soul.
tgt_text.2930: Therefore the one who was superior in virtue received the first place, which, indeed, fell to him as his due.
tgt_text.2931: For he also obtained the blessing in connection with the per­ fection of prayer.
tgt_text.2932: But he is a vain and conceited pretender to wisdom who said, " He took away my blessing and also my birthright."
tgt_text.2933: For what he took, 0 foolish man, was not yours, but was rather the opposite to what was yours.
tgt_text.2934: For your deeds are thought worthy of slavery, but his are thought worthy of supremacy.
tgt_text.2935: And if you are content to become the slave of the wise man, you shall receive your share of reproof and of correction, and so you shall discard ignorance and folly which are the destruction of the soul.
tgt_text.2936: For thy father, when praying, says to you, " You shall serve your brother,"t but not now;
tgt_text.2937: for he will not be able to endure your endeavouring to throw off the yoke.
tgt_text.2938: But when you have loosed his yoke from off your neck, that is to say, when you have cast off the boastfulness and arrogance which you had, after you had yoked yourself to the chariot of the passions, under the guidance of the cha­ rioteer, Folly.
tgt_text.2939: Now, indeed, you are the slave of cruel and intolerable masters, who are within yourself, and who look upon it as a law never to set any one free;
tgt_text.2940: but if you run away and escape from them, then the master who loves slaves will receive you in a good hope of freedom, and will not sur­ render you any more to your former companions, having learnt from Moses that necessary doctrine and lesson, " Not to give up a servant to his master who has escaped from his master unto him;
tgt_text.2941: for he shall dwell with him in any place which shall please him.
tgt_text.2943: But as long as you did not escape, and while you were still bridled with the bridle of those masters, you were unworthy to be the servant of a worse master.
tgt_text.2944: Giving thus the greatest proof of a mean, and lowly, and servile disposition, when you said, " My birthright and my blessing."t
tgt_text.2945: For these are the words of men who have fallen into immode­ rate ignorance, since it belongs to God alone to say, " Mine for to him alone do all things properly belong.
tgt_text.2946: And to this he will himself bear witness when he says, "My gifts, my offerings, my first fruits."
tgt_text.2947: tYou must take notice here that gifts are spoken of in contra­ distinction to offerings.
tgt_text.2948: For the former display the manifesta­ tion of the vastness of the perfect good things which God gives to those men who are perfect, but the latter are only prepared to last a very short time, and are partaken of by well-disposed practisers of virtue who are making progress towards perfec­ tion.
tgt_text.2949: On which account Abraham also, when following the will of God, retained those things which had been given to him by God :
tgt_text.2950: " but sends back the horses of the king of Sodom "§ as the wages of harlots.
tgt_text.2951: And Moses also condescends to administer justice in most important points, and with reference to things of the greatest value.
tgt_text.2952: But the more unimportant causes and trials he commits to judges of inferior rank to investigate.
tgt_text.2953: And whoever ventures to assert that any thing is his own shall be set down as a slave for ever and ever;
tgt_text.2954: as he who says, " I have loved my master, and my wife, and my children;
tgt_text.2955: I will not depart and be free."*
tgt_text.2956: He does well in confessing that slavery is proper for him;
tgt_text.2957: for can he be any thing but a slave who says, " Mine is mind, which is the master, being its own master, and possessed of absolute power;
tgt_text.2958: mine, also are the outward senses, the sufficient judges of corporeal substances ;
tgt_text.2959: mine, also are the offspring of these objects of intellect which are the offspring of the mind, and the objects of the outward senses, which are the offspring of those same outward senses ;
tgt_text.2960: for it is in my power to exert both the mind and the outward senses ?"
tgt_text.2961: But it is not sufficient for such a man only to bear witness against himself, but, being also condemned by God, who sentences him to most durable and everlasting slavery, he shall undergo his sentence :
tgt_text.2962: and be bored in the ear, that he may not receive the language of virtue, but that he may be a slave for ever, both in his mind and in his outward senses, which are bad and pitiless masters.
tgt_text.2964: And to the woman he said, I will greatly multiply thy sorrow and thy groaning, "†
tgt_text.2965: The affection which is called pain is a suffering peculiar to woman, who is a symbol of the outward sense.
tgt_text.2966: For to suffer pain belongs to the same subject to which to experience pleasure does also belong.
tgt_text.2967: But we experience pleasure through the medium of our outward senses, as of necessity we also suffer pain through the same medium.
tgt_text.2968: But the virtuous and purified mind suffers pain in the least degree;
tgt_text.2969: for the outward senses have the least degree of power over him.
tgt_text.2970: But passion is exceedingly power­ ful in the case of the foolish man, inasmuch as he has no anti­ dote in his soul by which he can ward off the evils which proceed from the outward senses and from those objects which can only be perceived by them.
tgt_text.2971: For as an athlete and a slave are beaten in two different manners, the one in an abject man­ ner, giving himself up to the ill-treatment, and yielding to it submissively;
tgt_text.2972: but the athlete opposing, and resisting, and par­ rying the blows which are aimed at him.
tgt_text.2973: And as you shave a man in one way, and a pillow in another;
tgt_text.2974: for the one is seen only in its suffering the shaving, but the man does himself do something likewise, and as one may say, aids the infliction, placing himself in a posture to be shaved;
tgt_text.2975: so the irrational man, like a slave, submits himself to another, and surrenders himself to the endurance of pains as to intolerable mistresses, being unable to look them in the face, and wholly incapable of conceiving any masculine or free thoughts.
tgt_text.2976: On which account a countless number of painful things are endured by him through the medium of the outward senses.
tgt_text.2977: But the man of experience, valiantly resisting like a brave athlete with strength and vigour, opposes himself resolutely to all painful things, so as not to be wounded by them;
tgt_text.2978: but so as to keep all their blows at a distance.
tgt_text.2979: And it seems to me that he might with great spirit utter the verses of the tragedian against pain in this manner :
tgt_text.2981: Now scorch and burn my flesh, and fill yourself
tgt_text.2982: With ample draughts of my life's purpled blood;
tgt_text.2983: For sooner shall the stars' bright orbs descend Beneath the darkened earth, the earth uprise Above the sky, and all things be confounded, Than you shall wrench one flattering word from me."
tgt_text.2985: But as God has allotted all painful things to the outward sense in great abundance and intensity, so also has he bestowed on the virtuous soul a boundless store of good things.
tgt_text.2986: Accordingly he speaks with reference to the perfect man Abraham in the following manner:
tgt_text.2987: " By myself have I sworn, saith the Lord, that because thou hast done this thing and hast not withheld thy son, thy beloved son from me, that in blessing I will bless thee, and in multiplying I will multiply thy seed as the stars of heaven, and as the sand which is on the shore of the sea."†
tgt_text.2988: He says this, and having confirmed his promise solemnly and by an oath, and by an oath, too, such as could alone become God.
tgt_text.2989: For you see that God does not swear by any other being than himself, for there is nothing more powerful than he is;
tgt_text.2990: but he swears by himself, because he is the greatest of all things.
tgt_text.2991: But some men have said that it is inconsistent with the character of God to swear at all;
tgt_text.2992: for that an oath is received for the sake of the confirmation which it supplies;
tgt_text.2993: but God is the only faithful being, and if any one else who is dear to God;
tgt_text.2994: as Moses is said to have been faithful in all his house.*
tgt_text.2995: And besides, the mere words of God are the most sacred and holy of oaths, and laws, and institutions.
tgt_text.2996: And it is a proof of his exceeding power, that whatever he says is sure to take place ;
tgt_text.2997: and this is the most especial characteristic of an oath.
tgt_text.2998: So that it would be quite natural to say that all the words of God are oaths confirmed by the accomplishment of the acts to which they relate.
tgt_text.3000: They say, indeed, that an oath is a testimony borne by God concerning a matter which is the subject of doubt.
tgt_text.3001: But if God swears he is bearing testimony to himself, which is an absurdity.
tgt_text.3002: For the person who bears the testi­ mony, and he on whose behalf it is borne, ought to be two different persons.
tgt_text.3003: What, then, are we to say?
tgt_text.3004: In the first place, that it is not a matter of blame for God to bear testi­ mony to himself.
tgt_text.3005: For what other being could be competent to bear testimony to him ?
tgt_text.3006: In the second place, He himself is to himself every thing that is most honourable-relative, kinsman, friend, virtue, prosperity, happiness, knowledge, understanding, beginning, end, entirety, universality, judge, opinion, intention, law, action, supremacy.
tgt_text.3007: Besides, if we only receive the, expression, " By myself have I sworn," in the manner in which we ought, we shall be in no danger from sophistry.
tgt_text.3008: May we not, then, say, that the truth is something of this sort?
tgt_text.3009: None of those beings which are capable of entertaining belief, can entertain a firm belief respecting God.
tgt_text.3010: For he has not displayed his nature to any one;
tgt_text.3011: but keeps it invisible to every kind of creature.
tgt_text.3012: Who can venture to affirm of him who is the cause of all things either that he is a body, or that he is incorporeal, or that he has such and such distinctive qualities, or that he has no such qualities ?
tgt_text.3013: or who, in short, can venture to affirm any thing positively about his essence, or his character, or his constitu­ tion, or his movements ?
tgt_text.3015: He alone can utter a positive assertion respecting himself, since he alone has an accurate knowledge of his own nature, without the possibility of mis­ take.
tgt_text.3016: His positive assertion, therefore, is one which may be thoroughly trusted in the first place, since he alone has any knowledge respecting his actions ;
tgt_text.3017: so that he very appropriately swore by himself, adding himself confirmation to his assertion, which it was not possible for any one else to do.
tgt_text.3018: On which account men who say that they swear by God may well be con­ sidered impious.
tgt_text.3019: For no man can rightly swear by himself, because he is not able to have any certain knowledge respect­ ing his own nature, but we must be content if we are able to understand even his name, that is to say, his word, which is the interpreter of his will.
tgt_text.3020: For that must be God to us imperfect beings, but the first mentioned, or true God, is so only to wise and perfect men.
tgt_text.3021: And Moses, too, admiring the exceeding excellency of the great uncreated God, says, " And thou shalt swear by his name,"* not by himself.
tgt_text.3022: For it is sufficient for the creature to receive confirmation and testimony from the word of God.
tgt_text.3023: But God is his own confirmation and most unerring testimony.
tgt_text.3025: But the expression, " Because thou hast done this thing,"† is a symbol of piety.
tgt_text.3026: For to do everything for the sake of God alone is pious.
tgt_text.3027: In consequence of which we do not spare even that beloved child of virtue, prosperity, sur rendering it to the Creator, and thinking it right that our off­ spring should become the possession of God, but not of any created being.
tgt_text.3028: And that expression, also, is a good one, " In blessing I will bless thee."
tgt_text.3029: For some persons do many acts worthy of a blessing, but yet not in such a way as to obtain a blessing.
tgt_text.3030: Since even a wicked man does some actions that are proper, but he does not do them from being of a proper disposition.
tgt_text.3031: And sometimes a drunken man or a mad man speaks and acts in a sober manner, but still he is not speaking or acting from a sober mind.
tgt_text.3032: And children, who are actually infants, both do and say many things which reasonable men do also do and say ;
tgt_text.3033: but they, of course, do it not in consequence of any rational disposition, for nature has not yet endowed them with a capacity of reasoning.
tgt_text.3034: But the law giver wishes the wise man to appear deserving of blessing not occasionally, accidentally, and, as it were, by chance, but in consequence of habits and a disposition deserving of blessing.
tgt_text.3036: Therefore it is not sufficient for the unfortunate external sense to be abundantly occupied with pains, but it must also be full of groaning.
tgt_text.3037: Now groaning is a violent and intense pain.
tgt_text.3038: For we are very often in pain without groaning.
tgt_text.3039: But, when we groan, we are under the influence of most grievous and thickly pressing pain.
tgt_text.3040: Now, groaning is of a twofold nature.
tgt_text.3041: One kind is that which arises in those who desire and are very eager for august objects and who do not succeed in them, which is wicked;
tgt_text.3042: the other kind is that which proceeds from persons who repent and are distressed for previous sins, and who say, "Miserable are we, how long a time have we passed infected with the disease of foolishness, and in the practices of all kinds of folly and iniquity."
tgt_text.3043: But this kind of groaning does not exist unless the king of Egypt, that is to say, the impious disposition wholly devoted to plea­ sure, has perished and departed from our soul, " For, after many days, the king of Egypt died."
tgt_text.3044: *Then immediately, as soon as vice is dead, the man who has become alive to the perceptionof God and of his own sin, groans, " For the children of Israel groaned at the corporeal and Egyptian works;
tgt_text.3045: " since the reigning disposition devoted to pleasure, while it is alive within us, persuades the soul to rejoice at the sins which it commits;
tgt_text.3046: but, when that disposi­ tion is dead, it groans over them ;
tgt_text.3047: on which account it cries out to its master, beseeching him that it may not again be per verted, and that it may not arrive at only an imperfect sort of perfection.
tgt_text.3048: For many souls who have wished to turn to re­ pentance have not been allowed to do so by God, but, been dragged back, as it were by the ebbing tide, having returned to their original courses;
tgt_text.3049: in the manner in which Lot's wife did, who was turned into stone because she loved Sodom, and who reverted to the disposition and habits which had been con­ demned by God.
tgt_text.3052: Their cry has gone up to God, bearing witness to the grace of the living God."
tgt_text.3053: For if he had not powerfully summoned up to himself the supplicatory language of that people it would not have gone up;
tgt_text.3054: that is to say, it would never have gained power and increase, would never have begun to soar so high, flying from the lowness of earthly things.
tgt_text.3055: On which account, in the next passage, God is represented as saying, " Behold the cry of the children of Israel has come up to me."*
tgt_text.3056: Very beauti­ fully here does Moses represent that their supplications have reached God, but they would not have reached him if he who was working him had not been a good man.
tgt_text.3057: But there are some souls which God even goes forward to meet:
tgt_text.3058: " I will come to you and bless you."
tgt_text.3059: You see here how great is the kindness of the Creator of all things, when he even anticipates our delay and our intentions, and comes for­ ward to meet us to the perfect benefiting of our souls.
tgt_text.3060: And the expression used here is an oracle full of instruction.
tgt_text.3061: For, if a thought of God enters the mind, it immediately blesses it and heals all its diseases.
tgt_text.3062: But the outward sense is always grieved and groans, and brings forth the perception of its objects with pain and intolerable anguish.
tgt_text.3063: As also God him­ self says, " In sorrow thou shalt bring forth children.
tgt_text.3064: "Now, the sense of sight brings forth the operation of seeing, the sense of hearing is the parent of the operation of hearing, so is the sense of taste of tasting ;
tgt_text.3065: and, in short, each outward sense is respectively the parent of its corresponding operation ;
tgt_text.3066: but still it does not produce all these effects in the foolish man without severe pain.
tgt_text.3067: For such a mail is affected by pain when he sees, and when he hears, and when he tastes, and when he smells, and, in fact, when he exerts any one of these outward senses.
tgt_text.3069: On the other hand, you will find virtue not only conceiving with extraordinary joy, but also bringing forth her good offspring with laughter and cheerfulness;
tgt_text.3070: and you will also find the offspring of the two parents to be actually cheer­ fulness itself.
tgt_text.3071: Now that the wise man becomes a parent with joy, and not with sorrow, the word of God itself will testify to us when it speaks thus :
tgt_text.3073: And God said unto Abraham, Sarai, thy wife, shall no longer be called Sarai, but her name shall be Sarah ;
tgt_text.3074: I will bless her, and give thee a son from her."†
tgt_text.3075: And, afterwards, Moses proceeds to say, " And Abraham fell upon his face and laughed, and said, " Shall a son be born to him who is a hundred years old;
tgt_text.3076: and shall Sarah, who is ninety years old, have a son?"
tgt_text.3077: Abraham, therefore, appears here to be in a state of joy, and to be laughing because he is about to become the father of happiness, that is to say, of Isaac ;
tgt_text.3078: and virtue, that is to say, Sarah, laughs also.
tgt_text.3079: And the same prophet will further bear witness, speaking thus, "
tgt_text.3080: And it had ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women, and she laughed in her mind and said, such happiness has never yet happened to me to this time, and my lord," that is to say, the divine Lord, "is older than I;
tgt_text.3081: " in whose power, however, this thing must inevitably be, and in whose power it is becom­ ing to place confidence.
tgt_text.3082: For the offspring is laughter and joy.
tgt_text.3083: For this is the meaning and interpretation of the name of Isaac.
tgt_text.3084: Therefore, let the outward sense be grieved, but let virtue be always rejoicing.
tgt_text.3085: For, also, when happiness, that is Isaac, was born, she says, in the pious exaltation, " The Lord has caused me laughter, and whoever shall hear of it shall rejoice with me."*
tgt_text.3086: Open your ears, therefore, 0 ye initiated, and receive the most sacred mysteries.
tgt_text.3088: and the expression, " has caused," is equivalent to " has begotten."
tgt_text.3089: So that what is here said has some such meaning as this, " The Lord has begotten Isaac."
tgt_text.3090: For he is the father of perfect nature, sowing and begetting happiness in the soul.
tgt_text.3092: And thy desire," says God, " shall be to thy husband."t
tgt_text.3093: There are two husbands of the outward senses.
tgt_text.3094: The one a legal one, the other a destroyer.
tgt_text.3095: For the object of sight, acting upon it like a husband, puts the sense of sight in motion ;
tgt_text.3096: and so does sound affect the sense of hearing, flavour the sense of taste, and so on with each of the outward senses respectively.
tgt_text.3097: And these things attract the attention of and call the irrational outward sense to itself, and become the masters of it and govern it.
tgt_text.3098: For beauty enslaves the sight, and sweet flowers enslave the sense of taste, and each of the other objects of outward sense enslaves that sense which cor­ responds to them.
tgt_text.3099: See the glutton, what a slave he is to all the preparations which cooks and confectioners devise.
tgt_text.3100: Behold the man who is devoted to the study of music, how he is governed by the harp, or the flute, or by any one who is able to sing.
tgt_text.3101: But the sense which turns itself to its legitimate husband, that is to say, to the mind, derives the greatest possible advantage from that object.
tgt_text.3103: Let us now see what account Moses gives of the I mind itself, when it is set in motion in a way contrary to right reason.
tgt_text.3104: And God said unto Adam, " Because thou hast listened to the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree of which I commanded thee not to eat, because thou hast eaten of it, cursed is the earth in thy actions."*
tgt_text.3105: It is a most mis­ chievous thing, therefore, for the mind to be swayed by the outward senses, but not for the outward senses to be guided by the mind.
tgt_text.3106: For it is at all times proper that that which is better should rule, and that that which is worse should be ruled.
tgt_text.3107: And the mind is better than the outward senses.
tgt_text.3108: As, therefore, when the charioteer has his horses under command and guides the animals with the rein, the chariot is guided wherever he pleases;
tgt_text.3109: but if they become restiff, and get the better of the charioteer, he is often dragged out of his road, and sometimes it even happens that the beasts themselves are borne by the impetuosity of their course into a pit, and every­ thing is carried away in a ruinous manner.
tgt_text.3110: And, as a ship holds on her right course when the pilot has the helm in his hand and steers her, and she is obedient to her rudder, but the vessel is upset when some contrary wind descends upon the waves and the whole sea is occupied by billows;
tgt_text.3111: so when the mind, which is the charioteer or pilot of the soul, retains the mastery over the entire animal, as a ruler does over a city, the life of the man proceeds rightly.
tgt_text.3112: But when the outward sense, which is devoid of reason, obtains the supremacy, then a terrible confusion overtakes the man, as might happen if a household of slaves were to conspire and to set upon their master.
tgt_text.3113: For then, if one must tell the truth, the mind is set fire to and burnt, the outward senses handling the flame and placing the objects of their operation beneath, as fuel.
tgt_text.3115: And Moses, indeed, speaks of and describes such a conflagration of the mind as this which arises in consequence of the operation of the outward senses, when he says, " And the women still burnt additional fires in Moab." t
tgt_text.3116: For this expres­ sion being interpreted means, from the father, because the mind is our father."
tgt_text.3117: For then," says Moses, " the expounders of rid­ dIes will say, Come to Heshbon, that the city of Sihon may be built and furnished.
tgt_text.3118: Because fire has gone forth out of Hesh­ bon, and a flame out of the city of Sihon, and has devoured as far as Moab, and has consumed the high places of Arnon.
tgt_text.3119: Woe unto thee, Moab, Chemosh is destroyed:
tgt_text.3120: their sons who had sought to escape have been given up, and their daughters have become captive to Sihon, king of the Amorites.
tgt_text.3121: And the seed of them shall perish, from Heshbon even to Dibon.
tgt_text.3122: Moreover, the women still burnt additional fire in Moab."
tgt_text.3124: and these must here mean enigmas, full of indistinctness.
tgt_text.3125: Behold the reasoning of the physician :
tgt_text.3126: —" I will purge the sick man, I will nourish him, I will heal him with medicines and with diet, I will ex­ tirpate his diseased parts, I will cauterise him."
tgt_text.3127: But very often nature has healed the man without these remedies ;
tgt_text.3128: and very often too has suffered him to die though they were applied:
tgt_text.3129: so that the reasonings of the physician have been utterly found out to be dreams, full of all indistinctness and of riddles.
tgt_text.3130: Again, the husbandman says, I will scatter seed, I will plant;
tgt_text.3131: the plants shall grow, they shall bear fruit, which shall not only be useful for necessary enjoyment, but which shall also be abundant for superfluity ;
tgt_text.3132: and then, on a sudden, fire, or a storm, or continued rains, have destroyed everything.
tgt_text.3133: But at times man has brought his labours to their due accomplish­ ment, and yet he who formed all these plans has derived no advantage from their being accomplished, but has died before they were accomplished, and has in vain promised himself the enjoyment of the fruits of his labours.
tgt_text.3135: It is best, therefore, to trust in God, and not in uncertain reasonings, or unsure conjectures.
tgt_text.3136: " Abraham trusted in the Lord, and it was counted to him for righteous­ ness."*
tgt_text.3137: And Moses governed the people, being testified to that he was faithful with his whole house.
tgt_text.3138: But if we distrust our own reason, we shall prepare and build ourselves a city of the mind which will destroy the truth.
tgt_text.3139: For Sihon, being interpreted means destroying.
tgt_text.3140: In reference to which he who had dreamed, waking up, found that all the motions and all the advances of the foolish man are merely dreams that have no portion of truth in them, for the very mind is found to be a dream ;
tgt_text.3141: and the only true doctrine is to believe in God, and to trust to vain reasonings is a mere delusion.
tgt_text.3142: But irrational impulse goes forth and proceeds to each extremity, while both the reasonings and the mind corrupt the truth.
tgt_text.3143: On which account, Moses says that " fire went out of Heshbon, and flame out of the city of Sihon."
tgt_text.3144: So absurd is it to trust either to plausible reasonings, or to the mind which corrupts the truth.
tgt_text.3146: And it devours even as far as Moab that is to say, as far as the mind.
tgt_text.3147: For what other creature, except the miserable mind, can a false opinion deceive ?
tgt_text.3148: It devours and consumes, and, in truth, it swallows up the pillars in it;
tgt_text.3149: that is to say, all the particular notions which are engraved and impressed upon it, as upon a pillar.
tgt_text.3150: But the pillars are Arnon, which, being interpreted, means the light of Arnon, since every one of these facts is made clear by reasoning.
tgt_text.3151: Accord­ ingly, Moses begins presently to lament over the self-satisfied and arrogant mind in this manner:
tgt_text.3153: For, if you give attention to the riddles which arise out of the perception of what is probable, you have destroyed the truth by so doing.
tgt_text.3154: "The people of Chemosh," that is to say, thy people and thy power, have been found to be mutilated and blinded.
tgt_text.3155: For Chemosh, being interpreted, means feeling with the hand.
tgt_text.3156: And this action is the especial characteristic of one who does not see.
tgt_text.3157: Now, their sons are particular reasonings—exiles;
tgt_text.3158: and their opinions are in the place of daughters, being captives to the king of the Amorites, that is to say, of those who con­ verse with the sophist.
tgt_text.3159: For the name Amorites, being inter­ preted, means talkers, being a symbol of the people who talk much;
tgt_text.3160: and their guide and leader is the sophist, and he who is skilful in reasoning and clever in investigating arts ;
tgt_text.3161: a man by whom all those are deceived who once overpass the boundary of truth.
tgt_text.3163: Sihon, then, who destroys the sound rule of truth, and his seed also, shall both perish;
tgt_text.3164: and so shall Heshbon, namely, the sophistical riddles, as far as Debon;
tgt_text.3166: And very con­ sistently with nature shall this be.
tgt_text.3167: For what is probable and plausible has not a positive knowledge respecting truth, but only a trial and controversy and a litigious contest and strife, and all such things as these.
tgt_text.3168: But it was not sufficient for the mind to have its own peculiar evils, which were perceptible only to the intellect;
tgt_text.3169: but still the women burnt additional fire, that is to say, the outward senses excited a great con­ flagration to have an effect upon it.
tgt_text.3170: See, now, what the meaning is of what is here said.
tgt_text.3171: We who very often by night desist from energizing according to any one of the outward senses, receive absurd impressions respect­ in-, many different things, since our souls exist in a state of perpetual motion and are capable of an infinite variety of changes.
tgt_text.3172: There were, therefore, things quite sufficient for its destruction which it brought forth out of itself.
tgt_text.3173: But now, as it is, the multitude of the outward senses has brought against it a most incalculable multitude of evils, partly from objects of sight and partly from sounds;
tgt_text.3174: and besides that, from flavours and from such essences as affect the sense of smell.
tgt_text.3175: And one may almost say that the flavour which arises from them has a more pernicious influence on the disposition of the soul than that which is engendered in the soul itself, without any co- operation or agency of the organs of sense.
tgt_text.3177: One of these women is Pentephoe, the wife of Pharaoh's chief cook.*
tgt_text.3178: We must now consider how a mail who was a eunuch can be represented as having a wife.
tgt_text.3179: For there will here be something which will seem to offer a reasonable ground for perplexity to those who do not take the expressions of the law in an allegorical sense.
tgt_text.3180: For the mind is really a eunuch, and really the chief of cooks, using not merely such pleasures as are simple, but those also which are superfluous, and is therefore called a eunuch and barren of all wisdom, being the eunuch and slave of no other master than of that squan­ derer of all good things, Pharaoh.
tgt_text.3181: On another principle, therefore, it might appear a most desirable thing to be a eunuch, if our soul, by that means escaping vice, might be able also to avoid all knowledge of passion.
tgt_text.3182: On which account Joseph, that is to say, the disposition of continence, says to Pleasure, who accosts him with, "Lie with me, and being a man behave as a man, and enjoy the pleasant things which life can afford."
tgt_text.3183: He, I say, refuses her, saying, " I shall be sinning against God, who loves virtue, if I become a votary of pleasure ;
tgt_text.3184: for this is a wicked action.
tgt_text.3186: And, at first, he only skirmishes, but presently he fights and resists valiantly, when the soul enters into her own dwelling, and, having recourse to her own strength and energy, renounces the temptations of the body, and performs her own appropriate actions as those which are the proper occu­ pation of the soul;
tgt_text.3187: not appearing in the house of Joseph, nor of Pentephoë, but in the house.
tgt_text.3188: Nor does Moses add a word to describe whose house he means, in order to give you oppor­ tunity to interpret allegorically, in an inquisitive spirit, the meaning of the expression, "to do his business."
tgt_text.3189: The house, therefore, is the soul, to which be runs, leaving all external affairs, in order that what is spoken of may there be done.
tgt_text.3190: But may we not say that the conduct of the temperate man is what it is, and is directed by the will of God ?
tgt_text.3191: For there was not present any inconsistent idea of all those which are accustomed to find their place within the soul.
tgt_text.3192: Moreover, pleasure never ceases from struggling against the yoke, but, seizing hold of his clothes, she cries, " Lie with me."
tgt_text.3193: Now, clothes are, as it were, the covering of the body, just as life is protected by meat and drink.
tgt_text.3194: And she says here, " Why do you renounce pleasure, without which you cannot live ?
tgt_text.3195: Behold, I take hold of the things which cause it;
tgt_text.3196: and I say that you could not possibly exist unless you also made use of some of the things which cause it.
tgt_text.3197: "What, then, says the temperate man ? " Shall I," says he, "become a slave to passion, on account of the material which causes passion ?
tgt_text.3198: Nay, I will depart out of reach of the passion."
tgt_text.3199: For, leaving his garment in her hand, he fled, and escaped out of doors.
tgt_text.3201: And who, some one perhaps, may say, ever escapes in-doors ?
tgt_text.3203: Or have not some people, avoiding the guilt of sacrilege, committed robberies in private houses, or though not beating their own fathers, have not they insulted the fathers of others ?
tgt_text.3204: Now these men do escape from one class of offences, but they run into others.
tgt_text.3205: But a man who is perfectly temperate, ought to avoid every description of offence, whether greater or less, and never to be detected in any sin whatever.
tgt_text.3206: But Joseph, for he is a young man, and because as such he was unable to struggle with the Egyptian body and to subdue pleasure, runs away.
tgt_text.3207: But Phineas the priest, who was zealous with a great zeal for God's service, did not provide for his own safety by flight;
tgt_text.3208: but having taken to himself a yoke horse, that is to say, zeal com­ bined with reason, would never desist till he had wounded the Midianitish woman (that is to say the nature which was con­ cealed in the divine company), through her belly,- in order that no plant or seed of wickedness might ever be able to shoot out from it.
tgt_text.3210: On which account after folly has been utterly eradicated, the soul receives a two-fold prize, and a double inheritance, peace and holiness, two kindred and sister-like virtues.
tgt_text.3211: We must therefore refuse to listen to such a woman, that is to say to a wicked temptation of the outward senses, since "
tgt_text.3212: God gave a good reward to the midwiyes,"†because they disregarded the commands of the wasteful Pharaoh, " saving the male children of the soul alive," which he wished to destroy, being a lover of the female offspring alone, and rejecting all knowledge of the Cause of all things, and saying, " I know him not."‡
tgt_text.3213: But we must give our belief to another woman, such as it was ordained that Sarah should be, Sarah being in a figure the governing virtue ;
tgt_text.3214: and the wise Abraham was guided by her, when she recommended him such actions as were good.
tgt_text.3215: § For before this time, when he was not yet perfect, but even before his name was changed, he gave his attention to subjects of lofty philosophical speculation ;
tgt_text.3216: and she, knowing that he could not produce anything out of perfect virtue, counselled him to raise children out of her handmaid, that is to say out of encyclical instruction, out of Agar,|| which name being interpreted means a dwelling near;
tgt_text.3217: for he who meditates dwelling in perfect virtue, before his name is enrolled among the citizens of that state, dwells among the encyclical studies, in order that through their instrumentality he may make his approaches at liberty towards perfect virtue.
tgt_text.3218: After that, when he saw that be was now become perfect, and was now able to become a father, although he himself was full of gratitude towards those studies, by means of which he had been recommended to virtue, and thought it hard to renounce them;
tgt_text.3219: he was well inclined to be appeased by an oracle from God which laid this command on him. "
tgt_text.3220: In everything which Sarah says, do thou obey her voice."
tgt_text.3221: ¶Let that be a law to every one of us to do whatever seems good to virtue;
tgt_text.3222: for if we are willing to submit to everything which virtue recommends we shall be happy.
tgt_text.3225: And thou eatest of the tree of which alone I commanded thee that thou shouldst not eat,''* is equivalent to saying, You made a covenant with wickedness, which you ought to have repelled with all your strength.
tgt_text.3226: On this account, " Cursed art thou;
tgt_text.3227: " not, cursed is the earth for thy works.
tgt_text.3228: What, now, is the reason of this ?
tgt_text.3229: That serpent, pleasure, which is an irrational elevation of the soul, this is intrinsically accursed in its own nature ;
tgt_text.3230: and being such, attaches itself only to the wicked man, and to no good mail.
tgt_text.3231: But Adam is the intermediate sort of mind which at one time if investigated is found to be good, and at another time bad;
tgt_text.3232: for inasmuch as it is mind, it is not by nature either good or bad, but from contact with virtue or with vice, it frequently changes for the better or for the worse ;
tgt_text.3233: therefore it very naturally is not accursed of its own nature, as neither being itself wickedness nor acting according to wickedness, but the earth is accursed in its works:
tgt_text.3234: for the actions which proceed from the entire soul, which he calls the earth, are open to blame and devoid of innocence, inasmuch as he does every­ thing in accordance with vice.
tgt_text.3235: In reference to which fact God adds, that " In sorrow thou shalt eat of .it."
tgt_text.3236: Which is equivalent to saying, you shall enjoy your soul in sorrow ;
tgt_text.3237: for the wicked man does enjoy his own soul with great pain the whole of his life, having no legitimate cause for joy ;
tgt_text.3238: for such cause is only produced by justice and prudence, and by the virtues which are enthroned as companions with them.
tgt_text.3239: LXXXIX. " Thorns, therefore, and thistles shall it bring forth to you."
tgt_text.3240: But what is it which is produced and which shoots up in the soul of the foolish man except the passions which goad and sting and wound it ?
tgt_text.3241: Which Moses here, speaking symbolically, calls thorns, and which irrational appetite rushes upon at first like fire, and so hastens to meet, and afterwards uniting itself to them, it consumes and destroys all its own nature and actions.
tgt_text.3244: But if fire when it has gone forth finds thorns, and shall also burn a threshing-floor, or a crop of wheat, or a field of corn, then he who kindled the fire shall pay the damage." t
tgt_text.3245: You see therefore when it has gone forth, that is to say, irrational impetuosity, it does not only burn the thorns, but finds them :
tgt_text.3246: for being inclined to seek out the passions, it attains to what it has been desiring to find;
tgt_text.3247: but when it has found it, it consumes these three things,-perfect virtue, improvement, and goodness of disposition.
tgt_text.3248: Moses therefore here compares virtue to a threshing-floor;
tgt_text.3249: for as the crops when collected are brought to the threshing-floor, so also are the good things which exist in the soul of the wise man brought to virtue ;
tgt_text.3250: and improvement he likens to the crop of wheat, inasmuch as both the one and the other are imperfect, aiming at the end;
tgt_text.3251: and goodness of disposition he compares to a field of corn, because it is well adapted to receive the seeds of virtue ;
tgt_text.3252: and each of the passions he calls thistles (τριβόλια), because they are divisible into three parts:
tgt_text.3253: the passion itself, the efficient cause, and the effect which arises from the combined operation of the two.
tgt_text.3254: As for instance pleasure, what is pleasant, and the being pleased;
tgt_text.3255: appetite, the object of appetite, and the indulgence of appetite ;
tgt_text.3256: pain, what is painful, and the suffering pain ;
tgt_text.3257: fear, what is fearful, and the being in a state of fear.
tgt_text.3259: And thou shalt eat the herb of the field;
tgt_text.3260: in the sweat of thy brow shalt thou eat thy bread."
tgt_text.3261: He here speaks of the herb of the field and of bread, as if they were synony­ mous, or identical with one another.
tgt_text.3262: The herb of the field is the food of the irrational animal;
tgt_text.3263: but the irrational animal is a worthless creature, which has been deprived of right reason.
tgt_text.3264: The outward senses are also irrational, though they are part of the soul.
tgt_text.3265: But the mind, which is eager for the attainment of those things which are the objects of the outward sense by means of the irrational outward senses, does not attain its desires without labour and sweat;
tgt_text.3266: for the life of the foolish man is very full of distress and very burdensome, since he is always aiming at and greedily coveting the things which give pleasure, and all such things as wickedness is wont to do.
tgt_text.3267: And how long shall this last?
tgt_text.3268: "Until," says God, "you return to the dust from which you were taken."
tgt_text.3269: For is he not now ranked among the things of the earth, and among things which have no consistency, ever since he deserted the wisdom which is from heaven?
tgt_text.3270: We must consider therefore to what point he is coming back;
tgt_text.3271: but may we not consider whether what he says has not some such meaning as this, that the foolish mind is at all times averted from right reason, and that it has been originally taken not from any sublime nature, but from some more earthly material, and whether it is stationary, or whether it is in motion, it is always the same, and desirous of the same objects.
tgt_text.3272: On which account, God adds that, " Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return."
tgt_text.3273: And this is equivalent to what has been said before.
tgt_text.3274: Moreover this sentence also signifies, the beginning and the end are one and the same thing.
tgt_text.3275: For there hadst thou beginning in the perishable bodies of the earth;
tgt_text.3277: in them, during the interval of your life, between its beginning and its end, passing along a road which is not plain and easy, but rough, full of briars and thorns, the nature of which is to tear and wound thee.
tgt_text.3279: God cast out Adam, and placed him opposite the paradise of happiness ;
tgt_text.3280: and he placed there the cherubim and a flaming sword, which turned every way, to keep the way of the tree of life.
tgt_text.3281: *In this place Moses uses the expression, He cast out," but previously he said, "He sent out," not using the various expressions at random, but being well aware with reference to what parts he was employing them with propriety and felicity.
tgt_text.3282: Now a man who is sent out is not hindered from returning at some subsequent time;
tgt_text.3283: but he who is cast out by God must endure an eternal banishment, for it is granted to him who has not yet been completely and violently taken prisoner by wickedness, to repent, and so to return back to virtue, from which he has been driven, as to his great country;
tgt_text.3284: but he who is weighed down by, and wholly subjected to, a violent and incurable disease, must bear his misfortunes for ever, being for all times unalterably cast out into the place of the wicked, that there he may endure unmitigated and everlasting misery.*
tgt_text.3285: Since we see Agar,t by whom we understand the middle kind of instruction which is confined to the encyclical system, twice going forth from Sarah, who is the symbol of predominant virtue, and once returning back by the same road, inasmuch as after she had fled the first time, without being banished by her mistress, she returned to see her master's house, having been met by an angel, as the holy scriptures read :
tgt_text.3286: but the second time, she is utterly cast out, and is never to be brought back again.
tgt_text.3288: And we must speak of the causes of her first flight, and then again of her second perpetual banishment.
tgt_text.3289: Before the names of the two were changed, that is to say, before they had been altered for the better as to the charac­ teristics of their souls, and had been endowed with better dispositions, but while the name of the man was still Abram, or the sublime father, who delighted in the lofty philosophy which investigates the events which take place in the air, and the sublime nature of the beings which exist in heaven, which mathematical science claims for itself as the most excellent part of natural philosophy, and the name of the woman was still Sarai;
tgt_text.3290: the symbol of my authority, for she is called my authority, and she had not yet changed her nature so as to become generic virtue, and all genus is imperishable, but was as yet classed among things particular and things in species;
tgt_text.3291: that is to say, such as the prudence which is in me, the temperance which is in me, the courage, the justice, and so on in the same manner;
tgt_text.3292: and these particular virtues are perishable, because the place which receives them, that is to say I, am also perishable.
tgt_text.3293: Then Agar, who is the middle kind of encyclical instruction, even if she should endeavour to escape from the austere and stern life of the lovers of virtue, will again return to it, since it is not, as yet, able to receive the generic and imperishable excellencies of virtue, but can only touch the particular virtues, and such as are spoken of in species, in which it is sufficient to attain to mediocrity instead of extreme perfection.
tgt_text.3294: But when Abram, instead of an inquirer into natural philosophy, became a wise man and a lover of God, having his name changed to Abraham, which being interpreted means the great father of sounds ;
tgt_text.3295: for language when uttered sounds, and the father of language is the mind, which has attained to what is virtuous.
tgt_text.3296: And when Sarai instead of being ray authority, had her name also changed to Sarah, the meaning of which is princess, and this change is equivalent to becoming generic and imperishable virtue, instead of virtue special and perishable :
tgt_text.3297: then will arise the genus of happiness that is to say, Isaac;
tgt_text.3298: and he, when all the feminine affections * have ceased, and when the passion of joy and cheerfulness are dead, will eagerly pursue, not childish amusements, but divine objects ;
tgt_text.3299: then too those elementary branches of instruction which bear the name of Agar, will be cast out, and their sophistical child will also be cast out, who is named.
tgt_text.3302: And they shall undergo eternal banishment, God himself confirming their expulsion, when he bids the wise man obey the word spoken by Sarah, and she urges him expressly to cast out the serving woman and her son ;
tgt_text.3303: and it is good to be guided by virtue, and especially so when it teaches such lessons as this, that the most perfect natures are very greatly different from the mediocre habits, and that wisdom is a wholly different thing from sophistry;
tgt_text.3304: for the one labours to devise what is persuasive for the establishment of a false opinion, which is pernicious to the soul, but wisdom, with long meditation on the truth by the knowledge of right reason, brings real advantage to the intellect.
tgt_text.3305: Why then do we wonder if God once for all banished Adam, that is to say, the mind out of the district of the virtues, after he had once contracted folly, that incurable disease, and if he never permitted him again to return, when he also drives out and banishes from wisdom and from the wise man every sophist, and the mother of sophists, the teaching that is of elementary instruction, while he calls the names of wisdom and of the wise man Abraham, and Sarah.
tgt_text.3307: Then also, " The flaming sword and the cherubim have an abode allotted to them exactly in front of paradise."
tgt_text.3308: The expression, " in front," is used partly to convey the idea of a resisting enemy, and partly as suitable to the notion of judg­ ment, as a person whose cause is being decided appears in front of his judge:
tgt_text.3309: partly also in a friendly sense, in order that they may be perceived, and may be considered in closer connection by reason of the more accurate view of them that is thus obtained, just as archetypal pictures and statues are placed in front of painters and statuaries.
tgt_text.3310: Now the first example of an enemy placed directly in front of one is derived from what is said in the case of Cain, that " he went out from the face of God, and dwelt in the land of Nod, in the front of Eden."*
tgt_text.3311: Now Nod being interpreted means commotion, and Eden means delight.
tgt_text.3312: The one there­ fore is a symbol of wickedness agitating the soul, and the other of virtue which creates for the soul a state of tranquillity and happiness, not meaning by happiness that effeminate luxury which is derived from the indulgence of the irrational passion of pleasure, but a joy free from toil and free from hardship, which is enjoyed with great tranquillity.
tgt_text.3313: And it follows of necessity that when the mind goes forth from any imagination of God, by which it would be good and expedient for it to be supported, then immediately, after the fashion of a ship, which is tossed in the sea, when the winds oppose it with great vio­ lence, it is tossed about in every direction, having disturbance as it were for its country and its home, a thing which is the most contrary of all things to steadiness of soul, which is engendered by joy, which is a term synonymous with Eden.V.
tgt_text.3314: Now of the kind of opposition of place which is connected with standing in front of a judge for judgment, we have an example in the case of the woman who has been suspected of having committed adultery.
tgt_text.3315: For, says Moses, " the priest shall cause the woman to stand in front of her lord, and she shall uncover her head."*
tgt_text.3316: Let us now examine what he intends to show by this direction.
tgt_text.3317: It often happens that what ought to be done is not done, in the manner in which it ought to be done, and sometimes too that which is not proper is nevertheless done in a proper manner.
tgt_text.3318: For instance, when the return of a deposit is not made in an honest spirit, but is intended either to work the injury of him who receives it back again, or by way of a snare to bear out a denial in the case of another deposit of greater value, in that case a proper action is done in an improper manner.
tgt_text.3319: On the other hand, for a physician not to tell the exact truth to a sick patient, when he has decided on purging him, or performing some operation with the knife or with the cautery for the benefit of the patient, lest if the sick man were to be moved too strongly by the anticipation of the suffering, he might refuse to submit to the cure, or through weakness of mind might despair of its succeeding;
tgt_text.3320: or in the case of a wise man giving false information to the enemy to secure the safety of his country, fearing lest through his speaking the truth the affairs of the adversaries-should succeed, in this case an action which is not intrinsically right is done in a proper manner.
tgt_text.3321: In reference to which distinction Moses says, " to pursue what is just justly,"* as if it were possible also to pursue it unjustly, if at any time the judge who gives sentence does not decide in an honest spirit.
tgt_text.3322: Since therefore what is said or done is openly notorious to all men, but since the intention, the consequence of which what is said is said, and what is done is done, is not notorious, but it is uncertain whether it be a sound and healthy motive, or an unhealthy design, stained with numerous pollutions;
tgt_text.3323: and since no created being is capable of discerning the secret intention of an invisible mind, but God alone;
tgt_text.3324: in reference to this Moses says that " all secret things are known to the Lord God, but only such as are manifest are known to the creature."
tgt_text.3325: And therefore it is enjoined to the priest and prophet, that is to say to reason, " to place the soul in front of God, with the head uncovered,"t that is to say the soul must be laid bare as to its principal design, and the sentiments which it nourished must be revealed, in order that being brought before the judgment seat of the most accurate vision of the incorruptible God, it may be thoroughly examined as to all its concealed disguises, like a base coin, or, on the other hand, if it be found to be free from all participation in any kind of wickedness, it may wash away all the calumnies that have been uttered against its bringing him for a testimony to its purity, who is alone able to behold the soul naked.
tgt_text.3327: This, then, is the meaning of coming in front of one's judge, when brought up for judgment.
tgt_text.3328: But the case of coming in front of any one which has a bearing upon connection or familiarity, may be illustrated by the example of the all-wise Abraham.
tgt_text.3329: " For," says Moses, " he was still standing in front of God." ‡
tgt_text.3330: And a proof of his familiarity is contained in the expression that "he came near to God, and spoke."
tgt_text.3331: For it is fitting for one who has no connection with another to stand at a distance, and to be separated from him, but he who is connected with him should stand near to him.
tgt_text.3332: And to stand, and to have an unchangeable mind comes very near to the power of God, since the Divinity is unchangeable, but that which is created is intrinsically and essentially changeable.
tgt_text.3333: Therefore, if any one, restraining the changeableness natural to all created things by his love of knowledge, has been able to put such violence on any thing as to cause it to stand firm, let him be sure that he has come near to the happiness of the Deity.
tgt_text.3334: But God very appropriately assigns to the cherubim and to the flaming sword a city or abode in front of Paradise, not as to enemies about to oppose and to fight him, but rather as to near connections and friends, in order that in consequence of a continued sight and contemplation of one another, the two powers might conceive an affection for one another, the all­ bounteous God inspiring them with a winged and heavenly love.
tgt_text.3336: But we must now consider what the figurative allu­ sions are which are enigmatically expressed in the mention of the cherubim and of the flaming sword which turned every way.
tgt_text.3337: May we not say that Moses here introduces under a figure an intimation of the revolutions of the whole heaven?
tgt_text.3338: For the spheres in heaven received a motion in opposite direc­ tions to one another, the one sphere receiving a fixed motion towards the right hand, but the sphere of the other side receiving a wandering motion towards the left.
tgt_text.3339: But that outermost circle of what are called the fixed stars is one sphere, which also proceeds in a fixed periodical revolution from east to west.
tgt_text.3340: But the interior circle of the seven planets, whose course is at the same time compulsory and voluntary, has two motions, which are to a certain degree contrary to one another.
tgt_text.3341: And one of these motions is involuntary, like that of the planets.
tgt_text.3342: For they appear every day proceeding onwards from the east to the west.
tgt_text.3343: But their peculiar and voluntary motion is from west to east, according to which last motion we find that the periods of the seven planets have received their exact measure of time, moving on in an equal course, as the Sun, and Luci­ fer, and what is called Stilbon.
tgt_text.3344: For these three planets are of equal speed;
tgt_text.3345: but some of the others are unequal in point of time, but preserve a certain sort of relative proportion to one another and to the other three which have been mentioned.
tgt_text.3346: Accordingly, by one of the cherubim is understood the extreme outermost circumference of the entire heaven, in which the fixed stars celebrate their truly divine dance, which always proceeds on similar principles and is always the same, without ever leaving the order which the Father, who created them, appointed for them in the world.
tgt_text.3347: But the other of the cherubim is the inner sphere which is contained within that previously mentioned, which God origin­ ally divided in two parts, and created seven orbits, bearing a certain definite proportion to one another, and he adapted each of the planets to one of these ;
tgt_text.3348: and then, having placed each of these stars in its proper orbit, like a driver in a chariot, he did not entrust the reins to any one of them, fearing that some inharmonious sort of management might be the result, but he made them all to depend upon himself, thinking that, by that arrangement, the character of their motion would be rendered most harmonious.
tgt_text.3349: For every thing which exists in combina­ tion with God is deserving of praise;
tgt_text.3350: but every thing which exists without him is faulty.
tgt_text.3352: This, then, is one of the systems, acccording to which what is said of the cherubim may be understood allegorically.
tgt_text.3353: But we must suppose that the sword, consisting of flame and always turning in every direction, intimates their motion and the everlasting agitation of the entire heaven.
tgt_text.3354: And may we not say, according to another way of understanding this alle­ gory, that the two cherubim are meant as symbols of each of the hemispheres ?
tgt_text.3355: For they say that they stand face to face.
tgt_text.3357: since the two hemispheres are also exactly opposite to one another, and incline towards the earth which is the centre of the whole universe, by which, also, they are kept apart from one another.
tgt_text.3358: But the only one of all the parts of the world that stands firmly was most appropriately named Vesta* by the ancients, in order that there might be an excellently arranged revolu­ tion of the two hemispheres around some object firmly fixed in the middle.
tgt_text.3359: And the flaming sword is a symbol of the sun ;
tgt_text.3360: for as he is a collection of an immense body of flame, he is the swiftest of all existing things, to such a degree that in one day he revolves round the whole world.
tgt_text.3362: I have also, on one occasion, heard a more ingenious train of reasoning from my own soul, which was accustomed frequently to be seized with a certain divine inspiration, even concerning matters which it could not explain even to itself;
tgt_text.3363: which now, if I am able to remember it accurately, I will relate.
tgt_text.3364: It told me that in the one living and true
tgt_text.3365: God there were two supreme and primary powers-goodness and authority ;
