tgt_text.4460: but they will benefit themselves very greatly by determining to become friends to God.XVII.
tgt_text.4461: I think, therefore, that enough has been now said with respect to those who appear to think that they do others good or harm.
tgt_text.4462: For it has been shown, that that which they think that they are doing to others, they in either case do to themselves.
tgt_text.4463: We will now examine the remainder of this event;
tgt_text.4467: To which answer is made, "I do not know;
tgt_text.4469: It is therefore worth while to con­ sider the question whether it can be appropriately said of God that he asks a question.
tgt_text.4470: For he who asks a question or puts an inquiry is asking or inquiring about something of which he is ignorant;
tgt_text.4471: seeking an answer through which he will know what he as yet does not know.
tgt_text.4472: But everything is known to God, not only all that is present, and all that is past, but also all that is to come.
tgt_text.4473: What need, then, has he of an answer which cannot give any additional knowledge to the questioner?
tgt_text.4474: But we must say that such things cannot properly be uttered by the Cause of all things, but that, as it is possible to say what is not true without lying, so it is possible for one to put a question or an interrogatory without either making inquiry or seeking for information. "
tgt_text.4475: Why, then," some one will say, " are such words spoken ?"
tgt_text.4476: In order that the soul which is about to give the answer may prove by itself what it answers correctly or incorrectly, having no one else either as an accuser or an adversary.
tgt_text.4477: Since, when he asks the wise man,
tgt_text.4478: Where is virtue ?t that is to say, when he asks Abraham, about Sarah, he asks, not because he is ignorant, but because he thinks that he ought to answer for the sake of eliciting praise from the answer of him who speaks.
tgt_text.4479: Accordingly, Moses tells us that Abraham answered, " Behold, she is in the tent ;
tgt_text.4480: " that is to say, in the soul.
tgt_text.4481: What then is there in this answer that contains praise ?
tgt_text.4482: Behold, says he, I keep virtue in my house as a treasure carefully stored up, and on account of this I am immediately happy.
tgt_text.4483: For it is the use and enjoyment of virtue that is happiness, and not the bare possession of it.
tgt_text.4484: But I should not be able to use it unless you, by letting down the seeds from heaven, had yourself made virtue pregnant;
tgt_text.4485: and unless she had brought forth the germs of happiness, namely, Isaac.
tgt_text.4486: And I consider that happiness is the employment of perfect virtue in a perfect life.
tgt_text.4487: In reference to which he, approving of his own determination, promises that he will complete perfectly all that he asked.
tgt_text.4489: To him therefore the answer brought praise, as he confessed that virtue without the divine favour was not sufficient of itself to help any one ;
tgt_text.4490: and, in consequence, it also brings blame to Cain, who says that he does not know where he is who has been treacherously slain by him.
tgt_text.4491: For he appears by this answer to be wishing to deceive his hearer, as one who does not see everything, and who has no previous suspicion of the deceit which he is about to use.
tgt_text.4492: But every one is wicked and worthy of proscription who thinks that the eye of God can ever fail to see anything.
tgt_text.4493: But Cain here speaks arrogantly, "Am I my brother's keeper?"
tgt_text.4494: For we might altogether say he was sure hereafter to lead a miser­ able life, if nature made you the guardian and keeper of so good a man.
tgt_text.4495: Do you not see that the lawgiver entrusts the keeping and preservation of the holy things not to any chance person, but to the Levites, who were the most holy persons in their opinions ?
tgt_text.4496: for whom the earth and the air and the water were considered an unworthy inheritance, but the heaven and the whole world were looked upon as their due.
tgt_text.4497: And the Creator alone is worthy of these things, to whom they have fled for refuge, becoming his sincere suppliants and servants, showing their love for their master in their continued service, and in the unhesitating observance of all the com­ mands which are laid upon them, and in the preservation of the things entrusted to them.
tgt_text.4499: And it has not fallen to the lot of all the suppliants to become guardians of the holy things, but to those only who have arrived at the number fifty, which proclaims remission of offences and perfect liberty, and a return to their ancient pos­ sessions.
tgt_text.4500: "For this," says the Scripture, "is the law concerning the Levites :
tgt_text.4501: from twenty-five years old and upwards, they shall go in to wait upon the service of the tabernacle of the congregation:
tgt_text.4502: and from the age of fifty years they shall cease waiting upon the service thereof, and shall serve no more;
tgt_text.4503: but shall minister with their brethren in the tabernacle of the con.
tgt_text.4504: gregation, and they shall keep what is to be kept, and shall do no service."*
tgt_text.4505: Therefore, the Scripture charges him who has half perfection (for the number fifty is perfect, and the number twenty-five is the half of fifty), to work and to do what is holy, approving his ministration by his works.
tgt_text.4506: And the beginning, as an old writer has said, is half of the whole.
tgt_text.4507: But the perfect man it does not enjoin to labour any longer, but only to preserve what he has acquired by labour and diligence.
tgt_text.4508: For may I never become a practiser of what I ought not to be a preserver;
tgt_text.4509: subsequently practice therefore is mediocrity not perfection, for it takes place not in perfect souls, but in such as are seeking after perfection.
tgt_text.4510: But it is the perfect duty of guardianship to deliver to memory the well-practised con­ templations of holy things, the excellent deposit of knowledge to a faithful guardian, who is the only one who disregards the ingenious and manifold nets of forgetfulness;
tgt_text.4511: so that the Scripture, with great propriety and felicity, calls him who is mindful of what he has learnt, the guardian of it.
tgt_text.4512: And such an one before he practised was a pupil, having another to teach him;
tgt_text.4513: but when he became competent himself to guard what he had learnt, he then received the power and rank of a teacher, having appointed his brother, his own uttered dis­ course, to the ministration of teaching.
tgt_text.4514: For it is said that, " His brother shall minister;
tgt_text.4515: " * so that the mind of the good man is the guardian and steward of the doctrines of virtue.
tgt_text.4516: But his brother, that is to say, uttered discourse, shall minister instead of him, going through all the doctrines and speculations of wisdom to those who are desirous of instruction.
tgt_text.4517: On which account Moses, also, in his praises of Levi, having previously said many admirable things, adds subsequently, " He has guarded thy oracles and kept thy cove­ nant." t
tgt_text.4518: And presently he continues, " They shall show thy justification to Jacob, and thy law to Israel.
tgt_text.4519: Therefore, he here clearly asserts that the good man is the guardian of the words and of the covenant of God.
tgt_text.4520: And, indeed, in another place he has shown that he is the best interpreter and declarer of his justifications and laws;
tgt_text.4521: the faculty of interpretation being displayed through its kindred organ-the voice, and guardianship being exerted through the mind, which having been made by nature as a great storehouse, easily contains the conceptions of all things, whether bodies or things.
tgt_text.4522: It would therefore have been worth the while of this self-loving Cain to have been the keeper of Abel;
tgt_text.4523: for if he had kept him he would have attained to a compounded and moderate kind of life, and would not have been filled with unmodified and absolute wickedness.
tgt_text.4527: The voice or the blood of thy brother cries out to me from out of the ground."*
tgt_text.4528: The expression, " What hast thou done," shows in­ dignation at an unhallowed action, and also ridicules the man who thought he had committed the murder secretly.
tgt_text.4529: The in­ dignation now arises at the intention of the man who has done the deed, because he designed to destroy what was good ;
tgt_text.4530: but the ridicule is excited by his thinking that he has plotted against one who is better than himself, and at his having plotted not so much against him as against himself.
tgt_text.4531: For, as I have said before, he who appears to be dead is alive, inasmuch as lie is found to be a suppliant of God and to utter a voice;
tgt_text.4532: and he who believes that he is still alive is dead, as to the death of the soul, inasmuch as he is excluded from virtue, according to which alone he is worthy to live.
tgt_text.4533: So that the expression, " What hast thou done?" is equivalent to, "Thou hast done nothing;
tgt_text.4534: thou hast done no good for thyself.
tgt_text.4535: "For neither was the sophist, Salaam, who was an empty mul­ titude of contrary and contending doctrines, when he was desirous to imprecate curses upon and to injure the good man, able to do so;
tgt_text.4536: since God turned his curses into a blessing, in order to correct the unjust man of wickedness and to display his own love of virtue.
tgt_text.4538: But it is the nature of sophists to have for enemies the faculties which are in them, while their language is at variance with their thoughts and their thoughts with their lan­ guage, and while neither is in the least degree consistent with the other.
tgt_text.4539: At all events, they wear out our ears, arguing that justice is a great bond of society, that temperance is a profitable thing, that continence is a virtuous thing, that piety is a most useful thing, and, of each other virtue, that it is a most wholesome and saving quality.
tgt_text.4540: And, on the other hand, that injustice is a quality with which we ought to have no truce, that intempe­ rance is a diseased habit, that impiety is scandalous, and so going through every kind of wickedness, that each sort is most pernicious.
tgt_text.4541: And, nevertheless, they never cease showing by their conduct that their real opinion is the reverse of their lan­ guage.
tgt_text.4542: But, when they extol prudence and temperance and justice and piety, they then show that they are, above all measure, foolish, and intemperate, and unjust, and impious ;
tgt_text.4543: in short, that they are throwing into confusion and overturning all divine and human regulations and principles.
tgt_text.4544: And to them, therefore, one may very properly say what the divine oracle said to Cain, " What is this that thou hast done ?"
tgt_text.4545: What good have ye done yourselves ?
tgt_text.4546: What have all these discourses about virtue profited your souls?
tgt_text.4547: In what particular of life, whether small or great, have ye done well ?
tgt_text.4549: Have you not, on the contrary, contributed to advancing true charges against yourselves ?
tgt_text.4550: because, by expressing your ap­ proval of what is good, and philosophising as far as words go, you have been excellent interpreters, but are nevertheless dis­ covered to be men who both think and practise shameful things.
tgt_text.4551: In fact, all good things are dead in your souls, these evils having been there kindled ;
tgt_text.4552: and, on this account there is no one of you who is really alive.
tgt_text.4553: For as, when some musician or grammarian is dead, the music and grammar which existed in them dies with them, but their ideas survive, and in a manner live as long as the world itself endures;
tgt_text.4554: according to which the existing race of men, and those who are to exist hereafter in continual succession, will, to the end of time, become skilful in music and grammar.
tgt_text.4555: Thus, also, if the prudence, or the temperance, or the 'courage, or the justice, or, in short, if the wisdom of any kind existing in any individual be destroyed, nevertheless the prudence existing in the nature of the immortal universe will still be im­ mortal ;
tgt_text.4556: and every virtue is erected like a pillar in imperish­ able solidity, in accordance with which there are some good people now, and there will be some hereafter.
tgt_text.4557: Unless, indeed, we should say that the death of any individual man is the de­ struction of humanity and of the human race, which, whether we ought to call it a genus, or a species, or a conception, or what­ ever else you please, those who are anxious about the investiga­ tion of proper names may determine.
tgt_text.4558: One seal has often stamped thousands upon thousands of impressions in infinite number, and though at times all those impressions have been effaced with the substances on which they were stamped, still the seal itself has remained in its pristine condition without being at all injured in its nature.
tgt_text.4559: Again, do we not think that the virtues, even if all the characters which they have impressed upon the souls of those who have sought them should become effaced by wicked living, or by any other cause, would never­ theless preserve their own unadulterated and imperishable nature ?
tgt_text.4560: Therefore, they who have not been duly initiated in instruction, not knowing anything about the differences between wholes and parts, or between genera and species, or about the homonymies which are incidental to these things, mix up all things together in a confused mass.
tgt_text.4561: On which account every one who is a lover of self, by surname Cain, should learn that he has destroyed the namesake of Abel, that is to say species, individuality, the image made according to the model;
tgt_text.4562: not the archetypal pattern, nor the genus, nor the idea, which he thinks are destroyed together with animals, though, in fact, they are indestructible.
tgt_text.4563: Let any one then say to him, reproving and ridiculing him, What is this that thou hast done, 0 wretched man ?
tgt_text.4564: Does not the God-loving opinion which you flatter yourself that you have destroyed, live in the presence of God ?
tgt_text.4565: But it is of yourself that you have become the murderer, by destroying from out of its seat the only quality by which you could live in a blameless manner.
tgt_text.4567: And what was said afterwards is uttered very beauti­ fully, with reference either to the beauty of the interpretation of which it is susceptible, or to the conception which may be dis­ covered in it.
tgt_text.4569: The voice of the blood of thy brother calls to me from out of the earth."
tgt_text.4570: This now, which is a very sublime expression if we regard the language in which it is couched, is intelligible to all those who are not utterly uninitiated in elo­ quence.
tgt_text.4571: But let us consider the ideas which are apparent in it as well as we are able.
tgt_text.4572: And first of all, let us consider what is said about the blood ;
tgt_text.4573: for in many places of the law as given by Moses, he pronounces the blood to be the essence of the soul or of life, saying dis­ tinctly, " For the life of all flesh is the blood thereof." *
tgt_text.4574: And when the Creator of all living things first began to make man, after the creation of the heaven and the earth, and all the things which are between the two, Moses says, " And he breathed into his face the breath of life, and man became a living soul," showing again by this expression that it is the breath which is the essence of the life.
tgt_text.4575: And, indeed, he is accustomed dili­ gently to record all the suggestions and purposes of God from the beginning, thinking it right to adopt his subsequent state­ ments to aid to make them consistent with his first accounts.
tgt_text.4576: Therefore, after he had previously stated the breath to be the essence of the life, he would not subsequently have spoken of the blood as occupying the most important place in the body, unless he had been making a reference to some very neces­ sary and comprehensive principle.
tgt_text.4577: What then are we to say ?
tgt_text.4578: The truth is, that every one of us according to the nearest estimation of numbers, is two persons, the animal and the man.
tgt_text.4579: And each of these two has a cognate power in the faculties, the seat of which is the soul assigned to it.
tgt_text.4580: To the one portion is assigned the vivifying faculty according to which we live;
tgt_text.4581: and to the other, the reasoning faculty in accordance with which we are capable of reasoning.
tgt_text.4582: Therefore, even the irrational animals partake of the vivifying power ;
tgt_text.4583: but of the rational faculty, God—I will not say partakes, but is the ruler, and that is the fountain of the most ancient Word.
tgt_text.4585: Therefore, the faculty which is common to us with the irrational animals, has blood for its essence.
tgt_text.4586: And it, having flowed from the rational fountain, is spirit, not air in motion, but rather a certain representation and character of the divine faculty which Moses calls by its proper name an image, showing by his language that God is the archetypal pattern of rational nature, and that man is the imitation of him, and the image formed after his model;
tgt_text.4587: not meaning by man that animal of a double nature, but the most excellent species of the soul which is called mind and reason.
tgt_text.4588: On this account, Moses represents God as calling the blood the life of the flesh, though he is aware that the nature of the flesh has no participation in intellect, but that it does partake of life, as also does our whole body.
tgt_text.4589: And the soul of man he names the spirit, meaning by the term man, not the compound being, as I said before, but that Godlike creation by which we reason, the roots of which he stretched to heaven, and fastened it to the outermost rim of the circle of those bodies which we call the fixed stars.
tgt_text.4590: For God made man, the only heavenly plant of those which he placed upon the earth, fastening the heads of the others in the mainland, for all of them bend their heads downwards * but the face of man he has exalted and directed upwards, that it might have its food of a heavenly and incorruptible nature, and not earthly and perishable.
tgt_text.4591: With a view to which, he also rooted in the earth the foundations of our body, removing the most insensible part of it as far as possible from reason;
tgt_text.4592: and the outward senses, which are as it were the body-guards of the mind, and the mind itself, he established at a great distance from the earth, and from all things con­ nected with it, and bound it with the periodical revolutions of the air and of the heavens, which are imperishable.
tgt_text.4594: Let us then no longer doubt, we who are the disciples of Moses, how man conceived an idea of God who is destitute of all figure, for he was taught the reason of this by the divine oracle, and afterwards he explained it to us.
tgt_text.4596: —" He said that the Creator made no soul in any body capable of seeing its Creator by its own intrinsic powers.
tgt_text.4597: But having considered that the knowledge of the Creator and the proper understanding of the work of Creation, would be of great advantage to the creature (for such knowledge is the boundary of happiness and blessedness), he breathed into him from above something of his own divine nature.
tgt_text.4598: And his divine nature stamped her own impression in an invisible manner on the invisible soul, in order that even the earth might not be destitute of the image of God.
tgt_text.4599: But the arche­ typal pattern was so devoid of all figure, that its very image was not visible, being indeed fabricated in accordance with the model, and accordingly it received not mortal but immortal conceptions.
tgt_text.4600: For how could a mortal nature at the same time remain where it was and also emigrate?
tgt_text.4601: or how could it see what was here and what was on the other side ?
tgt_text.4602: or how could it sail round the white sea, and at the same time traverse the whole earth to its furthest boundaries, and inspect the customs and laws of the nations on all the affairs and bodies which are in existence ?
tgt_text.4603: On separating them from the things of the earth, how could it arrive at a contemplation of the sublimer things of the air and its revolutions, and the peculiar character of its seasons, and all the things which at the periodical changes of the year are made anew.
tgt_text.4604: and, according to their usual habit, brought to perfection?
tgt_text.4605: Or again, how could it fly through the air from earth to heaven, and investigate the natures which exist in heaven, and see of what nature they are, how they are moved, what are the limits of their movements, of their be­ ginning and of their end ;
tgt_text.4606: how they are adapted to one another and to the universe according to the just principles of kindred ?
tgt_text.4607: Is it easy to have an accurate comprehension of the different arts and of the different branches of knowledge which bring ex­ ternal things into shape, and which are concerned with the affairs of the body and of the soul, with a view to the improve­ ment of the two, and to understand ten thousand other things.
tgt_text.4608: of which it is not easy to describe either the number or the nature in language ?
tgt_text.4609: For of all the faculties which exist in us, the mind alone, as being the most rapid in its motions of all, appears to be able to outrun and to pass by the time in which it originates, according to the invisible powers of the universe and of its parts existing without any reference to time, and touching the universe and its parts, and the causes of them.
tgt_text.4610: And now, having gone not only to the very boundaries of earth and sea, but also to those of air and heaven, it has not stopped even there, thinking that the world itself is but a brief limit for its continued and unremitting course.
tgt_text.4611: And it is eager to advance further;
tgt_text.4612: and, if it can possibly do so, to com­ prebend the incomprehensible nature of God, even if only as to its existence.
tgt_text.4613: How, then, is it natural that the human intellect, being as scanty as it is, and enclosed in no very ample space, in some membrane, or in the heart (truly very narrow bounds), should be able to embrace the vastness of the heaven and of the world, great as it is, if there were not in it some dortion of a divine and happy soul, which cannot be separated from it ?
tgt_text.4614: For nothing which belongs to the divinity can be cut off from it so as to be separated from it, but it is only extended.
tgt_text.4615: On which account the being which has had imparted to it a share of the perfection which is in the universe, when it arrives at a proper comprehension of the world, is extended in width simultaneously with the boundaries of the universe, and is incapable of being broken or divided ;
tgt_text.4616: for its power is ductile and capable of extension.
tgt_text.4618: Let this then be enough to say concisely about the essence of the soul.
tgt_text.4619: And now proceeding in regular order, we will explain the expression, that " the voice of his blood cries out," in this manner,-of our soul, one part is dumb, and one part is endowed with utterance.
tgt_text.4620: All that part which is devoid of reason is likewise destitute of voice, but all that part which is rational is capable of speech, and that part alone has formed any conception of God;
tgt_text.4621: for, by the other parts of us, we are not able to comprehend God, or any other object of the intel­ lect.
tgt_text.4622: Of our vivifying power, therefore, of which the blood is, as it were, the essence, one portion has particular honour, namely, that of speech and reason ;
tgt_text.4623: I do not mean the stream which flows through the mouth and tongue, but I speak of the fountain itself, from which the channels of utterance are, in the course of nature, filled.
tgt_text.4624: And this fountain is the mind;
tgt_text.4625: by means of which, all our conversations with and cries to the living God take place, at one time being voluntary, and at another involuntary.
tgt_text.4626: But he, as a good and merciful God, does not reject his suppliants, and most especially he does not, when they, groaning at the Egyptian deeds and passions, cry to him in sincerity and truth.
tgt_text.4627: For at such a time Moses says that, " their words go up to God,"* and that he listens to them, and delivers them from the evils that surround them.
tgt_text.4628: But that all these things should happen when the king of Egypt dies, should be a most strange thing ;
tgt_text.4629: for it would be natural that when the tyrant died, all those who have been tyrannised over by him should rejoice and exult;
tgt_text.4630: but at that time they are said to groan. "
tgt_text.4631: For after many days the king of Egypt died, and the children of Israel groaned."
tgt_text.4632: tNow here, if we look merely at the words, the expression does not appear to be reasonable ;
tgt_text.4633: but if we have regard to the faculties in the soul, then its consistency is discovered.
tgt_text.4634: For as long as he who scatters abroad and dissipates the opinions about good things, namely, Pharaoh, is vigorous in us, and appears in a sound and healthy state, if indeed we can say that any wicked man is in such a condition, we receive pleasure, driving temperance away from our borders.
tgt_text.4635: But when he loses his strength, and in a manner dies, he who has been the cause of men's living in a filthy and lascivious manner, then we, fixing our eyes on modesty of life, bewail and groan over our­ selves on account of our former way of living;
tgt_text.4636: because then, honouring pleasure before virtue, we joined a mortal life to an immortal one;
tgt_text.4637: and the law taking pity on our continued lamentation, gently receives our suppliant souls, and easily drives, away the Egyptian calamities which are brought upon them by the passions.
tgt_text.4639: But on him who is incapable of receiving repent­ ance on account of the enormity of the pollution which lie has incurred by the murder of his brother, namely, on Cain, he lays well-deserved and fitting curses;
tgt_text.4640: for in the first place he says to him, " And now, cursed art thou upon the earth:
tgt_text.4641: "* show­ ing first of all that he is polluted and accursed, not now for the first time when he has committed the murder, but that he was so before, the moment that he conceived the idea of it, the intention being of equal importance with the perfected action;
tgt_text.4642: for as long as we only conceive wicked things in the bad imagination of our minds, still, during that time, we are guilty of thoughts only, for the mind is capable of being changed even against its will;
tgt_text.4643: but when performance is added to the intention that has been conceived, then our deliberate purpose becomes also guilty;
tgt_text.4644: for this is the chief distinction between voluntary and involuntary sin.
tgt_text.4645: But the scripture here pronounces that the mind shall be accursed, not from anything else, but from the earth;
tgt_text.4646: for of all the most grievous calamities which can happen to it, the earthly portion which exists in each of us is found to be the cause.
tgt_text.4647: At all events, when the body is afflicted with disease, it adds the miseries which are derived from itself, and so fills the mind with grief and despondency;
tgt_text.4648: or, on the other hand, if it has grown fat immoderately through enjoyment of pleasures, it makes all the faculties of the mind duller for the comprehension of nobler objects.
tgt_text.4649: For, indeed, each of the outward senses is capable of re­ ceiving injury;
tgt_text.4650: for either a man beholding beauty is wounded by the darts of love, which is a terrible passion ;
tgt_text.4651: or else, per­ haps, if he hears of the death of any one related to him by birth, he is bowed down by sorrow:
tgt_text.4652: very often, too, taste gets the mastery of a man, when it is either tortured by disagree­ able flavours, or weighed down by the multitude of delicacies.
tgt_text.4653: And why need I speak of the impetuous passions, which tend to the connexion of the two sexes?
tgt_text.4654: These have destroyed whole cities, and countries, and mighty nations of the earth:
tgt_text.4655: to which fact nearly the whole multitude, both of poets and of historians, bears abundant testimony.
tgt_text.4657: And as to the manner in which the mind becomes accursed upon the earth, he adds further information imme­ diately afterwards, saying:
tgt_text.4658: " The earth which opened her mouth to receive the blood of thy brother."
tgt_text.4659: For it is very difficult for the mouths of the outward senses to be opened and widened, as even when they are not open the flood of the objects appreciable only by them rushes in like an overflowing river, nothing being capable of resisting their evident impetuosity;
tgt_text.4660: for then the mind is found to be overwhelmed, being wholly absorbed by so vast a wave, and being utterly unable to swim against it, or even to raise its head above it;
tgt_text.4661: but it is neces­ sary to employ all these things not so much for whatever objects can possibly be effected, but for those that are best;
tgt_text.4662: for the sight can perceive all colours and all shapes;
tgt_text.4663: but still it ought to behold only things worthy of light, and not of dark­ ness.
tgt_text.4664: Again, the ear can receive all kinds of sounds ;
tgt_text.4665: but some it ought to disregard;
tgt_text.4666: for myriads of the things that are said are disgraceful.
tgt_text.4667: Nor, 0 foolish and arrogant man, because nature has given you the faculty of taste, ought you to fill your­ self insatiably with everything, like a cormorant;
tgt_text.4668: for there are many things not merely among such as are nutritious, but of those which are exceedingly so, which have, nevertheless, produced diseases accompanied with great suffering.
tgt_text.4669: Nor does it follow that, because for the sake of the perpetua­ tion of your race you have been endowed with the powers of generation, you ought to pursue pollutions and adulteries and other impure connections;
tgt_text.4670: but only such as, in a legitimate manner, engender and propagate the race of mankind.
tgt_text.4671: Nor, because you have been made endowed with a mouth and a tongue and the organs of speech, ought you to say everything and to reveal what ought not to be spoken, for there are times when to hold one's peace is useful.
tgt_text.4672: And, in my opinion, these who have learnt to speak have also learnt to be silent, the same capacity teaching a man both lines of conduct.
tgt_text.4673: But those men who relate what they ought not, do not display the faculty of eloquence, but the weakness of their faculty of silence.
tgt_text.4674: On which account we labour to bind each of the mouthpieces of the senses before-mentioned with the im­ perishable bonds of temperance. "
tgt_text.4675: For whatever is not bound with a bond," says Moses, in another passage, "-is impure,"* as if'the cause of its unhappiness was the fact of the parts of the soul being relaxed and open and dissolved;
tgt_text.4676: but that the fact of their being compacted and tightly bound together con­ tributed to goodness and soundness of life and reason.
tgt_text.4677: He, therefore, curses the godless and impious Cain with deserved curses;
tgt_text.4678: because, having opened the caverns of this concrete creature, he opened his mouth for all external things, praying to receive them in an insatiable manner and to contain them, to the utter destruction of the God-loving doctrine, Abel.
tgt_text.4681: On this account shall he cultivate the earth ;
tgt_text.4682: 'Ϯ he does not say, " He shall become a farmer."
tgt_text.4683: For every farmer is an artist, because farming is an art.
tgt_text.4684: But any of the common people are cultivators of the earth, giving their service to provide themselves with necessaries, without any skill.
tgt_text.4685: These men, then, as they have no superintendent in all that they do, do much harm ;
tgt_text.4686: and whatever they do well they do by chance, and not in accordance with reason.
tgt_text.4687: But the works of farmers, which are performed according to knowledge, are all of them, of necessity, useful.
tgt_text.4688: On this account it is that the law-giver has attributed to the just Noah the employment of a farmer;
tgt_text.4689: ‡ showing by this that, like a good farmer, the virtuous man eradicates in the wild wood all the mischievous young saplings which have been planted by the passions or by the vices, but leaves untouched all those which bear fruit, and which may act instead of a wall and prove a firm defence for the soul.
tgt_text.4690: And, again, among the trees capable of cultivation he manages them in different ways, and not all in the same way:
tgt_text.4691: pruning some and adding props to others, training some so as to increase their size, and cutting down others so as to keep them dwarf.
tgt_text.4692: Again, when he sees a vine flourishing and luxuriant he bends down its young shoots to the ground, digging trenches to receive them, and again heaping up the ground on the top of them ;
tgt_text.4693: and they at no dis­ tant period, instead of parts, become whole trees, and instead of daughters they become mothers, having moreover put off the old age which is the usual companion of maternity.
tgt_text.4694: For, having desisted from distributing and apportioning its nourish­ ment amongst numerous offspring, inasmuch as they are able to support themselves, that which was previously weak from being drained by this cause becomes so fully satiated as to grow fat and young again.
tgt_text.4695: And I have seen another man who cut away the less de­ sirable shoots of trees which admitted of cultivation, as soon as they appeared above the ground, and left only a small piece adhering to the root itself.
tgt_text.4696: And then taking a branch in good condition from another tree of a good sort, he scraped away the one shoot down till he came to the pith, and the shoot which was attached to the root he cut at no great depth, but opening it just sufficiently to make the union perfect, and then putting into the cleft the shoot which he had pared away he fitted it in ;
tgt_text.4697: and from these two shoots one single tree of one united nature sprang up, each portion giving to the other that which was useful to it;
tgt_text.4698: for the roots support the shoot which has been fitted into them, and prevent it from drying up and withering, and the shoot which has been inserted as a reward for its nourishment supplies the root with good fruit in requital.
tgt_text.4699: There are also an innumerable host of other operations in farming which proceed on rules of art, which it would be superfluous to enumerate on the present occasion, for we have only dwelt on this point at such length for the purpose of showing the difference between the man who is only a cul­ tivator of the earth, and one who is a farmer.
tgt_text.4701: Accordingly the bad man never ceases from employ­ ing, without any of the principles of art, his earth-like body, and the outward senses which are akin to it, and all the external objects of these outward senses, and he injures his miserable soul, and he also injures what he fancies he is benefiting exceedingly, his own body.
tgt_text.4702: But the good man, for he has skill in the art of a farmer, manages the whole of his materials in accordance with the principles of art and reason ;
tgt_text.4703: for when the outward senses behave insolently, being borne forward with irresistible im­ petuosity towards the external objects of the outward senses, they are easily restrained by some contrivance among those which art has devised;
tgt_text.4704: but when an impetuous passion in the soul becomes violent, bringing forth voluptuous itchings and ticklings arising from pleasure or from appetite, or on the other hand, stings and agitation, caused by fear or grief, it is softened by the previously prepared saving medicine;
tgt_text.4705: and if any evil devouring as it goes, proceeds further, like a sister of the cancrous disease, which creeps over the body, it is cut out by reason which proceeds in its operations in accordance with knowledge.
tgt_text.4706: In this manner then the trees of the wild wood are brought into a state of tameness, but all the plants of the cultivated and fruit-bearing virtues have for their shoots studies, and for their fruits virtuous actions, of each of which the farming skill of the soul promotes the growth, and as far as depends upon it, it makes them immortal by its industry.
tgt_text.4708: Very clearly therefore is the good man thus shown to be a farmer, and the bad man to be only a cultivator of the land;
tgt_text.4709: and I wish that while he is thus cultivating the land, the earthly nature which environs him, bad imparted some vigour to him, and had not, as it has, taken away something of the power which he had before, for we read in the scripture, "It shall not add its strength to thee to give it to thee," and such would be the character of a man who was always eating or drinking and never satisfied, or who was incessantly in­ dulging in the pleasures of the belly, and devoting his energies to the gratifying of his carnal appetites, for deficiency produces weakness, but fulness produces strength ;
tgt_text.4710: but when, amid abundance of things an insatiability is united with excessive in­ temperance, that is hunger;
tgt_text.4711: and they are truly wretched whose bodies are filled, while their passions are empty and still thirsting;
tgt_text.4712: but of the lovers of knowledge the prophet speaks in a great song, and says, "That she has made them to ascend upon the strength of the earth, and has fed them upon the produce of the fields,"* showing plainly that the godless man fails in attaining his object, in order that he may grieve the more while strength is not added to these operations in which he expends his energies, but while on the other hand it is taken from them;
tgt_text.4713: but they who follow after virtue, placing it above all these things which are earthly and mortal, dis­ regard their strength in their exceeding abundance, using God as the guide to conduct them in their ascent, who proffers to them the produce of the earth for their enjoyment and most profitable use, likening the virtues to fields, and the fruits of the virtues to the produce of the fields, according to the prin­ ciples of their generation ;
tgt_text.4714: for from prudence is derived prudent action, and from temperance temperate action, and from piety pious conduct, and from each of the other virtues is derived the energy in accordance with it.
tgt_text.4716: Now these energies are especially the food of the soul, which is competent to give suck, as the lawgiver says, " Honey out of the rock, and oil out of the solid rock,"* mean­ ing by the solid rock which cannot be cut through, the wisdom of God, which is the nurse and foster-mother and educator of those who desire incorruptible food ;
tgt_text.4717: for it, as the mother of those things which exist in the world, immediately supplies food to those beings which are brought forth by her;
tgt_text.4718: but they are not all thought worthy of divine food, but only such are honoured with that as do not show any degeneracy from their parent;
tgt_text.4719: for there are many which a scarcity of virtue, which is more terrible than a scarcity of meat and drink, has de­ stroyed ;
tgt_text.4720: but the fountain of divine wisdom is borne along, at one time in a more gentle and moderate stream, and at another with greater rapidity and a more exceeding violence and impetuosity.
tgt_text.4721: When, therefore, it descends gently it sweetens after the manner of honey, but when it comes on swiftly the whole material enters like oil into the light of the soul.
tgt_text.4722: This rock, Moses, in another place, using a synonymous expression, calls manna the most ancient word of God, by which appellation is understood, something of the most ge­ neral possible nature, from which two cakes are made, one of honey and the other of oil, that is to say, two different sys­ tems of life, exceedingly difficult to distinguish from one another, both worthy of attention, at the very beginning instilling the sweetness of these contemplations which exist in the sciences, and again emitting the most brilliant light to those who take hold of the things which are the objects of their desire, not fastidiously, but firmly, and scarcely by means of unremitting and incessant perseverance.
tgt_text.4723: These then, as I have said before, are they who ascend up upon the strength of the earth.
tgt_text.4725: But to the impious Cain, neither does the earth contribute anything to give him vigour, even though he never concerns himself about anything which is exterior to it;
tgt_text.4726: on which account, in the next sentence, he is found " groaning and trembling upon the earth,"* that is to say, under the in­ fluence of grief and terror ;
tgt_text.4727: and such also is the miserable life of a wicked man, who has received for his inheritance the most painful of the four passions, pain and terror;
tgt_text.4728: the one being equivalent to groaning, and the other to trembling;
tgt_text.4729: for it is inevitable, that some evil should either be present to or impending over such a man.
tgt_text.4730: Now the expectation of im­ pending evil causes fear, but the suffering of present evil causes pain.
tgt_text.4731: On the other hand, he who pursues virtue is found to be in the enjoyment of corresponding blessings;
tgt_text.4732: for either he has acquired what is good or he will attain to it.
tgt_text.4733: Now the present possession perfects joy, which is the best of all pos­ sessions ;
tgt_text.4734: but the expectation of possessing it brings hope, the food of those souls which love virtue ;
tgt_text.4735: on account of which, putting away sluggishness, we, with spontaneous readiness, hasten onwards to good actions.
tgt_text.4736: From that soul therefore, in which justice has brought forth a male offspring, that is to say just thoughts, it has also at the same time removed all pain­ ful things, and the birth of Noah will bear testimony in con­ firmation of this, and the interpretation of the name of Noah is just;
tgt_text.4737: and of him it is said, " he will make us to rest from our works, and from the labours of our hands, and from the earth, which the Lord God has cursed ;
tgt_text.4738: "t for it is the nature of justice in the first place to cause rest instead of labour, being utterly indifferent to the things that are in the confines between wickedness and virtue, riches and glory, and power and honour, and all other things which are akin to these, which are the chief objects of the energies of the human race.
tgt_text.4739: And, in the second place, to destroy those pains which exist in accordance with our own energies;
tgt_text.4740: for Moses does not (as some wicked men do) say.
tgt_text.4741: that God is the cause of evils, but our own hands;
tgt_text.4742: indicating, by a figurative expression, the works of our hands, and the voluntary inclinations of our mind to the worser part.
tgt_text.4744: Last of all, Noah is said " to comfort us concern­ ing our work, because of the ground which the Lord God hath cursed."*
tgt_text.4745: But by this is meant wickedness, which is esta­ blished in the souls of foolish men;
tgt_text.4746: the remedy for which (as one seeks for remedies for a severe disease) is found to be the just man, who is in possession of the panacea, justice.
tgt_text.4747: When, therefore, he has repelled these evils he is filled with joy, as also is Sarah :
tgt_text.4748: for she says, " The Lord hath caused me laughter;
tgt_text.4749: " and she adds further, Iso that whosoever hears it shall rejoice with me. "†
tgt_text.4750: For God is the author of virtuous laughter and joy ;
tgt_text.4751: so that we must look upon Isaac not as the offspring of creation, but as the work of the uncreate God.
tgt_text.4752: For if Isaac, being interpreted, means laughter, and if it be God who is the cause of laughter according to the true testi­ mony of Sarah, then he may be most properly said to be the father of Isaac.
tgt_text.4753: And he also gives a share to Abraham of his own proper appellation, to whom, when he eradicated pain from wisdom, he gave rejoicing as an offspring.
tgt_text.4754: If, therefore, any one is worthy to listen to the account of the creative power of God he is of necessity joyful, and rejoices in company with those who have had a longing to hear the same.
tgt_text.4755: And in the account of the creative power of God you will find no cunningly devised fable, but only unalloyed laws of truth firmly established.
tgt_text.4756: Moreover, you will find no vocal measures or rhythm, no melodies alluring the hearing with musical art;
tgt_text.4757: but only most perfect works of virtue, which have all of them a peculiar har­ mony and fitness.
tgt_text.4758: And as the mind rejoices which is eager to hear of the works of God, so also does language, which is in harmony with the conceptions of the mind, and which in a manner is compelled to attend to them, feel exultation.
tgt_text.4760: And this will also be proved by the oracle which was given to the all-wise Moses, in which these words are con­ tained :
tgt_text.4761: " Behold, is there not Aaron thy brother, the Levite?
tgt_text.4762: I know that he will speak for thee;
tgt_text.4763: and behold he will be coming forth to meet thee, and he will rejoice in himself when he seeth thee. "‡
tgt_text.4764: For here the Creator says, that he knows that uttered speech is a burden to the mind, because it speaks ;
tgt_text.4765: for he represents it, that is to say, articulate sound, as the organ, as it were, of all this concrete being of ours.
tgt_text.4766: This speech speaks, and discourses, and interprets both in your case and mine, and in that of all mankind, the things conceived in the mind, and it moreover comes forward to meet the things - which the mind conceives;
tgt_text.4767: for when the mind being excited towards any object connected with it receives an impetus, either because it has been moved internally by itself, or because it has received some remarkable impressions from external circum­ stances, it then becomes pregnant and labours to bring forth its conceptions.
tgt_text.4768: And, though it tries to deliver itself of them, it is unable to do so till sound, like a midwife, acting either through the medium of the tongue or of some other of the organs of speech, receives those conceptions and brings them to light.
tgt_text.4769: And this voice is itself the most manifest of all the conceptions.
tgt_text.4770: For, as what is laid up is hidden in darkness until light shines upon it and exhibits it, in the same manner the conceptions are stored away in an invisible place, namely, the mind, until the voice, like light, sheds its beams upon them and reveals everything.
tgt_text.4772: Very beautifully, therefore, was it said that speech goes forth to meet the conceptions, and that it runs on endea­ vouring to overtake them, from its desire of giving information respecting them, for everything has the greatest affection for its own proper employment;
tgt_text.4773: and the proper employment of speech is to speak, to which employment therefore it hastens by a kind of natural kindred and propriety.
tgt_text.4774: And it rejoices and exults when, shedding its rays upon it as it were, it accu­ rately sees and overtakes the sense of the matter exhibited ;
tgt_text.4775: for then, seizing it in its embrace, it becomes its most excellent interpreter.
tgt_text.4776: At all events, we repudiate those chatterers and interminable talkers, who, in the long passages of their con­ versations, do not properly keep to their conceptions, but merely connect long and empty and, to say the truth, lifeless sentences.
tgt_text.4777: Therefore the conversation of such men as these is inde­ corous, and is justly condemned to groan;
tgt_text.4778: as, on the other hand, it is inevitable that that conversation which proceeds from a proper consideration of the objects of its consideration must rejoice, since it comes in an adequate manner to the in­ terpretation of the things which it saw and comprehended vigorously;
tgt_text.4779: and this is a matter within the knowledge of almost every one from his daily experience.
tgt_text.4780: For, when we thoroughly understand what we are saying, then our speech rejoices and exults, and is rich in most emphatic and appropriate expres­ sions, with which, using great copiousness and fluency of un­ hesitating diction, it sets before the hearer what it desires to exhibit to him in a most evident and efficient manner.
tgt_text.4781: But when the comprehension of the conceptions is doubtful, then the speech stumbles and exhibits a great deficiency of suitable and felicitous expressions, and speaks very inappropriately;
tgt_text.4782: on which account it is tedious and wearisome and wanders about, and instead of persuading its hearers it pains their ears.
tgt_text.4784: Again, it is not every speech which should come forward to meet the conceptions;
tgt_text.4785: nor is it every kind of con­ ception that it should come to meet;
tgt_text.4786: but only the perfect Aaron who should come forward to meet the conceptions of the most perfect Moses.
tgt_text.4787: Since else why, when God had said, " Behold, is not Aaron thy brother ?" did he add, " the Levite," if it were not for the sake of teaching that it belongs to the Levite and priest, and to virtuous speech alone, to give inform­ ation respecting the conceptions of the mind, which are shoots of the perfect soul.
tgt_text.4788: For never may the speech of a wicked man be interpreter of divine doctrines, for such an one would deform their beauty by his own pollutions;
tgt_text.4789: and, on the other hand, may what is intemperate and disgraceful never be related by the utterance of a virtuous man, but may sacred and holy conversations always deliver the relation of holy things.
tgt_text.4790: In some of the best governed cities of the world they say that such a custom as this prevails.
tgt_text.4791: When any man who has not lived well attempts to deliver his opinion, either in the council or in the assembly of the people, he is not permitted to do so by his own mouth, but is compelled by the magistrates to deliver his opinion to some virtuous and honourable man to explain in his behalf;
tgt_text.4792: and then he, when he has heard what he wishes said, rises up and unfolds the meaning of the sewn up mouth of his instructor, becoming his extempore pupil;
tgt_text.4793: and he displays the imaginations of another, scarcely consider­ ing the original concern of them even in the rank of a hearer or spectator.
tgt_text.4794: So some people do not choose to receive even benefits from unworthy persons, but look upon the injury accruing from the shame of taking their advice as greater than the.
tgt_text.4795: advantage which can be derived from it.
tgt_text.4797: This lesson the most holy Moses appears to teach;
tgt_text.4798: for such is the object of the statement that Aaron the Levite is coming forward to meet his brother Moses, and that when he sees him he rejoices in himself;
tgt_text.4799: and the statement that he rejoices in himself shows also, besides the doctrine which has already been mentioned, another more connected with politics, since the lawgiver is here exhibiting that genuine joy which is most especially akin to the human race;
tgt_text.4800: for to speak strictly, the feeling of joy does not belong to abundance of money, or of possessions, or to brilliancy of renown, nor, in short, to any one of those external circumstances which are lifeless and unstable, and which contain the seeds of their decay in themselves:
tgt_text.4801: nor yet does it belong to personal strength and vigour, and to the other advantages of the body, which are common to even the most worthless men, and which have often brought inevitable destruction on those who pos­ sessed them.
tgt_text.4802: Since then it is only in the virtues of the soul that genuine and unadulterated joy is found, and since every wise man rejoices, he rejoices in himself, and not in his surrounding circumstances ;
tgt_text.4803: for the things that are in himself are the virtues of the mind on which it is worthy for a man to provide him­ self :
tgt_text.4804: but the circumstances which surround him are either a good condition of body or an abundance of external wealth, which are not proper objects for a man to pride himself on.
tgt_text.4806: Having shown, therefore, as far as we could by the most unmistakeable testimony of Moses that, to rejoice is the peculiar property of the wise man, we will now also show that to hope also belongs to him alone;
tgt_text.4807: and here again we shall have no need of any other witness than Moses ;
tgt_text.4808: for he tells us that the name of the son of Seth was Enos :
tgt_text.4809: and Enos, being interpreted, means hope. " He hoped first," says Moses, "to call upon the name of the Lord his God."*
tgt_text.4811: for to a man inspired with the principles of truth what can be more akin and appropriate than a hope and expectation of the acquisition of good things from the one bounteous God ?
tgt_text.4812: This, if one must speak the plain truth, is, properly speaking, the only real birth of men, as those who do not hope in God have no share in rational nature.
tgt_text.4813: On which account Moses, after he had previously mentioned with respect to Enos that " he hoped to call upon the name of the Lord his God," adds in express words, " This is the book of the generation of men;
tgt_text.4815: for it is written in the book of God that man is the only creature with a good hope.
tgt_text.4816: So that arguing by contraries, he who has no good hope is not a man.
tgt_text.4817: The definition, therefore, of our concrete being is that it is a living rational mortal being ;
tgt_text.4818: but the defi­ nition of man, according to Moses, is a disposition of the soul hoping in the truly living God.
tgt_text.4819: Let good men, then, by all means having received joy and hope for their blessed inheritance, either possess or expect good things :
tgt_text.4820: but let bad men, of whom Cain is a companion, living in fear and pain, reap a harvest of a most bitter portion, namely, either the presence or the expectation of evils, groan­ ing over the miseries which are actually oppressing them, and trembling and shuddering at the expected fearful dangers.
tgt_text.4822: However, we have now said enough on this sub­ ject, and let us proceed to investigate what comes afterwards.
tgt_text.4824: " And Cain said unto the Lord, My crime is too great to be forgiven."t
tgt_text.4825: Now what is meant by this will be shown by a consideration of simple passages.
tgt_text.4826: If a pilot were to desert his ship when tossed about by the sea, would it not follow of necessity that the ship would wander out of her course in the voyage ?
tgt_text.4828: If a cha­ rioteer in the contest of the horse-race were to quit his chariot, is it not inevitable that the course of the free horses would be disorderly and irregular ?
tgt_text.4829: Again, when a city is left destitute of rulers or of laws, and laws, undoubtedly, are entitled to be classed on an equality with magistrates, must not that city be destroyed by those greatest of evils, anarchy and lawlessness ?
tgt_text.4830: And in the same manner, by the ordinances of nature, the body must perish if the soul be absent;
tgt_text.4831: and the soul, if reason be absent.
tgt_text.4832: Reason, too, must be destroyed by the absence of virtue.
tgt_text.4833: But if each of these things is such an injury to the things that are abandoned by them, then how great must we consider is the misfortune of those persons who are abandoned by God ?
tgt_text.4834: Whom he has rejected as deserters from his band :
tgt_text.4835: and put out of the pale of his sacred laws, considering them them unworthy of his superintendence and governmerit.
tgt_text.4836: For we must absolutely be certain that a person who is deserted by his superior and benefactor is guilty of great crimes and liable to severe accusations.
tgt_text.4837: For when would you say that a man destitute of skill is most greatly injured ?
tgt_text.4838: Would it not be when he is utterly abandoned by knowledge ?
tgt_text.4839: And when would you say that the ignorant and wholly uninstructed man is most injured ?
tgt_text.4840: Must it not be when instruction and educa­ tion complete their desertion of him?
tgt_text.4841: When again do we most deplore the condition of the foolish ?
tgt_text.4842: Is it not when prudence has utterly rejected them ?
tgt_text.4843: And when do we pro­ nounce intemperate or unjust men, miserable?
tgt_text.4844: Is it not when temperance and justice have condemned them to an eternal banishment from their dominion ?
tgt_text.4845: When do we pro­ nounce the impious, wretched ?
tgt_text.4846: Is it not when piety has cut them off from her peculiar rites ?
tgt_text.4847: So that it seems to me that those who are not utterly impure should pray to be chastised and rejected rather than deserted ;
tgt_text.4848: for desertion will most easily ruin them, as vessels without ballast and without a pilot;
tgt_text.4849: but correction will set them right again.
tgt_text.4850: Are not those boys who are beaten by their preceptors, for whatever errors they commit, better than those who have no schoolmaster ?
tgt_text.4851: And are not those who are reproved by their teachers, for all the errors they commit in the arts which they are studying, better than those who receive no such reproof?
tgt_text.4852: And are not those young men who have been accounted especially worthy of that natural superintendence and government, which those who are parents exercise over their children, more fortunate and better than those who have had no such protectors?
tgt_text.4853: And if they have not such natural protectors, do they not receive guardians as governors in a secondary rank, who are accus­ tomed to be appointed over them out of pity for their orphan state;
tgt_text.4854: to fill the place of parents to them in all things that are expedient ?XL.
tgt_text.4855: Let us, therefore, address our supplications to God, we who are self-convicted by our consciousness of our own sins, to chastise us rather than to abandon us;
tgt_text.4856: for if he abandons us, he will no longer make us his servants, who is a merciful master, but slaves of a pitiless generation :
tgt_text.4857: but if he chastises us in a gentle and merciful manner, as a kind ruler, he will correct our offences, sending that correcting conviction, his own word, into our hearts, by means of which he will heal them;
tgt_text.4858: reproving us and making us ashamed of the wicked­ nesses which we have committed.
tgt_text.4859: On this account the law­ giver says, " Every word which a widow or a woman who is divorced vows against her own soul shall remain against it."*
tgt_text.4861: God the husband and father of the universe, supplying the origin and generation of all things, we shall be speaking rightly :
tgt_text.4862: as we shall if we call that heart widowed and divorced from God which either has not received divine seed, or, after having received it, has again voluntarily made it abortive.
tgt_text.4863: Therefore every thing which it decides it shall decide against itself:
tgt_text.4864: and these things shall remain utterly incurable.
tgt_text.4865: For how can it be anything but a most intolerable evil, for a creature which is inconstant and easily moved in every direction, to lay down any positive decision and determination about itself, attributing to itself the virtues of the Creator ?
tgt_text.4866: One of which is that, according to which, it defines in an unhesitating and unalterable manner.
tgt_text.4867: Therefore, not only shall it be widowed of knowledge, but it shall likewise be divorced from it.
tgt_text.4868: And the meaning of this expression is as follows :
tgt_text.4870: For the soul which is widowed of, but is not yet divorced from, what is good, is able, in a manner, after long perseverance, to come to a reconciliation and agreement with her lawful husband, right-reason.
tgt_text.4871: But the soul which has once been utterly separated from it, and which has been removed to a different abode, has been cast out for ever and ever, as utterly incapable of reconciliation or peace, and is entirely unable to return to its previous habitation.
tgt_text.4873: This, then, may be enough to say about the ex­ pression, " My crime is too great to be forgiven."
tgt_text.4874: †Let us now consider what follows that verse .—" Cain says, "
tgt_text.4875: But if thou castest me out this day from off the face of the earth, and from thy face I shall be hidden." ‡
tgt_text.4876: What sayest thou, my good man ?
tgt_text.4877: If thou art utterly cast out from the whole earth, shall you still be hidden ?
tgt_text.4879: For shall you be able to live ?
tgt_text.4880: or are you ignorant of this, that nature has given animals different places to live in, and has not assigned the same place to them all ?
tgt_text.4881: She has allotted the sea to the fishes, and to the whole race of aquatic animals, and the land to all the terrestrial animals.
tgt_text.4882: And man too, according, at least, to the composite nature of his body, is a terrestrial animal.
tgt_text.4883: And it is owing to this that all animals easily die when they have quitted the place which properly belongs to them, and have gone, as it were, into a foreign coun­ try ;
tgt_text.4884: as, for instance, when terrestrial animals go under the water, or when aquatic animals have sailed out upon the land.
tgt_text.4885: If, therefore you, being a man, should be cast out from the land, whither will you turn ?
tgt_text.4886: Will you dive under water, imitating the nature of aquatic animals ?
tgt_text.4887: TInt you will die the moment that you are underneath the water.
tgt_text.4888: Or will you take wings and raise yourself aloft, and so attempt to traverse the regions of the air, changing your character of a terrestrial, for that of a flying animal ?
tgt_text.4889: But, if it is in your power, change and re-fashion the divine impress that you bear.
tgt_text.4891: For in proportion as you raise yourself to a greater height, so much the more rapidly will you descend from that higher region and with the greater impetuosity to the earth, which is your appropriate place.
tgt_text.4893: Can a man, then, or any other created animal, hide himself from God ?
tgt_text.4895: Where can he hide himself from that being who pervades all places, whose look reaches to the very boundaries of the world, who fills the whole universe, of whom not even the smallest portion of existing things is deficient ?
tgt_text.4896: And what is there extraordi nary in the fact, that it is not practicable for any created being to conceal himself from the living God, when it is not even in his power to escape from all the material elements by which he is surrounded, but he must, if he abandon me, by that very act enter into another ?
tgt_text.4897: At all events, if the Creator, employ­ ing that act by which he created amphibious animals, had chosen also by the same act to create a new animal, one capa­ ble of living in any element, then, this animal, if it forsook the weighty elements of earth and water, would necessarily have gone to those which are naturally light, namely, air and fire.
tgt_text.4898: And, on the other hand, supposing that it had originally dwelt among those elements whose place is on high, if it had sought to effect a migration from them, it would have changed to the opposite region;
tgt_text.4899: for it was at all events necessary for it to appear steadily in one portion of the world, since it was not possible for it to run away out of every element;
tgt_text.4900: since, in order that nothing external might be omitted, the Creator scattered the whole of the four principles of everything over the universe, in order to create the existing* condition of the world, in order to make a most perfect universe of perfect parts.
tgt_text.4901: As therefore it is impossible for any one to escape from the whole of the creation of God, how can it be anything but still more impossible to escape from the Creator and Ruler him­ self?
tgt_text.4902: Let no one therefore too easily receiving these words in their obvious and literal acceptation without examination, affix his own simplicity and folly to the law;
tgt_text.4903: but let him rather consider what is here enigmatically intimated by figurative ex­ pressions, and so understand the truth.
tgt_text.4905: Perhaps now that which is intimated by the expres­ sion, "If thou castest me out this day from off the face of the earth, from thy face I shall be hidden," may be this, if thou dost not bestow on me the good things of the earth, I will not receive those of Heaven;
tgt_text.4906: and if no use and enjoyment of pleasure is afforded me, I have no desire for virtue, and if thou dost not allow me to participate in human advantages, thou mayest retain the divine ones to thyself.
tgt_text.4907: Now the things which among us are accounted necessary and valuable and genuine real goods are these;
tgt_text.4908: to eat, to drink, to be clothed in various colours and fashions ;
tgt_text.4909: by means of the faculty of sight, to be delighted with pleasant sights;
tgt_text.4910: by means of one's faculty of hearing to be delighted with melodies of all sorts of sounds;
tgt_text.4911: to be gratified through our nostrils with fragrant exhalations of odours;
tgt_text.4912: to indulge in all the pleasures of the belly and of the parts adjacent to the belly to satiety ;
tgt_text.4913: not to be indifferent to the acquisition of silver and gold;
tgt_text.4914: to be invested with honours and post of authority, and all other things which may tend to man's reputation;
tgt_text.4915: but as for prudence, or fortitude, or justice, austere dispositions which only make life laborious, those we pass by, and if we are forced to admit them into one calculation we must do so, not as perfect goods in themselves, but only as efficieuts of good.
tgt_text.4916: Do you therefore, 0 ridiculous man, affirm that if you are deprived of a superfluity of bodily advantages and external good things, you will not come into the sight of God?
tgt_text.4917: But I tell you that even if you are so deprived of them, you will by all means come into his sight;
tgt_text.4918: for when you have been released from the unspeakable bonds of the body and around the body, you will attain to an imagination of the uncreated God.XL VI.
tgt_text.4919: Do you not see in the case of Abraham that, "when he had left his country, and his kindred, and his father's house,''* that is to say, the body, the outward senses, and reason, he then began to become acquainted with the powers of the living God?
tgt_text.4920: for when he had secretly departed from all his house, the law says that, " God appeared unto him, "† showing that he is seen clearly by him who has put off mortal things, and who has taken refuge from this body in the'in­ corporeal soul;
tgt_text.4921: on which account Moses taking his tent " pitches it without the tabernacle, "‡ and settles to dwell at a distance from the bodily camp, for in that way alone could he hope to become a worthy suppliant and a perfect minister before God.
tgt_text.4922: And he says that this tent was called the tent of testimony, taking exceeding care that it may really be the tabernacle of the living God, and may not be called so only.
tgt_text.4923: For of virtues, the virtues of God are founded in truth, existing according to his essence :
tgt_text.4925: God alone exists in essence, on account of which fact, he speaks of necessity about himself, saying, " I am that I am,"§ as if those who were with him did not exist according to essence, but only appeared to exist in opinion.
tgt_text.4926: But the tent of Moses being symbolically considered, the virtue of man shall be thought worthy of appellation, not of real existence, being only an imitation, a copy made after the model of that divine tabernacle, and consistent with these facts is the circumstance that Moses when he is appointed to be the God of Pharaoh, was not so in reality, but was only conceived of as such in opinion, " for I know that it is God who gives and bestows favours, but I am not able to perceive that he is given, and it is said in the sacred scriptures, " I give thee as a God to Pharaoh," and yet what is given is the patient, not the agent;
tgt_text.4927: but he that is truly living must be the agent, and beyond all question cannot be the patient.
tgt_text.4928: What then is inferred from these facts ?
tgt_text.4929: Why, that the wise man is called the God of the foolish man, but he is not God in reality, just as a base coin of the apparent value of four drachmas is not a four drachma piece.
tgt_text.4930: But when he is compared with the living God, then lie will be found to be a man of God;
tgt_text.4931: but when he is compared with a foolish man, he is accounted a God to the imagination and in appearance, but he is not so in truth and essence.
tgt_text.4933: Why then do you talk nonsense, saying, " If thou castest me forth from off the earth, and from thee I shall be hidden."
tgt_text.4934: For one might say on the contrary, if I remove thee from the earth by part of thee, then I will manifestly show thee my own image.
tgt_text.4935: And a proof of this is, thou wilt depart from before the face of God, but when thou hast departed thou wilt not the less inhabit thy earthly body.
tgt_text.4936: For Moses says, after­ wards, " And Cain went forth from before the face of God and dwelt in the earth," * so that when thou art cast out from the earth, thou art not hidden from the living God ;
tgt_text.4937: but when thou desertest him thou takest refuge on earth in a mortal country.
tgt_text.4938: And indeed it will not be the case, that every one who findeth thee will hide thee, as thou sayest, speaking sophistically.
tgt_text.4939: For that which is found, is found in every case by two people, by one who resembles itself, or by one who is dissimilar.
tgt_text.4940: By one who resembles itself according to the kindred and relationship which exists in all things, and by him who is not like, according to the contrary unlikeness.
tgt_text.4941: The one, therefore, that is like, endeavours to preserve that which resembles itself, and that which is dissimilar endeavours to destroy that which differs from it.
tgt_text.4942: And let them know that Cain, and all other wicked men will not be slain by any one who meets them, but that evil doers imitating their kindred and connected wickednesses, will become guardians and pre­ servers of them;
tgt_text.4943: but all those who have cultivated prudence or any other virtue, will destroy them if they can, as irrecon­ cileable enemies.
tgt_text.4944: For, in short, all bodies and all things are preserved by the things which are akin to and attached to them, but are destroyed by those that are alien and hostile to them.
tgt_text.4945: On this account, also, the oracle which bears testimony against this pretended simplicity of Cain, says, " You do not think as you say "
tgt_text.4946: For you say, indeed, that whosoever finds out the devices of your act will slay you.
tgt_text.4947: But you know that it is not every one who will do so, as there are millions of men enrolled in your alliance;
tgt_text.4948: but he only who is a friend to virtue and an irreconcileable enemy to you.
tgt_text.4949: And God says, he " who slays Cain shall suffer sevenfold."
tgt_text.4950: But I do not know what analogy this real meaning of this expression bears to the literal inter­ pretation of it, " He shall suffer sevenfold.
tgt_text.4951: For he has not said what is to be sevenfold, nor has he described the sort of penalty, nor by what means such penalty is excused or paid.
tgt_text.4953: Therefore, one must suppose that all these things are said figuratively and allegorically;
tgt_text.4954: and perhaps what God means to set before us here is something of this sort.
tgt_text.4955: The irrational part of the soul is divided into seven parts, the senses of seeing, of smelling, of hearing, of tasting, and of touch, the organs of speech, and the organs of generation.
tgt_text.4956: If, therefore, any one were to slay the eighth, that is to say, Cain, the ruler of them all, he would also paralyse all the seven.
tgt_text.4957: For they are all con­ firmed by the vigorous strength of the mind, and they all feel weak simultaneously with any weakness exhibited by the mind, and they all endure relaxation and complete dissolution in consequence of the destruction which complete wickedness brings upon them.
tgt_text.4958: Now these seven senses are unpolluted and pure in the soul of the wise man, and here also they are found worthy of honour.
tgt_text.4959: But in that of the foolish man they are impure and polluted, and as I said before, punished, that is, they are worthy of punishment and chastisement.
tgt_text.4960: At all events, when the Creator determined to purify the earth by means of water, and that the soul should receive purification of all.
tgt_text.4961: its unspeakable offences, having washed off and effaced its pollutions after the fashion of a holy purification, he recommended him who was found to be a just man, who was not borne away by the violence of the deluge, to enter into the ark, that is to say, into the vessel containing the soul, namely, the body, and to lead into it " seven of all clean beasts, male and female," * thinking it proper that virtuous reason should employ all the pure parts of the irrational portion of man.
tgt_text.4963: And this injunction which the lawgiver laid down, is of necessity applicable to all wise men;
tgt_text.4964: for they have their sense of sight purified, their sense of hearing thoroughly ex­ amined, and so on with all the rest of their outward senses.
tgt_text.4965: Accordingly, they have the faculty of speech free from all spot or stain, and their appetites which prompt them to indulge the passions in a state of due subjection to the law.
tgt_text.4966: And every one of the seven outward senses is in one respect male, and in another, female.
tgt_text.4967: For when they are stationary, or when it is in motion, they are stationary while quiescent in sleep, and they are in motion while they are energising in their waking state;
tgt_text.4968: and the one in accordance with habit and tranquillity, as being subject to passion, is called the female;
tgt_text.4969: and the one which exists according to motion and energy, as one that is only conceived in action, is called the male.
tgt_text.4970: Thus, in the wise man, the seven senses appear to be pure;
tgt_text.4971: and on the contrary in the wicked man, they appear to be all liable to punishment.
tgt_text.4972: For how great a multitude of things do we imagine to be each day wrongly represented by our eyes, which go over to colours and shapes, and to things which it is not lawful to see ?
tgt_text.4973: And how so great a multitude of things suffer similar treatment from the ears which follow all kinds of sounds ?
tgt_text.4974: How many too are misrepresented by the organs of smelling and of taste, and by flavours and vapours, and' other things led on according to innumerable variations?
tgt_text.4975: I say nothing of that multitude of persons whom the unrestrainable impetuosity of an unbridled tongue has destroyed, or the in­ curable violence which leads man on to carnal connections with intemperate appetite.
tgt_text.4976: Cities are full, and all the earth from one side to the other, is full of these evils, in consequence of which, continual and unceasing and terrible wars are set on foot among men, even in times of peace, both publicly and privately.
tgt_text.4978: On which account it appears to me that all men who are not utterly uneducated would choose to be mutilated and to become blind, rather than to see what is not fitting to be seen, to become deaf rather than to hear pernicious dis­ courses, and to have their tongues cut out if that were the only way to prevent their speaking things, which ought not to be spoken.
tgt_text.4979: At all events, they say that some wise men, when they have been tortured on the wheel to make them betray secrets which are not worthy to be divulged, have bitten out their tongues, and so have inflicted on their torturers a more grievous torture than they themselves were suffering, as they could not learn from them what they desired;
tgt_text.4980: and it is better to be made an eunuch than to be hurried into wickedness by the fury of the illicit passions :
tgt_text.4981: for all these things, as they overwhelm the soul in pernicious calamities, are deservedly followed by extreme punishments.
tgt_text.4982: Moses says in the next passage that the Lord God set a mark upon Cain in order to prevent any one who found him from slaying him ;
tgt_text.4983: but what this mark is, he has not shown, although he is in the habit of explaining the nature of everything by a sign, as lie does in the affairs of Egypt, where God changed his rod into a serpent, and withered the hand of Moses till it became like snow, and turned the river into blood.
tgt_text.4984: Or may we not suppose that this mark was set upon Cain to prevent his being slain, as a token that he would never be destroyed ?
tgt_text.4985: For he has never once mentioned his death in the whole of the law, showing enigmatically that, like that fabulous monster Scylla, so also folly is an undying evil, which never entirely perishes, and yet which as to its capability of dying receives all time, and is never wholly free from death.
tgt_text.4986: And I would that the opposite event might happen, that all evils might be utterly eradicated, and might endure total destruction ;
tgt_text.4987: but as it is they are constantly budding forth, and inflict an incurable disease on all who are once infected by them.
tgt_text.4988: I. " And Cain went out from before the face of God, and dwelt in the land of Nod, opposite to Eden."*
tgt_text.4989: Now we may raise the question whether we are to take the expressions which occur in the books that have been handed down to us by Moses and to interpret them in a somewhat metaphorical sense, while the ideas which readily present themselves as derived from the names are very deficient in truth.
